HEADLINE: Three Women vs. a Broker;
Olde Is Accused of Blatant Job Discrimination

BYLINE: By SUSAN ANTILLA 

 BODY:
Less than a year ago, Mary Graff was at the top of her professional game. Of the more than 1,000 brokers at the Olde Discount Corporation, Ms. Graff, who had been with the company for 11 years, led the list of big bond sellers in the latest company newsletter. She also managed the office in Glenview, Ill., which was among the top 5 producers of the 200 Olde offices around the nation.
So imagine Ms. Graff's surprise when her boss told her last June that she was to be stripped of her manager's title, knocked back down to being an ordinary broker, moved to a different office and forced to give up most of her customer accounts. 
 "He said, 'You need to be closer to home to spend more time with your daughter,' " remembered Ms. Graff, who quit her job at Olde last September and has since been unemployed. "The 25-year-old guys have goals," she recalled him saying. "They want to drive fancy sports cars so they can pick up the girls and get out of mommy and daddy's house and get married."
Ms. Graff's story, which emerged in a formal complaint filed yesterday with the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, is but one tale among many about discrimination at Olde (pronounced OL-dee), the third-largest discount brokerage firm in the country. Current and former employees describe an atmosphere in which women have been publicly demeaned for having menstrual cycles. Managers have openly referred to blacks by such racial epithets as "monkeys," former employees say.
Young white men fresh out of college are the employees of choice, according to several dozen people interviewed for this article. It is rare, they say, to see any member of a minority group or someone older than 40 working there.
Amid all the disputes these days over the rights and wrongs of affirmative action in the workplace, such blatant racism and sexism sound bizarrely out of place. But even in this era when most corporate managements are extremely sensitive to issues of race, gender and age, a number of current and former employees say that old-style discrimination appears to be alive and well at Olde.
Moreover, according to lawyers for the complainants, the ease with which Olde has managed to demote women who rose through merit and to exclude blacks almost completely from its work force is testimony to what can still happen in the 1990's when a number of circumstances conspire to prevent exposure.
Olde, based in Detroit, strongly denies that it discriminates against women and blacks, said Frank Ortiz, outside counsel to Olde. And he said it was not true, as reported by former employees, that the company employs no blacks and fewer than a dozen women as brokers. He declined to provide specific figures.
Yesterday, three women -- including Ms. Graff -- filed a discrimination claim against Olde with the E.E.O.C. Later this week, they will file the same claim with securities industry arbitrators, said Mary Stowell of Leng Stowell Friedman & Vernon, the Chicago law firm that is representing the women. A copy was made available to The New York Times.
As a brokerage firm, Olde normally enjoys a cloak of secrecy about its employee disputes. When brokers get their licenses, they must agree to submit to an industry-run arbitration panel that handles all grievances in private. Such complaints, including the one filed yesterday, are usually kept hidden from the public.
"You can sue a corporation and go to court and get a jury that finds in your favor and the company has to change," said Linda D. Friedman, a lawyer at Leng Stowell. "But that's not the way it is in the securities industry. The records are all secret, so nothing changes."
And, as a private company, Olde faces no legal requirements to disclose lawsuits or arbitrations that affect its finances. Olde does not have Federal contracts, so it is not required to file employment data with the Government.
By all accounts, the policies at Olde stem from the top. The company, one of several nationwide firms that provide low-cost brokerage services, was started in 1970. The founder, Ernest Olde, now lives in the Cayman Islands and is still chairman. Mr. Ortiz said Mr. Olde and several other senior managers declined to be interviewed.
At a managers' meeting last year, the women's complaint contends, Mr. Olde "told the all-male audience words to the effect that they should not fall in love with a stock because 'it is like falling in love with a woman. It falls and falls and all you're left with is a big yeast infection.' " The complaint also says, "Finally, Ernest Olde directed the attendees to recruit 'young, good-looking, studly males' from college fairs and not to hire 'broads.' "
Susan Bell, who joined Olde in 1989 as a broker at one of its Phoenix offices, said in a complaint filed with the National Association of Securities Dealers in February that Mr. Olde had harassed her publicly at meetings of brokers. "He asked her what sexual overtures or sexual activities she would engage in to close a sale with a reluctant securities purchaser," stated the complaint, a copy of which was obtained by The Times.
According to the complaint, Ms. Bell was selected to attend a conference of top Olde brokers in August 1992 in Detroit. Once there, however, she was told to look for a new job, the complaint said. She was transferred in May 1993 to the Scottsdale, Ariz., office, where her salary was cut by 25 percent and she was left with $3 million of the $20 million in client assets she previously managed, the complaint said. Ms. Bell quit in September 1993.
"Olde feels omnipotent and above the law," said Julie Quintero, another former Olde manager. She joined Ms. Graff in filing the discrimination grievance with a third woman, who is still employed at Olde and declined to be interviewed. "We had a nonsmoking policy," Ms. Quintero said, "but he would walk around the office and pull out a cigarette and light it up. He'd say, 'It's my company and I can fire you all if I want.' "
Mr. Ortiz, the Olde lawyer, said that as a matter of policy, he would not comment on details of any pending arbitration complaint. But he denied that Mr. Olde had made the statements attributed to him in the latest complaint, and said the three women were not treated any differently from men. More broadly, he said, "I'm not going to comment on the perceived personality traits of Mr. Olde."
In demoting the women, Olde lost some of its top performers. All three plaintiffs in the discrimination case were on the list of the top 25 bond brokers that Ms. Graff led last May. Indeed, 5 of the 25 were women at a time when only 7 percent of Olde's brokers were women.
Apart from its treatment of women employees, the company went to extraordinary lengths to exclude blacks from its sales ranks, according to several former senior managers who spoke on condition of anonymity. An officer of the firm "would close the door with each regional manager and say, 'Don't hire blacks or women,' " one of the former managers recalled. "And he'd add: 'How do you do that? Give me 15 minutes and I can find something not to like about anyone.' "
To make the task easier, this former manager said, there was a sheet of questions to ask a job candidate over the telephone, some of which were quite difficult to answer. While young white male employees would frequently be hired despite their inability to get all the answers right, those who turned out to be either black or too old when they showed up for an interview could be given the excuse that they were being turned down because they had "flunked" the test, the manager said.
In past years, Olde also screened applicants by asking some to send photographs with their resumes, according to a woman hired in 1990.
The E.E.O.C. is "reviewing the employment practices of Olde," according to a letter from the agency that was sent to a former Olde employee. The E.E.O.C. would not comment on the investigation. Ms. Friedman, the lawyer, said that an investigator at the agency told her that Olde's hiring practices, particularly regarding blacks and older employees, were under scrutiny as a result of an unusual number of complaints by former employees.
The firm has made efforts in recent months to hire women and blacks as the heat has turned up from the investigation, Ms. Friedman said.
Mr. Ortiz acknowledged the E.E.O.C. investigation but said it was not aimed at Olde in particular.
In response to specific accusations, Mr. Ortiz said the company indeed asks applicants a list of questions. "But they're not used to rationalize hiring decisions," he said. "They are used merely to gain information and to evaluate the applicant." Asked whether the company ever relied on photographs of applicants, Mr. Ortiz said: "As a matter of policy, we don't ask for photographs. We've never asked."
In its early days, Olde had a higher percentage of women brokers than it does today. At that time, most brokers were little more than order takers who, by industry standards, were paid relatively small sums. In 1983, when salaries were approximately $12,000 a year, half of the Olde brokers in Illinois were women, according to the complaint filed this week.
But in 1993, to be more like a full-service firm, Olde started compensating brokers with handsome commissions. Last year, when the average salary had risen to $100,000, fewer than 1 percent of the Illinois brokers were women, the complaint said.
As recently as 1990, women filled nearly 15 percent of Olde's nationwide sales jobs, according to a company list of brokers. By 1993, that had dropped to 7.5 percent. In the brokerage industry over all, 28 percent of brokers were women in 1993, according to Census data, and 4.1 percent were black.
As Olde made the transformation to a fancier service outfit with higher broker pay, those women who managed to rise in the ranks faced constant harassment, critics of the company say. "The regional manager looked down at my wedding ring and said, "Do you really need to work?' " recalled Ms. Quintero, who was a branch manager in Olympia Fields, Ill.
A year ago, Ms. Quintero said she was told to distribute most of her accounts among her male colleagues, giving up earnings that averaged about $9,000 a month. She quit shortly after she was transferred to a new town, where her earnings were closer to $1,500 a month. "Just before this happened I bought a Mitsubishi 3000 GT," she said. "Now I think I should trade it in for a Chevette."
While the securities business has long been considered a bastion of white men, Olde stands out to Ms. Friedman, the lawyer, as an unusually hostile place for women and blacks. "We haven't seen this type of discrimination in the '90's," she said. "Most companies kind of get it by now."

HEADLINE: Wood Products Company Helps Write a Law to Derail an E.P.A. Inquiry

SERIES: Special Pleaders -- A periodic look at lobbying

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
A few weeks ago, some of Washington's top lawyer-lobbyists were closeted in a Senate office building with Republican staff members, reworking a bill by the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, to limit the powers of Government regulators.
After the lobbyists nipped and tucked at the wording, several key phrases drafted by Georgia-Pacific, the nation's largest wood products company, made it into the measure nearly verbatim. 
 Company officials will not say exactly what they did to shape the legislation, which is scheduled to come before the Senate Judiciary Committee for a vote this week. But they freely acknowledge their aim was to derail an ongoing Environmental Protection Agency inquiry into possible violations of the Clean Air Act at 26 of the company's operations. Millions of dollars in fines are at stake.
The provision would bar Federal officials from suing or prosecuting a company for actions taken on the advice of a responsible state or Federal official. That is what Georgia-Pacific says it did in not applying for permits at the plant sites, and company officials assert the environmental agency is using present-day rules to judge 15-year-old facts.
"We've been wronged in this whole thing," said Sheila Weidman, a company spokesman. "Like any American citizen, we're working through the legislative process to right that wrong.'
The Georgia-Pacific story is a tale of how one firm's pitched battle with one agency turned into legislation that could profoundly reshape the relationship between companies and all Government agencies on a myriad of issues.
Clinton Administration officials say it also illustrates how much Federal authority and practices can be changed by a few words in the right place.
The Justice Department said in a recent letter to the Senate Judiciary Committee that the proposed provision and related sections "creates enormous opportunities for abuse, and could immunize egregious violations that cost taxpayers millions of dollars and result in serious harm to the public."
Lois J. Schiffer, the Assistant Attorney General for the environment and natural resources division, said today that if the provision became law "we would have a very difficult time protecting public health and safety." She added: "This would not in any way satisfy the President's goal of regulatory reform that would give us fair, effective, and enforceable laws."
Georgia-Pacific, which is based in Atlanta, had some influential allies in the room the day the 97-page draft of the bill was hammered out.
Among those working on the bill's wording with Republican staffers were Henry Nickel and Turner T. Smith Jr., two partners in the Richmond law firm of Hunton & Williams. The firm has an extensive Washington-based environmental practice, and Senator Dole's chief counsel on regulatory issues, Kyle McSlarrow, is an alumni of the firm.
Court papers show that the firm is representing Hoechst Celanese, a chemical company locked in legal combat with the E.P.A. in three civil lawsuits. In defending Hoechst Celanese, a subsidary of the German company Hoechst A.G., the law firm has argued in a Texas court that the firm had the approval of state officials for everything it did. Roger J. Marzulla, another lawyer representing the company, said the legislation, if passed, would bolster the company's defenses against the environmental agency.
But the company, and several other officials from other industries, insist that this provision is not just another instance of lobbyists getting their way in Washington. The treatment of Georgia-Pacific, Hoechst Celanese and mining companies, they contend, has made clear some fundamental injustices in how Federal agencies enforce environmental laws.
Mr. Marzulla, a lawyer at the Washington firm of Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld, said: "This is not, as some have characterized it, just trying to fix a specific lawsuit or two. This is an important and challenging question."
Akin, Gump separately represents Hoechst Celanese in settlement negotiations with E.P.A. over the three civil suits and was recently hired by the company to lobby the Senate on the Dole bill. He said he did not draft the language, and does not know how it got into the bill.
Mr. Marzulla and other proponents of the measure said it is not unusual for companies to get permission from a state to do something, and then, years later, find themselves battling Federal agencies who have interpreted the law differently.
Over the years, courts have held that the Federal Government could not be bound by the word of a mis-informed or mistaken official. Taxpayers who rely on incorrect advice from the Internal Revenue Service are still obligated to pay everything they owe.
Environmental laws pose a more complicated problem. Although Congress has set national standards for air, water and land, much of the enforcement is delegated to states, which pass their own laws and oversee local programs. E.P.A. reserves the right to file Federal cases in instances in which, because of local political pressures or misinterpretations of the complex statutes, states have failed to take action against major polluters.
Steven A. Herman, the E.P.A.'s top enforcement official, said the agency seldom used that power. But the possibility that it might prevents states desperate to attract industry from cutting separate deals with companies. If the agency loses its authority to overrule state decisions, he said, the United States would no longer have a national environmental policy.
The provision backed by Georgia-Pacific, Hoeschst Celanese and mining concerns "allows a local company to really turn the screws on a state that is vulnerable economically," Mr. Herman asserted, adding, "It creates the threat of pollution havens -- states with a weak economies that are willing to sacrifice their health and safety to attract new industry."
The conflict between the wood products industry and E.P.A. arose in the late 1980's, when the agency began investigating Louisiana-Pacific of Portland, Ore., for violations of the Clean Air Act.
Federal officials charged that the company had systematically underestimated its emissions of volatile organic chemicals, a type of pollution that can cause smog. Under the 1977 statute, companies operating in regions with the cleanest air must undergo a stringent review, and apply for permits from state or Federal agencies if they build new plants that emit more than 250 tons of volatile organic chemicals a year. Permits are also required for significant modifications of a plant that increases emissions of these chemicals by more than 40 tons a year.
This is important because under the regulations, companies applying for permits can be required to install expensive pollution control technologies, the best available to the industry. In 1993, Louisiana-Pacific settled its case by paying an $11 million fine. Soon afterward, the E.P.A. and state agencies began scrutinizing other wood products companies, including Georgia-Pacific and Weyerhauser for similar violations.
Georgia-Pacific officials vehemently contested the E.P.A.'s view that the company should have applied for permits at its plants. They said the company had calculated its projected emissions of volatile chemicals using a method developed by the environmental agency.
Moreover, the company said it had relied on advice from state officials and regional E.P.A. officials in deciding whether to apply for the permits. After the E.P.A. served notice last August of possible violations at the Georgia-Pacific plants, environmental officials in several states, including Alabama, Virginia and Georgia took the company's side.
Mr. Herman of the E.P.A. declined to discuss the Georgia-Pacific or Hoechst Celanese cases, saying only: "We take our responsibilities seriously. We wouldn't be bringing these cases if we didn't think they were valid cases. They're a tremendous expense for us."
Soon after, company officials said, they decided to take their case to Congress. They drafted an amendment and gave it to Senator David Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas. Senator Pryor declined at the last minute to offer the measure.
A few weeks later, virtually the same language turned up in a draft of Senator Dole's bill as retooled by Senators Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, and Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa. In a later draft, it was modestly rewritten by committee staffers in the face of objections from the Administration and Senate Democrats.
Jeanne Lopatto, the Judiciary Committee's spokesman, termed the provision a matter of "basic fairness." She said the committee had consulted with Democrats, "the regulated community," and Administration officials and "then we drafted our bill."
Gordon Alphonso, senior counsel at the company, said: "For Georgia-Pacific to spend a significant amount of time and money addressing these issues when legislation would be an easier and quicker cheaper remedy, I think you would want to chose the easier, quicker, and cheaper remedy. You never know how long it will take for a court to reach a decision."
But David Hawkins, senior lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, said that is where the case belongs. "They're trying an end-run around the justice system," he said. "It doesn't surprise me that some states are taking Georgia-Pacific's side. One of the reasons we have a Federal statute is that we have a sorry history of states taking polluters sides."

HEADLINE: BOMBING IN SACRAMENTO: THE INVESTIGATION;
Bomb Meant for Predecessor Of Victim, Officials Say

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 25

 BODY:
Federal officials said today that a mail bomb that killed the chief lobbyist for a forest-products trade group in Sacramento, Calif., was apparently intended for a retired executive who had headed the group until a year ago.
The package was addressed to William N. Dennison, who served as president and chief executive officer of the California Forestry Association from 1980 to 1994 and was a highly visible figure in a number of contentious environmental issues. 
 Mr. Dennison was replaced by Gilbert B. Murray, who was killed on Monday as he was opening a small, heavy package wrapped in brown paper and mailed to the trade group's one-story brick building.
The explosion in the assocation's reception area knocked doors off their hinges, blew out ceiling tiles and shattered glass partitions inside the 7,500-square-foot office. Five other employees who were present at the time of the blast escaped unharmed.
Mr. Dennison, who lives in Rancho Cordova, a town about 15 miles east of Sacramento, could not be reached for comment. His telephone has been disconnected, and several friends and former colleagues said they did not know his whereabouts. In an interview in today's Sacramento Bee, Mr. Dennison said the bomb could only be the work of "a sick person."
"I can't imagine that what we do could be a threat to give the least reason to bomb an office," Mr. Dennison told The Bee, which first identified him as the intended target. He added: "If trying to manage natural resources is a threat, I don't know what isn't. There can't be any rationale for this." The newspaper did not indicate the circumstances of the interview or from where Mr. Dennison spoke.
Jean Wilhoit, the public affairs director for the P.&M. Cedar Products Company in Stockton, Calif., and a board member of the forestry association, said: "I know Bill is completely devastated by what has happened. He has probably cloistered himself until he can collect his thoughts and emotions."
In the years leading up to his retirement, Mr. Dennison was a prominent voice in what was widely known in the Pacific Northwest as "the timber wars," a struggle that pitted ranchers, loggers and the timber industry against environmentalists over the development of public and private lands.
"Bill Dennison was there during a time of fairly contentious issues in California," said Jay Watson, regional director of The Wilderness Society, adding that he was an especially vocal opponent of the Government's 1990 decision to declare the northern spotted owl, which makes its home in the old forests of the Northwest, a threatened species.
While environmentalists celebrated this expansive use of the Endangered Species Act to protect a nearly extinct animal, the timber industry mounted an intensive effort through the courts to overturn the Government's action.
"Through all that period, he was the No. 1 person for the timber industry," Mr. Watson said.
Betty Ball, a spokeswoman for the Mendocino Environmental Center, called Mr. Dennison "a key player for the timber industry." Noting, however, that he had recently retired, she added, "Whoever did this horrible thing in Sacramento was acting on old information."
A legislative aide in Sacramento who has worked extensively on forestry issues and who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, said: "Bill Dennison is far more contentious than Gil Murray ever was. Mr. Murray was more circumspect, less inflammatory. But Mr. Dennison could be as inflammatory as you can get without being irresponsible."
He added: "If you were fixating on wood, Mr. Dennison is someone whose name you might well have run across. He has been very visible."
In September 1993, for example, Mr. Dennison was among several dozen ranchers, loggers and timber industry leaders who attended a public hearing in Redding, Calif., to discuss President Clinton's plan to limit logging in old forests on Federal land. The policy would let the timber industry cut as much as one billion board feet of lumber each year in the forests of Washington, Oregon and northern California -- less than a fifth of the harvest during the 1980's.
At the Redding hearing Mr. Dennison said the plan "would be detrimental to the forests, and it would be devastating to Northern California families and businesses."
Earlier the same year, Mr. Dennison spoke at a two-day conference, called the Sierra Economic Summit, which was also called to discuss proposals to limit logging on public and private lands. Mr. Dennison said he was alarmed by any proposal that would call for the expansion of park land, a move that he said would result in losses of jobs, industry and a way of life in the Sierra for people who have lived there for generations.

HEADLINE: Soviet Archives: Half-Open, Dirty Window on Past

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

 BODY:
In early August 1930, Stalin wrote a routine note to his most loyal comrade in the Soviet leadership, Vyacheslav M. Molotov, with 10 directives. The second one dealt with the hoarding of coins, a problem the Kremlin was trying to deal with.
After venting his rage at the State Bank and the Finance Ministry, Stalin wrote, "Definitely shoot two or three dozen wreckers from these apparats, including several dozen common cashiers." 
 The note is one of 86 letters from Stalin to Molotov recently published by Yale University Press, and one of thousands of documents that have come fluttering from behind the long-impenetrable walls of Soviet archives since the Communist state collapsed in 1991.
The flow has produced its share of sensations and revelations, big and small, but also its frustrations. First among these is that the most important files remain solidly off-limits. And after the first wave of openness, American scholars say access is being steadily curtailed, especially for records of the post-Stalin period. More ominously, they report that secret-police agents have recently reappeared at top archives and major research institutes.
That does not mean the flow has stopped. Far from it; the revelations that have emerged, and are still emerging, are often dramatic.
The Stalin-Molotov letters give a tantalizing glimpse of the despot, ordering political executions in writing long before the terror got under way in the mid-1930's, delving into the smallest details of politics and the economy, neatly organizing his directives and thoughts in numbered paragraphs and concise orders.
Some other dramatic documents that have emerged include these:
*Proof of a direct order from the Soviet leadership to massacre Polish officers at Katyn Forest in Russia in 1941.
*The Russian-language version of the secret protocol to the Nazi-Soviet pact in 1939.
*Evidence that the Russians were undecided about invading Poland during the Solidarity years in the early 1980's.
*Proof that the Soviets had extensive information about the ill-fated Korean Air Lines Flight 007, including the black box of the passenger jetliner shot down by Soviet fighters in 1983.
*Evidence that Stalin ordered the North Korean invasion of South Korea in 1950.
Extensive transcripts of Politburo sessions and meetings of Warsaw Pact leaders have come out, detailing their thoughts and strategies through the cold war.
They demonstrate, for instance, how wary the Soviets were of committing forces to Afghanistan. A special Politburo report in April 1979, eight months before Soviet forces swept into the country, declared, "It is clear that due to the internal nature of the anti-governmental opposition, the use of Soviet troops in repressing the Afghan counterrevolution would seriously damage the international authority of the U.S.S.R. and would set back the process of disarmament."
But like many other archival discoveries, such findings often lead to more questions. Are there other letters from Stalin, revealing far greater crimes and plots, that Molotov withheld when he turned his files over to the archives in 1969? Are there documents that prove or disprove whether Stalin ordered the 1934 assassination of Sergei M. Kirov, the Leningrad party chief? That Alger Hiss was a spy? That there was a Soviet hand in the assassination of John F. Kennedy? Or in the shooting of Pope John Paul II in 1981?
 
The Output
Despite Volume, Much Is Sealed
 In the West, the archives have spawned something of a new industry.
The Cold War International History Project in Washington, headed by James G. Hershberg, has organized two major conferences and has published several bulletins of archival findings. The Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace at Stanford is microfilming huge volumes of Communist Party records. Crown Publishers has reportedly signed a contract to publish materials from the K.G.B. archives. Various joint projects have been set up to prepare guides to Russian archival holdings.
Yale University Press recently issued the first two volumes of an ambitious, 18-book "Annals of Communism" series of archival documents. The first two were a collection of Stalin's letters to Molotov, which includes the 1930 note about the hoarding of coins, and "The Secret World of American Communism," which details links between Moscow and the American Communist Party from the 1920's to 1945.
Russians, too, have burrowed into the cache. Gen. Dmitri Volkogonov, a military historian who has already drawn on newly available materials for biographies of Stalin and Lenin, now plans a two-volume history of the Soviet Union seen through the eyes of seven Soviet leaders, from Lenin to Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
The Progress Publishing Group, once part of the Soviet propaganda machine, plans to release a laser disk with documents, photos and documentary film about Hitler, including a 1970 order from Yuri V. Andropov, who was then K.G.B. chief, ordering that the remains of the Nazi dictator be burned.
Yet for all the output, the most intriguing Soviet documents remain sealed in the Presidential Archive, which was set up by Mr. Gorbachev, the last Soviet President, to safeguard important information from the disintegrating Communist Party, and was taken over after Mr. Gorbachev's fall by President Boris N. Yeltsin.
Almost all the most dramatic disclosures have come from this file, but usually only when Mr. Yeltsin has chosen to release them for political reasons. Many were made public in the case against the Communist Party before the Constitutional Court, others as gifts to foreign governments, others to embarrass Mr. Gorbachev. Researchers have had no independent access.
Similarly, K.G.B. and military files have been made public only at the discretion of their masters. The Foreign Ministry has granted many requests for material, but still keeps its catalogues classified, leaving it to archivists to determine what material a researcher might need.
"Over all, I don't think things have improved," said Mark Kramer, a history professor at Brown and Harvard who has been one of the most active American users of Soviet archives. "In fact, they've deteriorated."
Mr. Kramer said that on his last trip to Russia he was shown an internal directive dated Dec. 10, 1993, that set out a list of areas of Communist Party activities whose records were being put off-limits.
They include the party Secretariat, which ran the party; the departments dealing with international affairs and administrative organs, which included the K.G.B. and the military; medium machine-building, which handled nuclear weapons; all intelligence agencies, and documents on technological and scientific research.
When Mr. Kramer tried to get documents on these subjects on a recent visit, he was refused. "I was even not allowed to see documents I translated in 1992," he said. "I get the sense that a fair amount does pertain to the security services, the K.G.B. and foreign intelligence, and they just don't like to have any of their documents released."
Mr. Kramer and other researchers say the tightening of access correlates in part with a broader revival in Russia of a sense of continuity with the Soviet Union.
 
Tightened Access
After Initial Burst, Files Start to Close
 In the immediate aftermath of the collapse of the Communist Party in 1991, the prevailing mood in Russia was to distance the new system from the old. It was then that archives were opened, and that many of the most revealing documents emerged. But the initial euphoria soon waned under economic and political turmoil, while Russia's foreign policy recovered from the early infatuation with the West.
The turning point, researchers agree, was the publication in The New York Times on April 12, 1993, of a document culled from the Soviet archives by an Australian researcher, Stephen J. Morris, which purported to be the Russian translation of a Vietnamese report saying the real number of American prisoners in North Vietnam was three times the number publicly acknowledged by Hanoi.
Though the document was not particularly embarrassing to Moscow, it was used as a pretext to dismiss the director of the contemporary Communist archive, Rem Usikov, and to tighten access greatly. Mr. Usikov's successor, Anatoly Prokopenko, is reported to have told a researcher, "Yes, these documents have been declassified, but that doesn't mean people should be allowed to look at them."
More recently, the Hoover Institution project to microfilm 25 million pages from the Communist archives has come under fire as a pilfering of Russia's national heritage. Yuri Afanaseyev, a historian with solid democratic credentials, asserted that the state archive committee was "selling out Russia's past."
The entire idea of archives as public domain is novel to a nation that has always regarded them as a tool for officials and bureaucrats. Many archives are still considered the property of agencies like the intelligence service or the Foreign Ministry, and Russian archivists still believe that they are doing researchers a great favor by letting them in.
Another problem is the sheer volume of material and the big decrease in Government financing. A joint task force of the American Association for the Advancement of Slavic Studies and the American Historical Association reported that the 17 state archives of the Russian Federation alone include 65.3 million files on more than 300 miles of shelves, not to mention 2,200 republic, regional and local depositories controlled by the Russian State Committee on Archival Affairs.
Most are in dire need of money. The Russian State Historical Archive in St. Petersburg, housed in the 18th-century buildings of the Holy Synod and the Imperial Senate, have been declared in major danger of destruction by Western experts.
And just when researchers have come flooding in, those archivists who can have been leaving for other jobs because of low pay. In a recent conversation in Moscow, Sergei V. Mironenko, the director of the Russian State Archive, pointed to his secretary and whispered that her salary was not enough to buy food.
Like many other archivists, Mr. Mironenko has tried to line up outside publishing or cooperative agreements to make ends meet. That, however, has raised charges of commercialization. Many Western researchers have complained about what they view as exorbitant copying or "access" fees, and scholars have criticized some of the exclusive arrangements between archives and publishers.
The Crown arrangement to publish K.G.B. materials has come under special fire because it would essentially allow the political police to decide what to publish about itself without independent scrutiny, and without declassifying its holdings.
 
Distorted History
Picture of the Past Not Always True
 Apart from all the problems of logistics, cost and access, scholars have reaffirmed what they always knew, that files are only a partial image of the past, and not always an accurate one. A current example is a book by a Stalinist K.G.B. operative named Pavel Sudoplatov, who asserted in his memoir, "Special Tasks," that the K.G.B. received secret atomic information from several eminent Western scientists, including Niels Bohr.
Files found later have exonerated Mr. Bohr, but the book has dramatized the danger of releasing partial information or publishing isolated witnesses, especially former K.G.B. agents. The danger is particularly large because the K.G.B. files, like the secret police files in East Germany and other political files, name countless people, not all of them necessarily collaborators.
The Yale University collection of documents on the American Communist Party, for instance, has two 1942 documents about Edmund W. Stevens, an American journalist who spent most of his life in Moscow. Nobody doubted that he sympathized with the Soviet Union, but nobody knew what he did.
The Yale book carries a request from Gen. Pavel M. Fitin asking urgent information about Mr. Stevens, "a former leader of the American Komsomol." The reply says that Mr. Stevens, who died in 1992, was a member in good standing of the American Communist Party, and that he "could be useful in Moscow." No more.
One problem is that in a police state like the Soviet Union, many of the most damaging directives were probably never committed to paper, while many documents that did get circulated were intended to bolster the standing of a particular official, and so did not necessarily reflect the truth. Many sensitive documents have also been destroyed -- by Lavrenti P. Beria, the secret police chief, or in World War II, or during de-Stalinization.
Yet a remarkable volume of incriminating documents do survive, testament to a system that believed its secrets would never become public. Long lists of mass executions and tortures ordered by Stalin have survived, as well as letters by Lenin ordering a secret terror campaign in Latvia and Estonia as early as 1917, the year of the Bolshevik Revolution.
So Western scholars have learned to treat the archives more soberly. "The first wave in the archives was a search for revelations," Mr. Hershberg said. "The second wave has been more a re-evaluation of what is known and the integration of new material into history."
For scholars trained in assessing the partial evidence available during the cold war, the problem has often been not too little, but too much. William Taubman, professor at Amherst College, had to repeatedly delay publication of his biography of Nikita S. Khrushchev while he waded through the many new witnesses and documents that were constantly becoming available.
Like many other scholars who have worked with the new evidence, Mr. Taubman said his fundamental image of the man and the period proved accurate. What he gained was a wealth of detail.
"I think I've learned a ton of stuff," he said. "Not so much a kind of smoking gun -- like 'Khrushchev plotted the Kennedy assassination' -- but tons of details about the man, anecdotes, incidents, which enable me, I hope, to depict a living, breathing human being, rather than a caricature."

Interesting. Well, all the best, J. Stalin" ('Stalin's Letters to Molotov, 1925-1936')

HEADLINE: Market Pauses After 3 Straight Highs; Blue Chips Slightly Down

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks ended slightly lower yesterday as the market paused after setting three straight closing records in the last three sessions.
The Dow Jones industrial average was off 3.81 points at 4,300.17. On Monday the index closed at a new high of 4,303.98. 
 In the broader market, declining issues led advances 1,160 to 1,070 on active trading of more than 352 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
Analysts said the market was nervous about possible action on the sagging dollar from the Washington meeting of the Group of Seven finance ministers and central bankers.
"Right now what's scaring people is the G-7 meeting," said Trude Latimer of Ferguson, Andrews & Associates. "They're afraid of what the U.S. may be forced to do."
 But some analysts were betting that the Group of Seven nations -- the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Italy, Britain and Canada -- would do little more than pay lip service to increased cooperation to help lift the dollar.
Among the session's winners, Motorola rose 1 5/8 a share to 55 7/8 in active trading. Goldman, Sachs added the stock to its priority list.
Compaq Computer, which last week reported earnings in line with expectations, rose 1 5/8 a share to 39 1/8 in volume of more than 8.2 million shares, making it the most active Big Board issue. Among other technology stocks, I.B.M., which recently reported strong earnings, was up 1/8 to 93 5/8, and Autodesk fell 2 1/2 to 34 3/4. Dean Witter downgraded the stock to neutral from buy.
Cordis Corporation fell 3 3/4 a share to 75 after reporting third quarter earnings.
Kmart fell 1/2 to 14 7/8 in heavy Big Board volume after it cut its quarterly dividend in half and said it expected to report a first-quarter loss.
RJR Nabisco was down 3/4 to 26 5/8 in heavy volume after it reported lower-than-expected earnings.
UAL, the parent of United Airlines, rose 2 7/8 to 117 1/2 after reporting a $3 million profit, its first profitable first quarter since 1989.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks fell 0.74 point to 512.15. However, the Nasdaq index rose 2.37 to 831.28, and the American Stock Exchange index was up 0.02 point to 473.59.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite index of all listed common stocks fell 0.45 point to 276.39. The average share was down 5 cents.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of New York, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 5,008.385, down 5.584 points or 0.11 percent.
Analysts said that one reason for the market's pause was that traders were puzzled by the latest data that showed the economy was stronger than previously indicated.
The Conference Board, a private business group, reported that consumer confidence in its survey rose to 105.5 in April from a revised 100.2 in March. Economists had forecast a reading of 99.9 for April.
"People begin to wonder if the economy is in fact slowing down," said Tony Dwyer of Josephthal Lyon & Ross.
He said that if people were confident about their jobs and the future they would be more willing to spend, which could prompt the Federal Reserve to push up interest rates to slow the economy's growth.
Investors were also wondering about where the economy is headed.
"There is a debate in the market about what happens after the soft landing in the economy," said Hugh Johnson at the First Albany Company.
Some economists foresee a reacceleration of the economy, but others expect further slowing, he said, adding that some even expect a significant slowdown in 1996.
"Nobody knows who you should line up behind right now; it's an issue which is just not getting answered," he said.
He said the confusion has kept a brake on the broader market, which has lagged behind the record-setting run of the blue-chip market.

HEADLINE: Rio Verde Journal;
Americans Home on the Booming Range, in Brazil

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: RIO VERDE, Brazil

 BODY:
Out here in Brazil's big sky country, where the cows outnumber people and the billboards tout weed killers, Douglas Ferrell looks through the window of his air-conditioned tractor cab and sees dollar signs stretching to the horizon.
"I buy new land every year -- you can make 40 percent on your investment out here," said the 40-year-old soy and cotton farmer from Pennsylvania. Starting with a 1,200-acre farm a little over a decade ago, Mr. Ferrell has increased his holdings fivefold, bought 1,100 head of cattle and the latest in tractors and combines, and started construction on the tallest farmhouse -- two stories -- and the biggest grain silos ever seen in these parts. 
 One of his Mennonite neighbors recently cautioned that Mr. Ferrell was getting a "big head." But his success is part of an agricultural boom that is thrusting Brazil into the world's top ranks of food exporters.
Often overshadowed by Brazil's coastal industries, farming has been the country's fastest-growing sector since 1980. Over the last 15 years, farm production increased by 47 percent, while industrial production increased by just 11 percent.
This farming boom has made Brazil one of the world's top five "food powers" despite the fact that since 1980, the acreage under cultivation in Brazil has remained the same, and Government subsidies have been cut in half.
The productivity increases are a result of heavy investment in mechanization, typified by the brand new tractor and combines on Mr. Ferrell's farm.
Critics note that Brazilian agribusiness grows food for export while a large portion of the country's 154 million people go hungry at home.
"How can it be that, in one of the largest grain-exporting nations in the world, we have 32 million people going hungry and 8 million rural workers without land?" asked the Rev. Ricardo Rezende, a Roman Catholic priest who promotes the distribution of land to small Amazon homesteaders.
The World Bank estimates that about 7 percent of Brazilian children under the age of 5 suffer from malnutrition.
Big farmers respond that their efficiency keeps domestic food prices low and that their exports earn Brazil needed foreign exchange.
Brazilian farmers are so successful that they trample national borders in search of cheap land. Today, Brazilian colonists plant and harvest one-third of the soy planted in Bolivia and Paraguay, and own 4 percent of Uruguay's land.
But the region's "Green Revolution" is most visible here in the table-flat lands of the country's midwestern savannah, or cerrado.
"In 20 years, Brazil will be exporting throughout the world food produced in the cerrado," predicted Norman Borlaug, 81, the American agricultural scientist who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1970 for research that helped bring about Asia's "Green Revolution."
Over the last 25 years, grain production in the cerrado has quadrupled to 20 million tons. And farmers only till 15 percent of the arable land in a region with an area equal to that of Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Portugal and Spain combined.
"I could never have done this back in the States," said Mr. Ferrell, a straightforward man who monitors truck weights from a gauge in his farmhouse kitchen. "Last year, I bought a grain dryer. This year, I'm putting in the two storage bins."
As a North American pioneer in a South American wilderness, Mr. Ferrell played it safe by buying a farm next door to 100 American Mennonite farmers in Rio Verde.
"People used to be kind of rough around here," he recalled of his first visit to Goias state in the 1970's. "You know -- if you don't like 'em, shoot 'em -- that kind of thing."
Posting a farm sign, a plow disk inscribed "Filadelphia Ranch," Mr. Ferrell started farming surrounded by peace-loving neighbors with names like Koehn, Hibner, Mininger and Warkentin. He has seen his land values increase fivefold from the $100 an acre he and his father paid for their initial stake in 1981.
"I have been planting for 13 years, and I have never had a crop failure," Mr. Ferrell said. "Some of the Mennonites have been here almost 30 years and they have never had a crop failure."
With land fertile and cheap, and dependable rains, soy is grown more cheaply in Brazil's midwest than in the American Midwest. But there are considerable obstacles.
"We have a lot of trouble with transportation -- we are awful far from the ports," Mr. Ferrell said, referring to the Atlantic port of Santos, 600 miles southeast of here. Because of poorly maintained highways, a ton of Brazilian soy arrives at Santos costing more than a ton of American soy costs in New Orleans.
Like farmers everywhere, Mr. Ferrell has little use for the flash of big cities. For their annual trip to the States, his family drives five hours to Brasilia, to catch a flight north.
"I went to Rio once, on my honeymoon," he said, referring to Rio de Janeiro, a beach metropolis viewed by many rural Brazilians as their country's sin city. "They stole my pickup truck."

HEADLINE: Income Gap For Sexes Is Seen Wider In Retirement

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
While women usually earn less than men and are more likely to live in poverty, the economic gap between women and men widens in retirement, according to a new study by the Older Women's League.
Although many more women have entered the work force in recent decades, the study found, the gap between the average Social Security benefits paid to women and those paid to men is growing. 
 This year, the average monthly Social Security benefit women received is only 76 percent of the average benefit received by men. In 1970 women received, on average, 78 percent of the men's benefit. Among retired workers receiving Social Security benefits based on their own work records, women's average monthly benefits this year are $538, compared with an average of $858 for men.
The sex gap shows up in other measures, too: In 1993, women over 65 had a median annual income of $8,499 -- 57 percent of the $14,983 median income of older men.
Just 13 percent of women over 65 have private pensions, compared to 33 percent of older men. And the mean private pension for women is $3,940 annually, compared with $7,468 for men, based on a 1994 census report.
Social Security benefits and most private pensions are based on the number of years that a person is employed and the yearly earnings.
The survey by the league, a nonprofit advocacy group based in Washington, confirmed findings from earlier studies that the wage gap between men and women widens with age. While women age 25 to 34 earned 83 percent as much as men their age in 1994, women age 55 to 64 earned only 66 percent as much as their male counterparts.
"This is all a reflection of women having lower wages than men, and that's not changing," said Deborah Briceland-Betts, executive director of the league. "Today's working women seem to be destined to the same poor old age their mothers are having right now."
Because so many women now spend decades building a career, the number of women entitled to Social Security based both on their own work records and those of their husbands has skyrocketed -- from 5 percent of female recipients in 1960 to 25 percent in 1993.
But because women still earn less than men, and are far more likely to work part-time or to take several years off to care for children, their Social Security benefits remain low. Indeed, for most women who get Social Security through their husbands, that benefit, equal to half their husbands' monthly check, is more than the amount they would get based on their own work record.
In fact, the percentage of women drawing Social Security benefits based on their own work records has dropped, from 42 percent in 1970 to about 36 percent in 1993. So most women who work and contribute to Social Security for years receive the same benefits as they would have if they had never held a job.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Help Sought For World Loan Unit

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
Representatives of the world's poorest countries stepped into the growing congressional debate about foreign aid today by issuing a strong appeal to the United States and other donor countries to continue supporting the International Development Agency.
The appeal was made after a meeting of finance ministers from 24 developing countries, known as the Group of 24, which sets the third world's economic agenda just as the Group of Seven sets the industrial world's. The International Development Agency is the unit of the World Bank that tries to encourage development in poor nations by giving them very low-cost loans. 
 N'Goran Niamien, the Finance Minister of the Ivory Coast, headed the Group of 24 meeting and said a need to finance the agency had been "heavily emphasized" in the group's discussions. "We appeal to donors to replenish I.D.A.," he said.
He described the agency as well-managed and said it had "demonstrated its effectiveness." But he acknowledged that the political debate over its future had reached "a crucial point of particular concern" and said it would "be a tragedy if donors do not contribute."
Unlike the World Bank, which borrows its funds on private markets against the credit of its member governments, the International Development Agency receives infusions of government aid, called replenishments, every three years. The agency then offers loans for up to 40 years at a nominal interest rate to countries with average per-capita income of less than $835 a year.
The agency's 10th replenishment, worth $18 billion, is approaching its final year. And while Congress has authorized payment of most of the United States' first two annual contributions of $1.25 billion each, it is preparing to debate the payment for the final year amid growing signs of dissent from Republican leaders.
Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, has proposed phasing out United States contributions to the agency. In the Senate, such contributions must be approved by the Foreign Relations Committee, which is headed by Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is a staunch opponent of foreign aid.
Meanwhile, Representative Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat who is a member of the House Appropriations Committee, wants to block funds for the agency unless it stops lending to China.
Congress is also withholding $60 million from last year's United States contribution for budgetary reasons. And negotiations have just opened among the United States, Japan and other donors on the 11th refunding for the agency, though no agreement has been reached on its size.

HEADLINE: Only a Scant Increase in Employee-Benefit Costs

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
After years of absorbing hefty increases in what they pay for health care and other fringe benefits, the nation's employers seem to have regained control of this prominent business expense.
Benefit costs edged up only two-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter of 1995, the Labor Department reported today, the smallest rise in eight years. 
 Economists said the report was another sign that inflation was likely to remain tame. That is because employee compensation costs rose overall just 2.9 percent in the 12 months through March, the narrowest year-to-year increase for civilian workers since the Government began publishing such figures in 1981.
"This confirms that there's no inflation push from wages," Secretary of Labor Robert B. Reich said in an interview. The slight rise in benefits costs reflected employer scale-backs in coverage and greater reliance on health maintenance organizations, as well as requirements that employees shoulder a greater proportion of health costs.
But although growth in pay and benefits was being held to no more than the inflation rate -- retail prices also climbed 2.9 percent over the last 12 months -- bond traders found something else to worry about in indications that the economy might not be as weak as some of them had thought.
The price of long-term Treasury bonds ebbed after the Conference Board, a business-oriented research group, reported that that consumer confidence had jumped in April after a marginal March rise.
"The latest confidence readings show a strong increase in expectations for the next six months," Fabian Linden, executive director of the board's Consumer Research Center, said today in announcing the latest findings. "Over the years, this component of the index has proven to be a reliable forecaster of economic trends."
Based on a survey of 5,000 households, the consumer confidence index rose to 105.5 in April, its highest point in nearly five years, from 100.2 in March. Expectations for the next six month jumped to 97.8 from 90.1 after three straight declines. Assessment of the current situation edged up to 117 after the initial March figure of 117.1 was revised down to 115.3.
Confidence ebbed, however, in four of the nation's nine regions, including the Middle Atlantic states.
Another expansionary sign, at a time when many believe economic growth to be sharply slowing, was a report by the National Association of Realtors showing that sales of existing homes climbed 5.8 percent in March to an annual rate of 3.62 million, as milder weather encouraged buyers.
"The consumer still has some vigor," said Daniel Laufenberg, chief domestic economist at American Express Financial in Minneapolis. "Maybe he hasn't landed yet," Mr. Laufenberg added, alluding to the so-called soft landing that policy makers are seeking to produce in the economy at large after more than a year of rapid growth.
For many economists, though, the surprisingly tame Employment Cost Index warranted the most attention.
Although wages and salaries rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter, slightly more than the December quarter's six-tenths of 1 percent, this was more than offset by the sharp slowdown in benefits costs -- to two-tenths of 1 percent from seven-tenths of 1 percent the previous quarter.
Ed Yardeni of C. J. Lawrence/ Deutsche Bank was particularly impressed by American business' increasing ability to keep its costs under control. Not only did overall compensation costs show the skimpiest increase on record last quarter, he said, but "the benefits-inflation rate has been more than cut in half since 1990." Pay and benefits account for more than two-thirds of total business costs.
According to Albert Schwenk, economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, somewhat more than half the benefits deceleration in the January-March period reflected lower costs for health care. In industries producing goods, benefits fell three-tenths of 1 percent, primarily because workers were paying a larger share out of their own pockets. Often, this takes the form of extra premiums or higher deductibles before insurance kicks in.
Another way that companies save money is by inducing more of their employees to use the less expensive health maintenance organizations, rather than remaining in medical plans with no cost deterrent on which doctors they visit.
In addition, companies saved money was through lower payments to funds that provide for workers injured on the job, Mr. Schwenk said.
The other main benefits area is pension plans, where employers have been rapidly switching from traditional plans providing specific regular benefits for retirees to defined-contribution plans, like 401(k)'s, in which companies often make matching contributions to employee accounts and leave the responsibility for investment decisions to the employee.
Joseph Liro, an economist at S. G. Warburg, called the latest reading of the Employment Cost Index "extraordinarily reassuring" evidence that inflation was likely to remain subdued through the rest of the current business cycle. He suggested that the past pattern of rapidly rising costs in fringe benefits had perhaps been "permanently broken."

HEADLINE: Clinton Pledges to Defend Farm Subsidies

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: AMES, Iowa, April 25

 BODY:
President Clinton came to corn country today to do a little spring planting: he promised to defend Federal farm subsidies from Republican budget cuts as a way of sowing good will in an important political state where he hopes to stave off any challenge to his renomination.
"I don't believe that we ought to destroy the farm support program if we want to keep the family farm" and preserve gains made in recent international trade agreements, the President declared at a daylong conference on rural America sponsored by the Department of Agriculture and Iowa State University here, and broadcast live on public television around the state and nationwide on C-SPAN. 
 "We have a $20 billion surplus in agricultural trade," Mr. Clinton told the gathering of farmers, academics and community groups that also included Vice President Al Gore and Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman. "We've got a big trade deficit in everything else. I don't think we ought to give it up.
"Should we modify it, can we improve it?" he asked of the subsidy program. "I'm sure we can. Should we emphasize other things? Of course we should. But our first rule should be: do no harm."
The Republican-controlled Congress has threatened deep cuts in the more than $10 billion in annual Federal farm income and price support programs in its drive to produce a balanced Federal budget, and Mr. Clinton repeated today that deficit reduction remained a necessity. The Administration's own five-year farm plan, now being drafted, is expected to limit crop subsidies to moderate-size farms.
But speaking at this old land-grant college in the middle of a state whose Presidential caucuses will begin the 1996 campaign next winter, Mr. Clinton vowed to hold the line against deep cuts. He also called for more Federal investment in agricultural research, and "a much more serious national effort to focus on what our responsibilities are in the area of rural development in general."
"Washington tends to be much more ideological and partisan than Main Street America," Mr. Clinton said, noting that farm policy faced new challenges because political power had shifted unequivocally to the suburbs. "And we need more of Main Street up there, not more of what's up there down here."
The conference, which parallels a series of economic conferences the White House is holding around the country, was scheduled for last fall but was postponed pending ratification of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
The official purpose was governmental, and Mr. Clinton did no fund raising during his 30-hour stay in the state, and his schedule called for him to address the State Legislature. But the White House entourage made a huge impression (The Des Moines Register alone ran six articles about the visit in this morning's edition), the President rallied a cheering field house of Iowa State students this afternoon and politics hung over the trip.
Mr. Clinton's 43 percent victory in the 1992 general election here just equaled his nationwide margin of victory, and he must do well here next year. He did not really contest the Democratic caucuses in 1992, ceding victory to Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, the favorite son, so he did not have the familiarity with voters in a state that values retail politicking that he does in other states, like New Hampshire, where early primaries are held.
Mr. Clinton faces no declared opponent in his renomination effort, and his trip here, as well as others planned to important states in the weeks ahead, is aimed at insuring that he will not. Mark D. Gearan, the White House communications director, who is helping organize the President's political operation, said he hoped to have a coordinator in place here in a few weeks.
Half glasses perched on his nose, the President led 30 panelists through three round-table discussions on topics from mental health to economic development. Mr. Clinton was at his most garrulous, comparing notes with participants like Olive Valdez, a cattle breeder from Colorado who is hoping to start a low-fat, kosher beef packing cooperative. He fielded a question on campaign finance reform from Stephen Garst, who farms 6,000 acres of corn and soybeans in Coon Rapids, Iowa, and whose father, Roswell, played host to Nikita S. Khrushchev in a celebrated visit at the height of the cold war.
"I thought the fact that he came out here means they're at least trying to do something," Mr. Garst said after the conference. "We're not getting rich, and Newt and the boys say, 'Wipe them out, get rid of those terrible subsidies.' It's not that simple."
Mr. Clinton recalled his own youthful experiences on a farm in Arkansas, and here in the land where the tall corn grows, he apparently let hyperbole get the better of him, telling editors of The Register in an interview published today, "I am the only President who knew something about agriculture when I got there." That ignored Presidential agrarians from George Washington to Mr. Clinton's idol, Harry S. Truman, whose ability to plow straight furrows was famous.

HEADLINE: W. L. Eisenberg, 74, A Labor Mediator In 2,000 Disputes

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Dr. Walter L. Eisenberg, an economics professor emeritus at Hunter College who helped settle many labor disputes at the city, state and Federal levels, died on Saturday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 74.
The cause was a heart attack, said Beatrice Kaufman Eisenberg, his wife of 49 years. 
 Over more than three decades, Dr. Eisenberg was engaged as a mediator, arbitrator or fact-finder in some 2,000 labor-management confrontations. At his death, he was a member of the New York State Public Employment Relations Board, which he joined 10 years ago.
He was formerly associated with the city's Board of Collective Bargaining and the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Board. He served as chairman and public member of panels and commissions at all levels, dealing with minimum wages, pensions and employment, among other things.
The disputes at hand affected occupations of great diversity, including doctors, nurses and teachers, production and maintenance personnel, airline pilots and iron workers, to name a few.
Walter Eisenberg grew up in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn and graduated in economics from City College in 1941. He held master's and Ph.D. degrees in economics from Columbia University.
He began his career at Hunter College of the City University of New York in 1949 as a lecturer in economics. He was elected department chairman in 1965 and became dean of graduate studies at Hunter in 1972. He retired from the college in 1979, after which he made labor disputes his principal occupation.
He was a former board chairman of Group Health Insurance Inc. He retired from G.H.I. last year after more than 20 years on the board, but at his death was a member of the G.H.I. Home Care Board of Governors.
In addition to his wife, Dr. Eisenberg is survived by a daughter, Debbie Eisenberg Levene of Kitchener, Ont., a son, David, of Leawood, Kan., and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Met Life in Merger Talks With New England Mutual

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the New England Mutual Insurance Company said yesterday that they are discussing a possible merger.
Both insurers could gain something from a combination. Met Life's insurance sales to middle-income individuals declined last year and the company, which is based in New York, is eager to expand into the more rapidly growing segment of higher-income households that are New England Mutual's forte. New England Mutual, which is based in Boston, could benefit from the financial strength of Met Life, which is eight times its size. 
 The companies have been in talks for a few months, and Met Life executives have already conducted a detailed review of the commercial mortgages and real estate holdings that have bedeviled New England Mutual the last few years.
Problems with those investments are surmountable, the Met Life executives have concluded, and are more than offset by the appeal of New England Mutual's sales force and asset management business. Met Life is also attracted to New England Mutual's computer and back office systems, the handiwork of its chairman, Robert A. Shafto, a former executive at the Electronic Data Systems Corporation.
The talks were first reported yesterday in an article in The Wall Street Journal.
If any agreement is reached, Peter Harrington, a vice president at New England Mutual, said "it would only be on the basis that we retain our separate identity" with the New England Mutual name and Boston headquarters. New England's 3,000 sales agents are contractors who work for general agencies, while Met Life's more than 11,000 agents are its employees, so the companies would keep their sales forces separate.
Another insurance executive involved in the deal who spoke on condition of anonymity said New England could keep its name and identity, but that its policies, would, in effect, be backed by Met Life.
"The merger isn't really about job cuts or economies of scale, it is about Met Life being attracted to the glitter of the high-end market at a time when demographics and competition make it tough to grow in its traditional middle-income market," the executive said.
New England, he said, "wants a partner who is strong enough to take on the real estate without too big a hit to its own ratings."
While executives at the two companies were eager to play down the idea that the merger could result in cost savings as a result of job cuts, some analysts at rating firms said both Met Life and New England needed to pare expenses, with or without a merger. "Both companies need cost savings that they will not get if they adopt a hands-off strategy," said Larry Mayewski, head of life insurance ratings at the A. M. Best Company of Oldwick, N.J.
New England's ratings still qualify as strong, but they have dropped a bit in recent years as bad real estate investments have hurt its profits. The insurer is currently rated A by A. M. Best, the agency's third-highest level, and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, its fifth-highest rating. Met Life is rated A+ by A.M. Best and AA+ by S.& P.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Off on Fear Of Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dropped yesterday after a higher-than-expected consumer confidence report, which suggested that inflation could accelerate.
The Conference Board's confidence index in April rose to 105.5 from a revised 100.2 in March. Economists had expected the confidence index to slip to 99.9. 
 A weaker dollar also contributed to the slide, and bonds were under pressure from dealers jockeying for position ahead of yesterday's two-year note auction. When-issued yields as a result gained two to three basis points in early trading, only to break even in the afternoon. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The 30-year bond fell 6/32 to a price of 10321/32 for a yield of 7.32 percent, up from 7.31 percent on Monday.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist of the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said, "Based on Monday's 7.31 percent bond yield close, market participants have come to realize that the combination of a nine-month high in the bond market and a consumer confidence reading that hit a five-year high could not justify yields moving lower."
Mr. Chan called it interesting that the proportional increase in the Conference Board's confidence index (105.5 vs. 100.2) was much greater than the increase in the Michigan sentiment index (93.8 vs. 90.3), "given that the former index was completed with data that covered only the early part of the month."
He agreed that the report certainly increased investor fears about future inflation, but added that some of the components within the index offset that notion.
"Some of the collective bargaining agreement data showed virtually no inflation," Mr. Chan said. "The Labor Department said first-quarter wage increases averaged 1.9 percent for the first year of the contract, lower than the 2.5 in the fourth quarter of last year. Remember, wages account for two-thirds of the cost of producing a product."
Existing-home sales rose 5.8 percent to a 3.62 million annualized rate in March, reversing the 5.3 percent decline in February and a 4 percent drop in January. According to the National Association of Realtors, the increase was the highest since December's 3.76 million yearly rate.
"The 101-basis-point decline in average 30-year mortgage rates, as measured by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation weekly survey, since the middle of December is finally beginning to show up in the economy's most interest-rate- sensitive sector, mainly housing," Mr. Chan said. "It will be just a matter of time before we also see a small bounce-back in other interest sensitive sectors, such as autos."
Robert Perry, president of the San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank, told reporters after a presentation to the Bankers Association for Foreign Trade in Phoenix yesterday, that despite recent signs of strength in the economy, the outlook for a "soft landing" remained good.
At yesterday's Treasury auction of new two-year notes, the high yield was quoted at 6.524 percent, down from 6.717 percent last month. Ahead of today's auction, the five-year notes were offered at a price to yield 6.78 percent.
In the municipal market, bond prices were steady. Investors eagerly awaited high-income-producing bonds on expectations that the nearly six-month run in municipals may be slowing.
Municipalities sold about $720 million in new securities, up from $180 million on Monday. Many of the offerings yesterday got a mixed reception from investors with yields rising in the government bond market.
Yields on a $150 million California Housing Finance Agency issue, the week's largest offering, were raised as much as 5 basis points to increase demand after initial pricing. A bond due in 2026 was priced to yield 6.45 percent. For an investor in the 36 percent tax bracket, that would be equivalent to a taxable yield of 10.08 percent.
The single-family mortgage revenue bonds were comprised of $100 million in tax-exempt and $50 million in taxable bonds. Underwriters said for some investors the bonds were subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Forecasts of Freezing Weather Help Push Wheat Prices Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Wheat prices rose strongly yesterday, helped by forecasts for freezing temperatures in the Great Plains.
On other commodity markets, copper extended its losses while crude oil advanced. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities slipped 0.05 point, to 236.63. 
 Wheat for July delivery, the contract that represents this year's crop, jumped 7 cents, to $3.54 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade.
"The crop is so vulnerable and the market's so sensitive to additional damage and potential damage," said Susan Leighty, an analyst with Prudential Securities.
Temperatures will fall to the mid-20's early Thursday in Nebraska and northeastern Colorado, according to the National Weather Service. Temperatures below 24 degrees can damage winter wheat.
Some private meteorologists predicted another bout of freezing temperatures in the Great Plains for early next week.
"A weather market reacts as much to long-range forecasts as to short-range forecasts," Ms. Leighty said.
Nebraska and Colorado wheat was spared by a hard freeze on April 11 that struck southwestern Kansas and the Oklahoma and Texas Panhandles. New damage assessments tend to support preliminary estimates that losses from the April 11 freeze could reach 100 million to 150 million bushels, or 4 to 6 percent of the crop in the United States. The Agriculture Department previously estimated the American crop at 2.32 billion bushels.
But it still may be too early to get a handle on the damage, said Joe Victor, director of marketing for Allendale Inc., a futures brokerage firm in Crystal Lake, Ill.
"The bottom line is that we may have to wait until harvest before we get a better damage estimate," he said. "Wheat has done stranger things. It's just like a weed -- once you think you've got it down, it's going to come back."
Copper prices fell sharply for the second consecutive day on the Commodity Exchange of New York on signs of rising supplies and expectations for declining demand as the economy cools.
Freeport-McMoran Copper and Gold Inc. reported a 14 percent increase in copper production in the first quarter. The Cyprus Amax Minerals Company reported a 5 percent increase in production of the metal for the first quarter.
The May copper contract fell 2.15 cents, to $1.261 a pound, the lowest daily settlement for near-term deliveries since Nov. 11. Copper prices have dropped 6.6 percent in the last week.
Crude oil rebounded modestly on the New York Mercantile Exchange after an early dip below $20 a barrel prompted fresh buying. June crude oil rose 17 cents, to $20.29 a barrel.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops as Outlook Dims For Action by the Group of 7

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar ended lower against most leading currencies yesterday as expectations faded that the United States and its economic allies would take steps to bolster the value of the dollar.
Finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven industrial nations began a meeting in Washington yesterday. On Monday, the dollar gained after dealers bought the currency to hedge their positions on the chance that the nations -- the United States, Germany, Japan, Canada, Britain, France and Italy -- might take some action. 
 But in New York trading late yesterday, dealers sold dollars in anticipation that the meeting would end without any concrete step taken.
"People are anticipating nothing from the G-7 and are positioning themselves accordingly" by selling dollars, said Kevin Weir, currency salesman for ABN-Amro Bank in Chicago.
John McCarthy, foreign exchange manager at ING Capital Markets in New York, said, "They can talk about global issues, but the work will really have to be done in each individual country."
In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 81.82 Japanese yen from 83.10 yen on Monday. The dollar declined to 1.3691 German marks from 1.3762 marks. The British pound rose to $1.6130 from $1.6053.
The decline in the dollar came amid recent signs of discord among the Group of Seven nations concerning monetary policy. While Japanese officials have called for a concerted effort by the group to support the dollar, German and American officials have expressed skepticism that the group can do much to help the beleaguered currency.
"The level of acrimony among G-7 finance ministers has probably never been higher," said Todd Buchholz, an economic official in the Bush Administration who is now president of the G7 Group, a consulting firm.
In an interview with The Des Moines Register on Monday, President Clinton said the only steps that the United States could take to support the dollar were raising interest rates, which he sees as unwise, or cutting the budget deficit further, which he pledged to do.
Japan's trade surplus is partly responsible for the dollar's weakness, and dollar purchases by central banks can do little to halt the dollar's slide, he said.
