HEADLINE: The Nobel Laureates on Life

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, April 25

 BODY:
In an event its moderator, Ted Koppel, said was quintessentially American because it was "planned within an inch of its life," eight Nobel laureates in literature gathered here for discussions that covered subjects that seemed anything but planned. Indeed, if there was a theme to the two days of discussions that ended today, it revolved around the virtues of uncertainty and the unpredictable, which many of these noted writers extolled, as they did the power of myth in both life and art.
"Articulation is about precision, and once you get precise you are uncertain," said the ever-enigmatic and epigrammatic Joseph Brodsky, the Russian-born poet, who now lives in the United States and was the Nobel winner in 1987 and this country's poet laureate in 1991. 
 Wole Soyinka, the alternately mystical and didactic exiled Nigerian writer who won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1986, said, "Literature eschews absolutes and opens the human mind to the possibility of error."
Toni Morrison, the 1993 Nobelist, described herself as "enchanted by enchantment."
But perhaps it was the Japanese novelist Kenzaburo Oe, the Nobel winner last year, who summed up the interplay of myth and uncertainty in literature.
"It is the second job of literature to create myth," he said through an interpreter. "But its first job is to destroy that myth."
More than 1,000 people attended these freewheeling conversations on a stage at the Carter Presidential Center here. This was the last event of a multiyear Cultural Olympiad sponsored by The Georgia Review and the Atlanta Committee on the Olympic Games as part of the run up to the 1996 Summer Olympics, to be held in Atlanta. Its organizers said this was the largest gathering of Nobel literature laureates in the 94-year history of the prize.
Jeffrey Babcock, the director of the Olympic committee's cultural programs, noted that in recent years the cultural programs held by the host cities had centered on the performing arts. But Atlanta sought to create a four-year, multidisciplinary arts, entertainment and literature program to culminate with the Olympic Arts Festival, which is to coincide with the Summer Games.
Historically, culture was no stranger to the Olympic Games, said Rita Dove, the 1993 and 1994 American poet laureate who helped to organize this event, which, in addition to the panel discussions, included afternoon and evening readings by the laureates. During the Games in ancient Greece, she noted, there were music and literary competitions as well as appearances by writers looking for new and broader audiences for their work.
The gathering also included Czeslaw Milosz, the 83-year-old Polish-Lithuanian poet and 1980 Nobel Prize winner, who has lived in the United States for 35 years; the French novelist Claude Simon, 81, who won in 1985; the Mexican poet, essayist and diplomat Octavio Paz, 81, who won in 1990, and the poet and playwright Derek Walcott, 65, of Trinidad, who was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1992.
Mr. Koppel was right as far as advance preparations were concerned. The rigid planning of the event could be seen in the squadrons of Cadillacs that chauffeured the laureates from place to place and the small army of Olympic committee staff members with walkie-talkies, who reported the movements of the writers minute by minute. The air at the conference crackled with radio static as well as the artful and finely tuned words of the participants.
The event was also suffused with a cordiality and conviviality among the famous participants. On Saturday night, after their arrival, the laureates spent their time together watching the heavyweight title fight between George Foreman and Axel Schulz on television. On Monday, they lingered over a private luncheon at which they staged a mock "revolt of the laureates" on Mr. Brodsky's behalf to win this taciturn chain smoker the right to smoke in the usually nonsmoking Carter Center dining room.
There were small kindnesses and evident pleasures in their encounters. Sitting on a panel discussion next to Mr. Brodsky, Ms. Morrison poured him a glass a water while he spoke. Mr. Milosz openly expressed an almost childlike joy at finally meeting Mr. Soyinka, whom he said he had long admired.
Pulling together such a group, whose members crave their solitude, was a formidable task, said Stanley W. Lindberg, the editor of The Georgia Review, who thought of this in the first place.
"Our biggest problem was getting their attention," he said. "Derek is so casual about answering his mail and Toni Morrison has so many invitations. We promised Derek that he could carry the Olympic torch to get him here, and Rita Dove helped us get Ms. Morrison's attention."
The original concept, he said, was to get all 16 of the living Nobel laureates in literature, from the oldest, the 94-year-old Halldor Laxness, who lives in a nursing home in Reykjavik, Iceland, to the youngest, Mr. Brodsky, 54. But that proved impossible.
Through the two days of discussions, the laureates touched on subjects ranging from the role of the writer in society to the impact of the Nobel Prize on their lives. They talked of the lessons for the world in the Oklahoma City bombing, the Rwandan massacres and the fighting in Bosnia. They spoke of multiculturalism and political correctness and the opposing forces of universalism and particularism that are at the heart of so many conflicts.
Most scoffed at a specific role for artists. As Ms. Morrison said, "It is painful having agendas cut out for writers."
As for prizes, they were all accidents, said Mr. Paz. And multiculturalism and political correctness were imprecise terms most said they would like to see banished from the language, any language.
Mr. Koppel, who took to calling the laureates "G.W.'s" -- for Great Writers -- said he saw the bombing in Oklahoma City partly as a result of a society grown inarticulate and unused to expressing itself with language. The media aftermath, particularly television coverage, was seen as adding insult to this injury. Mr. Oe called it "pseudo-communication."
Mr. Soyinka said he was "concerned about preserving a special level of communications, a level very different from Oprah Winfrey." "There is a danger when we make a fetish out of communication," he added.
The curmudgeon of the gathering was Mr. Simon, the urbane Frenchman who seemed to reject all analysis of things current. In response to a question about what role literature could play along with economics, science and technology in improving society, he responded ambiguously through an interpreter, the poet Richard Howard, that "literature is of no use for anything at all, like Mozart."
There were lighter moments, of course. On Monday, the Cultural Olympiad organizers received a message from Sharon Stone, the actress who is filming in Savannah, Ga. She offered to send a chartered plane to pick up Mr. Paz so he could have lunch with her. She said she was a big fan of this writer, adding that she was also fluent in Spanish.
But his schedule did not allow Mr. Paz, who said he was unfamiliar with Ms. Stone's work, to make the trip. His longtime translator, Eliot Weinberger, a New York writer and essayist, volunteered to be Mr. Paz's stand-in. Sadly though, Mr. Weinberger said, he was informed that Ms. Stone's stand-in was not available to join him.

HEADLINE: With Budget Due, Giuliani Faces Gap Of Over $3 Billion

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
As Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani prepares to present his second city budget tomorrow, administration officials said yesterday that New York City's budget gap now exceeds $3 billion, forcing the Mayor to propose still deeper cuts in spending by the city's agencies.
The gap is now nearly $400 million above the $2.7 billion shortfall the Mayor projected just two months ago. At $3.1 billion, the gap represents about 10 percent of the budget for the fiscal year that starts in July. 
 City officials said the budget gap has widened largely because Medicaid costs have been higher than projected and because other spending in areas like overtime for city workers has exceeded projections as well.
To make up most of the projected shortfall, the Mayor will propose slashing spending by city agencies by nearly $400 million more than he proposed in February, for a total of about $1 billion, the officials said. He is also hoping that the state budget, when it is passed, will include changes that will save the city about $700 million in welfare and Medicaid payments. Other strategies for closing the gap will include seeking pay and benefit concessions from unions representing city workers.
The latest fiscal problems emerged on a day when hundreds of demonstrators, protesting planned budget cuts by the city and the state, blocked two bridges and two tunnels in Manhattan during the height of the rush hour. [Page B3.]
The Mayor is to present his executive budget to the City Council tomorrow. The budget, officials said, would largely reflect the outlines of the preliminary budget he unveiled in February but would include significant changes as well.
Among them, Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that he had backed away from two proposals in his preliminary budget plan last February. The first was to eliminate the sales tax on clothing that costs less than $100. The other was to reduce property taxes on co-ops and condominiums.
In a meeting yesterday with the editorial board of The New York Times, the Mayor said he would instead propose equivalent reductions in the commercial rent tax for small businesses throughout the city, eliminating that tax altogether on small businesses other than those below 96th Street in Manhattan, which fall under a different classification under this city tax regulation.
The Mayor's decision would, in effect, shift the benefits of his $185 million in proposed tax cuts away from shoppers and co-op owners and give them instead to a far smaller pool of people -- small-business owners.
Under the Mayor's plan, a typical small business in Brooklyn, whose rent totaled $50,000 a year, would no longer have to pay $3,000 in taxes. By contrast, a shopper buying a $100 shirt would save $4 if the city exempted clothing under $100 from its sales tax, which totals 4 percent.
The Council may oppose these tax cuts. Last month, Council leaders said the city should scale back Mr. Giuliani's cuts -- unless he could find a way to offer them without drastically reducing city services.
Aides to Mr. Giuliani said the Mayor decided to delay the tax cuts for clothing and co-ops and condos for at least a year because he was not sure that the State Legislature would approve the changes.
But the city can reduce the commercial rent tax on its own.
"We can't control what happens in Albany," one official said.
In fact, Albany figures prominently in the Mayor's efforts to close the budget gap. In his executive budget, the Mayor will scale back the savings he had hoped to receive from the state's cuts in Medicaid and welfare. The scope of those changes are still under debate by Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders.
The city budget, officials said, would anticipate $700 million in savings from Medicaid and welfare. The city and the state would share those costs. The Mayor's initial plan had called for $1.2 billion, but it has been clear for some time that neither the Governor nor the Legislature would make cuts that deep.
The Mayor's new figure, the officials said, generally reflected the amount the city would save under the agreement reached between Mr. Pataki and the Republicans in the State Senate. But if the Democratic-led Assembly's position prevails, the city's savings would be even less.
The officials said the Mayor would also propose $250 million in new aid from the state, in areas like school busing, nursing home care, prison costs and general aid for local governments. It remains far from certain that the city will receive all of that, which means the budget gap could turn out to be even larger.
The city's budget gap has grown steadily since the Mayor and the Council adopted the budget for the current year last June.
Budget gaps reflect the difference between projected revenues and projected spending in years ahead; they are notoriously variable, rising and falling depending on a variety of economic and political assumptions.
The latest projected gap reflected estimates by the city's fiscal monitors, including the City and State Comptrollers, who have held that the Mayor's office had made overly optimistic assumptions of state aid and had underestimated costs.
The new gap began the fiscal year at $900 million and has since grown step by step, largely because of a $500 million decline in city tax revenues, a drop in anticipated Federal and state aid, and $300 million in added pension costs.
The latest increase, officials said, reflected unexpected increases in spending that will carry from this fiscal year into the next. Those include overtime and increased costs for city Medicaid payments because the Health and Hospitals Corporation has been more effective at seeking Medicaid reimbursements, of which the city pays a quarter share.
In February, the Mayor proposed a $30.5 billion budget, which represented a cut of $1.3 billion, or 4 percent, in total city spending from the current year, the largest percentage cut since the Depression.
The leadership of the City Council yesterday briefed its members on its own draft recommendations for cuts in Medicaid and welfare, which would save the city $150 million less than the Mayor's new position. The Mayor's office had sought to persuade the Council to join with it in lobbying Albany to accept the Mayor's proposals.

LENGTH: 1218 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. AND 6 ALLIES VOW NEW EFFORTS TO REVIVE DOLLAR

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
The United States and six other leading industrial nations declared today that the dollar's decline had gone "beyond the levels justified by underlying economic conditions in the major countries," and they made a vague promise to strengthen both short-term tactics and long-term strategy to reverse its fall.
After days of recriminations among the economic powers over who is responsible for the turmoil in world currency markets, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin hailed the statement -- issued after a meeting of finance ministers and central bank chiefs of the Group of Seven -- as a strong signal of mutual resolve to reverse the dollar's decline. 
 "It was really a very constructive set of meetings in a constructive atmosphere," Mr. Rubin said at a news conference tonight at the Treasury Department. "Among those people, the people with real responsibility, there was a real spirit of cooperative enterprise."
But the most specific wording in the declaration was that the nations "agreed that orderly reversal of those movements is desirable," and it was unclear whether that by itself would be sufficient to reverse the dollar's slide.
As the ministers met today, the dollar, which has lost almost 17 percent of its value against the Japanese yen in three months, fell again, to 81.82 yen in late New York trading, down from 83.10 yen on Monday. [In afternoon trading in Tokyo on Wednesday, the dollar regained some ground, rising to 82.38 yen, up 0.55 yen.]
Part of the recent decline may have been precipitated by President Clinton's opposition to a rise in American interest rates to attract more investment and stimulate demand for dollars.
The managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, has repeatedly called for such an increase.
"We aren't going to do ourselves any good to spark a recession here at home by raising interest rates further," Mr. Clinton said in an interview that was published today in The Des Moines Register, before a daylong visit to Iowa. The President plays no direct role in setting rates, but his comments appeared part of a broader effort by Administration officials recently to pressure the Federal Reserve Board, for fear that another rise could send the economy into a downturn as the early 1996 primaries approach.
Mr. Clinton insisted that investors around the world had failed to appreciate his commitment to cutting the budget deficit. Some foreign critics cite the growing deficit as the main reason for the dollar's slide.
"Once the financial markets see that I am serious, that we're not about to have a $200 billion tax cut, and we're certainly not about to have a tax cut of any size -- not one red cent -- that is basically an add-on to this deficit, then they will stabilize and go forward," he said.
All day today the markets were jittery, with traders betting that the finance ministers and central bankers would issue a vague, soothing statement and that it would have little effect. Yet no one wanted to be caught out of the markets on the off-chance that the economic powers would decide that their discord was worsening the situation.
The officials ended up with something in between. It is somewhat unusual for the finance ministers to issue a communique after a meeting, but American and Japanese officials said today that a consensus had quickly emerged at the meeting in favor of making a statement.
However, it was short on specifics about how the countries would cooperate -- by joint intervention in the markets or by a rededication to economic fundamentals -- and it may not convince investors that bickering over the currency turmoil has been resolved.
France's Finance Minister, Edmond Alphandery, made clear tonight that he did not believe the statement went far enough. "If it had been drafted by us -- and this goes even more so for the Japanese -- it would have been much more specific," he said.
Asked if the ministers failed to go far enough, Mr. Rubin said of the statement, "I don't think it is bland. I think if you read it with some care, it's a very interesting statement." His aides said it marked the first time that the nations had agreed on a direction of action, if not the action.
Japanese officials acknowledged the absence of a concrete plan to rescue the dollar but still sought to portray the meeting as successful. Masayoshi Takemura, Japan's Finance Minister, emphasized at a news conference tonight that the communique spoke of reversing the dollar's downward movement, rather than simply halting it.
"This movement goes beyond the economic fundamentals," said Mr. Takemura, who became Finance Minister last year in a political deal that brought Japan's current coalition Government to power.
Germany's Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, said that the countries did not seriously consider resurrecting agreements to manage global currencies as they had in the 1980's.
All the Group of Seven members -- the United States, Canada, Japan, Germany, France, Britain and Italy -- hope their statement will squeeze speculators out of the market by raising fear that a worldwide consensus is building that the dollar has fallen too far.
"The major currencies are out of step with the fundamentals," Mr. Rubin said today. But private capital flows so dwarf the resources that governments can commit to stabilizing currencies that the ministers' chief power is persuasion.
Asked today why the group did not commit to joint action, Mr. Rubin, a former currency trader, said, "I don't think you can arrange anything in a currency market."
The question now is whether the persuasive force will be sufficient. "I think everyone has the sense that empty commentary is only going to send things lower," said David De Rosa, who directs foreign exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
The Administration is also trying to deflect calls for an interest-rate rise out of fear that it could kill off a soft landing for the economy.
For their part, Fed officials have played down the possibility of inflation's rising even as the falling dollar make imports more expensive for Americans.
Asked this morning if there was a risk of more inflation from the weak dollar, Alan S. Blinder, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, replied, "There is a little bit." He quickly modified his answer to "some" risk when a reporter suggested that his initial comment indicated a lack of concern about the possibility.
In the weeks leading to today's meeting, it seemed likely that the other economic powers were preparing criticism of the United States for its tactics in orchestrating the Mexican bailout, which included pressuring countries to back a larger emergency commitment for Mexico from the International Monetary Fund.
At the time, several nations complained that they had not been consulted. And in recent days, German officials have repeatedly said that a bailout of such magnitude must be "exceptional," and that the industrial nations could not regularly save emerging economies.
The criticisms were muted, however, by a surprising turn of events: Evidence is emerging that the Mexican bailout is working to some degree. The peso has strengthened in recent days, and Mexican officials say that their economy and finances have turned the corner.

HEADLINE: International Briefs;
Pretax Profits at Hoechst Surge in Quarter

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
The German chemicals company Hoechst A.G. said yesterday that its first-quarter pretax profit had nearly doubled. It cited improving business environments in Europe, Japan and the United States. In the first three months of the year, the company reported pretax profit of 984 million marks, or $720.6 million, up from 506 million marks in the corresponding period last year. 
 Hoechst attributed the 94 percent rise in earnings to economic recovery in Western Europe, reviving industrial production in Japan and economic growth in the United States and in emerging economies. Sales rose 8 percent to 13 billion marks, or $9.52 billion, from 12 billion marks.

HEADLINE: Mr. Rubin Says No

 BODY:
The dollar has fallen about 10 percent against the German mark and 20 percent against the Japanese yen, frightening German and Japanese exporters who fear their products will be priced out of the huge American market. It is no surprise, then, that the German and Japanese Finance Ministers -- meeting this week in Washington with their counterparts from five other industrialized powers -- insist that the United States correct the problem by raising interest rates.
It is no surprise, either, that Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin rejects the plea out of hand since raising rates would threaten to end the nation's economic recovery. The non-specific declaration issued yesterday by the ministers does little to resolve this dispute. 
 The best policy America can pursue for its allies is one that keeps inflation low and employment high. Low inflation will eventually keep the value of the dollar from fluctuating wildly and thereby destabilizing trade. High employment will keep demand for foreign-made goods high. What Mr. Rubin correctly points out is that America has already done what it should; employment growth is higher here than in Europe or Japan and inflation remains low, less than 3 percent per year.
The Germans say the United States should cut back Federal borrowing in order to take pressure off the dollar, but Mr. Rubin rightly points out that the Federal deficit, measured against the size of the economy, is smaller here than in Europe.
The Federal Reserve Board, which bears responsibility for keeping the economy on an even keel, has jacked up interest rates for a year because it feared inflation was about to kick higher. It postponed further hikes last month out of fear it might go too far and tip the economy into a downturn. Perhaps the Fed exaggerates the threat, but its judgment over the past few years has been sound. For the Fed now to push rates higher against its best judgment is to risk something far worse than dollar weakness: it risks triggering a recession here, which could drag Europe and Japan closely behind.
The country whose policies ought to change is Japan. Its economy is stagnant, inflation nonexistent and trade balance in surplus. For the sake of the Japanese people, as well as its trade partners, Japan ought to undertake monetary and fiscal easing. Instead it calls on the United States to adopt a self-defeating policy that threatens to wound itself and others.

HEADLINE: McNamara Took a Long Step to Heal Our Vietnam Wound

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Mr. McNamara's War" (editorial, April 12) you savagely attack Robert S. McNamara's acknowledgment of error in Vietnam as "prime-time apology and stale tears," declaring that he "must not escape the lasting moral condemnation of his countrymen." 
 No mea culpa deserves such contempt. It is true that his comes late -- very late -- but it should be saluted, not scorned. This country can never be truly reunited until the Vietnam wound is closed. Mr. McNamara, by his admission, has taken a long step toward the healing. What he needs now is company. The Presidents of those years are dead, but most of the other warlords are still among us. Let's hear from them.
You state: "Fifty-eight thousand Americans got to come home in body bags. Mr. McNamara, while tormented by his role in the war, got a sinecure at the World Bank and summers at the Vineyard."
These are the facts. Robert S. McNamara became Secretary of Defense on Jan. 21, 1961, and resigned on Nov. 29, 1967. On Jan. 19, 1968 -- nearly two months later -- the United States high command reported the total number of Americans killed in Vietnam as 16,459.
Our bloodiest years in Vietnam lay ahead. By the end of 1969 there would be 39,893 dead. Your final figure is correct: 58,135. But that was more than six years after Mr. McNamara left the Pentagon. So if it was Mr. McNamara's war, was it not also Mr. Rusk's? Mr. Bundy's? Mr. Clifford's? Mr. Rostow's? Mr. Laird's? And -- last, but certainly not least -- Mr. Kissinger's?
As writers we have always taken a solemn view of our responsibilities as Americans. Fifty years ago we served in the United States Marine Corps. We vigorously denounced the war in Vietnam -- though never the brave men who fought there -- and we openly, often bitterly, disagreed with all who were prosecuting it, including Robert McNamara.
We welcome his acknowledgment that the United States was wrong then, believing that America can never be damaged by an act of contrition, and we invite all those who stood with him to join him now on his knees.
 
WILLIAM STYRON
WILLIAM MANCHESTER
Roxbury, Conn., April 23, 1995

HEADLINE: Private Chefs for Busy People Who Like Their Meatloaf

BYLINE: By ANNE S. LEWIS 

 BODY:
WHEN Stephanie Hersh got her first job as a private chef for a family of four in Milton, Mass., in 1989, she did what she thought private chefs do: she spent each day preparing haute cuisine for dinner. At the end of the first week, her employer sat her down and said they needed to talk about menus.
As Ms. Hersh recalled it, her employer was reassuring but firm, telling her: "Not that this hasn't been wonderful -- it's just not the way we eat. We like foods like macaroni and cheese and meatloaf and lasagna." And so, Ms. Hersh promptly switched gears and began making simpler meals. 
 There was a time when private chefs provided five-course meals for the leisure class. Now, both the clientele and the cuisine are changing. Because of time-crunched, nutritionally conscious, two-career families, a new breed of private chef has been spawned: one who goes into a home and cooks affordable meals that are meant to appeal to those who are tired of restaurant and takeout food.
Now, there is even a business-support association for those wishing to start a personal chef service: the United States Personal Chef Association, which has 650 members in 46 states. It was founded in 1991 by David MacKay and his wife, Susan Titcomb, who is a personal chef in Albuquerque, N.M.
Work as a personal chef usually offers an easier life than restaurants. Four days a week, Nancy Davis, a former restaurant chef who runs a personal chef service in Austin, Tex., called Chef on the Run, dons her chef fatigues, loads her car with cooking equipment and groceries, and spends the day cooking in clients' kitchens -- a venue she says she vastly prefers to a restaurant kitchen, with its high stress level and nighttime hours, which make social life difficult.
Ms. Davis leaves 10 individually packaged entrees and side dishes for two in the refrigerators of those clients who are on an every-other-week schedule. Her portions are large, and clients sometimes stretch two meals from one. Although she makes things like lemon-grass chicken and crayfish enchiladas, she will also accommodate blander palates. Her charge is $260 for 10 meals for two people.
For nine years, Susan Goldstein of Personally Prepared by Susan, in Brighton, Mass., has been shopping and cooking for up to 15 clients. Three days a week, she cooks in the kitchens of her biweekly clients, spending five to seven hours shopping for food and cooking up to 10 meals. The other days, she serves her monthly clients, leaving them food for up to 30 meals in the freezer as well as heating and serving instructions.
Ms. Goldstein, 35, offers her clients menus with salads; vegetables; fish, meat and poultry entrees; pasta sauces and marinades; pizzas, and lasagnas. She will also cook anything on request; her service is tailored to each family's needs. Some clients ask her to prepare recipes from magazines or cookbooks. Her typical client, she said, is a dual-income professional couple with two to three children. For her services, Ms. Goldstein charges $25 an hour plus food costs.
It often happens that clients who are initially skeptical about the prospect of a stranger in their kitchen cooking what they fear could turn out to be no more than expensive Lean Cuisine quickly become converts to the luxury of sitting down to professionally prepared meals within minutes of arriving home from work.
Cindy Dade, an insurance agent, and her husband, Ronald Dade, an investment adviser, have been clients of Ms. Goldstein for five years. "We work long hours," Ms. Dade said, "and the last thing I want to do when I get home is have a bowl of cereal and go to bed. We want real meals, but I don't enjoy cooking when there's no time." She added that low-fat, healthy meals were a high priority.
For the Dades, who live in Amherst, Mass., having a private chef is a luxury without drawbacks. But, she admitted, "when it's time to choose menus and I say to myself, 'O.K., you can have anything in the world you want to eat, so what is it?' -- sometimes it's hard to say."
Steven Shavell, a law professor, and Catherine Shavell, a lawyer, enjoy the additional family time they gain from hiring Ms. Goldstein to cook meals every two weeks in their Cambridge, Mass., home.
"When you look at the economics, it's a bargain compared to going out to eat three times a week," Mr. Shavell said. "Even so, most people regard us as somewhat extravagant, and the notion of having someone come to your home to cook is considered a bit much." Still, he said he and his wife would prefer to eliminate other household services, like gardening and snow removal, rather than the chef service.
Members of the United States Personal Chef Association are not required to be trained chefs -- though some are -- and they range from retired jewelers to hairdressers and former military personnel. Business memberships cost $99 a year, and the association sells training systems ($595 to $895 a year), software packages ($49.95) and packages of tested recipes ($249).
"All that's required is a passion for cooking," Mr. MacKay said.
Members charge $8 to $13 a person for each meal. The names of personal chefs in given areas can be obtained by calling the association at (800) 995-2138.

HEADLINE: HIGH COURT KILLS LAW BANNING GUNS IN A SCHOOL ZONE

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
The Supreme Court today dealt a stinging blow to the Federal Government's ability to move into the realm of local law enforcement, ruling in a bitterly divided 5-to-4 decision that Congress acted beyond its constitutional authority five years ago when it made possession of a gun within 1,000 feet of a school a Federal crime.
The decision, with a majority opinion by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, was based on the Court's interpretation of the authority of Congress to regulate interstate commerce. While not overturning any precedents, the decision marked a sharp departure from the modern Supreme Court's expansive view of Congressional power to regulate commerce. 
 Justice Stephen G. Breyer, in a dissenting opinion, said the decision "threatens legal uncertainty in an area of law that, until this case, seemed reasonably well settled."
The Constitution's grant of authority to Congress to regulate interstate commerce has been the basis for the development of the Federal Government in many of its most familiar aspects, particularly since the Supreme Court reversed course in 1937 and began to uphold the regulatory laws at the heart of the New Deal.
The last time the Court overturned a Federal law on the ground that it exceeded the Congressional commerce authority was 1936, when it struck down minimum-wage and maximum-hour requirements in the coal industry.
The ruling today, declaring unconstitutional the Gun-Free School Zones Act of 1990, cast doubt on the ability of Congress to exercise jurisdiction over a range of activities it has recently defined as Federal crimes, including car jacking, drive-by shootings and violent demonstrations at abortion clinics.
Unlike the law the Court struck down today, which made it a crime simply to have a gun in a particular place, most Federal gun laws regulate activities like buying, selling or importing guns, activities that fall within the classic definition of interstate commerce and that the ruling today did not disturb.
But at the least, the decision is likely to encourage a new round of legal challenges to other gun control laws. "Everything will be tested now," one Congressional aide said.
For example, one recently enacted Federal law, the ban on assault weapons, which is already the subject of a Federal court challenge by the National Rifle Association, makes it a crime to possess the weapons as well as to manufacture or import them. Possession of machine guns, undetectable handguns and "cop-killer" bullets are also crimes under various Federal laws that may now be open to legal attack.
The Brady law, which imposes a five-day waiting period for gun purchases and requires state officials to conduct background checks of purchasers, has already been declared unconstitutional in a half-dozen Federal district courts. The basis for those decisions, which the Clinton Administration is appealing, was not the Congressional commerce power but state autonomy under the 10th Amendment, which reserves to the states the powers not explicitly delegated to the Federal Government by the Constitution.
While that is a different rationale than the one the Court employed today, the 10th Amendment and the commerce clause are closely related elements of an ongoing constitutional debate over state power within the Federal system.
The language of federalism rang strongly through Chief Justice Rehnquist's majority opinion, as well as in a concurring opinion filed by Justices Anthony M. Kennedy and Sandra Day O'Connor. Justices Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas, who filed his own concurring opinion, were the other members of the majority.
Joining Justice Breyer in dissenting were Justices John Paul Stevens, David H. Souter and Ruth Bader Ginsburg. Justice Breyer took the unusual step of reading from the bench this morning a portion of the dissenting opinion he wrote for himself and the three others. Justices Stevens and Souter filed their own dissenting opinions as well. Justice Stevens called the majority ruling "extraordinary."
In his majority opinion, Chief Justice Rehnquist said the Administration's arguments for upholding the Gun-Free School Zones Act "would bid fair to convert Congressional authority under the commerce clause to a general police power of the sort retained by the states."
The Chief Justice said the law was "a criminal statute that by its terms has nothing to do with 'commerce' or any sort of economic enterprise, however broadly one might define those terms." He rejected the Administration's argument that guns and violence in schools hurt the economy by undermining the educational process and making children less productive workers and citizens.
"If we were to accept the Government's arguments, we are hard-pressed to posit any activity by an individual that Congress is without power to regulate," Chief Justice Rehnquist said. By the same logic, he added, school curriculums and state laws governing divorce and child custody would also come under Federal control.
In his dissenting opinion, Justice Souter accused the majority of having abandoned the principles of judicial restraint. He urged his colleagues to remember the "painful lesson" of the New Deal era, when the Court's activism in striking down Federal laws under the commerce clause brought the Court into disrepute and under sustained political attack.
"It seems fair to ask whether the step taken by the Court today does anything but portend a return to the untenable jurisprudence from which the Court extricated itself almost 60 years ago," Justice Souter said.
One lesson from that period, he said, was that "nothing about the judiciary as an institution made it a superior source of policy on the subject Congress dealt with."
In the dissenting opinion that Justices Souter, Stevens and Ginsburg also joined, Justice Breyer said the decision "threatens legal uncertainty" in legal matters that until now "seemed reasonably well settled." His opinion included a 17-page appendix listing studies and reference works on violence in the schools and on the connection between education and the economy.
"Why could Congress, for commerce clause purposes, not consider schools as roughly analogous to commercial investments from which the nation derives the benefit of an educated work force?" Justice Breyer asked.
One question the majority left unresolved was whether the Gun-Free School Zones Act might have been upheld had Congress, in passing the legislation, included the references and detailed argument that the dissenting Justices provided.
Some passages in Chief Justice Rehnquist's opinion could be read as indicating that a more detailed rationale for the legislation -- not by Government lawyers defending it in Court but by those sponsoring and voting for it at the time -- could have bolstered the case that education was sufficiently connected with the national economy to come within Congressional authority.
But other part of the opinion appeared to look the other way, both with respect to the question at hand and to the broader issue of structural limits on Federal power over the states. The outer limits of Congressional authority under the commerce clause "always will engender legal uncertainty," he said, adding, "The Constitution mandates this uncertainty by withholding from Congress a plenary police power that would authorize enactment of every type of legislation."
Federal actions like caps on medical malpractice awards, which have been approved by the House of Representatives and are being debated in the Senate, will be open to challenge under today's ruling if they ever become law because this area of law is historically a state preserve with a limited connection to interstate commerce. The pending legislation also includes limits on damage awards for defective products, which would be likely to survive a challenge because products move in interstate commerce.
The decision, United States v. Lopez, No. 93-1260, upheld a 1993 ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans. That court overturned the conviction of a San Antonio high school student, Alfonso Lopez Jr., for violating the Gun-Free School Zones Act by carrying a concealed .38-caliber pistol and five bullets to school. The appellate court invalidated the law, calling it "a singular incursion by the Federal Government into territory long occupied by the states."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Adds To List of Cuts For Spending

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Raising the specter of harsh new spending cuts for New York City's schools, hospitals, libraries and museums, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has identified more than $400 million in additional cuts he says he would make, should the city fail to receive enough help from the state to close its yawning budget gap, officials said yesterday.
The contingency cuts, the officials said, were intended to put pressure on Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders, particularly Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, to include $950 million in savings and aid in the state budget that Mr. Giuliani has proposed to balance the city's budget. 
 But even before the Mayor could formally unveil the contingency list as part of his budget proposal today, there were indications that he might be turned down in Albany.
Asked specifically about the Mayor's request for additional aid yesterday, Mr. Pataki said: "The state is obviously facing a $5 billion deficit. It's very difficult for us to increase spending beyond what is already proposed, but we're certainly willing to look at it."
At the same time, a budget bill was passed last night in the Assembly that its Democratic leaders said would give the city $655 million in the new fiscal year -- far short of the Mayor's requests.
The Assembly's bill would reduce the city's savings from Medicaid and welfare cuts, but give the city new aid in areas like schools and transportation. Some of the new aid, however, would be earmarked for specific programs and thus could not be used to close the city's budget shortfall.
Even as the Assembly passed its version of the state budget in Albany, the Mayor and Mr. Silver continued their feud over aid for the city.
Mr. Giuliani said the Speaker's resistance to state cuts in entitlement spending would force still deeper reductions in city services.
"For every dollar that Shelly Silver puts back in entitlement spending, that's a dollar we have to take out of city services," Mr. Giuliani said. "There aren't many trade-offs left in the budget."
The Speaker's spokeswoman, Patricia Lynch, responded: "The Mayor should refrain from his partisan shots and concentrate on governing instead. He's participating in nothing more than Republican campaign rhetoric."
The exchange and the contingency cuts underscored the extent to which the Mayor's ability to balance the city budget for the fiscal year that begins in July will rely on actions taken in Albany.
The Mayor's Budget Director, Marc V. Shaw, declined to specify the contingency cuts. But other officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said they would hack away at highly visible services used by thousands of New Yorkers.
The reductions, the officials said, included a $60 million cut in the city's contribution to the Health and Hospitals Corporation. Spending for libraries would be reduced, forcing branches to lower the number of days they are open from six to five. The Cultural Affairs Department, which allocates funds to museums and arts groups, would face a 40 percent reduction in its proposed $80 million budget. That number already represents an 18 percent cut from this year.
Mr. Shaw insisted that this was not a false, doomsday list of the sort Mr. Giuliani has criticized in the past. When the trustees of the City University of New York warned that city and state budget cuts would have dire effects, the Mayor called their tactic the "Washington Monument" strategy: floating the worst-case scenario that was unlikely ever to be enacted as a scare tactic.
But Mr. Shaw said the Mayor would have no other choice but to follow through with these cuts if the city failed to receive the aid being sought from Albany.
"What this is all about is making relative choices," he said.
For his part, Mr. Giuliani said his new budget, the second for his administration, would set the city on a course toward lasting balance. It would be the first, he said, to detail plans to close the recurring budget gaps that have dogged the city since the late 1980's. In fact, he said, his multiyear plan will leave the city with budget surpluses in the years ahead.
"The plan that we put out for tomorrow will for the first time in some time produce structural balance for the city," Mr. Giuliani said at a news conference on Staten Island.
Raymond D. Horton, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private group financed by businesses, said it was premature to predict victory over the city's budget woes until the reductions in expenses proved to be recurring -- not simply temporary squeezing that could allow spending simply to rise again.
Ending the city's yearly budget gaps "is highly unlikely," he said, "unless the local economy improves much better than anyone sees right now and the Mayor and the Council become adverse to using one shots." The term "one shot" refers to budget-reduction strategies that are short-term fixes and have little positive effect on the underlying problem.
The Mayor also said yesterday that his budget would eliminate capital financing to build a new Police Academy in the South Bronx. The new academy, first proposed by Mayor Edward I. Koch in 1989 to replace the current building on 20th Street in Manhattan, has been fiercely debated, and an effort to kill the project seems certain to meet resistance in the Council, particularly from the Bronx delegation.
Mr. Giuliani said the city "had no choice" but to cut some large projects as part of his effort to cut capital spending by 22 percent because of a state limit on the amount of debt the city can carry.

HEADLINE: Excerpts of Opinions on Gun Ban Near Schools

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today in United States v. Lopez, declaring unconstitutional a Federal law banning the possession of guns near schools. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the majority opinion and was joined by Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia, Anthony M. Kennedy and Clarence Thomas. Dissenting were John Paul Stevens, David H. Souter, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Stephen G. Breyer. 

 
 
FROM THE DECISION
By Chief Justice Rehnquist
 In the Gun-Free School Zones Act of 1990, Congress made it a Federal offense "for any individual knowingly to possess a firearm at a place that the individual knows, or has reasonable cause to believe, is a school zone." 18 U.S.C. s922(q)(1)(A). The Act neither regulates a commercial activity nor contains a requirement that the possession be connected in any way to interstate commerce. We hold that the Act exceeds the authority of Congress "(t)o regulate Commerce . . . among the several States. . . ." U. S. Const., Art. I, s8, cl. 3. . . .
We start with first principles. The Constitution creates a Federal Government of enumerated powers. . . . The Constitution delegates to Congress the power "(t)o regulate Commerce with foreign Nations, and among the several States, and with the Indian Tribes." U. S. Const., Art. I, s8, cl. 3. . . .
We have identified three broad categories of activity that Congress may regulate under its commerce power. First, Congress may regulate the use of the channels of interstate commerce. Second, Congress is empowered to regulate and protect the instrumentalities of interstate commerce, or persons or things in interstate commerce, even though the threat may come only from intrastate activities. Finally, Congress's commerce authority includes the power to regulate those activities having a substantial relation to interstate commerce and those activities that substantially affect interstate commerce.
We now turn to consider the power of Congress, in the light of this framework, to enact s922(q). The first two categories of authority may be quickly disposed of: s922(q) is not a regulation of the use of the channels of interstate commerce, nor is it an attempt to prohibit the interstate transportation of a commodity through the channels of commerce; nor can s922(q) be justified as a regulation by which Congress has sought to protect an instrumentality of interstate commerce or a thing in interstate commerce. Thus, if s922(q) is to be sustained, it must be under the third category as a regulation of an activity that substantially affects interstate commerce. . . .
Section 922(q) is a criminal statute that by its terms has nothing to do with "commerce" or any sort of economic enterprise, however broadly one might define those terms. Section 922(q) is not an essential part of a larger regulation of economic activity, in which the regulatory scheme could be undercut unless the intrastate activity were regulated. It cannot, therefore, be sustained under our cases upholding regulations of activities that arise out of or are connected with a commercial transaction, which, viewed in the aggregate, substantially affects interstate commerce. . . .
The Government's essential contention, in fine, is that we may determine here that s922(q) is valid because possession of a firearm in a local school zone does indeed substantially affect interstate commerce. The Government argues that possession of a firearm in a school zone may result in violent crime and that violent crime can be expected to affect the functioning of the national economy in two ways. First, the costs of violent crime are substantial, and, through the mechanism of insurance, those costs are spread throughout the population. Second, violent crime reduces the willingness of individuals to travel to areas within the country that are perceived to be unsafe. The Government also argues that the presence of guns in schools poses a substantial threat to the educational process by threatening the learning environment. A handicapped educational process, in turn, will result in a less productive citizenry. That, in turn, would have an adverse effect on the Nation's economic well-being. As a result, the Government argues that Congress could rationally have concluded that s922(q) substantially affects interstate commerce.
We pause to consider the implications. . . . The Government admits, under its "costs of crime" reasoning, that Congress could regulate not only all violent crime, but all activities that might lead to violent crime, regardless of how tenuously they relate to interstate commerce. Similarly, under the Government's "national productivity" reasoning, Congress could regulate any activity that it found was related to the economic productivity of individual citizens: family law (including marriage, divorce, and child custody), for example. Under the theories that the Government presents in support of s922(q), it is difficult to perceive any limitation on Federal power, even in areas such as criminal law enforcement or education where States historically have been sovereign. Thus, if we were to accept the Government's arguments, we are hard-pressed to posit any activity by an individual that Congress is without power to regulate.
For instance, if Congress can, pursuant to its Commerce Clause power, regulate activities that adversely affect the learning environment, then, a fortiori, it also can regulate the educational process directly. Congress could determine that a school's curriculum has a "significant" effect on the extent of classroom learning. As a result, Congress could mandate a Federal curriculum for local elementary and secondary schools because what is taught in local schools has a significant "effect on classroom learning," cf. post, at 9, and that, in turn, has a substantial effect on interstate commerce. . . .
We do not doubt that Congress has authority under the Commerce Clause to regulate numerous commercial activities that substantially affect interstate commerce and also affect the educational process. That authority, though broad, does not include the authority to regulate each and every aspect of local schools. . . .
 
BY JUSTICE THOMAS,
Concurring

The Court today properly concludes that the Commerce Clause does not grant Congress the authority to prohibit gun possession within 1,000 feet of a school, as it attempted to do in the Gun-Free School Zones Act of 1990, Pub. L. 101-647, 104 Stat. 4844. Although I join the majority, I write separately to observe that our case law has drifted far from the original understanding of the Commerce Clause. In a future case, we ought to temper our Commerce Clause jurisprudence in a manner that both makes sense of our more recent case law and is more faithful to the original understanding of that Clause.
 
FROM THE DISSENT
By Justice Breyer
 The issue in this case is whether the Commerce Clause authorizes Congress to enact a statute that makes it a crime to possess a gun in, or near, a school. In my view, the statute falls well within the scope of the commerce power as this Court has understood that power over the last half-century. . . .
The Constitution requires us to judge the connection between a regulated activity and interstate commerce, not directly, but at one remove. Courts must give Congress a degree of leeway in determining the existence of a significant factual connection between the regulated activity and interstate commerce both because the Constitution delegates the commerce power directly to Congress and because the determination requires an empirical judgment of a kind that a legislature is more likely than a court to make with accuracy. The traditional words "rational basis" capture this leeway. Thus, the specific question before us, as the Court recognizes, is not whether the "regulated activity sufficiently affected interstate commerce," but, rather, whether Congress could have had "a rational basis" for so concluding. . . .
Applying these principles to the case at hand, we must ask whether Congress could have had a rational basis for finding a significant (or substantial) connection between gun-related school violence and interstate commerce. Or, to put the question in the language of the explicit finding that Congress made when it amended this law in 1994: Could Congress rationally have found that "violent crime in school zones," through its effect on the "quality of education," significantly (or substantially) affects "interstate" or "foreign commerce"? As long as one views the commerce connection not as a "technical legal conception" but as "a practical one," Swift & Co. v. United States, the answer to this question must be yes. Numerous reports and studies generated both inside and outside government make clear that Congress could reasonably have found the empirical connection that its law, implicitly or explicitly, asserts.
Having found that guns in schools significantly undermine the quality of education in our Nation's classrooms, Congress could also have found, given the effect of education upon interstate and foreign commerce, that gun-related violence in and around schools is a commercial, as well as a human, problem. Education, although far more than a matter of economics, has long been inextricably intertwined with the Nation's economy. . . .
Specifically, Congress could have found that gun-related violence near the classroom poses a serious economic threat (1) to consequently inadequately educated workers who must endure low paying jobs, see, and (2) to communities and businesses that might (in today's "information society") otherwise gain, from a well-educated work force, an important commercial advantage, of a kind that location near a railhead or harbor provided in the past. Congress might also have found these threats to be no different in kind from other threats that this Court has found within the commerce power, such as the threat that loan sharking poses to the "funds" of "numerous localities," Perez v. United States, and that unfair labor practices pose to instrumentalities of commerce, see Consolidated Edison Co. v. NLRB.
To hold this statute constitutional is not to "obliterate" the "distinction of what is national and what is local," ante; nor is it to hold that the Commerce Clause permits the Federal Government to "regulate any activity that it found was related to the economic productivity of individual citizens," to regulate "marriage, divorce, and child custody," or to regulate any and all aspects of education. Ante.
In sum, a holding that the particular statute before us falls within the commerce power would not expand the scope of that Clause. Rather, it simply would apply pre-existing law to changing economic circumstances.
 
BY JUSTICE SOUTER,
Dissenting
 The practice of deferring to rationally based legislative judgments "is a paradigm of judicial restraint." In judicial review under the Commerce Clause, it reflects our respect for the institutional competence of the Congress on a subject expressly assigned to it by the Constitution and our appreciation of the legitimacy that comes from Congress's political accountability in dealing with matters open to a wide range of possible choices. . . .
The modern respect for the competence and primacy of Congress in matters affecting commerce developed only after one of this Court's most chastening experiences, when it perforce repudiated an earlier and untenably expansive conception of judicial review in derogation of Congressional commerce power. A look at history's sequence will serve to show how today's decision tugs the Court off course, leading it to suggest opportunities for further developments that would be at odds with the rule of restraint to which the Court still wisely states adherence. . . .
Thus, it seems fair to ask whether the step taken by the Court today does anything but portend a return to the untenable jurisprudence from which the Court extricated itself almost 60 years ago. The answer is not reassuring. . . .
The question for the courts, as all agree, is not whether as a predicate to legislation Congress in fact found that a particular activity substantially affects interstate commerce. The legislation implies such a finding, and there is no reason to entertain claims that Congress acted ultra vires intentionally. Nor is the question whether Congress was correct in so finding. The only question is whether the legislative judgment is within the realm of reason. . . .
Because JUSTICE BREYER'S opinion demonstrates beyond any doubt that the Act in question passes the rationality review that the Court continues to espouse, today's decision may be seen as only a misstep, its reasoning and its suggestions not quite in gear with the prevailing standard, but hardly an epochal case. I would not argue otherwise, but I would raise a caveat. Not every epochal case has come in epochal trappings.

HEADLINE: Mystery Bomber Sent Taunting Letter to Victim at Yale, F.B.I. Says

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 26

 BODY:
Federal officials today released the text of a letter in which the mysterious serial bomber in the Unabom case ridicules one of his victims for opening the package that exploded and maimed him.
The letter was sent to David J. Gelernter, a prominent computer science professor at Yale University who was injured when a bomb went off in his hands in June 1993. The package-bomb blinded Dr. Gelernter in one eye, tore off part of his right hand, deafened him in one ear and wounded him in the chest. 
 "People with advanced degrees aren't as smart as they think they are," taunted the writer, who is also a suspect in a fatal package-bomb explosion in Sacramento on Monday. "If you'd had any brains you would have realized that there are a lot of people out there who resent bitterly the way techno-nerds like you are changing the world and you wouldn't have been dumb enough to open an unexpected package from an unknown source."
The rambling three-paragraph letter, which was postmarked Oakland, Calif., April 20, went on to criticize Dr. Gelernter's 1991 book, "Mirror Worlds" for asserting that the advance of computerization is inevitable. The letter used the Federal Bureau of Investigation's headquarters in Washington as its return address.
"In the epilog of your book," the letter said, "you tried to justify your research by claiming that the developments you describe are inevitable, and that any college person can learn enough about computers to compete in a computer-dominated world.
"Apparently people without a college degree don't count," the letter continued. "In any case, being informed about computers won't enable anyone to prevent invasion of privacy (through computers), genetic engineering (to which computers make an important contribution), environmental degradation through excessive economic growth (computers make an important contribution to economic growth) and so forth."
Law-enforcement officials have long believed that the bomber, whose targets over the last 17 years have mostly been involved with computer science, was violently opposed to changes in society brought about by computer technology. But until now, their intuition about motives were based almost wholly on circumstantial evidence.
In a letter to The New York Times this week, the bomber said that he was "out to get" scientists in the computer and genetics fields and that his immediate goal was the "destruction of the worldwide industrial system."
The letter sent to Dr. Gelernter makes a similar point. "If the developments you describe are inevitable, they are not inevitable in the way that old age or bad weather are inevitable," the letter said. "They are inevitable only because techno-nerds like you make them inevitable. If there were no computer scientists there would be no progress in computer science."
The F.B.I. said today that in addition to the letters received by The Times and Dr. Gelernter, two other letters had been sent, but it refused to reveal their recipients or contents.
The F.B.I. said all four letters were mailed on April 20 from the Oakland, Calif., area.
Although the writer used the first person plural in his letter to The Times, Special Agent Jim R. Freeman, head of the F.B.I. office here, said, "We don't have a shred of evidence that he is connected with other people in the placing of the bombs."
Dr. Gelernter's book, "Mirror Worlds. Or the Day Software Puts the Universe in a Shoebox. How it Will Happen and What It Will Mean." (Oxford University Press), describes a vision of the future in which interconnected computers will permit people to model and simulate the physical and social world extensively irrespective of whether some people dread becoming too dependent on their computers.
Dr. Gelernter has been a seminal thinker in a field known as parallel, or distributed, computer processing. which employs tens, hundreds or even thousands of processors or separate computers simultaneously to greatly speed computing times.
On Monday, a package that the F.B.I. says was mailed by the mysterious bomber killed Gilbert B. Murray, president and chief lobbyist of the California Forestry Association, a timber industry trade group. It was the second Unabom fatality in five months and the third since the bombings began in 1978. Twenty-two others have been wounded.
Authorities have been concerned because with each attack, "the devices have become more destructive, without increasing in size," Mr. Freeman said.

HEADLINE: Women's Work: What's New, What Isn't

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS 

 BODY:
Yesterday was National Secretaries Day. Today is Take Our Daughters to Work Day. Many women are celebrating both.
Fully one in five of all working women holds a secretarial or clerical job, a proportion that has remained largely unchanged since 1950. At the same time, women now constitute a majority of workers in a wide range of occupations long male-dominated, including psychologist, accountant, journalist, bus driver, bartender, and insurance or real estate agent. 
 They also make up the majority of public officials and administrators. One of them, Karen Nussbaum, director of the Women's Bureau of Labor at the United States Labor Department, recalls that after graduating from college she began her working career as a secretary at Harvard University and as a waitress.
"In my generation," the 45-year-old Ms. Nussbaum said, "there wasn't a woman who did not start as a secretary or a waitress, and I did both. If you wanted to sell insurance, you went in as a secretary. There was no other point of entry.
"Ten years ago two younger women, right out of college, were in front of me on a plane talking about sales. And I realized, this is different, mostly due to affirmative action and the women's movement and a difference in large part, too, by education and family income. So that a whole group found themselves not starting out as clerical workers."
But, she noted, "you still find a very large group of women in clerical and low-wage service work, and 75 percent of working women still earn less than $25,000" a year.
Even within those job categories in which women now outnumber men, they generally still lag in wages.
A computer analysis of census results conducted for The New York Times by Dr. Andrew A. Beveridge, director of the Program for Applied Research at Queens College, found profound and, in some cases, surprising shifts in the work force during the last 50 years.
In 1940, when fewer than 1 in 4 workers was a woman, about 1 in 6 working women was employed in a manufacturing job, usually as a machine operator. One in 8 was a domestic worker then, a proportion that by 1950 had plunged to about 1 in 15. Now, according to the census figures, fewer than 1 in 100 working women is employed as private household help.
Not until 1980, though, did manufacturing slip to second place as an employer of women, behind secretarial and clerking work, which each accounted for more than 1 in 10 female workers. By 1990, when women constituted more than half the work force, manufacturing had dropped to fourth, behind clerks, secretaries, and the combined category of managerial and office workers.
About 1 in 20 female workers is a schoolteacher, a proportion that has remained fairly constant since 1940.
Given the numbers, some jobs seem still very much women's work. Women account for 98 percent of secretaries, more than 9 of 10 professional nurses, bookkeepers, bank tellers and housekeepers, and more than 8 of 10 waiters, librarians, cashiers and telephone operators, but fewer than 1 of 50 carpenters or automobile mechanics.
The most dramatic changes in the work force during the last half-century coincided with pronounced educational gains by women and the shifts that the women's movement helped produce in employers' hiring goals and policies.
By 1990, women accounted for 44 percent of all economists, up from 14 percent 20 years earlier; for 27 percent of lawyers and judges, from 6 percent; for 38 percent of pharmacists, from 16 percent; for 22 percent of doctors, from 11 percent, and for 30 percent of stockbrokers, from 13 percent.
During that same two-decade period, women roughly doubled their proportion among public officials and administrators, bartenders, designers and advertising or insurance agents.
But for a variety of reasons -- including tenure that is generally shorter than that of their male counterparts, their tendency to do more part-time work, and discrimination -- women generally still earn less than men within a given job category.
Among psychologists, for example, the median salary income recorded in 1990 was $31,000 for men and $22,000 for women. Even among psychologists under the age of 35 -- a group in which men and women are more likely to have comparable experience -- the median for men ($19,000) surpassed that for women ($17,000). Among young economists, the median for men was $30,000, for women $24,000. Among young telephone operators, men's median was $11,000, women's $10,000.
When all men and women are compared, regardless of age, the disparities are much greater.
"There've been breakthroughs in non-traditional areas," said Marie C. Wilson, president of the Ms. Foundation for Women, which sponsors the annual Take Our Daughters to Work Day. "But historically, when women start to dominate the field, the pay goes down and the prestige will go down" -- in particular, she said, where many of those women are nonwhite.
Women in 1990 earned more than men -- and just slightly -- in only a few job categories, including bank tellers, secretaries and assistant librarians.
In a number of categories within the under-35 group, though, women account for a higher proportion of workers than they do among the all-age work force. This suggests that in the 1990's they will continue to make inroads in many male-dominated fields and that some jobs may become less subject to stereotyping by sex.
Among workers under age 35, women now account for fully 1 in 3 doctors, 4 in 10 mail carriers and a majority of purchasing agents. Further, nearly 1 in 10 nurses and nearly 2 in 10 telephone operators among this younger group are now men.

GRAPHIC: Table: "Changing Times" lists the proportion of jobs filled by women, of all jobs in given occupations. (Source: Program for Applied Research, Queens College)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexico Eager to Celebrate End to Crisis Despite Hardships

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, April 26

 BODY:
It may be too early to celebrate, but Mexican officials lately have turned optimistic when they talk about an end to the country's current economic crisis, even as the hardships of the Mexican people are increasing sharply.
A beefed-up peso and a stock exchange that has come back from the dead are just two of the signs officials cite to show that the Government's austere economic recovery plan is working. 
 But it is clear that as Mexico's economic picture brightens, the level of misery for individual Mexicans increases almost in step. Unemployment and inflation are both exceeding the Government's projections, and interest rates on loans have remained punishingly high. Now, most investors and financial analysts, already burned by overly optimistic Government projections, say it is far too early to tell whether the worst is over.
"There are two faces to this crisis," said Luis Pazos, a Mexican economist who is often critical of the Government. "The fact that the Government has implemented the recovery program has brought back the confidence of many international investors. But the first impact of the program here has been to impoverish the people."
The chief spokesman for the Government's recovery program, Alejandro Valenzuela, said today that there was no escaping the pain caused by the attempt to undo Mexico's worst economic crisis in a decade. But, he said, "the indicators speak for themselves."
Since March 9, when the Government's latest austerity plan was announced, the peso has regained slightly more than one-quarter of its value, and it was expected to become stronger after the Chicago Mercantile Exchange began offering peso futures contracts on Tuesday. Today the peso-dollar exchange rate was 5.795, down from 7.45 pesos to the dollar in early March.
The Mexican stock market has risen more than 65 percent since March 9 to surpass the 2,000 level, closing at 2,006.98 today. The recovery was at first driven by local investors. Later some adventurous foreign investors jumped in. Some first-quarter earnings, like those of Banamex and Bancomer, two of the largest banks in Mexico, have been surprisingly strong, in part because they were better than what had been expected.
Last month Mexico's nonpetroleum exports grew by nearly 29 percent, while imports -- most used to come from the United States -- declined by 3.4 percent. The Mexican Congress is considering bills to encourage private investment by allowing competition in long-distance telephone service, communication satellites, natural gas distribution and Mexico's outdated railroad system.
"Things seem to have taken a turn for the better far more quickly than anyone thought on March 9," said Ricardo Peon, head of research at Barings Securities in Mexico City. "Mexico is on the right track, but it's not there yet."
What concerns investors are unresolved issues like the stability of Mexico's banking system, the depth of the recession that the Government deliberately caused with its recovery plan and the danger that if the peso strengthens too much too soon, it will make products more costly and pull the rug out from under Mexico's export-driven recovery.
Shadowing the signs of recovery are the rising social costs of the Government's economic plan and the tremendous hardships that the Mexican people are forced to bear.
In January and February 750,000 people lost their jobs because of the crisis, according to Government figures, equaling what officials had expected to see by the end of June. Many private economists say the real figure is far higher. Interest rates for mortgages, car loans and credit cards remain higher than 80 percent.
In addition, the increase in the national value-added sales tax on April 1 to 15 percent, from 10 percent, is already pushing up inflation, which the central bank reported to be 5 percent in the first two weeks of this month. The figures indicate that inflation will exceed the Government's official annual estimate of 42 percent.
So far, Mexicans have taken the hardship in stride. Even when the officially established price of tortillas increased by about 25 percent earlier this month, there was no street violence.
"President Zedillo made a calculated bet that the Mexican populace will remain docile as it has for decades," said Lawrence D. Krohn, senior economist for Latin America at UBS Securities Inc. in New York. "But just because the country hasn't come apart at this point certainly doesn't mean that it won't six months from now."

HEADLINE: Dow Edges Lower, but Nasdaq Climbs to Record

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks edged lower yesterday as Wall Street worried about the dollar, but gains in technology stocks lifted the Nasdaq index to a record.
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.34 of a point, to 4,299.83, on renewed concerns about the dollar after finance ministers from the Group of Seven industrialized nations gave only verbal support for the ailing currency. 
 In the broader market, advancing issues led declines 1,160 to 1,075 in active trading of more than 350 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Nasdaq index climbed to a record on the strength of technology stocks. It rose 5.63 points, to 836.91, eclipsing the old high of 832.64, set April 13.
"There were big upticks in some of the big institutional names, and the weighting they have took the average to a new high on big volume," said Bob Antolini at Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette.
The Toshiba Corporation of Japan said it was negotiating with customers to raise the prices of memory chips, and that gave impetus to the technology issues. Intel shares climbed 1 3/8, to 99 5/8, a closing high, on optimism over demand for its Pentium chip; Apple Computer gained 1/2, to 38 1/4, and Sun Microsystems gained 1 7/8, closing at 39 1/2.
I.B.M., which reported last week that its first-quarter earnings had nearly quadrupled, led the Dow industrials, gaining 1 5/8, to 95 1/4. Other blue-chips, however, treaded water for the second straight session after surging 34 points Monday, to a record high of 4,303.98.
"We don't really have any motivation for either the bulls or the bears to get crazy at this point," said David Holt, director of technical research at Wedbush Morgan.
Analysts said the focus was again on the dollar after G-7 ministers threw their verbal support behind the battered currency but failed to come up with concrete measures at their Washington meeting.
The ministers said the dollar's recent slide to a record low of less than 80 Japanese yen was not justified by the performance of their economies and called for an "orderly reversal" of the decline.
The dollar was mixed in American trading yesterday, rising against the yen but losing ground against the German mark.
Philip Orlando, senior vice president at First Capital Advisers, said the dollar could be the key to the next movement of stocks. If it again slides below the 80-yen level in coming weeks, the Federal Reserve may be forced to raise interest rates at its May 23 policy-making meeting, he said. "The catalyst initiating a consolidation of some magnitude is going to be currency," he added.
A rate increase would revive concerns of an economic slowdown and lower corporate profits and could lead to a correction of up to 400 points in the Dow index, he said.
Chrysler's stock fell 2 1/2, to 41 5/8, on speculation that Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire investor, would not be able to raise the financing necessary for his $22.8 billion takeover bid.
Reader's Digest tumbled 7 7/8, to 39 7/8, after it warned Wall Street of a slowdown in earnings growth in fiscal 1995 and 1996, citing increased paper costs.
Glenayre Technologies shot up 6 1/2, to 57, after its quarterly earnings came in well ahead of analysts' expectations.
U.S. Robotics rallied 10 1/4, to 79, after its strong quarterly earnings prompted analysts to raise their profit forecasts.
American Mobile Systems gained 311/16 to 87/16 on news it was being bought by Nextel Communications in a stock swap valued at $65 million. Nextel slipped 1/8, to 15 1/2.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 0.51, to 512.66. The American Stock Exchange index edged up 0.27, to 473.86.
The N.Y.S.E. Composite index of all listed common stocks rose 0.10 to 276.49. The average share was up 1 cent.
The Wilshire Associates equity index -- the market value of N.Y.S.E., American and Nasdaq issues -- was at a new high of 5,015.271 up 6.886 or 0.14 percent.
