HEADLINE: Bias Hits Hispanic Workers

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO

 BODY:
Efrain Castillo, a 43-year-old truck driver, was forced to quit his job in mid-March after Mexico's economic crisis hit border-area businesses and left him idle two or three days each week. "There's just no work," he lamented, looking up from job-search forms at the state's cavernous downtown unemployment office on Front Street.
But Mr. Castillo, who came to the United States from Mexico in the early 1970's, is not just one American citizen whose livelihood happened to depend on the Mexican economy. He is a member of a growing Hispanic labor force that is losing ground in this country's increasingly competitive job market. 
 Many Hispanic workers are held back by outmoded skills, job inexperience and weaker education credentials. But these days they are also finding themselves increasingly subject to intense suspicion, resentment and, in many cases, outright discrimination.
"They ask you for your Social Security number, your alien card," Mr. Castillo said, and added that he was never previously aware of such scrutiny. And his wife, who is undocumented, can no longer work at all. "A few years ago she could, but not now," Mr. Castillo said. "It's almost impossible."
Here, in the city with the nation's highest unemployment rate among Hispanic people, almost any conversation highlights how job prospects for Hispanic people -- particularly lower-income entry-level workers -- are shrinking. But Government statistics make it clear that this is a nationwide phenomenon as well. During the last few years, even as the overall unemployment rate has shrunk substantially, joblessness among the 12 million Hispanic workers in the civilian labor force has barely budged. In particular, it has worsened relative to that of blacks, a group often in competition for lower-echelon jobs. In January, the Hispanic unemployment rate briefly jumped to 10.2 percent, matching the black jobless rate for the first time in the two decades for which detailed records about ethnic groups have been kept.
In California, home to about one-third of the country's Hispanic population, the Hispanic unemployment rate actually exceeded that of blacks, 11.2 percent to 11 percent, for the three-month period through January.
Hispanic workers have also lost ground compared with non-Hispanic whites. Until about five years ago, joblessness among Hispanic workers typically averaged about one and a half times the rate for whites. But today Hispanic people are nearly twice as likely as whites to be unemployed.
"We are quite concerned about this," said Charles Kamasaki, senior vice president of the National Council of La Raza, the largest Hispanic advocacy group. "This could be some sort of sea change."
Despite the great prominence given recently to stepped-up efforts to police the nation's borders, illegal immigrants appear to be an insignificant factor in the widening gap between Hispanic joblessness and that of other Americans, according to various experts. They say that undocumented workers, often toiling desperately in private or "off the books" jobs, generally avoid being tallied by the Government.
Rather, the official job-market distress is concentrated among native-born Hispanic people and legal immigrants, involving dispiriting economic and social forces that are not likely to be quickly reversed. The figures also point to a rise in anti-Hispanic discrimination in hiring that is perhaps best exemplified by Proposition 187, the contentious but highly popular measure approved by California voters in November. Among other things, that initiative is aimed at denying welfare and other government benefits to immigrants lacking proper credentials.
"There's no doubt that discrimination has increased against Latinos," said Juan Vargas, Deputy Mayor of San Diego and the first Hispanic member of its City Council. "Proposition 187 has created almost a crisis in the Latino community. It has employers panicked."
Some elements of Proposition 187 have been challenged as unconstitutional but its passage, according to Mr. Vargas and others, has helped chill public opinion toward Hispanic people and made employers even more wary of hiring them.
Other forces are at work as well. Mexican-Americans, for example, had been quite successful in obtaining industrial and military-related jobs in the Midwest and Southern California. But under the common pattern of "last hired, first fired," they have made up a disproportionate number of the casualties in recent years as these businesses slimmed down to cut labor costs or in response to military cutbacks.
"When you downsize these labor markets, Hispanics get hit very hard," said Rodolfo de la Garza, a professor of government at the University of Texas and vice president of the Tomas Rivera Center, a Hispanic research organization. This reflects relatively low seniority and a lack of job alternatives because of obsolescent skills.
Traditionally, Mexican mechanics learned to fix fenders, hammering them back in shape with ball peen hammers, Professor de la Garza said. "But you don't fix fenders any more, you replace fenders," he said.
Idled military-plant workers have sometimes displaced Hispanic workers on the lower rungs of the economic ladder, taking work as waiters, cab drivers or on construction jobs.
And while the educational attainment of Hispanic people has improved, their schooling still lags well behind that of blacks and whites and is improving at a slower pace than that of blacks, according to La Raza, the advocacy group.
Yet another factor is what Irma Castro, former executive director of the Chicano Federation, calls the "younging" of the Hispanic community. That includes Mexican-Americans in the Southwest, Puerto Ricans in New York and a newer wave of arrivals from Central and South America who have spread themselves more or less equally to various regions of the country, with a concentration in Washington. Cubans, mainly in Florida, tend to be older, better educated and more prosperous than other Hispanic people.
"As our numbers grow, the average age drops," with the median age for Hispanics now barely over 26, almost eight years younger than for non-Hispanics, Ms. Castro said. "Traditionally, the Hispanic worker has been underemployed and underutilized," she added. "And now these younger workers are coming into the labor force with very little skills" and, especially among children of immigrants, often with a lesser work ethic as well. Across all ethnic groups, unemployment among younger workers tends to be much higher than the rate among older adults.
Another factor that is difficult to measure is the impact of the late 1980's amnesty for many undocumented workers who were long resident in the United States. That brought many Hispanic people out of the underground economy into the official work force. And because the Hispanic population tends to be concentrated in places like California and New York, which were particularly hard hit by the economic downturn of the early 1990's, the vulnerability to job losses now shows up more prominently in Government figures.
For all that, it is clear that joblessness rose more sharply for Hispanic people than for non-Hispanic people during the 1990-91 recession and, particularly related to blacks, has worsened since. Puerto Ricans suffered most from the recession because of their concentration in the hard-hit Northeast, according to Peter Cattan, an economist with the the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Even backbreaking field work, often the first stop for recent immigrants and disdained by many non-Hispanic people, is proving increasingly trying, according to Claudia E. Smith of California Rural Legal Assistance. "During peak season, what I'm seeing is underemployment," she said. "And the jobs go to the younger, more strapping ones -- it's become that kind of a meat market."
Still, after allowing for the various economic and social forces, many Hispanic people and others have reluctantly concluded that discrimination may be the biggest single reason for the deterioration of Hispanic work life.
In this they concur with findings of the General Accounting Office, the Congressional research organization, which studied the consequences of the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986, which barred employers from knowingly hiring ineligible workers.
The G.A.O., in a 1990 report, found "widespread discrimination," with 19 percent of employers acknowledging one or more illegal practices as a result of the 1986 law.
"We don't like to talk about it because we don't like to look like we're complaining," Ms. Castro said, lamenting what she said was widespread discrimination reflected in the vote in Proposition 187. "But I think it's just rampant."
And the current economic crisis in Mexico can only make things worse, specialists say, with a sharp rise in immigration -- much of it illegal -- expected to begin in coming months.
"What may well be happening," Mr. Kamasaki contended, "is increased labor market discrimination because people think all Latino applicants are immigrants."

HEADLINE: State's Hospital Bill Surcharges Upheld

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 26

 BODY:
The United States Supreme Court today upheld New York State's practice of raising revenues by tacking surcharges onto hospital bills, saving the state's health financing system from potential collapse.
Several states use similar surcharges or taxes to help pay for indigent health care, to boost hospital revenues and even to close state budget gaps, as New York did in 1992. The primary principle behind the practice -- subsidizing health care for the indigent by taxing hospital payments by the insured -- was at the center of the debate over Federal health care legislation in 1993 and 1994. 
 The precedent provided by today's unanimous ruling, which reversed a series of lower court decisions, would seem to give states broad powers to set hospital rates and maintain the status quo. In the near term, that is likely to allow governors to save hundreds of millions of dollars and avoid some tax increases.
In Connecticut, for instance, Gov. John G. Rowland expects to gain $150 million that he had not anticipated receiving if the surcharge system had been struck down. He may also now avoid a divisive debate over an alternative tax on hospital revenues that he had proposed to compensate for any lost income.
In New York, an adverse ruling would not have cost the state anything this year because the state won a temporary reprieve from Congress last month in the form of a special waiver. But it would have cost the state's hospitals $200 million this year and the state $60 million next year, according to the State Health Commissioner, Barbara A. DeBuono.
More significantly, a different ruling could have cost the state more than $1 billion a year if the ruling were later applied to a surcharge that is used to compensate New York hospitals for care provided to indigent patients. That surcharge, which averages 5.5 percent, was not directly at issue in the case decided by the Supreme Court.
Aides to Gov. George E. Pataki said Mr. Pataki may ultimately support deregulation of health care rates. But they rejoiced today that the courts would not force him to do so on a timetable that could cost the state huge sums when it could least afford it.
With the fiscal year now 26 days old, Mr. Pataki is still negotiating with the Legislature over his plan to close a budget gap of more than $4 billion and to provide $720 million in tax cuts.
The ruling stemmed from a lawsuit, known originally as Travelers vs. Cuomo, in which insurance companies maintained that the surcharges violated the Federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act. The plaintiffs argued that the 1974 E.R.I.S.A. prohibits states from passing laws that affect employee benefit plans, including health insurance plans that are made more costly by hospital surcharges.
But Justice David Souter wrote that the surcharges, because they affect all commercial insurance plans in the same way, did not have a direct effect on the way those plans operate or compete against each other.
"Any conclusion other than the one drawn here would have the unsettling result of barring any state regulation of hospital costs on the theory that all laws with indirect economic effects on E.R.I.S.A. plans are pre-empted," Justice Souter wrote.
Pataki administration officials said the ruling will give them breathing room to determine how they want to redesign New York's huge and highly regulated medical system.
Dr. DeBuono said she wants to study the possibility of reducing the state's power to set hospital rates, although she said she has not yet decided that she favors such deregulation. The looming loss of billions of dollars in health care revenues would have made a comprehensive study impossible, she said.
"I am pleased that this landmark Supreme Court decision will avoid disruption to the health care community and allow New York the time to undertake an orderly evaluation of the state's current hospital financing system," Dr. DeBuono said. "The decision also maintains New York State's flexibility in redesigning a reimbursement system to achieve our objectives of expanding access to high quality medical services at an affordable cost."
Hospital industry officials said a different ruling would have been catastrophic.
"If they had ruled against us, the system probably would have collapsed," said Daniel Sisto, president of the Healthcare Association of New York State, which represents hospitals and nursing homes.
Kenneth Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, said, "It would have been either meltdown of the health care system or an enormous amount of debt absorbed by the state overnight."
The ruling also maintains New York's policy of providing a competitive pricing advantage to Blue Cross and Blue Shield insurance plans by exempting their policyholders from the surcharges.
The state provides that advantage because the not-for-profit Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans accept all paying applicants for health insurance; they provide coverage for many New Yorkers who might not be accepted by for-profit commercial insurers.
Health insurance executives said today the decision would harm patients by allowing states to continue to impose higher hospital rates on commercial health insurers. Those increases typically are then passed along to policyholders through higher premiums.
"What this decision really means is that New York's consumers and employers who purchase insurance are going to pay more," said Bill Gradison, president of the Health Insurance Association of America. "In effect, they are being asked to subsidize the Blues."
The Travelers lawsuit challenged three separate surcharges on health care payments that New York has imposed over the years.
The largest, enacted in 1988, is a 13 percent surcharge on hospital bills that is paid only by commercial insurers and self-insurance plans. The surcharge provides a competitive advantage for Blue Cross plans, and hospitals keep the $200 million generated each year.
In 1992, the state added another 11 percent to the surcharge on hospitals for one year. The hospitals were required to pass the revenues along to the state, producing about $60 million to help close a budget gap.
Also in 1992, the state imposed a 9 percent surcharge on health maintenance organizations, which was designed both to close the state budget gap and to encourage the H.M.O.'s to enroll Medicaid recipients. By meeting targets for enrolling Medicaid recipients, health maintenance organizations could avoid the charges.

HEADLINE: East Harlem Pathmark Plan Appears Headed for Defeat

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
A plan to build a big supermarket in one of Manhattan's most economically depressed communities appeared headed for defeat yesterday as members of the Manhattan Borough Board prepared to vote this morning on the $12 million project.
Opponents of the 53,000-square-foot Pathmark supermarket planned for East Harlem, who fear that the store will hurt local bodega owners, said they had the necessary votes to block the sale of a vacant, city-owned lot on 125th Street where the store would be built. And telephone calls to the board's members confirmed that unless 11th-hour negotiations were successful, the plan would be killed. 
 "The votes are cast," said City Councilman Antonio Pagan, who opposes the project. "Pathmark will not be built."
Yesterday afternoon, in a last-minute effort to change the outcome of the vote, Pathmark officials said they would contribute additional economic development money to community groups in East Harlem, and the project's developers offered to provide technical assistance to minority businesses and entrepreneurs in the neighborhood.
But opponents said the offer was too little and too late.
The project, which is planned for 125th Street and Third Avenue, has evolved in recent weeks into a clash of politics, race and business.
Opponents -- many of them Hispanic residents and merchants of East Harlem -- have argued that the giant store will endanger the more than 200 bodegas and small grocery stores that already operate in the area.
Black residents of Harlem have been more supportive, arguing that the project will bring 200 jobs and finally give minority residents of upper Manhattan the wider selection and lower prices that giant supermarkets have long offered in wealthier neighborhoods.
Because the project's developers, a consortium of nonprofit groups known as the East Harlem Abyssinian Triangle, will receive $1.1 million in Federal and state grants, a low-interest mortgage loan, as well as tax abatements, opponents also charge that Pathmark is receiving an unfair competitive advantage.
"We are opposed to the size of it and to all of the government subsidies given to it," said Councilman Adam Clayton Powell 4th, who collected 5,000 signatures from East Harlem residents who don't want the supermarket. "We would not oppose it if they came in with their own money."
Members of the Manhattan Borough Board, which consists of Manhattan's 10 City Council members, Borough President Ruth W. Messinger, and the chairman of the affected community board, are scheduled to vote this morning on whether to approve the sale of the land to the developers.
In addition to Mr. Pagan and Mr. Powell, Councilman Charles Millard said yesterday that he would vote against the store. Other council members said that Kathryn E. Freed, Andrew Eristoff, and Guillermo Linares had stated their intent to vote against the project, but the three did not return calls seeking comment. Councilman Thomas K. Duane said he would not make a decision until this morning.
C. Virginia Fields and Ronnie M. Eldridge said they would vote in favor of the plan. In addition, Councilman Stanley Michaels and the chairman of Community Board 11, Eddie Baca, are expected to vote in favor. Ms. Messinger would vote only in the event of a tie.
Under the plan, the city would sell the land to the consortium for $1.5 million and provide the developers with a mortgage at one percent interest. The consortium would then apply to Chemical Bank for $8 million to build the store, and Pathmark would take out a 25-year lease on the property, paying the developers $1.06 million a year in rent. An additional $1.5 million is to come from a private investor group.
"This represents a perfect partnership between the public sector, the private sector, and a nonprofit group," said Joan McCleod, a project manager from Abyssinian Development Corporation, a member of the consortium.
To placate the opposition, Pathmark last night said it would contribute $25,000 per year, for a minimum of five years, to create an economic development fund for East Harlem. The Woodbridge, N.J.-based company said the funds would be held in escrow in an East Harlem bank and administered by a community-based organization. Also, Pathmark and the developers said they would "use their best efforts" to place East Harlem-based minority businesses in the additional 8,000 square feet of retail space planned for the site.
But the opponents were unmoved by the offer. "Some bread crumbs are being thrown at this community at the 11th hour," Mr. Powell said. "It's a desperate attempt to save something that's already dead."
For Ms. Messinger, who supports the supermarket, the outcome of the vote could have lingering political implications. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, whom Ms. Messinger might eventually challenge in a mayoral race, has uncharacteristically chosen to stay out of the argument over the supermarket.
In a news conference earlier this week, the Mayor said he wanted to let other political leaders "work it out, debate it, and come to a decision."
Both sides have asked the Mayor to intervene, but he said any decision he makes would anger one side or the other. "This is a sort of sucker invitation," Mr. Giuliani said. "I generally don't get involved in sucker invitations."
If the plan passes the borough board, however, Mr. Giuliani would have to rule later on proposed tax abatements for the project.
While opponents of the current plan said they would approve a smaller store built without Federal grants, officials of Pathmark said the grocery store chain would not renegotiate the terms of the project. "It's not going to change," Stan Sorkin, a company spokesman, said.
Mr. Sorkin said that after four years of negotiating with city officials to develop the East Harlem site, the company was "getting blindsided at the last minute. We're going to have to rethink where we want to spend our resources," he said.

HEADLINE: Cold Comfort From the Mayor

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani boasted last week that new screening procedures and work requirements had wrung thousands of fraudulent applicants out of Home Relief, the New York State program of cash assistance for poor residents who do not qualify for Federal welfare. One day later the Mayor proposed to eliminate the program entirely. But why abandon the truly needy, the only recipients who would presumably be left once fraud is vanquished?
The Mayor's answer is that the able-bodied poor need only assistance in finding jobs, not cash. As proof, the mayor's office points to three months' experience under the new program, during which the number of Home Relief applicants in New York City who found jobs soared almost 400 percent. But three months prove nothing. States that have already done what Mr. Giuliani proposes have seen quite different results. 
 Pennsylvania, Michigan and Ohio have recently cut back or eliminated their versions of Home Relief. Former recipients did not fare well. In Pennsylvania, less than 3 percent of recipients were steadily employed the year after benefits were cut back. In Michigan only about 20 percent were working two years after benefits were terminated. The results in Ohio were similar.
These cutbacks in Home Relief did not produce large increases in the homeless population. But the outcomes give little support to the cheerful notion that Home Relief recipients will easily find work. Most manage only to scrape by in the underground or illegal economy at the margins of civil existence. Mayor Giuliani is right to point out that Home Relief in New York is far more generous than anywhere else. Even so, a Home Relief recipient in New York City receives only about $350 a month -- not enough to cover a typical rent check.
A policy of requiring recipients to work, if need be at community service at minimum wages, could be a sensible way to help put dysfunctional adults back on their feet. But to threaten to cut off people who, through no fault of their own, cannot find work demeans New York's proud history of helping the destitute.

HEADLINE: Did Yale Impostor Really Earn B Grades?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The well-publicized story of Yale's expulsion of Lon Grammer, a transfer student who gained admission to Yale by allegedly falsifying documents, would by now have been forgotten were it not for this twist: Mr. Grammer is said to have achieved a 3.0 grade point average at Yale, as compared with the 2.1 he earned at little-known Cuesta College. Prof. Paul J. Korshin (letter, April 23) sees this as but another indication of declining standards in higher education. 
 Grade inflation is a serious matter, but what evidence exists to show Mr. Grammer had a B average at Yale? No Yale official is at liberty to make transcript information public. As far as I can tell, reports of Mr. Grammer's B average stem from assertions by Mr. Grammer or his legal representatives. None of the half-dozen reporters with whom I have spoken saw any official documentation.
I would urge Mr. Grammer to produce his Yale transcript for the press. If for some reason he should be unable to locate this document, my office will gladly furnish him a copy.
 
DONALD P. GREEN
Undergraduate Studies Director, Yale
New Haven, April 23, 1995

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasuries Mixed On Data for Durable Goods

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, after a Government report of an unexpected rise in durable goods orders for March led to some weakness in bond prices.
At the same time securities dealers were setting up for the Treasury's $11.5 billion five-year note auction yesterday, a normal preoccupation that often lowers prices because inventories are lightened to make room for new securities. 
 The price of the 30-year bond rose 2/32 , to 10323/32 , for a yield of 7.32 percent, unchanged from Tuesday, but shorter maturities were mixed.
The market's concern about the report on durable goods was that it showed the industrial sector was not slowing as much as had been suggested by other data, including the national purchasing managers' index last month. Some economists, however, discounted the durables report as an aberration.
The Commerce Department reported that orders for durable goods rose six-tenths of 1 percent, against forecasts for a decline of half a percent. Without transportation, the orders rose 1 percent, and gained four-tenths of 1 percent excluding military orders.
Analysts said the report jolted the long maturities, lowering prices from morning highs, which could make securities more attractive going into an auction.
Jack McIntyre, senior fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said the market "also used the five-year note auction as an excuse to sell intermediate maturities ahead of the auction."
Mr. McIntyre said the five-year Treasury note auction yesterday went well, with good demand from dealers and noncompetitive bids by small investors of about half the 12-month average of $830 million.
The high yield at the auction was 6.815 percent, down from 6.994 percent last month and the lowest yield since June 1994, when it was 6.77 percent. Today the Treasury plans to sell $17.75 billion of new 52-week bills, which were carrying a rate of 5.82 percent by late in the day.
Market participants said the rebound of the dollar after the meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations gave bonds only brief support, while short-covering by dealers helped to lift bonds more, particularly in the longer maturities. The easing of the prices of oil, gold and silver added relief to the bond market.
In the municipal bond market, prices fell as the prospect of changes in the Federal income tax code made some investors take a hard look at the benefits of tax-exempt securities.
On Tuesday Senator Pete Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, and Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, introduced the Unlimited Savings Allowance Tax Act, proposing that all personal savings be exempt from taxes and providing an 11 percent flat-rate business tax that permits a deduction for capital investments.
Analysts said a key feature of the Nunn-Domenici plan would allow an investor to deduct capital gains income from taxes if the gain was rolled into other stocks, bonds and savings accounts. The change would put other investments on nearly equal ground with municipal bonds if the proceeds were reinvested.
The average yield to first call for the Bond Buyer's index of 40 municipal issues rose 2 basis points, to 6.27 percent.
In the corporate bond market, in which the lack of new issues has sent some investors into the asset-backed securities market, Sears, Roebuck & Company sold $522 million of fixed-rate credit-card-backed securities yesterday in two parts through underwriters led by CS First Boston.
Sears sold the securities through a special trust formed for that particular offering, the Sears Credit Account Master Trust II 95-3. For $500 million of the securities, the average life is 5.06 years, with the interest rate set at 7 percent and priced at 9923/32 , to yield 7.171 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up Sharply Against Yen In Biggest Rally in 20 Months

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar staged its biggest one-day rally in 20 months against the Japanese yen yesterday, surging more than 2 percent after the United States and other leading industrial nations said the dollar's slide was not justified. It also stabilized against other currencies.
Finance ministers from the Group of Seven nations said late Tuesday that recent movements in the currency markets "have gone beyond levels justified by underlying economic conditions." 
 The group's statement called for an "orderly reversal" of the dollar's 16 percent slide against the yen so far this year and its nearly 12 percent drop against the German mark. Some traders said the statement hinted that more aggressive action might be coming in an effort to bolster the dollar.
"All the euphoria after the G-7 rhetoric has popped the dollar up," said Kevin Lawrie, foreign exchange manager at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. The Group of Seven consists of the United States, Germany, Japan, Britain, France, Canada and Italy.
The dollar rose as high as 84.40 yen in New York trading before retreating somewhat. It was quoted late yesterday at 83.80 yen, compared with 81.82 yen on Tuesday.
The dollar also traded as high as 1.3863 marks before settling at 1.3670 marks, little changed from 1.3699 marks on Tuesday.
The dollar's early gains against the mark were erased when investors bought marks and sold yen, traders said. To accomplish that, traders often buy dollars for yen, then sell those dollars for marks.
The British pound was also little changed at $1.62152, up from $1.6130.
The chorus of voices declaring that the dollar's fall has been overdone threw an element of caution into betting on further dollar declines. Adding to the caution, traders said, was a bout of dollar-buying by Japan's central bank in Asian trading.
"It makes you hesitate before hitting the sell button," said Joe Francomano, a foreign exchange trader at the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank in New York.
Still, the Group of Seven announced no concrete steps to help the dollar, leaving many traders wondering what further action, if any, the central banks would actually take.
"It's rhetoric, and not backed by action," Mr. Lawrie of Mellon said. "The market wants to see more before we really attack the upside on the dollar."
To bolster the dollar, the Group of Seven's central banks could make coordinated dollar purchases, which have served only to stabilize the dollar this year.
They could also adjust their interest rates, with further cuts by the Germans and Japanese being offset by an increase in American rates. But so far, the United States has shown little interest in raising rates to halt the rise of the yen and the mark.

HEADLINE: March Durable-Goods Orders Had an Unexpected Rebound

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
Led by the demand for computers and electronic equipment, orders to factories in the United States for interest-sensitive durable goods rebounded in March from their first decline in four months.
The Commerce Department said today that orders for expensive items expected to last at least three years climbed six-tenths of 1 percent last month, after falling a revised seven-tenths of 1 percent in February. The original report put that decline at eight-tenths of 1 percent. 
 Analysts had forecast a drop of half a percent in March and said the surprising recovery was a sign of business confidence and solid growth, despite other indications of weakness in the economy. They said they saw little cause to fear an inflationary boom.
"It's healthy growth, even better than expected," said Robert Eggert, who heads Eggert Economic Enterprises, a forecasting firm in Sedona, Ariz. "The personal computer market is hot as a pistol."
Financial markets, concerned that a surge in economic growth would lead to inflation and another round of increases in interest rates by the Federal Reserve, fell after the Government's report but then recovered.
Analysts said most signs pointed to a slowdown from the booming growth that closed out 1994 and predicted moderate economic expansion this year.
On Friday the Commerce Department is scheduled to provide its first broad look at the economy for the first quarter of 1995, when it announces the preliminary figures for gross domestic product.
"While interest rates have gone up, they have to be balanced against business prospects," said Charles Renfro, an economist at Alphametrics, a forecasting firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. "If prospects are good and the rates are only up moderately, there's no reason to cut back on investment. And, of course, the world economy is expanding."
He predicted that the gross domestic product for the first quarter this year would show a solid annual growth rate of 3.2 percent, compared with 5.1 percent for the last three months of 1994.
The Federal Reserve has raised a key short-term interest rate seven times since February 1994. Analysts had expected the orders for durable goods to decline in March, because the orders are usually affected by rising interest rates that make buying on credit more expensive.
The Commerce Department said the increase in orders was led by a rise of 6.1 percent in electronic and other electrical equipment. Industrial machinery and equipment rose 2.7 percent, after climbing 1.4 percent during the previous month and soaring 9.1 percent in January.
The orders for all durable goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $164.3 billion, up $1 billion from February. New orders for the first three months of this year were 3.4 percent higher than those in the fourth quarter of last year.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Disneyland and the old U.S.S.R.: Sharing something in common.

BYLINE: Peter Passell 

DATELINE: ANAHEIM, Calif.,

 BODY:
IT'S 3 o'clock on a sunny April afternoon, and tens of thousands of parents know exactly where their children are. Here at Disneyland, the line for Pirates of the Caribbean is an hour long. But that's nothing: Splash Mountain will set you back 90 minutes. And somewhere, deep in the bowels of Adventureland, 10-year-olds are hunkering down for the two and a half hour trial-by-boredom that precedes entry to Indiana Jones's Temple of the Forbidden Eye.
Nothing so graphically illustrates the organizational triumph of Disney as its ability to make people stand in line and like it. But wait. Didn't lines symbolize the bankruptcy of the Soviet system? Maybe Disneyomics has more in common with Soviet rationing than is first apparent. 
 Every veteran of Econ 101 understands the pitfalls of running an economy without the help of prices that reflect cost and value. In the Soviet Union, bread was cheap and easy to get. It was so cheap and easy that it was occasionally fed to pigs in lieu of grain.
By contrast, most consumer goods were deliberately rationed by waiting time. Thus everyone but party bigwigs and assorted heroes of socialism was forced into waiting lines for cars, apartments, video recorders, even good shoes. Nobody knew how many items to produce because nobody had a clue about their relative value.
So, why the comparison with Disney, that jewel in American capitalism's crown? Entry to Disneyland is by flat fee: $45 for adults, $35 for children plus $6 for parking. Thereafter, all rides are "free." The only attempt to use prices to match demand to supply is at the gate, where southern Californians and vacationers on package tours obtain discounts on off-peak days.
But Mickey and Donald are gentle commissars, specialists in minimizing the pain of waiting.
Waiting times are generally posted. Crowd control is friendly but firm, eliminating anxiety that the race will be won by the aggressive. If V.I.P.'s do manage to talk their way past the crowds, the proletariat never notices. And the really long queues are hidden inside buildings. "We try to create a total guest experience," explains John Dreyer, a spokesman for the Walt Disney Company.
But that still leaves a puzzle: Why doesn't Disney charge for individual rides according to their popularity, thereby reducing the waste inherent in queuing? Why, for that matter, asks Gary Becker, a Nobel laureate in economics at the University of Chicago, doesn't Disney price like museums and cable television systems? After all, they manage to charge a flat fee for access to the standard fare and then add on additional charges for premium entertainment.
Alternatively, why doesn't Disney offer its version of business class along with coach, charging, say, $100 to wait in separate (and presumably shorter) lines? Ski resorts manage this very discreetly, notes Walter Oi, an economist at the University of Rochester, by allowing skiers who buy lessons to cut into the lift lines.
One possibility is that theme park visitors are mostly one-time visitors, and thus Disney can afford to fool them by charging modestly and then delivering less access to rides than expected. But Robert H. Frank, an economist at Cornell University, dismisses the idea. "Disney," he explains, "lives on good will and word-of-mouth."
A more plausible explanation is the appeal of the salad bar: Americans don't like to think about budgets and find the experience particularly unpalatable when they are vacationing. It is no accident that cruise ships, ski resorts, rental car companies -- and most other theme parks -- use similar one-price-buys-everything plans.
Lawrence White, an economist at the Stern School of Business at New York University, offers yet another hypothesis. "Waiting in line is part of the fun," he suggests. What's more, there is safety in numbers: the lines validate consumers' decisions to go to Disneyland, much the way the difficulty of reserving a table at a trendy restaurant confirms the patrons' choice.
Perhaps the most intriguing explanation comes from Mr. Frank. If rides like Indiana Jones were priced high enough to eliminate the lines, he argues, it would be possible for visitors to spend hundreds of dollars a day on not-so-cheap thrills. Hence flat-rate pricing, he argues, "may be a way of rationing kids' demands without ever forcing their parents to say no."
What, then, does Disney pricing have to do with Soviet pricing? Both assume efficiency isn't everything, that rationing with time instead of money allows people to avoid confronting the unwelcome realities of inequity and limited income.
Like the Disney Company, the Soviets were in the business of packaging fantasy. Needless to say, Mickey does it much better. But the fact that it works for Disney suggests it just might work in more situations than economists like to admit.

GRAPHIC: Drawing.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Takes a Severe Tumble As Most Commodities Decline

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
A rebound in the dollar and talk of gold sales by the International Monetary Fund prompted speculators to bail out of the precious metals markets yesterday, sending gold sharply lower.
Other commodities like orange juice also fell, and the Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities dropped 2.43 points, to 234.20. 
 At the Commodity Exchange, gold for June delivery fell $4.30 an ounce, to $388, barely above a four-week low of $387.50 reached near the close. July silver dropped 14.9 cents, to $5.634 an ounce. Trading volume in both markets was heavy.
William O'Neill, a Merrill Lynch analyst, said precious metals were shaken by the currency market's positive reaction to Tuesday's meeting of the finance ministers from the Group of Seven industrial nations, even though the meeting produced no immediate measures to support the dollar.
The dollar jumped 1.98 Japanese yen in New York trading yesterday, ending at 83.80 yen.
Gold was also undermined by comments late Tuesday by Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Kenneth Clarke, that there was "quite a lot of support" among the finance ministers for selling up to 6 percent of the gold held by the I.M.F. to help heavily indebted countries.
Such I.M.F. gold sales were endorsed in principle late yesterday by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and the Finance Minister of Canada, Paul Martin.
Elsewhere, frozen concentrated orange juice futures settled at five-week lows after tumbling the 5-cent daily limit. July juice ended down the limit at 106.40 cents a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange.
"There was exaggerated fund buying on the upside and now it's been exaggerated selling on the downside," a trader said.
The market's fundamental outlook remains healthy, traders said, in part because Florida is supplying a greater portion of the nation's needs as Brazil reduces shipments.
At the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, lumber futures fell as cash markets turned soft. Reports that wholesalers are still discounting wood helped push prices to two-week lows. May lumber fell $6.60, to close at $260.70 for a thousand board feet.
Soybeans closed near yesterday's lows despite a bullish industry report released ahead of the opening. Even amid lower supplies, United States exports face growing competition from South America. May soybeans closed down 3.25 cents, at $5.65 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Moves to Bolster Ability to Handle Crises

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
Finance Ministers from rich and poor countries took a first step today toward strengthening the International Monetary Fund's capacity to head off future Mexican-style financial crises and giving the institution more resources to cope with those it fails to prevent.
At the first meeting of the I.M.F.'s policy-setting Interim Committee since the Washington-based institution contributed $17.5 billion to the Mexican rescue package, the ministers agreed to study ways to tighten I.M.F. surveillance over members' economies, creating a new financial safety net to help countries hit by sudden capital outflows and increasing the fund's lendable capital. 
 The reform proposals closely follow those put forward earlier this week by the United States Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, and Michel Camdessus, the I.M.F's Managing Director.
Agreement appeared strongest on the need for the I.M.F. to monitor members' economies more closely to see if they are in danger.
"There was real progress on surveillance," the Belgian Finance Minister, Philippe Maystadt, chairman of the meeting, said.
Regarding aid to Mexico, that nation's Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz, told bankers attending a meeting of the International Institute of Finance here today that his country would run a small trade surplus in the first quarter of 1995 -- compared with a deficit of $ 4.5 billion in the comparable period of 1994 -- as a result of the austerity measures he has taken.
He said the money lent by the United States and the I.M.F. would be sufficient to meet Mexico's debt repayment needs this year, and Mexico would probably not need to draw on some $ 10 billion of credits promised by the Bank for international Settlements in Basel, Switzerland.
Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Kenneth Clarke, said the I.M.F. should concentrate its surveillance on "the world's key economies -- perhaps 30 to 40 countries, where events could have a global impact."

HEADLINE: A New World Bank: Consultant to Third World Investors

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
If James D. Wolfensohn has his way, the finance ministers gathering for a World Bank-sponsored meeting Thursday on third world development strategies will soon be dealing with a radically different international lending institution.
Mr. Wolfensohn, the 61-year-old investment banker and arts patron, becomes the World Bank's ninth president in June, and what he has in mind is nothing less than a revamping of the bank's role. 
 Instead of financing dams and other big development projects in the third world, he says, the bank will focus far more on private investments. And instead of doing what it has done for the last 50 years -- putting more money into more projects in developing nations than any other institution -- it will function more as a consultant or adviser.
"We must create the conditions for private capital to flow into all these countries," Mr. Wolfensohn said in an interview. "That means insuring they develop a healthy, skilled work force, encouraging good governance and a favorable regulatory environment for business. The World Bank must use its skills and expertise in these fields to show them how to attract private investment. The World Bank is now a minor source of capital."
According to Lyn Squire, the World Bank's research director, "the bank will become more of a knowledge-based institution, advising countries on developing their private sector." He says the bank has considerable expertise in teaching people how to form a society based on the rule of law, how to develop stock and bond markets, and how to institute regulations that will help, not hinder, business.
The proposed changes come at a critical time in the bank's history. It is under attack by environmentalists and others, who charge that its huge development projects help neither the environment nor the poor. And in Washington, a Republican Congress is reluctant to allocate money for third world development.
Mr. Wolfensohn's emphasis on an advisory role and on private investment could be just the antidote. "There is need for change and I intend to be an instrument of change," he insists. He is giving himself until January to decide on a plan of action.
His approach is not just a response to critics. The enthusiasm for private investment reflects a recent turnabout in development financing, with private investment replacing aid as the primary engine of economic development.
As recently as 1990, World Bank loans and other official development aid -- $57.9 billion -- exceeded private investment in third world countries -- which totaled $45.5 billion. By last year, that had been sharply reversed, with private investment reaching $179.9 billion and official assistance coming to $54.5 billion.
But private investment is largely confined to certain countries, with 87 percent going to 20 nations, led by China. Sub-Saharan Africa got less than 1.5 percent, and more than a billion people worldwide still live on less than $1 a day.
Mr. Wolfensohn will be pushing for third world investment at a time when such private risk-taking is slowing down. With higher interest rates, there is less money for foreign investment, and the Mexican crisis has scared away potential investors from countries beyond Mexico.
"Mr. Wolfensohn's challenge now is to convince more developing countries to become attractive to investors," persuading those investors that they are a good risk," said Richard Frank, one of three managing directors sharing control until Mr. Wolfensohn arrives.
Mr. Wolfensohn acknowledges that the World Bank must do more to encourage private investment in countries that have yet to attract private investors. To underscore this commitment, soon after he joins the bank he will make his first field trip to Africa, where poverty and instability is so great that the bank is only able to operate in half the 48 countries. "We are in the poverty-reduction business," he said, "so I'm starting in the market where the need for our services is greatest."
Under Mr. Wolfensohn's predecessor, Lewis T. Preston, who has cancer and is retiring early, the World Bank has been doing more to help countries attract investment.
Poverty reduction has been declared the World Bank's "overarching goal," and social lending for health and education has tripled, to $3.1 billion since 1990, and will reach $5 billion by the end of the century. This has twin aims: protecting basic social programs against austerity measures while encouraging the creation of the skilled, healthy work force investors want.
Mr. Preston has also moderated the World Bank's enthusiasm for ever-higher lending. His emphasis on quality of lending over quantity has meant a drop in new loans, to $14.2 billion last year from $16.9 billion in 1993. Only 18 percent of projects performed poorly last year -- by the bank's standard, that means producing less than 10 percent annual return -- compared with 37.5 percent below standard in 1992.
The bank has also become more accountable, creating an appeals panel to adjudicate complaints about its projects from citizens of borrowing countries. Still, difficulties abound. While the bank lends only to governments, its private-sector arm, the International Finance Corporation, encourages private investment in developing countries by taking stakes in their projects, offering a measure of protection against abuses by local officials.
A recent report by the Overseas Development Council in Washington, a pro-aid lobby, urges the International Finance Corporation to do more. Its top management is reluctant. "With a $10 billion portfolio set to grow 15 to 20 percent a year until the year 2002, we are doing all we dare," said Daniel F. Adams, vice president for operations. Come June, this could lead to friction with Mr. Wolfensohn if the new bank president opts for the development council's recommendations.
Mr. Frank, one of the interim managing directors, thinks the answer for the World Bank is to promote more private investment in basic facilities projects by guaranteeing them against risks like government interference with pricing. He also wants the bank to lend more for restructuring and recapitalizing third world banking systems.
In June, the World Bank will lend Mexico $1 billion to reform its banking system, its largest loan ever, with big loans also planned for Argentina and Morocco.

HEADLINE: Justices Step In as Federalism's Referee

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
Unlike President Clinton, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist does not hold news conferences. But if he did, it would not occur to anyone to ask him whether he was still relevant.
The Supreme Court's stunning decision of Wednesday that Congress lacked the authority to bar gun possession in or near schools was a forceful reminder not only of the Court's raw power -- nine people, divided 5 to 4, invalidated a law that two houses of Congress and the President of the United States approved five years ago -- but also of its inevitable role in shaping the country's ongoing political dialogue. 
 Had Chief Justice Rehnquist's majority opinion in United States v. Lopez landed in a vacuum, it would have been an important constitutional development but scarcely one to provoke statements on the Senate floor or the kind of urgent scrutiny the decision received all over Washington.
But this is a season in which questions of federalism are unusually high on the agenda -- not only the efforts of state officials to shed unwanted Federal mandates, a prominent topic during the opening weeks of the new Congress, but also the new interest, prompted by the Oklahoma City bombing and the Clinton Administration's proposed responses, in the appropriate division of law-enforcement authority between the Federal and state governments.
The Court's rediscovery of limits on Federal power under a constitutional provision, the commerce clause, that it had not interpreted in such a way in nearly 60 years is bound to affect the federalism debate in ways that may not be apparent until the full dimensions of the ruling itself become clear, perhaps years from now as its principles are tested in other contexts.
One indication of how far the new majority intends to go could come quickly. The Justices heard arguments two months ago in a case that has received much less attention but that poses a closely related question about the Federal Government's law-enforcement authority under its constitutional power to regulate interstate commerce. A decision could come any week.
This second case, United States v. Robertson, raises the question whether the Federal racketeering law can be applied to a business-related crime that occurs essentially within the borders of a single state.
The Federal law, the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, or RICO, makes it a crime to invest racketeering proceeds in a business "the activities of which affect interstate or foreign commerce." A Federal appeals court, ruling that the operations of a small Alaska gold mine did not affect interstate commerce, overturned the conviction of a former Federal prosecutor for investing narcotics proceeds in the mine.
By the same token, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that the Gun-Free School Zones Act was not within the power of Congress to regulate interstate commerce because the possession of guns near schools was not sufficiently related to commerce. If the Justices agree with the lower court in the Alaska case, they will be taking that analysis a considerable step further, because the gold mine was self-evidently a commercial operation in a way that schools are not.
Furthermore, Miguel A. Estrada, an assistant solicitor general, argued to the Court in the Government's appeal, people and supplies moved into and out of Alaska as part of the gold mine's operations.
"Is there any business enterprise in America that wouldn't be covered" by the Government's broad theory of the commerce power, a skeptical Justice Sandra Day O'Connor asked Mr. Estrada. No, he replied: "In our economy in this day and age, I can't think of anything that is likely to happen in the real world" that would not be related to interstate commerce.
It was just such a broad interpretation of interstate commerce that the Court's majority, including Justice O'Connor, rejected on Wednesday in the Lopez decision. If the Justices also reject the broad definition when it concerns an actual business, and not only a nonprofit customary function of state government like public education, it will be clear that the Lopez case applies beyond a rather anomalous Federal law.
The Court would then be repudiating one of the fundamental principles underlying the modern understanding of the commerce clause: that the power of the Federal Government grows necessarily, almost organically, as the increasingly complex and interrelated national economy makes the concept of local boundaries essentially obsolete.
In place of that longstanding view, the Court would be reinserting itself into a role it explicitly renounced in a landmark decision 10 years ago: that of guardian of the Federal-state balance.
In that 1985 decision, Garcia v. San Antonio Transit, the Court said restrictions on the scope of Congressional authority to regulate interstate commerce must come not from "judicially created limitations" but from the political process itself. Because states themselves participate in Federal decision-making through their representation in Congress, the Court said, "the political process ensures that laws that unduly burden the States will not be promulgated."
Like the Lopez ruling 10 years later, the Garcia decision left a deeply divided Court. Justices O'Connor and Rehnquist, two of the four dissenters, pledged in their opinion in the Garcia case that "this Court will in time again assume its constitutional responsibility."
Developments not only within the Court but also outside it may have strengthened the Garcia dissenters' hand. To the alarm of much of the Federal judiciary, Congress has demonstrated a nearly insatiable appetite for showing its concern about various problems, from household violence to drive-by shootings, by adding them to the growing list of Federal crimes and, in the process, placing them on the dockets of Federal judges.
The Judicial Conference of the United States, the Federal judiciary's policy-making arm, which Chief Justice Rehnquist heads, has opposed several of these bills and urged Congress to reconsider its approach.
Judge Maryanne Trump Barry of the Federal District Court in Newark, head of the Judicial Conference's criminal law committee, told the House Judiciary Committee last year that the Federal courts were not equipped to take over proceedings for what have historically been state and local offenses. Noting that there were more trial judges on the California state courts than in all the Federal district courts combined, Judge Barry said that "scarce judicial resources needed by the Federal courts to try major crimes" would be "diluted" if various proposals then under consideration in the 1994 crime bill became law. Many did.
While Congressional Republicans generally applauded the Court's solicitude toward the states in Wednesday's decision, they may find that a Supreme Court that re-assumes a role as activist policeman of the Federal-state boundary is not always to their liking. The Federal limits on state-court damage awards, now being debated in the Senate as part of the Republican-sponsored civil justice measure, may well not match the Court's view of appropriate Federal action even if the states welcome them. Relevance, in other words, may be a double-edged sword.

HEADLINE: Ex-Official Pleads Guilty in Orange County's Fall

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 27

 BODY:
In the first criminal action since Orange County was forced into bankruptcy late last year, the county's former treasurer, Robert L. Citron, pleaded guilty late today to six felony counts, including misappropriating hundreds of millions of dollars and misleading investors in the county's bonds.
Mr. Citron, whose investment strategies with high-powered securities caused $1.7 billion in losses and created the largest municipal bankruptcy in American history, was subdued and wan as he entered his plea late today before Judge David Carter of the Orange County Superior Court. 
 The plea agreement marked an about-face for Mr. Citron. Previously, he had insisted that he was not the architect of his own investment schemes and that he had broken no laws in his efforts to manage the county's funds. In a state Legislature hearing earlier this year, he had blamed his principal broker, Merrill Lynch & Company, for pushing him into the ultimately disastrous investment practices.
Although Mr. Citron is essentially accused of bankrupting one of the nation's most prosperous counties with his reckless investment schemes, the District Attorney's office said he did not benefit personally from the illegal acts. They appear to have been undertaken in an effort to rescue a financial house of cards once his losses began to grow.
Assistant District Attorney Jan Nolan read the felony counts in the televised court appearance, then asked, "Is it true?" Mr. Citron, a slender, bespectacled, 70-year-old man who just a few months ago was juggling billions of dollars daily, answered, "It is."
The Orange County District Attorney said the maximum sentence Mr. Citron could receive would be 14 years in prison.
Mr. Citron has agreed to cooperate with the continuing criminal investigation. Today's plea agreement thus appears unlikely to be the last legal action in this case, which has become a landmark not only for municipal government but also for the financial markets.
Mr. Citron suffered many of his losses because of strategies involving highly complex investments known as derivatives -- investments that are tied to, or derived from, the performance of an underlying asset, like a currency, or the performance of a financial market, like interest rates. Derivatives were involved in the collapse earlier this year of Barings P.L.C. and caused hundreds of millions of dollars of losses for companies including Gibson Greetings Inc. and Procter & Gamble.
The losses at those two companies, and at several others, were caused by a sharp and unexpected rise in interest rates, which forced the prices of bonds and a number of other securities to decline sharply. But the magnitude of the losses was magnified by the fact that in each case derivatives were being used, leading to much faster swings in prices.
Orange County has already sued the broker with whom Mr. Citron had done most of his trading, Merrill Lynch, for $2 billion. Because today's plea agreement clearly suggests that there was fraud in the sale of some of Orange County's bonds, it raised the prospect that Merrill, the underwriter of some of those bonds, might also face charges. The Securities and Exchange Commission is also investigating the case for possible violations of the securities laws.
William Popejoy, Orange County's chief executive, said at a news conference this evening that he hoped the plea agreement would persuade the Wall Street firm to settle with the county.
Timothy Gilles, a Merrill spokesman, said that securities firm had no comment.
Mr. Citron was released on $25,000 bond. His sentencing was set for Aug. 4.
Mr. Citron was always something of an anomaly. He was a Democrat elected repeatedly for the job of treasurer of one of the most conservative and heavily Republican counties in America. He was personally a simple man who attended the University of Southern California, spent his career with the county government, earned $104,353 a year and ate lunch three times a week at a local Elks Club lodge.
But as part of his job he managed a huge $7.4 billion fund that made him one of the more prominent government investors in the country. The money came not just from Orange County, but a variety of other local governments and government agencies. He had attracted the funds because of his surprisingly good investment returns in previous years.
Despite their powerful resistance to taxes, these governments were happy to invest their money in a fund that seemed to earn them something for nothing. In fact, the pain of the losses Mr. Citron ultimately suffered was exacerbated by the fact that Orange County and some of these other government agencies borrowed huge sums of money to invest even more in Mr. Citron's fund.
When the fund began to suffer losses, particularly after interest rates began to rise sharply early last year, Mr. Citron took a number of steps that ultimately added to depth of the problems. That is when he is believed to have committed most of his crimes.
In the plea agreement, he was charged with making false statements to sell Orange County securities, making false bookkeeping entries, misappropriating hundreds of millions of dollars of funds by shuffling money between different accounts. The only specific losses with which he was charged was causing $2.5 million in damages.
Mr. Citron resigned from his job on Dec. 4 and the county filed for bankruptcy two days later. Since then, the county has cut 1,500 jobs, slashed services and is on the brink of defaulting on about $1 billion in bonds that come due this summer.
"I hope this allows the county to get some part of its anger behind them," Mr. Popejoy said tonight.

HEADLINE: 20 Years After War, 3 in Hanoi on Healing Mission

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, April 25

 BODY:
They are all survivors of the war, these three Americans whose lives tell the history of their country's ordeal in Vietnam.
They gathered in a newly whitewashed ward of an otherwise decrepit children's hospital: a decorated veteran whose leg was blown off in a Vietnamese rice paddy in 1968; a doctor who in 1971 announced that he would refuse to fight in Vietnam, a declaration that could have landed him in prison, and a Vietnamese-born engineer, who was only a boy of 7 on that fateful night 20 years ago this week when American evacuation helicopters carried the rest of his family away from Saigon, and left him behind. 
 All three were here -- on the 20th anniversary of the fall of Saigon and the end of the war -- to try to make peace with Vietnam by healing its children.
"When the Army sent me to Vietnam, they told me I was fighting for the people of Vietnam," said Jeffrey Fredrick, 45, the veteran from Tallahassee, Fla., who lost his right leg to a Vietcong booby trap in Cu Chi Province. "Now, at last, it's true. Now I really am fighting for these people."
With $1.3 million from the United States Government through the Agency for International Development and $300,000 from the Vietnam Veterans of America Foundation, Mr. Fredrick and an American team are opening a clinic to supply state-of-the-art plastic braces to help handicapped Vietnamese children to walk.
The opening ceremony at the clinic will be held Saturday, the eve of the anniversary of the end of the war.
It was Mr. Fredrick who recruited the others: Dr. Jeffrey H. Garrison, 51, a rehabilitative-medicine specialist from St. Petersburg, Fla., who during the war declared himself a conscientious objector and refused to fight, and Quan Pham, the 27-year-old Vietnamese-American technician who was abandoned by his family in Saigon on April 29, 1975.
Mr. Pham was left behind when his father, a pilot with the South Vietnamese Air Force, fled with his wife and his three other children aboard one of the last American evacuation helicopters fleeing Tan Son Nhut Air Base, on the outskirts of Saigon.
Mr. Pham, who was then staying with his grandmother elsewhere in the city, spent the next six years as a child laborer in Saigon, now Ho Chi Minh City. "I hauled ice, I hauled coal, I chopped wood," he recalled.
"When my family was evacuated, I was so young then that I didn't understand what was happening," he said. "I just remember that I was very confused."
He did not see his parents again until 1981, when he was allowed by the Vietnamese Government to leave Vietnam to join them in Florida, where today they own a dry-cleaning business.
"Coming back to Vietnam was my idea," said Mr. Pham, who had worked with Mr. Fredrick in his orthopedic clinic in Tallahassee. While his father remains a staunch anti-Communist and was wary of his son returning to the former enemy capital, Hanoi, "my parents still wanted me to come back and do something for Vietnam," he said.
Mr. Pham interrupted the conversation to help a group of hospital workers tear off the packing material from some of the newly imported equipment for the clinic, including an infrared oven that will be used to bake flesh-colored plastic into leg braces.
The braces will be molded individually from the legs of Vietnamese children who cannot walk, or cannot walk normally, because of birth defects and disease. The clinic is expected to care for at least 1,000 children a year who, until now, could have hoped only for crude leg braces made of bamboo.
Dr. Garrison, the team's physician, felt that the time was finally right for him to come to Vietnam, 24 years after he informed his draft board in Peekskill, N.Y., that he would refuse to fight in the war.
Dr. Garrison, a Quaker, said his religious principles barred him from fighting in any war -- an explanation that was eventually accepted by the draft board.
"And even if you believed that war was a justifiable behavior -- and I don't -- the Vietnam War really seemed to be trumped up," Dr. Garrison, 51, said. "Now I believe that there is a moral obligation to help the recovery of this country."
Meeting for the first time with his patients this week, Dr. Garrison saw what had become of Vietnam two decades after the war. In one of the poorest countries on earth, his tiny patients entered the examination room wearing little but soiled rags, their misshaped bodies often a testament to poor nutrition and to diseases, including polio, that have been eradicated from the developed world.
Other children, he said, suffer from birth defects that could be a result of their mothers' poor nutrition during pregnancy.
One young mother carried a year-old boy who suffered from cerebral palsy, his ears misshapen and his back so extended that it seemed the muscles might tear. "He cannot even recognize me," the frightened mother told Dr. Garrison, asking for some sort of help that might allow the boy just to crawl.
Dr. Garrison tried to comfort the woman, saying that eventually the clinic might be able to help the boy with braces for his deformed legs. But privately he told visitors, "I don't know that this boy will live."
It is difficult to tell that Mr. Fredrick, the clinic director, is an amputee. He walks with only the slightest hitch in his stride.
"The idea of having all these kids walk with a brace and play in a playground is unrealistic," said Mr. Fredrick, who turned the lessons learned from his affliction into a life's career -- he now runs clinics for the manufacture of orthopedic devices. "But we want to do everything that it takes to rehabilitate as many as we can."
Mr. Fredrick said that he felt no bitterness toward the Vietnamese over the loss of his leg, insisting that he was in fact lucky.
"It's amazing that I didn't lose both legs," he said of the searing blast from the booby trap in 1968. "A whole lot of other people have reason to be bitter about the war -- and they're the people of Vietnam."
He said he resented the American veterans who use the war "as an excuse," adding, "Vietnam has become an across-the-board excuse for a whole generation of guys who messed up their lives."
"Compare our trauma to the trauma of these little kids," he said, nodding to a dank hallway filled with anxious Vietnamese parents cradling their handicapped children. "Now that -- that's trauma."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Parents and others crowded the hallway of a children's clinic in Hanoi, waiting to be seen. Jeffrey Fredrick, center with briefcase, and two other survivors of the war are trying to make peace with Vietnam by healing its children. HEADLINE: At an Israeli Checkpoint, Food Rots, Tempers Boil

BYLINE: By JOEL GREENBERG 

DATELINE: EREZ CROSSING, Gaza Strip, April 27

 BODY:
After waiting four days at checkpoints earlier this month to drive his vegetables out of the Gaza Strip, Suleiman Qdeih moved to the head of a line of trucks with a load of spoiling produce and simmering resentment.
The delay had ruined his cargo. 
 "It has all turned into garbage in the sun and heat," he said shortly before Israeli soldiers began a security check of his truck, which was packed with tomatoes, eggplants and cucumbers. "If I don't get through now, I'm going to dump it all."
Transport restrictions imposed after a Gaza truck carrying explosives was found in southern Israel last month have dealt another heavy blow to Gaza's crippled economy.
Shipment of goods in and out of the area has been severely curbed for weeks, adding to losses caused by a border closing that prevents tens of thousands of Palestinian laborers from reaching jobs in Israel. The restictions were imposed by Israel to block suicide attacks by Palestinian militants; such attacks have killed more than 65 people in the past year.
The damage to the Palestinian economy caused by the ban on workers, estimated by United Nations officials at $2 million a day, has brought pressure on Israel from the United States and other countries, which the losses are wiping out the benefits of their financial assistance.
At a meeting in Paris today, the donors agreed to provide $60 million to help cover the authority's $136 million budget deficit for the rest of this year. Israel pledged to ease the flow of goods to and from Gaza, but asserted that the key to free movement was improved security.
In the past, hundreds of Palestinian trucks passed daily through this fortified, Israeli-controlled crossing on the northern edge of the Gaza Strip, carrying vegetables, fruits and flowers to the West Bank and Israel and for export overseas, and bringing back Israeli goods.
Now only several dozen trucks are allowed each day, and their loads must be transferred to Israeli trailers and checked by soldiers. Even fewer trucks actually enter Israel, and they must travel in convoys escorted by the police.
At the checkpoints, whether they are controlled by the Israelis or by the Palestinian police, long security checks leave scores of trucks stranded for days. Ship departures from Israeli ports have been missed, and dozens of tons of spoiled produce have had to be dumped.
The curbs on shipments from Israel have caused more damage. Gaza industries lack raw materials, flour is in shorter supply and a shortage of cement has hampered building projects. These problems have driven up prices of basic goods.
Critics say the restrictions have brought new security risks by driving an entire population dangerously close to despair.
"This is destroying people, agriculture and the economy," said Juma Thum, a truck driver who arrived at Erez after a three-day wait. "A person who can't find money in his pocket to feed his children will want to blow himself up."
Frustrated drivers have already held angry protests at roadblocks, dumping spoiled goods. The Palestinian Authority initially hit back by barring Israeli goods from the Gaza Strip, but Gazans depend on those products and so the authority loosened its restrictions.
"Israel wants to suffocate the Palestinian Authority," asserted Nabil Abu Irdeina, an authority spokesman. "This is collective punishment, which is endangering the whole peace process."
Some truck drivers doubt Israeli assertions that the issue is security, saying Israel's true aim is to turn embittered Gazans against their own government.
"It would be better if they closed off the border entirely," said Raji Taha, a truck driver. "We won't take from them, they won't take from us, and we'll live on tomatoes and cucumbers. This is no way to live."
Ramiz Abu Taha, a cigarette distributor from Rafah, in southern Gaza, said he had been cut off from his Israeli suppliers. Like many Gazans, he seemed torn between continuing dependence on Israel and a desire to separate from it.
"Israel is responsible for us," he said, but he added: "If they don't want to deal with us, fine. Let them close the border. But they have to open other borders, to Egypt, so we can be self-reliant. Now we are surrounded. We are in a big jail."
