HEADLINE: Clinton and Yeltsin Seeking Common Ground for Talks

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin struggled today to find common ground in anticipation of their summit meeting next month in Moscow, papering over some disputes, ignoring others, and resolving none of them.
Their 30-minute telephone conversation was cordial but vague, underscoring strains between the United States and Russia that American officials made no effort to hide. Senior American officials acknowledged that Mr. Clinton did not even raise the most serious issue dividing Washington and Moscow: Russia's $1 billion deal to build two nuclear energy reactors for Iran, which the United States wants canceled. 
 Shortly before the conversation, Mr. Clinton met for 10 minutes with Russia's Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, who spent much of the afternoon lobbying leading lawmakers in Congress not to punish Russia for its deal with Iran and its war in the breakaway republic of Chechnya.
"We all unanimously took the view that Russia should not be making the sale and asked him simply to not do it," said Senator Richard C. Lugar, Republican of Indiana.
Mr. Kozyrev countered by saying that Russia was doing nothing more than what the United States was doing with its deal to provide North Korea with nuclear energy, Mr. Lugar said. The Russian added that the technology involved was not dangerous, the money involved was important for Russia's economy and the United States should seek to encourage Russia's ties to Iran.
Although the Administration's official line is that Mr. Yeltsin must be supported because he is the elected President, Administration officials admit that relations are based more on mutual suspicion than on trust.
In fact, the main reason Mr. Clinton will be in Moscow 13 days from now is that the relationship would only get worse if he is not. Russian officials have made clear that they would be highly insulted if the President of the United States did not attend ceremonies commemorating the 50th anniversary of the victory over Germany in World War II.
But there are no illusions inside the Administration that Mr. Clinton will move Mr. Yeltsin from his fixed positions on Bosnia, Iran, the eastward expansion of NATO or the rebellion in Chechnya. Since no policy breakthroughs are expected, the two sides are preparing modest joint statements reaffirming support for the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty and a willingness to work together on European security issues.
The absence of progress in the conversation between the two Presidents was best captured in an exchange with Coit Blacker, the chief Russia specialist in the National Security Council, who took notes on the conversation and later briefed reporters.
Asked if there was any progress on the Iran nuclear reactor, Chechnya or NATO, he replied:
"The President took advantage of his time on the phone with President Yeltsin to raise a number of issues and to underscore, as far as we're concerned, the importance of working these through in ways that are consistent with what we think is in the long-term interest not only of our own security but international security more broadly."
Asked then if there had been no progress, Mr. Blacker said, "You can characterize it as you choose."
Addressing Mr. Yeltsin as "Boris," Mr. Clinton emphasized the need to protect the good part of the relationship between their countries rather than dwell on the bad, one senior Administration official said.
In particular, Mr. Clinton stressed the need to find a formula for European security that would include Russia's signing on to a program of military cooperation with NATO.
Russia had taken preliminary steps to join the arrangement but Mr. Yeltsin later balked, convinced that the program was an effort to expand NATO and isolate Russia.
In his conversation with Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Clinton only briefly mentioned the need for a permanent Russian cease-fire in Chechnya and to resolve various arms control disputes, officials said.
He did not remind Mr. Yeltsin that he still had not turned over a complete list of pending arms sales to Iran, something he had promised Mr. Clinton last fall at a summit meeting in Washington, they said.
Most surprising, they said that Mr. Clinton did not express specific concern over Russia's nuclear deal with Iran. Secretary of State Warren Christopher has charged that Iran is on a "crash course" to develop nuclear weapons and presented Mr. Kozyrev with extensive classified intelligence information to make the Administration's case.
Although Mr. Clinton intends to raise the Iran nuclear deal when he meets with Mr. Yeltsin, the Russians have made clear they do not share Washington's concerns and that they plan to go ahead with it.
Mr. Clinton also asked Mr. Yeltsin for his help in trying to find Frederick C. Cuny, an American disaster relief expert, and five Russian aid workers who disappeared on a mission to Chechnya this month.
The American Embassy in Moscow is sending four officials to the North Caucasus to hunt for Mr. Cuny following the failure of an earlier mission, the State Department said.

Fighting In Chechnya
 MOSCOW, April 28 (AP) -- Russian troops shelled a battered Chechen village and fought rebel guerrillas today, hours before a cease-fire by Russia was to begin.
President Boris N. Yeltsin ordered the unilateral cease-fire to coincide with a visit to Moscow by world leaders, but there were few signs the fighting in the secessionist republic would stop. The cease-fire is to take effect at 12:01 A.M. Friday and last until May 12.
Even before Mr. Yeltsin could sign the cease-fire, the Defense Minister, Pavel S. Grachev, warned that Russian troops would retaliate heavily for any attack by Chechen rebels.

HEADLINE: In U.N.'s Future, a Leaner Budget

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 27

 BODY:
For the first time in years, the United Nations, an organization not celebrated for penny-pinching, will find its new budget significantly reduced -- 4.2 percent less than the current one.
The leaner budget, which needs the General Assembly's approval before it takes effect in January, was devised by Joseph E. Connor, a retired American business executive with 38 years' experience in public accounting and auditing. In the year since he was hired as the new Under Secretary General for Administration and Management, Mr. Connor has moved quietly to tighten up an organization with a sometimes cavalier disregard for thrift. 
 "Governments are downsizing, outsourcing, innovating, and we have to be the same way," Mr. Connor said in an interview in his pin-tidy office on the 27th floor of the United Nations Secretariat. "It's imperative that all international organizations realize that they don't work for themselves, they represent the member states. They've got to justify what they produce."
In a note sent Wednesday to diplomatic missions of the 185 member states, he outlined the first details of a budget of $2.51 billion for 1996-97 that is $109 million less than the current budget of nearly $2.62 billion for 1994-95.
The saving in the proposed budget is being achieved by dropping $92 million worth of obsolete missions and programs, like a longstanding anti-apartheid campaign, and by shaving $36 million more through efficiency. Spending will increase $19 million in areas like human rights and drug control. Of this, $2.8 million will go to strengthen internal oversight of the staff and spending.
The frugalities are proposed at a time when Congress has threatened to cut back contributions to the United Nations. The United States provides a quarter of the United Nations' regular budget and 31.7 percent of peacekeeping costs. Congress has moved to trim Washington's share of peacekeeping costs to 25 percent as well. The United States and other nations forced the United Nations to trim its staff in the late 1980's in return for bailing it out of a financial crisis.
Mr. Connor, who is 63, worked for Price Waterhouse for 36 years, retiring in 1992 as its chief executive. He taught accounting and business management at Georgetown University's Graduate School of Business, until Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali brought him to the United Nations last May 2.
He joined an organization that is long on bureaucracy and short on professional management. The member nations call the shots, and the Secretary General does not even directly control some United Nations agencies.
"It's not designed for management," Mr. Connor said of the system. "It defies oversight because there is no person who is the chief executive of the organization."
In a culture where virtually no one gets laid off, Mr. Connor has picked 201 jobs for elimination from a Secretariat staff of about 10,115. Some 66 jobs will be created in new areas, and 26 will be transferred to the regular budget from peacekeeping operations. The new budget is based on a projection that the United Nations can run with 10 percent fewer people. He has already eliminated 45 employees through retirement, buy-outs and what he calls talk-outs.
Mr. Connor said he wanted supervisors to stop feeling helpless in the face of incompetence and union resistance. At the United Nations, work is almost uniformly rated good or excellent because employees can appeal anything less than enthusiastic appraisals of their performance.
"When a supervisor knows he may have to spend two or three years defending an evaluation," Mr. Connor said, "he's not likely to make a critical evaluation."
Some of Mr. Connor's proposals would strike American businessmen as common sense, though he said, "It's a revolution over here."
He wants the budget to reflect a meaningful strategic plan, not merely requests from departments and agencies as happens now. Such a plan would include evaluations, he said, with "financial consequences" for activities that fail to measure up. He said the $36 million to be saved in the new budget by "focusing on how to work better" is more than double the $15 million that the Secretary General asked for.
But Mr. Connor observed that the United Nations output was not as quantifiable as, for instance, automobiles produced on an assembly line. And unlike a business, the United Nations has no income beyond what it gets from its members. It cannot borrow money or issue bonds.
"We have no net worth, we have no assets, we have no capital," Mr. Connor said. Tardy payments of assessments by many member nations -- the United States was more than $1.2 billion in arrears as of April 15 -- have forced the United Nations to shuffle income to cover its expenses.
Mr. Connor said he was calling a halt to new ideas to give the organization a chance to catch up. He conceded that he can only go so far to rein in the system.
"It's the Secretariat's job to put on the table where the least effective spending is," he said, adding: "It's up to members to decide what the member states want the organization to do. We would like to do that with the cooperation and participation of member states."

HEADLINE: 'Isolationism' Strongly Attacked By Top Clinton Security Adviser

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
The President's national security adviser today attacked what he called a rising wave of isolationism in the nation.
The national security adviser, Anthony Lake, made one of the Administration's fiercest attacks against isolationism at a time when many Republicans in Congress are seeking to slash foreign aid and restrict President Clinton's ability to commit United States troops to United Nations peacekeeping operations. 
 "Our policy of engagement in world affairs is under siege, and American leadership is in peril," he said in a speech to the Woodrow Wilson Center, a research group specializing in foreign affairs.
Mr. Lake argued that isolationists were seeking to undo a successful post-World War II system built on military might, foreign assistance and leadership in the world economy. He leveled his harshest criticisms at "back-door isolationists," a group that he said denies that it is isolationist even as it supports scaling back the United States role in world affairs.
"These back-door isolationists and unilateralists cast themselves as the true guardians of American power," he said. "But through their actions they could become the agents of American retreat. They champion American leadership but they want it the one way you can't have it: on the cheap."
He argued that if the United States turned isolationist, problems like international terrorism and aggression by countries like Iraq would only grow worse.
"Defeating these threats requires persistent engagement and hands-on policies," he said. "Defeating them demands resources. Throwing money at problems won't make them go away -- but we also cannot solve problems without money. The measure of American leadership is not only the strength and attraction of our values, but what we bring to the table to solve the hard issues."
Mr. Lake defended United States cooperation with other countries in providing money and troops for United Nations peacekeeping missions. He said such operations have been successful in Cyprus, Haiti, Cambodia, Namibia and along the Iraq-Kuwait border.
"We would pay much more if we performed even a small number of these missions unilaterally," he said.

HEADLINE: Governors' Draft Plan Rejects Parts of House Welfare Bill

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
The bipartisan leadership of the National Governors' Association has drafted a new proposal to overhaul the nation's welfare system, urging the Senate to reject stringent work requirements and many other provisions of a welfare bill passed last month by the House.
A sweeping critique of the House bill, prepared by the staff of the association, says "most states do not believe they can achieve" the goals of the House bill, which would require half of all adult welfare recipients to work by 2003. 
 A letter drafted by the governors' association asks the Senate "to avoid prescribing narrow Federal work standards for the cash assistance block grant," which under the House bill would replace the main welfare program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children.
Republican governors, including Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey and George V. Voinovich of Ohio, voiced some of these objections two weeks ago. But the new letter drafted by the governors' association would put the imprimatur of that bipartisan organization on a much broader critique of the House bill.
The governors' statement could be very influential, since the Senate Finance Committee will soon begin drafting a welfare bill, and few members have expressed strong convictions about how to proceed. In addition, Republicans may need Democratic votes to overcome a filibuster on the Senate floor.
In their draft statement, the governors urge the Senate not to impose "rigid work standards" on the states, saying that such requirements could impede efforts by the states to devise innovative work programs. The governors also say they "oppose the wholesale elimination of Federal services to legal noncitizens," which they say would result from the House bill. And they urge the Senate to reject provisions of the House bill that would deny aid to hundreds of thousands of disabled children now receiving cash assistance under the Supplemental Security Income program.
The governors also oppose provisions of the House bill that would prohibit Federal welfare payments to unmarried teen-age mothers and additional children born to women already receiving welfare. Likewise, they say the question of whether to impose a time limit on welfare, like the five-year limit in the House bill, should be left to the states.
Under the House bill, welfare recipients would be counted as working only if they engaged in "work activities" for a specific number of hours: 20 hours a week from 1996 through 1998, rising to 35 hours a week in 2002.
The governors expressed misgivings about these requirements. "If the Senate decides to impose a standard for hours of work," they said, "we urge you to recognize that in our society mothers with young children typically work only part time. We believe that any standard for hours of work should not ask more of low-income single parents with young children than is demanded of other mothers with young children. In particular, the governors do not think it is reasonable to mandate 35 hours of work a week."
In a letter to the governors, Raymond C. Scheppach, executive director of the governors' association, said, "I believe that we need to begin discussing options for a bipartisan Senate welfare reform package that N.G.A. could support." Moreover, Mr. Scheppach said, if the governors make a bipartisan recommendation to the Senate Finance Committee, "it is likely to be taken quite seriously."
The chairman of the committee, Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, has said he supports a block grant for the main cash assistance program. The governors' association recommends three separate block grants, for cash assistance to poor families, for child care and for the protection of children who have been abused or neglected.
The association has no policy on whether Federal payments for foster care and adoption assistance should be incorporated in a block grant, as the House bill would require. But Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, and the National Association of Counties say the Federal Government should continue to guarantee such payments for anyone who meets the eligibility criteria.
The governors said the House bill did not provide enough protection against recessions. They urged the Senate to create a contingency fund to help states that experience economic problems or faced sudden increases in the numbers of abused and neglected children referred to state agencies by local courts.

HEADLINE: TERROR IN OKLAHOMA: COURT CASE;
Bomb Delays Man's Trial On Gun Charge in Virginia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
A judge in Roanoke, Va., has delayed the trial of a member of an anti-government paramilitary group in Virginia on gun charges, saying it would be difficult to find an impartial jury.
The judge, Jackson L. Kiser of Federal District Court, said speculation about links between the Oklahoma City bombing and paramilitary groups in other states had tainted prospective jurors. 
 The trial was scheduled to start on Wednesday.
Judge Kiser said the trial of William Stump 2d, a 35-year-old unemployed machinist accused of conspiracy to violate Federal gun laws, would be delayed at least six weeks.
Donald R. Wolthuis, the Assistant United States Attorney who is prosecuting the case, said Judge Kiser's "concerns about public sentiment over Oklahoma City were well-taken."
Mr. Stump is one of five members of the Blue Ridge Hunt Club, a tiny, now-defunct citizens' paramilitary group, who were charged last summer after the police infiltrated the group. He is accused of possessing illegal firearms and silencers.
Two men, including the club's president, James Roy Mullins, pleaded guilty to charges against them last February, and the trial of the other two men was scheduled to start next Monday in the same court.
Mr. Wolthuis said he expected Judge Kiser to postpone that proceeding, too.
Mr. Stump, who is representing himself in the case, did not return a telephone call seeking comment.
The club was formed in April 1993 after the Federal raid on the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex.
The club's 15 members had met three times before the arrests, and then disbanded, the police said.

HEADLINE: Mr. Clinton Bows to Farmers

 BODY:
President Clinton's pledge to Iowa farmers this week that he would defend Federal farm subsidies was pointless pandering to special interests.
Farmers are the nation's richest welfare recipients; full-time farmers typically earn four times as much as non-farm families. The Federal Government pays farmers and huge agribusinesses not to grow crops or send food abroad. Mr. Clinton says that is a nifty way to boost exports. But taxpayers who foot the bill might take exception. 
 The Federal program stifles food production, which jacks up prices and hurts both consumers and the economy. The farm program costs taxpayers about $10 billion a year and adds an equal amount to food bills, driving up the price of milk, fruit, sugar and many other necessities by about 10 percent.
The Government has no obligation to preserve agribusiness or family farms if the consequence is to take money from poor consumers in order to pump up the bank accounts of multinational companies and often-wealthy farmers. At a moment when the Republicans are on the verge of wiping out spending programs for the poor, Mr. Clinton has no business preserving subsidies that go overwhelmingly to middle- and upper-class families.
Senator Richard Lugar, from the farm state of Indiana, has courageously called for reducing farm subsidies. That offers a model for a fellow Presidential candidate sitting in the White House.

HEADLINE: Cities Also Need Limits on Lawsuits

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The fight for tort reform has moved to the Senate floor. The House of Representatives began the process of correcting the abuses that plague our system of civil justice by approving limitations on joint and several liability and placing a cap of $250,000 on pain and suffering damages (health care suits only) and a similar cap on punitive damages. 
 The reforms approved by the Senate Commerce Committee, however, are limited to product liability, and do not include the delivery of services, which is the fastest growing segment of our economy. The committee's bill needs to be strengthened significantly.
In the past seven years, municipal litigation costs have more than doubled, and the number continues to rise. Last year, New York city paid out over $260 million in damages and settlements, in contrast to the $108 million a mere eight years earlier.
Every New Yorker pays the price of these judgments. Think of the crimes that could have been stopped, the children who could have been taught or the taxes that could have been cut if this litigation lottery had not been giving away city money.
The Senate should broaden the Commerce bill to preserve the reforms in the House common sense legal standards reform bill. It should also pass another amendment, modeled on a 1984 Moore-Gephardt bill. Under the amendment, defendants that agree promptly to assume liability for economic losses would not be responsible for noneconomic damages like "pain and suffering," absent intentional misconduct. This "early offer" concept would encourage early settlements, limit windfall payments and put money into the hands of plaintiffs shortly after their injury.
 
PAUL A. CROTTY
Corporation Counsel
New York, April 27, 1995

HEADLINE: A U.N. Success Story

BYLINE: By Elizabeth Becker; ELizabeth Becker, senior foreign editor of National Public Radio, is author of "When the War Was Over," a history of modern Cambodia.

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia

 BODY:
For years, it was called the Broken Bridge. Blown up by Communist sappers in 1972, it left a silhouette that ended halfway across the Tonle Sap River, at the edge of this city. A few months ago, it reopened, repaired by the Japanese, who originally built it. The American Friendship Highway, which connects the city to its only seaport, is being repaired by the United States.
Nearly two years after the United Nations peacekeeping force left Cambodia, these countries and other guarantors of the 1991 Paris Peace Agreement are still committed to insuring that one of the U.N.'s most ambitious and expensive peace plans protects and rebuilds Cambodia. 
 But as Cambodia marks the 20th anniversary of the Khmer Rouge takeover, the successes of this peacekeeping mission have been overlooked. When experts discuss the U.N., the debate centers on whether Bosnia or Somalia was the biggest failure. The Cambodian peace mission is dismissed as too costly and ineffective because the Khmer Rouge still exist, the peasants are still poor and the Government is corrupt. What's forgotten is what moved the U.N. to mount the plan: two decades of war; destruction of the society by the Khmer Rouge, who caused one million deaths and massacred intellectuals, creating one of the world's lowest literacy rates; economic decay reflected in annual per capita income under $200.
 The Paris plan has worked, however imperfectly. It ended the war, brought 350,000 refugees home and set up democratic elections, in which 90 percent of the population voted. Today, the lives of the people are improving and the national mood favors work, not rebellion. A small middle class is growing. The gross national product is up 5.2 percent, to about $2.2 million. The currency is stable. The budget is balanced.
And the Khmer Rouge are being cornered. Their soldiers are defecting by the hundreds. The dwindling force of 5,000 Khmer Rouge has been pushed back to barred redoubts in northwestern Cambodia.
The National Assembly created one of Asia's most democratic constitutions. Cambodia has a thriving human rights community. Indeed, the hard-won individual rights are among the U.N.'s greatest achievements, showing Cambodians what a normal life can be, with the freedom to see friends, say what they want and do as they please.
Cambodia's return to democracy has been rocky. Freedoms are under constant attack by leaders who liked the old ways. Corruption is everywhere: Ninety percent of the country's high school seniors failed final exams when they were prevented from cheating. The Government openly colludes with Asian lumber companies, both making millions of dollars from cutting down the country's forests. But a foreign official said: "I've seen this stage in other countries' climb out of poverty. It will take another 20 years, but Cambodia is on its way."
To end the war, 15 countries spent five years negotiating an agreement with the Cambodians. More than 30 countries donated money and troops to the mission. Cambodia was a long-term project devised by countries that did not cut and run. Should these countries doubt their success, they might consider the career of Prince Norodom Sirivudh. He was recently squeezed out of the Government in a dispute. In the old days, someone like him would have joined a rival army or fled to Paris. Instead, he is opening Cambodia's first think-tank, from which to espouse his dissenting opinions. Would that Bosnia, Somalia or Haiti were at that stage of political life two years after the U.N.'s blue helmets left.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Back to the Future

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In 1933, with farmers bankrupt and desperate in the Great Depression, Congress passed the Agricultural Adjustment Act to regulate farm production. Three years later the Supreme Court held it unconstitutional: beyond the power of the Federal Government.
The A.A.A. decision and others of the time paralyzed Government efforts to bring the country out of the Depression. And they brought on a crisis for the Court itself: a crisis of public confidence. 
 In 1937 the Supreme Court abandoned its pinched view of Federal power and began sustaining new economic and social legislation. That was the end of the crisis. So we of later generations were taught in constitutional law classes. But was it really the end?
The question has to be asked after the Court's astonishing decision this week that a 1990 Federal law making it a crime to have a gun within 1,000 feet of a school was unconstitutional. A 5-to-4 majority held that the law was not within Congress's power to regulate interstate commerce: the first such decision by the Supreme Court since 1936.
The way Chief Justice William Rehnquist wrote the opinion of the Court opened the possibility that all kinds of modern legislation could now be upset: laws on machine-gun sales, attacks on abortion clinics and many other subjects. That is because the opinion relied on abstract categories to decide whether something is within or outside the commerce power.
Chief Justice Rehnquist said, for example, that education was not "commercial." But the Court in 1971 upheld a law against loansharking in purely local circumstances because it might affect commerce. And it upheld a law against racial discrimination in motels that might serve interstate travelers.
Again, the majority opinion said that something could be regulated by Congress only if it had a "substantial" effect on commerce. That sounded like a throwback to the opinions of the early 1930's that tried to draw a line between "direct" and "indirect" effects on commerce: a distinction that foundered on its own confusion.
Justice Stephen Breyer, in a dissent for himself and Justices John Paul Stevens, David Souter and Ruth Bader Ginsburg, noted that schools cost the country $230 billion in 1990 and that education was crucial to American prosperity in a world economy. It was rational for Congress to decide, he said, that the menace of guns in schools did the country economic harm.
Rational is the key word. For decades now the Supreme Court has given Congress leeway to legislate under its commerce power so long as it had a rational basis for its action. The Court has declined to substitute its judgment for the legislators'.
Justice Souter, in a separate dissent, reminded the majority of what happened in the 1930's when willful judges decided that mining and manufacturing were not "commerce." He warned against "ignoring the painful lesson learned in 1937."
In the A.A.A. case in 1936 Justice Harlan F. Stone, dissenting, said the decision reflected the notion "that it is the business of courts to sit in judgment on the wisdom of legislative action." Justice Souter, echoing that theme, said it was not for the Supreme Court to say "whether Congress was correct" in passing the school gun law. "The only question is whether the legislative judgment is within the realm of reason."
When it comes to individual rights such as freedom of speech, the courts have a special duty to scrutinize what legislators do. For minorities by definition are not likely to be protected in legislatures. But the claims of states' rights have ample influence in Congress.
There is a wonderful irony in the Supreme Court stepping forward today -- or more accurately stepping backward -- to limit the legislative power of the Federal Government. States' rights used to be a rallying cry for conservatives, but today they are demanding Federal action in all kinds of areas traditionally left to the states.
Federalization of tort law is an example. Conservatives are even demanding a Federal medical malpractice law. The Wall Street Journal editorial page, voice of the right, is all for Federal tort reform -- but it cheered the Supreme Court decision on the school gun law. It depends whose ox is gored.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Progress Seen In Auto Talks With Japan

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 27

 BODY:
Negotiators from the United States and Japan reported some progress in trade talks on automobiles and auto parts today, raising the possibility that an agreement could be reached next month and avert American sanctions on Japan.
Officials from both sides said, however, that wide differences still remained between the countries following talks here among technical experts on Wednesday and today. 
 "I don't think we're near an agreement," one American official said today. "But we both have a better understanding of what the U.S. side is looking for and what is possible on the Japanese side."
But a Japanese official was a little more positive. "The gap is narrowing," he said, adding that the talks this week were far more "constructive" than ones last week in Washington, when no progress was made. On some issues, he said, "I think the positions of the two countries are not very far apart."
The Clinton Administration, frustrated that nearly two years of negotiations have proved fruitless, has threatened to impose sanctions on Japan if there is no accord soon. A list of Japanese products on which 100 percent tariffs might be levied may be published as early as next month.
If Washington does take that step, Japan has threatened to break off the negotiations and file a complaint with the World Trade Organization.
Some United States officials had been hoping for an agreement by late next week, when the top trade officials of the United States, Japan, Canada and the European Union will be meeting near Vancouver, British Columbia. At that time, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, is expected to meet Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Minister of International Trade and Industry of Japan.
Officials from both sides said today that it might be difficult to reach an accord in Vancouver. But one American official said that the chance of at least a conceptual agreement "is a lot higher than some of the skeptics would give it."
The automotive sector, which accounts for a large chunk of America's trade deficit with Japan, is the only priority area under the 1993 trade "framework" between the two nations for which an agreement has not been reached.
Washington has three goals in the talks: increasing the number of Japanese car dealers that carry American vehicles; relaxing regulations on automobile inspections and repairs in Japan so that more American spare parts can be used, and increasing purchases of American parts by Japanese automobile manufacturers.
The Japanese official, who like the American officials spoke on the condition of anonymity, said, "We understand that somehow an agreement can be reached" on the first two issues.
Japan is likely to agree, for instance, to remove restrictions on certain replacement auto parts.
But the issue of parts purchases remains a big obstacle. Washington has said it cannot envision an agreement that does not include voluntary plans by Japan's auto manufacturers to increase their purchases of American parts. But Japan has said such purchase plans are a matter for the private sector and has refused to talk about them in the discussions between the two governments.
American officials have directly approached Japan's automobile manufacturers, but those companies have said they will not increase the size of the purchase plans they announced last year.
"I don't think it's reasonable that we private Japanese companies are compelled by the United States Government to draft a voluntary program," said Hiroshi Okuda, executive vice president of the Toyota Motor Corporation. "I think there's something wrong there."
Japanese Government officials and auto executives argue that the Japanese industry is no position to increase purchases of foreign parts. Production of cars in Japan has fallen for four consecutive years. And Japanese auto companies, some of which are suffering heavy losses, have been trying desperately to cut costs, partly by reducing their expenditures on parts and materials by up to 30 percent in the next two to three years.
But Japanese companies also insisted last year they would not issue such plans only to suddenly announce them. One factor that could make them change their minds this time is that the sharp rise of the Japanese yen against the dollar makes it more attractive to buy American parts, which are becoming cheaper in Japan, and to shift more auto production to the United States.

HEADLINE: Justice Department Views Microsoft From Both Sides

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
On Monday, Justice Department officials were in Federal court defending Microsoft against allegations of monopolistic practices. Today, Justice Department officials went to another Federal court to file suit against Microsoft, contending it would violate antitrust laws with a planned merger.
That peculiar combination gave the Justice Department the appearance of having reversed itself with dizzying speed. But antitrust law is less a matter of broad philosophy than of individual cases, and the Justice Department argued today that there was no inconsistency in pursuing such apparently different outcomes in different cases. 
 Antitrust lawyers and economists -- even Microsoft's top lawyer -- generally agreed. But some lawyers watching the case also noted that legal and political factors might have added to the department's motivation for today's action.
At a purely legal level, today's lawsuit was brought under a different antitrust law from the battle fought during the last year. "I don't see that there's any inconsistency," said James F. Rill, a former Assistant Attorney General for Antitrust in the Bush Administration. "You've got two different statutes, a merger law and a monopolistic" practices law, he said.
At the level of economic theory, the two battles are also different.
One old dispute is whether the aggressive marketing practices that led to Microsoft's dominance in the field of operating systems -- programs like DOS and Windows that control how computers organize and process information -- was anti-competitive. By contrast, the struggle that began today concerns whether Microsoft would exert monopoly power if it were allowed to merge its software empire with that of Intuit Inc., the leading producer of personal finance software. (Intuit produces Quicken, the highly popular program for managing accounts and budgets, and two income tax preparation programs.)
In other words, a company seeking to maintain a large market share through possibly anti-competitive business practices poses one set of economic issues. A company with a large market share that tries to merge with another major company in a similar market poses a different set of issues.
In the first legal battle, the Justice Department sought last year to prevent Microsoft from using what were seen as anti-competitive marketing tactics to maintain its overwhelming share of the market for operating systems software. The Justice Department put little emphasis on the sheer size of Microsoft's 70 percent to 80 percent market share.
When Microsoft agreed last summer to abandon the contested marketing practices, the Justice Department accepted the arrangement. It even joined Microsoft's side before the United States Court of Appeals on Monday to defend the deal.
The Justice Department came under heavy criticism last summer for settling the case. That led some lawyers to suggest today that the department was being tough on Microsoft in the Intuit case to placate its critics and to show the Court of Appeals that it was keeping a close eye on Microsoft.
Steven C. Sunshine, the Deputy Assistant Attorney General for mergers who handled the Intuit and Microsoft merger case today, said there were no such motives. He argued that the the timing of the two cases was coincidental. "The facts are completely separate," he said.
He said that since he joined the Justice Department in the summer of 1993, it has expressed concern about 35 mergers, either by filing lawsuits or by warning the companies of anti-competition problems. In 25 to 30 of these mergers, the companies reached a settlement with the Justice Department and the merger was concluded, he said.
The Justice Department has reached settlements in other mergers by requiring that legal barriers be erected between business units to prevent employees in different divisions from working together in anti-competitive ways. But Mr. Sunshine ruled out such a settlement in the Microsoft case.
"The problems here are fundamental and the remedy is to stop the merger, and that's what we asked the court to do," Mr. Sunshine said.
And William H. Neukom, the senior vice president for law and corporate affairs at Microsoft, was skeptical that his company would accept any such arrangement. "We don't like fire walls very much between technical communities," he said, "and we don't think there's any basis for that in this case."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Are Lower Ahead of Report on Growth

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were lower yesterday, weighed down by concern that the economy has not slowed enough to ward off fears of inflation.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 5/32 , to 10318/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 7.33 percent, from 7.32 percent on Wednesday. 
 Some of yesterday's softness in prices was attributed to profit taking ahead of today's preliminary report on the gross domestic product for the first quarter.
The data are expected to show a 3.1 percent growth rate, which is not as strong as the 5.1 percent in the fourth quarter of last year but strong enough to keep inflation fears in the forefront of market worries. Indeed, traders were so focused on today's report that yesterday they shrugged off data showing more Americans than expected filed claims for jobless benefits the previous week.
Traders say that if today's number is stronger than expected, it will revive expectations of an increase in interest rates. But data showing faster growth could also support the dollar. A stronger dollar would in the long run bolster bond prices.
The dollar weighed on the market throughout the day. While it edged up against the German mark yesterday, it slipped against the Japanese yen. Ray Worseck, chief economist and manager at A. G. Edwards & Sons, said the dollar's recent plight would turn around some day "and the market will use it as an excuse to buy."
The Chicago Purchasing Managers' index for April, which is also scheduled to be released today, is expected to slip to 50.3 from 55. The University of Michigan confidence index is also due and is seen as slipping to 93.2 from 93.8.
Yesterday the market continued to grapple with supply as the Treasury held its fourth auction of the week, including the regular weekly bill auction on Monday, with the sale of $17.75 billion in new 52-week bills. It brought the week's total of Treasury securities auctioned to $70.2 billion.
The average rate at auction yesterday was 5.90 percent in what was described by some analysts as an average auction. It was 12 basis points lower than the last auction and the lowest average since Oct. 13, 1994, when it was 5.72 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Otherwise the market resorted to it general pattern of the last three days, showing weakness early and then some improvement later in the day, said James W. Schroeder, a Treasury-bond analyst with MMS International in Chicago.
Although the long maturities did not break out in either direction yesterday, Mr. Schroeder said, "I think the potential is there for tomorrow because we have been so tightly confined."
Elsewhere, the Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it had affirmed the long-term BBB rating and A-2 commercial paper on the debt of the Nissan Motor Company and its subsidiaries. But S.& P. changed its outlook on the company to "negative," suggesting a possible rating cut in the future. The rating agency cited the potential negative effects of the appreciation of the Japanese yen.
While Nissan's current long-term debt rating is BBB, the fourth-highest grade S.&. P. awards, and its lowest investment-quality rating. A rating of BB or lower would be considered speculative, or junk. Total rated debt is about $3.6 billion.
Nissan relies heavily on Japanese exports, which are made more expensive by a strong yen. A downgraded debt rating would make it more expensive for Nissan to borrow money.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Dow Chemical and Grace Post Profits Above Expectations

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: MIDLAND, Mich., April 27

 BODY:
Two large chemical companies, the Dow Chemical Company and W. R. Grace & Company, reported better-than-expected earnings today, reflecting a chemical industry boom in which other companies have shared.
Higher prices and increased shipments, especially from surging overseas economies, have helped companies restore profit margins that were anemic last year. 
 "The chemical industry is benefiting from global supply and demand," said Paul Raman, a chemicals analyst at S. G. Warburg & Company. "It will continue very strongly through 1995 into 1996."
Profit margin improvement was particularly noticeable at Dow Chemical. It's after-tax profit margin, excluding nonrecurring items, rose to 10.6 percent in the first quarter, from 3.9 percent a year ago.
The company, based here, said it had net income of $584 million, or $2.10 a share, after a charge of $49 million, or 13 cents a share, for an acquisition made by its 71 percent-owned Marion Merrell Dow subsidiary. In the quarter a year ago, a charge of $8 million, or 3 cents, related to losses from short-term investments made by Marion Merrell Dow resulted in net income of $173 million, or 62 cents.
On an operating basis, profit was equal to $2.23 a share, well above analysts' expectations of $1.78 a share, and the 1994 quarter's 65 cents. Revenue rose 33.3 percent, to $5.96 billion from $4.54 billion.
Shares rose 50 cents, to $70.375, on trading of 1.00 million shares, exceeding its three-month daily average of 967,900.
W. R. Grace, based in Boca Raton, Fla., said first-quarter net earnings rose 24.3 percent, to $47.5 million, or 50 cents a share, from $38.2 million, or 41 cents, a year earlier.
On an operating basis, the earnings were up 57 percent, excluding a $12.5 million charge, equal to 14 cents a share, related to its management turmoil. The specialty chemicals and health care company took the charge to settle the contract of its former chief executive, J. P. Bolduc, who was forced out in March, for legal, pension and other corporate expenses.
Without the charge, profit from operations was $60.0 million, or 64 cents a share, well ahead of analysts' expectations of 46 cents a share.
Revenue rose 25 percent, to $1.35 billion from $1.08 billion.
Shares in Grace rose 75 cents to close at $53.625 today on trading of 729,100 shares, surpassing its three-month daily average of 643,100.
"All of the company's six core businesses and every geographic region contributed to the excellent results in the quarter," said Thomas Holmes, acting chief executive.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims in Unexpected Climb

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for state unemployment benefits climbed unexpectedly last week to the highest level since the start of the year, the Government said today.
New claims for unemployment pay rose by 8,000 in the week that ended last Saturday, to 349,000, from a revised 341,000 the week before. The total was the highest since 356,000 in the week that ended on Jan. 7, the Labor Department said. 
 The weekly total exceeded Wall Street economists' forecasts of 342,000 initial claims.
The closely watched four-week moving average of new jobless claims, which smooths out weekly fluctuations and is considered a more accurate barometer of the job market, climbed to the highest level since last July.
The average was up by 2,750, to 344,000 applications, from a revised 341,250 the prior week and the highest since 347,750 in the week ended July 30 last year.
The department said a total of 2,472,000 people were receiving state benefits in the week ended April 15, up from a revised 2,466,000 the week before.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Weakens Against Yen But Gains Ground vs. the Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar changed course against the yen yesterday, weakening on speculation that automotive trade talks between the United States and Japan would collapse and on fears of further slowing in the American economy.
But the dollar strengthened against the German mark, which currency dealers called the indirect result of a rebounding Italian lira. Many dealers were selling marks and buying lire on optimism that the Italian Government could work out a pension plan that would lessen its borrowing needs. 
 Dealers described the trading volume as light, which exaggerated moves in the market and left the dollar mostly higher against other currencies. They attributed the sluggish trading to a typical end-of-month decline and the coming May Day holiday in Europe, with many traders taking off early.
"The market doesn't know which direction it wants to turn in," said Elena Shperling, chief dealer at the New York branch of the Banco di Sicilia.
After its biggest one-day gain against the yen in 20 months on Wednesday, the dollar retreated yesterday in late New York trading to 83.68 yen from 83.80 yen. The dollar edged up to 1.3785 marks, from 1.3700 marks on Wednesday. The British pound rose to $1.6173 from $1.6152.
Part of the dollar's decline against the yen came from traders who sold to lock in profits from the rally Wednesday, when the market reacted to a pledge by the Group of Seven industrial nations to work toward a stronger dollar.
But uncertainty over the trade talks between the United States and Japan also emerged as a reason for some of the selling.
"There were some rumors going through the market that the auto talks broke down," said Charles Spence, director of treasury sales at the New York branch of the Standard Chartered Bank of Britain.
Negotiators from the United States and Japan said yesterday that there had been some progress in the talks but that wide differences remained.
If the talks fail, the United States is expected to tolerate a lower dollar, since that would make Japanese cars more expensive in the United States and hurt Japan's exporting strength.
Others attributed the dollar's weakness against the yen to expectations that today's report on the United State gross domestic product for the first quarter would show more evidence of a slowdown. A slowing economy diminishes the likelihood that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates, which tend to bolster the dollar.

HEADLINE: TV WEEKEND;
Saigon in the Final Hours Before the Surrender

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
"The Fall of Saigon" is a vivid, exciting, painful account of the final hours before the unconditional surrender of South Vietnam, 20 years ago this weekend. Meshing newsreel clips with first-person accounts, the two-hour documentary brings back the desperate efforts to save the Vietnamese who had worked with the United States and still trusted their allies not to desert them. The overriding feeling is one of shame over the many who were left behind to the mercies of the triumphant Communists. A former Central Intelligence Agency man says, "I couldn't look into their eyes."
Most of these two hours is focused on the American Embassy, into which South Vietnamese flocked in hopes of refuge and escape as North Vietnamese troops converged on their city. What one official calls "a daisy chain of helicopters" carried thousands from the embassy rooftop to waiting aircraft carriers. As depicted tonight, it was a heroic achievement. But errors were made and time ran out; hundreds had to be left behind. Many more Vietnamese remained in the city, waiting for promised pick-ups that never came. 
 Scenes of panic on the streets -- looting, South Vietnamese soldiers shedding their uniforms and throwing away their weapons, people running every which way to escape the inevitable -- are effectively juxtaposed with the high-pressure orderliness of the exodus by helicopter.
No comment is made here on the larger issue of responsibility for the war itself, lately reawakened by Robert S. McNamara's apologia. Gerald R. Ford, the President at the time, and Henry A. Kissinger, who was both Secretary of State and National Security Adviser, express their regrets. "For me a great emptiness, a great sadness," says Mr. Kissinger. But far more affecting are the words of one of the last few exhausted marines to be carried off in the last helicopter: "Most of us were crying."
 
'Martin's Lament'
'Religion and Race
in America'
PBS, tonight at 10
(Channel 13 in New York)
Can America's black and white Christians worship together, as the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. envisioned? That is the significant question addressed with more earnestness than inspiration by "Martin's Lament: Religion and Race in America." In visits to two churches in Indianapolis, one mostly black, one mostly white, pastors and congregants talk about the difficulty of meeting the needs of people with different traditions.
The burden, all agree, is on whites not just to allow blacks to sit alongside them of a Sunday morning, but also to change church practices to make minorities truly welcome. Members of a small interracial Roman Catholic congregation tell of the satisfactions of mixing cultural traditions. Full Sunday morning integration, a few of those interviewed say, means moving away from the images of Jesus as a white male (a professor at the Howard University School of Divinity announces that Jesus was definitely black) and joining in efforts toward economic and political equality.
Now and then the program comes to life, but the slow motion, the relentless church music and the repetition of fairly simple ideas can act as a soporific. Just like some Sunday services.
 
'Newt Gingrich and the Republican Revolution'
A&E, tonight at 9
 Politics, not policy, is the subject of this brisk two-hour review of the first 100 days of the Republican-controlled Congress. It is a mostly familiar but tidily packaged account of how Newt Gingrich got to be the first Republican Speaker of the House in 40 years and about what he has been up to since. The energetic and combative Mr. Gingrich is described as combining a distaste for the spirit of the 1960's with a hankering after some Newt-age future.
The program does a little score-keeping, but offers no evaluation of the famous Contract With America as bills reach the Senate and White House. Among the many Capitol players on camera in brief snatches are Mr. Gingrich himself and such allies as Representative Henry J. Hyde, now head of the House Judiciary Committee, and adversaries like Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Minority leader. You can also hear from Mr. Gingrich's biographer, Jeff Kamen, who seems to be under the impression that his subject is a mixture of the better parts of St. Paul and Paul Bunyan.

HEADLINE: Where the 45's Keep Spinning

BYLINE: By NEIL STRAUSS 

 BODY:
THE singles' bar is dying in Manhattan. Some say this is because of economics; others say it's because of changing times. But there is no denying that it's getting harder and harder to find a good single in New York City. It's all CD's nowadays.
We are talking about jukeboxes, of course, those hulking machines that stand ostentatiously against the wall in most bars night after night, sucking up quarters and dollar bills and giving back a mood. It can be a rock-and-roll, hip-hop, oldies, jazz, disco, Latin or opera mood. Jukeboxes offer interactive entertainment in its rawest form, giving patrons the power of ambiance control, something few other public places allow for. 
 But exactly 10 years ago, the jukebox experienced the most profound innovation in its 106-year history: the birth of the CD jukebox. Originally, jukeboxes played wax cylinders. Then they switched to 78-rpm singles, to 33-rpm singles and, eventually, to 45's. Despite all these changes, jukeboxes were always oriented toward the purity of a single song, usually a popular hit or a novelty. That is, until the compact disk came along and the age of album jukebox began.
In addition to reviving an ailing jukebox industry, the CD changed the faces of bars everywhere. On the plus side, customers are now able to choose from more than 1,000 songs on the average 100-CD jukebox, instead of from the 200 songs on the average 100-single vinyl jukebox. But on the other hand, each song on a CD jukebox costs 50 cents instead of a quarter, and jukebox junkies can subject the patrons of a bar to a 75-minute marathon of music by a single artist by playing one CD from beginning to end. Also, 45's are made for songs that are no more than three and a half minutes (longer singles cost extra to make). With CD's, a popular song like Led Zeppelin's "Stairway to Heaven" can last eight minutes, which can be grueling for a bar patron who's not a classic-rock fan or who's just plain sick of the song.
Nonetheless, Manhattan bars have been trading in their vinyl jukeboxes for CD ones at an alarming rate. The remaining vinyl machines are starting to look like museum pieces. At P. J. Clarke's on the Upper East Side, for example, a CD jukebox sits against the southern wall of the bar, filled with everything from cartoon music to opera to Broadway show tunes; immortalized above it is a picture of the bar's former 1950's Seeburg vinyl jukebox, lovingly photographed and framed like a dear, departed ancestor.
Finding a New York bar that has kept its vinyl jukebox can be hard. Even the seediest of dives, where cockroaches roam the walls and glasses are decorated with traces of lipstick from customers past, have gone digital. But a few bar owners have stuck with vinyl, and almost all of them are proud of their decision, carefully stocking their machines with an interesting array of singles.
"To me, selecting music for a jukebox is like scoring a film," said Philip Hartman, a screenwriter who is an owner of the Two Boots pizza chain, which has an early-1970's Rowe/AMi jukebox in its East Village restaurant. "When you choose the music, you have to be sensitive to your audience and give them songs that are appropriate to their mood and background."
The singles on the Two Boots jukebox, culled in part from Mr. Hartman's collection of nearly 5,000 singles, range from African music by Fela to bubble-gum pop by the Ohio Express to music by New York bands like Helmet, White Zombie and Sammy, all of which have at least one member who used to work at Two Boots or at Mr. Hartman's other East Village restaurant, the Levee, which recently burned down.
Mr. Hartman takes such good care of his jukebox that he even writes out the label for each song himself. "Everything has to be in my handwriting," he said. "And it has to be done with a certain brand of pen and in certain colors. The jukebox is as much a part of the place as the menu is."
 
San Francisco Native
 The world's first jukebox, experts say, ate its initial nickel on Nov. 23, 1889, at the Palais Royale Saloon in San Francisco. It contained only one song on a wax cylinder, and customers had to listen to it through a tube held to the ear. In 1906, freedom of choice prevailed and John Gabel's hand-cranked Automatic Entertainer replaced listening tubes with a giant amplifying horn, supplanted cylinders with flat records and offered several selections. Thus, the modern jukebox was born, replacing player pianos everywhere, from social clubs to brothels. In the late 1930's, the word jukebox was coined, most likely derived from the Southern black slang word "jook," to dance.
According to the Amusement and Music Operators Association, there are currently 250,000 jukeboxes in the country. Of those, 40 percent play CD's and 60 percent play vinyl. In New York City, which is always trying to be one step ahead of the rest of the country, the number of CD jukeboxes has far surpassed that of vinyl jukeboxes. Elsewhere in the country, CD jukeboxes are taking over more slowly.
"In the next few years, you're going to see the percentage of vinyl jukeboxes keep dropping," said Fred Newton, a spokesman for the Amusement and Music Operators Association. "It usually takes a generation for a new technology to sink in. That's what happened when jukeboxes switched from playing 78's to 33-rpm records. So we're about midstream in the whole changeover from 45's to CD's."
At places like Showman's Cafe, a Harlem bar with an old-timey feel, it's easy to understand the circumstances leading to the disappearance of jukeboxes that play older formats. Standing in the back of the bar is a 1970's Seeburg Super Disco jukebox, all flashy colors and lights, which stands out from the bar's more basic 40's-style jazz decor. The Super Disco machine is stocked with singles that range from rare jazz songs by Art Blakey, Horace Silver and Jazz at the Philharmonic to contemporary soul by Whitney Houston and Luther Vandross. But the jukebox is on its last legs and most of the singles it plays wobble and warble.
"They've been asking us to get a CD jukebox because this one has been dying slowly," said Mona Lopez, the bar's manager, referring to the jukebox owner who rents the machine to them. "We'll probably get the CD jukebox because it's getting too hard to find the vinyl 45's that we want, especially since we cater to an older crowd."
 
The Atmosphere Factor
 Another argument in favor of the CD jukebox, some people say, is that compact disks offer better sound quality than vinyl. Michael Roscishewsky, the manager of the Blue and Gold Tavern in the East Village, thinks so. But that doesn't mean he's going to trade in his analog jukebox for a digital one. "We've always had a vinyl jukebox here, ever since my grandfather owned the place," he said. "CD sound quality may be better, but people can go home and listen to their CD's. Vinyl has its own feeling that suits our atmosphere."
William Bunch, whose quest to find America's best jukebox is documented in his recent book, "Jukebox America" (St. Martin's Press), said he felt the sound of vinyl jukeboxes was warmer and more intimate. "There's a whole sensation to vinyl jukeboxes that you don't get with CD ones," he said. "A good jukebox has been played so much you get to hear the scratch and fuzz of the needle dropping on the record. You will find some obscurities on CD jukeboxes, but by and large I think the great jukebox songs are one-shots or oddities or neat, alternative songs that you tend to find only on vinyl."
Jeremy Tepper, who publishes the magazine Street Beat, a glossy guide to coin-operated amusement in bars, said that vinyl also had a hipness factor. With the television series "Happy Days" in mind, he said: "When a record starts skipping, you can just kick the jukebox to fix it. But that doesn't work with CD's. And with vinyl, I always liked the idea that it was cooler to choose the B-side of a single than the A-side."
Mr. Tepper is probably New York's foremost jukebox expert. In addition to founding Street Beat, he runs his own record label, Diesel Only, which puts out mostly vinyl 45's by new bands and distributes them to jukeboxes nationwide. Street Beat's list of the most-requested singles on America's jukeboxes reads like a guide to a specific genre of music that could be lost if vinyl disappears from bars. These jukebox tunes illuminate a male world of drinking, bad pick-up lines and general chest-thumping, and include Clarence Carter's "Strokin'," Confederate Railroad's "Trashy Women," Showdown's "Rodeo Song" and, the song that results when men follow the advice in these songs too literally, George Thorogood's "I Drink Alone."
"I think there's a subset of hits that are pretty much resigned to jukebox play," Mr. Tepper said. "Unlike the current low-fi, indie-rock singles that are coming out, these records are not for collectors. They're designed to be heard in jukeboxes and bars. Some of them are too risque for radio, anyway."
Mr. Bunch credits the vinyl jukebox with helping to kick-start rock-and-roll. "Jukeboxes were a watermark in the creation of the music we love today," he said. "If you go back to the 30's, the record industry was dominated by a few New York companies that were putting out Mantovani kind of things. But if you went out to a town in Illinois or Mississippi, the local people were cutting records for $20 and getting it on the local jukebox. So people out in the heartland were listening to their own music, instead of letting record labels dictate it to them. And that helped Robert Johnson, Louis Jordan and everything that became rock-and-roll."
 
Hot Off the Press
 This process is still occurring. In general, young bands will press their own vinyl single before making a costlier CD. Nightingale, a bar in the East Village, supports local bands with its worn-out Rowe/AMi jukebox, which stocks almost exclusively singles by New York rockers past and present, like the Wives, Jono Manson and the Mighty Sweetones and Simon and the Bar Sinisters. The jukebox even includes eight or so singles released on Mr. Tepper's Diesel Only label, including one by the band he plays in, the World Famous Bluejays.
One problem with many singles that bands release themselves or on small labels, Tom Hosier, the manager of Nightingale, said, is that the records have small holes in the center, so that they can fit directly onto a record player but not a jukebox. But this isn't a problem for those who know where to go: two record stores, Bleecker Bob's in Greenwich Village and Downstairs Records in midtown Manhattan, will for a nominal fee widen the holes in these 45's so that they can fit on a jukebox.
Two of Manhattan's best vinyl jukeboxes are at two East Village restaurant-bars -- Great Jones Cafe and Baby Jake's -- the former because of the selection and the latter because of the jukebox itself. Great Jones's Rowe/AMi, built in the early 1980's shortly before the introduction of the CD jukebox, functions the same way a good radio station should. It plays songs most people have never heard but should. Its wide selection of roots music includes Slim Gaillard's "Yip Roc Heresy," Bill Doggett's "Gumbo," Lowell Fulson's "Make a Little Love" and Edgar Blanchard's "Lonesome Guitar."
"That jukebox is there for every 10th customer," Bill Judkins, who manages Great Jones, said. "Nine people walk in there and say, 'I don't know any of these records.' Then the 10th person walks in and can't believe that this obscure song he knows can be found on a jukebox anywhere. I'm always happy when someone walks in there with a note pad and writes down a couple of titles that he wants to go find."
At Baby Jake's, the jukebox is a testament to the pre-rock era. Dividing different sections of songs on the 1950's Seeburg Select-O-Matic 100 are title cards for "Hawaiian Music," "Blues and Novelties," "Hillbilly" and "Hymns and Spirituals." Unfortunately, the songs on the jukebox, a mix of classic oldies and new hits, aren't faithful to the title cards; but they can still be heard for 1950's prices: three songs for a quarter.
Anyone wishing to take a tour of Manhattan's jukeboxes would do well to stop at the Grassroots Tavern in the East Village. There, one can see what happens when an industry can't make up its mind. The bar's Rowe/AMi jukebox can play more than 80 singles, in addition to six CD's. It's what is known as a combo jukebox, and there aren't many left now that jukebox manufacturers have decided on the CD as their format of choice.
"I love this jukebox," said John Schrader, a 21-year-old student, as he selected one song from the soundtrack to "Pulp Fiction" and a Bob Dylan single. "I love the sound of vinyl, but I like being able to choose whatever I want off a CD. So you get the best of both worlds."
 
Bars True to Vinyl
 Here is a sampling of bars in Manhattan that have vinyl on their jukeboxes.

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Donald G. McNeil Jr. 

 BODY:

Hard-Nosed Mysticism
The premise of the show now in previews at the American Jewish Theater is catchier than that of most new musicals. The show is set in the Ottoman Empire in 1665 and follows a little-known chapter in Jewish history: Shabbatai Sevi -- a mystic fixated on a Talmudic saying that the Messiah will arrive when all men are holy or all are sinners, and sure that holiness was impossible -- attracted hundreds of thousands of converts to his doctrine of universal sin. He married a Christian prostitute at his delayed bar mitzvah and tried to find a way through evil to perform "the great tikkun," or rectification, that would repair a shattered God. 
 "Shabbatai," by Michael Schubert and Michael Edwin, has no more information about the movement than would fit in one encyclopedia paragraph, and it keeps slipping its 17th-century mooring by using rapping rabbis and Neil Diamond jokes. But it does fit right into the American Jewish Theater's tradition of spoiling for a fight.
While other theaters have lobby photos of past productions, Stanley Brechner, the artistic director, has posted an Anti-Semitism Hall of Fame. Another clipping right near the box office is about his 1993 battle with the Roundabout Theater over his cramped basement space. Last year, the theater's window was smashed by black youngsters who were upset over racial taunts in "The Day the Bronx Died."
In the fall, Mr. Brechner was eager to describe how his own subscribers flung their tickets in his face after "Have You Spoken to Any Jews Lately?," which set a "Twilight Zone"-version of the Holocaust in an American resort town. Others were upset by "Hey, Buddy," because the young Jew's response to anti-Semitism is murder.
Now "Shabbatai" walks the line. In one scene, a Torah is torn in half; in another, one is walked on. The song "Not Another False Messiah" manages to equate David Koresh, Jimmy Swaggart, Jim Jones and Sun Myung Moon with Rabbi Menachem Schneerson, the late Lubavitcher spiritual leader, and to toss off a similar crack about the Pope. Can protests be far behind?
"Yes, I do want to pick a fight," Mr. Brechner said this week. "You reach a point where you've done the revivals and the cute plays, and you've catered to your audience and to the critics. But if you're going to do Jewish theater, there has to be a reason for it. It should have an edge."
 
When Life Was Simpler
 It never fails. Let a production claim a record -- as "Love! Valour! Compassion!" claimed this week to have paid back its investors in an unprecedented six weeks -- and phone calls come in saying, "But you forgot. . . ."
One of those calls mentioned Bernard Slade's "Tribute," starring Jack Lemmon as a joker forced to look back at his life when he discovers he has leukemia. In 1978, it made Broadway history when the producer, Morton Gottlieb, paid his investors back at the opening night party.
Admittedly, the parallels aren't exact. With Mr. Lemmon's star power, "Tribute" did huge grosses during its tryouts in Boston and Toronto; that's where the money came from. Many producers who choose to do pre-Broadway tours, like Fran and Barry Weissler, are able to earn enough to arrive in Times Square essentially paid for.
In an interview this week, Mr. Gottlieb said many of his hits, which included "Sleuth" and "Same Time Next Year," paid back quickly.
"But life was simpler then," he said. "I'd take a theater that hadn't been used for a long time and make deals with the owners and the unions. Costs weren't as high. And you could get people to give you things for just a mention in the program. Tavern on the Green did our opening-night party for 'Tribute' for free."
Mr. Gottlieb is still known for making a cult of thrift. He carries food home from theater party buffets; the highest compliment he once paid his general manager on "Coco" was that "he made Hepburn fly economy."
At 73, he travels by bicycle instead of splurging on subways or taxis. In 1968, he did "Lovers," with Art Carney, and there was a bike in the show and an extra in case it broke. "I'm still riding that understudy," he said.
 
Musical Chairs
 Besides dollars, twofers and TDF vouchers, the theater has another currency, one redeemable for charitable deductions: previously owned seats.
The Atlantic, Classic Stage and the Vineyard Theaters all have matching gray chairs this year, courtesy of the Nederlander chain, which donated them after the Minskoff Theater was refurbished with cushiony red ones for "Sunset Boulevard" in the fall. The small theaters ended up with far more comfortable houses than they could have afforded.
And up in Connecticut, the Sharon Playhouse, which is reopening this summer as the Sharon Stage with Estelle Parsons and Carol Kane in "Twice Removed," a comedy about a Presidential race, will have 388 blue seats donated by the Jujamcyn chain from its refurbishing of the Virginia Theater. The rest of the Virginia's chairs went back to the chair company for freshening up.
 
Footlights
 *"Buddy: The Buddy Holly Story," which had no success on Broadway but has played for six years in the West End, showed that the English have a taste for musical biographies of popular American singers. Now its producers are trying a variant. This week, they announced "Jolson," which is to open in London in the fall with a multimillion-dollar budget and a cast of 40, and is to star Brian Conley, who has his own television comedy show.
*Having outlasted, by its own reckoning, eight Presidents, three "My Fair Lady" revivals and an actors' strike, "The Fantasticks" will turn 35 on Wednesday. That will be its 14,488th performance at the Sullivan Street Playhouse in Greenwich Village, so that the longest-running musical of all time has gone on longer than "A Chorus Line," "Les Miserables" and "42d Street" -- combined.
*Anyone who arrives by the normal 8 P.M. curtain time for "Smokey Joe's Cafe" tonight will see a pregame show put on by the understudies that everyone (except the understudies) hopes will last only half an hour. The Broadway cast will be at Shea Stadium singing "The Star-Spangled Banner" for the Mets' first home game. Then it will get a police escort back to Manhattan trying for an 8:30 curtain.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Damage Report, Mr. Caliban" -- Patrick Stewart, a member of the Royal Shakespeare Company before he was an ally of the Klingon Empire, will play Prospero in the New York Shakespeare Festival's production of "The Tempest" in Central Park this summer. George C. Wolfe, who is directing, still has some shoes to fill. He needs a few "truly expert stilt-walkers," but won't explain why.

HEADLINE: OPERA REVIEW;
Nicolai's 'Wives' as a Welcome Cutting-to-Size

BYLINE: By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
One of the pleasures of Shakespeare's "Merry Wives of Windsor" is Falstaff's deflation: this gargantuan figure of great appetites and greater pretense is finally reduced to human size. One of the pleasures provided by Otto Nicolai's 1845 version of "Merry Wives" is seeing the same thing happen to the opera form: desire, adultery, jealousy and retribution -- all the ponderous, grand themes of operatic plots -- are turned into comic divertissements, deflated into songful farce.
And one of the great pleasures of the student production of the Nicolai classic at the Manhattan School of Music is that the spirit of that deflation so often comes through. Not all of the singing is first-rate; there are times when Rosalind Elias's production strains too much for farce, and the dancing fairies that bring Falstaff to his senses are too often unintentionally campy. But even the Shakespeare play has its flaws, and on Wednesday night, a viewer was more than willing to look beyond such details for the deftly performed score (conducted by Glen Cortese) and the appealing charms of the best members of the cast. 
 A highlight was the Falstaff, who is not a student but a faculty member and veteran singer, Spiro Malas, who enjoyed much success a few years ago as Tony in the Broadway revival of "The Most Happy Fella." His drinking song, "Als Bublein klein," was intoxicating, a well-phrased, broad-gestured celebration. And when joining in the dueling duet with Mr. Ford (sung by the young baritone Maxim Zhdanovsky), Mr. Malas somehow managed to seem both self-important and deferential to his student colleague.
The other main vocal pleasure was in Madeline Bender's rendition of Mrs. Ford (she will sing again tonight, and is to be replaced in the final performance, on Sunday afternoon, by Meredith Kitchin). Ms. Bender is a graduate student of Joan Caplan and her singing was lovely, lithe and accurate and charmingly Rossinian. Heather Sarris was accomplished and forthright as her compatriot, Mrs. Page. Soo Hee An produced some fine upper-register phrases as Anne, and the rest of the cast -- Philip Torre as Mr. Page, David Blackburn as Slender, Shon Sims as Dr. Caius and Todd Horman as Fenton -- clearly enjoyed themselves as they provided pleasures to the audience.
One of Ms. Elias's innovations in this otherwise traditional staging was to add English dialogue, adapting the Shakespeare characters Quickly, Bardolph and Pistol to amplify the frivolity. The idea worked fine and would have been still more effective had the opera itself been sung in English rather than in German as "Die Lustigen Weiber von Windsor." Nicolai's music would hardly have minded. This is a cosmopolitan score, full of Italianate turns and lighthearted satire. Genre pieces -- the drinking song, the hunting song, the love duet, the Rossinian finale -- are turned into comic backdrops. Even Falstaff can seem to float. This work tapped a strain of innocent pleasure in the often solemn heritage of German Romanticism, and innocent pleasure is just what this performance provided.
