HEADLINE: East Harlem Supermarket Is Approved

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
After what he described as a sleepless night, City Councilman Guillermo Linares switched sides yesterday and cast the decisive vote as the Manhattan Borough Board approved a plan for a 53,000-square-foot Pathmark supermarket in East Harlem.
The $12 million project, which has been in the planning stages for more than four years, became the source of political, ethnic and corporate struggles in recent weeks. Opponents insisted that the huge store would drive small neighborhood shops out of business, and they criticized the government subsidies called for in the plan. But proponents said the new store would benefit customers and create jobs in the economically depressed area. 
 By Wednesday evening, opponents thought they had enough votes to block the plan, which required board approval for the sale of the city-owned lot on which the market is to be built. At 1 A.M. on Thursday, Mr. Linares telephoned one of his supporters, Alfredo Rodriguez, the owner of Associated Food Stores in East Harlem. As the two discussed the hotly contested project, Mr. Rodriguez said Mr. Linares assured him: "Alfred, I'm with you. I'm going to vote no."
But the dawn brought a change of heart for Mr. Linares, who said he switched sides only a couple of hours before the vote out of concern that the project's defeat might intensify racial polarization in the community. Many of the development's opponents are Hispanic; many supporters are black.
"The killing of this project had the potential of causing major confrontation between the African-American community and the Latino community," Mr. Linares said. Noting that he remained concerned about the impact the development will have on grocery stores in the area, Mr. Linares said, "It's time to recognize the value of change."
The sale of the land must now clear a review by the city's Economic Development Corporation and then must have final approval from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. The Mayor, in a terse statement yesterday, said, "I will review the borough board's decision."
The proposal presents a delicate political problem for the Mayor, since Hispanic small-business owners have formed an important element of his support. Local bodega owners have led opposition to the plan. But Council members on both sides of the issue said they did not expect the Mayor to halt the project at this juncture.
Mr. Linares's announcement that he would vote in favor of the project led to applause and jeers from a contentious standing-room-only crowd in the Manhattan Borough President's office.
As the final 7-to-5 vote was tallied, Mr. Rodriguez sprang from his seat. Leaning across the boardroom table and angrily pointing his finger at Mr. Linares, he shouted, "You sold out!" Councilman Adam Clayton Powell 4th, who represents the district where the store will be built and has led the opposition to it, accused Mr. Linares of succumbing to "pressure or deals."
One Harlem couple at the meeting, Pauline Morris, 30, and her husband, Gregory, 47, said that the new supermarket and pharmacy to be built at 125th Street and Third Avenue would be a boon to neighborhood residents. Because Mr. Morris uses a wheelchair, his wife said that "we can't get around inside the small grocery stores in our area, and the selection is bad. We're happy about this."
Surveys have suggested that a majority of residents, both black and Hispanic, want the large selection, the convenience and the 200 jobs that the supermarket is expected to provide. But a feverish lobbying campaign by mostly Hispanic East Harlem merchants had produced significant opposition in the community and on the borough board. In addition to the threat to existing businesses, opponents had criticized the Federal and state grants that the project's nonprofit development consortium is receiving.
For Mr. Linares, who had been working with the opposition, his reversal was an exercise of political independence that some of his colleagues suggested might undermine his future trustworthiness. As the city's only elected Dominican-American official, Mr. Linares represents Washington Heights, Inwood and Marble Hill, communities heavily studded with Dominican-owned stores.
"Yesterday in the afternoon when it became apparent that the project was virtually killed," Mr. Linares said yesterday, "I began searching in my mind and conscience for what would be in the best interest of the community." Looking shaken after the vote, he added, "I never thought it would be this difficult."
The borough board -- which consists of Manhattan's 10 Council members, Borough President Ruth Messinger and the chairman of the affected community board (in this case Eddie Baca from Community Board 11) -- was required to vote on the sale of the city-owned property to the developers, the East Harlem Abyssinian Triangle Corporation.
Ms. Messinger, who supported the project from the beginning, and the developers said they were disappointed that Mayor Giuliani had not publicly supported the proposal.
The Rev. Calvin O. Butts, pastor of Harlem's Abyssinian Baptist Church, which has a community development arm that is part of the consortium developing the project, said: "I'm very surprised by the Mayor. He said to me on two occasions, face to face, that he supported us."
The borough board's two Republican members, Charles Millard and Andrew Eristoff, who voted against the project, said they had not discussed their votes with the Mayor. Mr. Millard said he knew the Mayor had "certainly stopped pushing" for the project. In addition to the Federal subsidies, Mr. Millard said he felt the project had political flaws.
"This is a Hispanic community and many of the community leaders there felt left out," he said.
Ms. Messinger surprised some board members when she told them that although she usually did not vote on board matters except in case of a tie, she was going to vote in this case. "I usually don't vote since I chair the meetings," Ms. Messinger said. "But this is the largest private dollar investment in Harlem in 20 years."
Pathmark, based in Woodbridge, N.J., has 142 supermarkets and 34 drug stores. The company, which last year had $4.3 billion in sales, operates 17 supermarkets and 24 drugstores in New York City, employing 5,000 people.
Under the plan, the city will sell the land to the East Harlem group for $1.5 million and provide the developers with a mortgage at one percent interest. The developers will also receive $1.1 million in Federal and state grants and a city tax exemption. Chemical Bank is providing an $8 million market-rate loan for construction, and Pathmark will take out a 25-year lease on the property, paying the developers $1.06 million a year in rent. An additional $1.5 million in investor equity is being provided by The Retail Initiative Inc., an affiliate of Local Initiatives Support Corporation, a community development group started by the Ford Foundation.
"Profits derived by the development team will be reinvested into the Harlem community for much-needed housing, health care facilities, day care, jobs and education," said Councilwoman C. Virginia Fields, who voted for the project. She said the project's results would determine whether economic development in Harlem "will go forward now, or will it take another 25 years."
The board members who voted in favor of the project were Ms. Messinger, Mr. Baca, Mr. Linares, Ms. Fields, Ronnie M. Eldridge, Thomas K. Duane and Stanley E. Michaels, who was absent from the meeting but had an assistant cast his vote. Those opposed were Mr. Powell, Mr. Millard, Mr. Eristoff, Kathryn E. Freed and Antonio Pagan.

HEADLINE: Cemetery Watchdog Goes and Debate on Regulation Begins

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
For eight months, Ralph Perfetto investigated stolen bones, backyard burials, embezzled cemetery trust funds and tales of graves dug in heaps of construction debris and refrigerator parts.
The rights of the dead are inalienable, the director of the State Division of Cemeteries liked to say. And so Mr. Perfetto, who was appointed to a six-year term last August, held public hearings, listening to complaints of twice-sold graves and price gouging, and promised prosecutions. 
 "He's a sincere man, a breath of fresh air, and we've not seen anything like him," Rabbi Elchonon Zohn, an official with a Jewish burial society in Queens, said of Mr. Perfetto when he met him at a public hearing last January. "But the cemeteries in this state have had a free run for years. I wonder if Mr. Perfetto is strong enough to last?"
Mr. Perfetto, who considered himself a kind of advocate for the dead, didn't last long. He was dismissed earlier this month by officials with Gov. George E. Pataki's administration who told him his position had been eliminated. Under a provision contained in the Governor's proposed budget, the State Division of Cemeteries is to be abolished, and the regulation of the 1,908 nonprofit cemeteries in New York is to be turned over to the Attorney General's office.
The debate over who should regulate the state's nonprofit cemeteries -- the cemeteries hold more than $1 billion in trust funds -- has opened a window into a lucrative, but often ignored industry.
Some religious and political leaders, who considered Mr. Perfetto to be the first truly zealous watchdog of the cemetery industry in years, see his firing and the elimination of his department as the Pataki administration's concession to cemetery directors who do not wish to be scrutinized. Mr. Perfetto filed suit in Manhattan earlier this month seeking to be reinstated.
But Zenia Mucha, a spokeswoman for Mr. Pataki, said Mr. Perfetto's dismissal amounted to nothing more than replacing a member of a former administration with someone "who shares our views." There is an interim cemeteries director until the post is eliminated. And she said the proposal to abolish the Division of Cemeteries was in keeping with the Governor's plan to "downsize state regulatory agencies."
For the last four decades, the financial operations of the state's nearly 2,000 nonprofit cemeteries -- there are 6,000 cemeteries in New York, counting municipal, private and religious ones -- have been overseen by the Division of Cemeteries. Annual audits of the cemeteries were conducted, and requests for price increases were reviewed. But even the cemetery owners did not consider the oversight rigorous enough.
Mr. Perfetto, a former United States Customs investigator, said that when he took over last summer, only about 250 of the nonprofit cemeteries were "on more or less solid ground." More than a half a dozen in the metropolitan area had to be taken over by receivers acting on behalf of the state.
Mr. Perfetto found that for years, some cemetery officials appeared to be embezzling money from trust funds, taking illegal loans, even paying personal mortgages with cemetery funds. He listed his findings, which included scores of examples, in a memo drawn up shortly before he was dismissed, he said.
At a series of unprecedented public hearings on cemeteries held across the city last January, dozens of people testified about being insulted and overcharged at cemeteries, of having cemetery officials lose track of who had been buried where and of having paid for the perpetual care of a relative's grave only to learn that in 1995, perpetual care is good for about eight years.
The firing of Mr. Perfetto and the proposed abolition of the Division of Cemeteries pits cemetery directors against some political and religious leaders, particularly Jewish leaders, in a sharp debate over how best to regulate the cemeteries.
Jules Polonetsky, a Democratic assemblyman from Brooklyn, calls the Pataki's administration's move "a pure and simple giveaway to the cemeteries."
"There was limited oversight of them to begin with, and now there could be less," Mr. Polonetsky said. "The people who run these cemeteries are drooling over the proposal."
One cemetery president, Dan Austin, who parts company with the others, believes that Mr. Pataki is making a mistake.
"To do away with the Division of Cemeteries would give the cemetery people the license to do what they want, and the atrocities would go on," Mr. Austin said. "The firing of Mr. Perfetto was purely political, and it basically says: the public be damned."
It is Jewish leaders who say they most fear the dismantling of the Division of Cemeteries. Because Jewish law requires speedy burials, Jewish leaders have long complained that the nonprofit cemeteries charge exorbitant fees for burial on weekends or holidays. Lobbyists for the cemeteries say they have introduced separate legislation establishing fines for price gouging to address such concerns.
Critics of Mr. Pataki's plan believe the Attorney General's office will not be willing or able to devote staff and resources to closely monitor the cemeteries.
They are further troubled that the proposal allows individual cemeteries to set their own prices for burials without prior approval by the Attorney General's office. Those concerns are not eased by the fact that one Pataki administration official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said earlier this year that Attorney General Dennis Vacco preferred not to take on the added role of overseeing the state's cemeteries.
And in a recent letter to the Governor, Rabbi Maurice D. Simokes, president of the Long Island Board of Rabbis, charged that the proposal "was virtually drafted by the cemeterians who would seem to have a direct line to the ear of the Governor."
The wife of Nick Barrella, a lobbyist for cemetery owners, is the sister-in-law of Michael Finnegan, chief counsel to Mr. Pataki. As well, the wife of Lawrence F. Sloane, another lobbyist involved in trying to abolish the Division of Cemeteries was an aide to Mr. Pataki when he was a state senator and currently holds a position in the administration.
Ms. Mucha, the Governor's spokeswoman, dismissed the claim of improper influence as "ridiculous."
And Mr. Barrella, who has played a central role in pushing for the abolition of the Division of Cemeteries, insisted that the proposal to charge the Attorney General's office with oversight responsibility would lead to a more meaningful regulation of the cemeteries. He contended that the Division of Cemeteries has been ineptly run for years and that the proposal would eliminate the division's $600,000 budget.
"No sleight of hand is being pulled here," said Mr. Barrella, the chief lobbyist for the New York State Cemeteries Association. "We are a legitimate organization, not a criminal organization."
Mr. Barrella's clients argue that their proposal would result in "more intelligent regulation" that would not burden the hundreds of small cemeteries in the state run by volunteers. They say the proposal would require cemeteries to register their officers with the Attorney General and submit certified annual reports. It would also increase the required annual contributions made by each cemetery to its perpetual care and general maintenance funds.
These officials say the proposal is essential to sustaining an industry that they admit has been plagued by mismanagement and whose fortunes have been hurt by changing demographics, increased labor costs and diminishing available space in graveyards. They believe that the many cases of malfeasance at cemeteries in the state in recent years only underscore the division's inability to adequately monitor their financial operations.
"There's no doubt cemeteries in New York are troubled," said Mr. Sloane, a consultant whose management firm has advised and represented cemeteries in New York State for years. "But I think the supervision of the troubled cemeteries would be better under the Attorney General."
A handful of prominent officials in the State Assembly predict the proposal will be eliminated before the budget is passed, and say negotiations on a resolution to the question of oversight will be lengthy.
Meanwhile, Mr. Perfetto waits to have his day in court. He has said that while "not all the people in charge of cemeteries are crooks," people trying to bury their dead with dignity and economy should not be reduced to "captive consumers who can be treated like dirt."

HEADLINE: GIULIANI'S SPENDING PLAN: THE STRATEGY;
Giuliani Frames Budget Choice: Cut Welfare, or Cut Middle-Class Services

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Unveiling his second budget yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sought to frame the fiscal debate in both New York City and Albany as a stark choice between cuts in health and welfare programs for the poor or reductions in services cherished by the middle class.
He did so by putting a contingency plan in his budget for vast cuts in libraries, schools, the city university, sanitation, and the arts that he said would have to take place unless Assembly Democrats go along with Medicaid and welfare cuts that would allow the city to stop spending $750 million on those poverty programs. 
 Tactically, that move put immediate pressure on the Democrats by casting the budget debate in class terms, with the Democrats portrayed as the advocates of what Mr. Giuliani called "wildly out of control entitlement spending at levels that are excessive compared to any other place in America."
Mr. Giuliani may also have been laying the groundwork to blame the Democrats two years from now if the city's wrenching deficits mean he has to explain to voters in an election year why there was an erosion in city services and the quality of life despite his assurances as a candidate that the city could curb spending, reduce taxes and at the same time "improve services for all New Yorkers."
For as he proposes his second budget, Mr. Giuliani faces the fiscal and political dilemma that the city's budgetary problems have not diminished under his stewardship. After a year in which Mr. Giuliani slashed $2 billion in spending and won union consent to lure 15,000 workers off the municipal payroll through buyouts, the city's deficit has only grown. Where Mr. Giuliani faced a $2.3 billion deficit coming into office, now the Mayor has to deal with a $3.1 billion deficit.
Part of the reason for the growing deficit is Mr. Giuliani's own budget policies. Almost $2 billion of the savings Mr. Giuliani achieved in his first year in office were one-time cash infusions brought about by selling assets, settling outstanding legal claims or refinancing debt, fiscal monitors say. The result is that the savings provided no long-term reduction in city spending patterns.
But the deficit has also been worsened by the sluggishness of the city's economy, which has proved far more responsive to the interest rate policies of the Federal Reserve than to the fiscal policies of the Giuliani administration.
New York City continues to lag behind the nation in economic growth. The robust job growth that occured in the first half of last year slowed in the second half so that the city saw only a net increase of 22,500 jobs. So far this year, the increase in private sector employment has been more than offset by the drop in government jobs, resulting in a net loss of 2,200 jobs.
Wall Street, which accounts for 17 percent of city tax revenues and which had been the engine leading the metropolitan region out of recession, went into a sharp slump last year as it was buffeted by the Federal Reserve's interest rate policies. As a result, the city saw a drop in tax collections that officials say is steeper than any in recent years, even those during the depths of the recession of the early 90's. And the welfare rolls rose for another year.
What all of this means is that Mr. Giuliani was faced once again with an enormous problem in his second budget. And saying that city services could not bear the brunt alone, Mr. Giuliani crafted a deficit reduction strategy that relied heavily on cutting Medicaid and welfare entitlement programs.
Originally, he had hoped to get Albany's approval to reduce Medicaid and welfare spending in the city by $1.2 billion. Now, with even Republican Gov. George E. Pataki and the Republican Senate loath to go that far, he has scaled back to $700 million the savings he expects the city to receive automatically by piggybacking on state welfare and Medicaid cuts. (The city and state poverty programs work in close tandem under state law.)
Mr. Giuliani seeks to close the rest of the deficit by asking labor to come up with $600 million in savings, by cutting agencies by $1 billion, by seeking $250 million in additional state aid, $50 million in Federal aid, selling assets and a host of smaller actions.
But the risk inherent in this strategy is that a third or more of the savings the Mayor needs is hostage to the State Legislature, which is locked in a fiercely partisan stalemate over Governor Pataki's own budget priorities and the welfare and Medicaid cuts. Just this week, the Assembly passed its own budget bills that scale back the depth of the Medicaid and welfare cuts and leave the Mayor far short of the $900 million in fiscal relief he is seeking from the state.
It remains to be seen whether Mr. Giuliani's posture of pitting welfare and Medicaid cuts against deeper cuts in services will put the pressure he desires on Assembly Democrats.
Recent polls have shown both the Governor and the Mayor's popularity ratings damaged by their budget policies, and there were signs yesterday that Democrats were not simply going to allow Mr. Giuliani to frame the debate over the budget.
"Driving an economic wedge between the people of New York will not help us reclaim our fiscal health," said Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President and a possible challenger to Mr. Giuliani in 1997. "Nor will a narrow definition of entitlements that fails to include the more than $700 million in tax relief given to businesses and property owners each year. All entitlements -- not just those for the poor -- must be on the table."
Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, left open the possibility that the Council might contest some of Mr. Giuliani's plans to move ahead with $185 million in tax cuts even as he seeks to slash spending on government and entitlements.

HEADLINE: Senator, in Fury, Advances Regulatory Bill

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
With a furious bang of his gavel, the chairman of a bitterly divided Senate Judiciary Committee today turned back the committee's Democrats and moved ahead on the most ambitious version so far of Republican legislation to roll back environmental and other regulations.
Senator Orrin G. Hatch, his voice rising in anger, abruptly ordered the legislation approved without a formal vote this morning. The chairman, a Republican from Utah, said Democrats on the committee had exhausted his patience by continuing to argue for changes in the bill. 
 The committee session, short as a thunderstorm, highlighted the increasingly fractious politics surrounding Republican proposals to roll back regulations. The legislation, similar to provisions of the Republicans' Contract With America that have already been approved by the House, would reopen a generation of environmental, health and safety rules to potential review in an effort to reduce regulatory costs on businesses.
The bill is not scheduled for floor debate until after Memorial Day, allowing ample time for some kind of compromise to emerge from the Senate's back rooms and head off a prolonged and highly partisan debate.
But that would take the cooperation of the majority leader, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, who is the prime sponsor of the bill that passed the Judiciary Committee today. So far, he has shown no interest in a more moderate version that was unanimously approved by a different Senate committee last month.
Senator Dole's preferred version, as refined by Republicans on the Judiciary Committee, contains provisions repealing the existing prohibition against cancer-causing chemical residues in processed foods, providing new defenses for companies accused of breaking pollution laws, and nullifying existing statutory and court-ordered deadlines for enforcing environmental laws.
At its heart are elaborate requirements to assess the costs and benefits of regulations, giving far more weight to economic factors than is common under existing laws.
Another feature of the proposal, and the reason for its consideration by the Judiciary Committee, is its broad new grounds for regulated businesses to challenge Federal rules in court.
The legislation approved today by the Judiciary Committee would repeal the law, known as the Delaney Clause, which prohibits residues of certain cancer-causing chemicals in processed foods. That provision was inserted in the bill at the behest of the farm, food processing and grocery industries. They have long argued that the clause is outdated and that the public can be adequately protected against cancer without flatly banning these substances.
But the Dole bill is far broader than that, potentially reopening thousands of regulations issued to enforce a generation of laws ranging from the Clean Air Act and Clean Water Act to those requiring toxic waste dumps to be cleaned up and laborers to be protected from hazards at work.
The Clinton Administration and many Democrats, joined by labor, consumer and environmental groups, strongly oppose the Judiciary Committee's bill.
Committee members who oppose the bill, although a minority, succeeded two weeks ago in delaying the panel's action until after the Congressional recess by promising Mr. Hatch that the committee could finish as soon as the Senate returned to work this week.
To Senator Hatch, that deal guaranteed that the Democrats would not try to prolong the debate. But when the committee convened early this morning, Senators Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware and Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts suggested that more time might be needed because the committee had scheduled a hearing on terrorism this afternoon. Under their goading, Mr. Hatch first bristled and finally erupted.
"It is clear that some of my colleagues on the committee wish to filibuster this measure," the chairman said, his composure draining away. "But the dilatory efforts of a few members to further delay committee action on this measure will not prevail."
"Then it's over!" Senator Hatch suddenly declared, cracking his gavel down on the wooden table. He slammed down a notebook, turned on his heel and stalked out of the room.
Because he had previously won the committee's unanimous consent to complete action without delay, he ruled, no vote was necessary.
"There's a lot of pressure on all the Republican chairmen to move things through," Senator Biden said later. "Are the trains running on time?"
The opponents are counting on Senate rules, which allow extended debate, to slow any bill like this one, which President Clinton will probably veto if it passes unchanged.
"Mr. Dole has managed to go even further than the House in providing relief for the special interests, the polluters and their lawyers," said Carol M. Browner, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. "This does not represent rational reform or refinement; this is a continuation of the frontal assault of our ability to do our job."
Senator Dole's role in pressing for a far-reaching bill could bolster his fund-raising efforts among industry groups, which have been lobbying hard for the bill, while cementing his support in the conservative wing of his party as he sets out on his quest for the 1996 Republican Presidential nomination.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

International 3-7
 
PEACE IN EL SALVADOR
Barely three years after United Nations mediators brokered a settlement to end a conflict that killed at least 75,000 people, El Salvador has been transformed by peace. 1
 
SOUTH KOREA GAS BLAST
Rescuers worked into the night to search for survivors of a gas explosion that killed at least 100, more than half of them teen-agers, in Taegu, South Korea. 3
 
ARMY LINK TO JAPANESE SECT
The Japanese Army acknowledged that two of its sergeants were secret members of the sect suspected in the nerve gas attack last month on the Tokyo subway system. 3
 
PARADE PROTOCOL IN MOSCOW

HEADLINE: Without Welfare, Giuliani Suggests, Many Might Move

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to cut welfare benefits, combined with similar proposals in Albany, could prompt many welfare recipients to move out of New York State, the Mayor said yesterday.
If welfare recipients were able to break free from their dependency on government benefits, enabling them to move freely around the country, the Mayor said, "that would be a good thing" for them. He did not directly answer a question of whether the city would be better off if many welfare recipients left town. 
 "A natural consequence of a reduction in benefits might very well be that that would happen," said Mr. Giuliani, who on Thursday released a city budget calling for reductions of $700 million in welfare and Medicaid benefits. "There was a contention back 10 years ago that's precisely what happened when Pennsylvania did away with the equivalent of Home Relief, that people moved to New York and other states. But I've never seen proof that that was the case."
The Mayor denied a report broadcast on WNYC radio yesterday quoting him as saying on Thursday that a population shift of welfare recipients out of New York would be a "good thing" for the city. Speaking to reporters at an impromptu news conference called because of the broadcast report, he said that the intention of his welfare cutbacks was to balance the budget and remove those who are not entitled to benefits from the rolls -- not to force people to move.
The Mayor's statement came a day after he unveiled a $31.1 billion city budget containing tough new eligibility requirements for providing benefits to parents with dependent children, beginning in July. The requirements, already in effect for the far smaller Home Relief program for childless, able-bodied adults, would reduce the number of applicants with children by 30 percent, city budget officials told reporters on Thursday.
The administration, however, spent much of the day backpedaling from Thursday's assertions about the new rules for the Aid to Families with Dependent Children program. Mr. Giuliani retreated from the 30 percent reduction figure, saying he had no idea what the effect of the new requirements would be.
"I have no idea whether they're right or wrong or what they're basing it on," he said. He was referring to the budget officials who first predicted the 30 percent reductions. "I would not state a percentage because I don't know what it is. They're making that determination. It may turn out to be right; it may turn out to be wrong."
In addition, a top mayoral aide backed away from the position of the budget office that the Mayor's new program would base eligibility for the A.F.D.C. program on the rules that now apply to Home Relief. Richard Schwartz, one of the architects of the Mayor's plans to restructure welfare, said that the issue needs to be studied further before the city decides what kind of restrictions to implement.
In January, the city began intense reviews of all applicants for Home Relief. Workers visit their homes unannounced to see if they live at their stated addresses, and use computer checks of their Social Security numbers to see if they have any income that they have not reported. The Mayor announced earlier this month that the process had reduced the number of applicants by more than 60 percent over the same period last year, and the new budget is built on the assumption that the number of A.F.D.C. applicants would decline by 30 percent, according to budget officials.
But using the same rules for both Home Relief, which is paid for by the city and state, and A.F.D.C., which is paid for primarily by the Federal Government, could bring legal difficulties. Federal courts have ruled that while home visits to A.F.D.C. recipients are legal, they must be announced in advance and must be for the purpose of protecting the child -- not investigating welfare fraud.
Mr. Schwartz said that it was premature to discuss the precise nature of the eligibility rules because they are still being studied by city officials. Asked if, under the new rules, a mother would have to take her children to the same office in downtown Brooklyn where all Home Relief applicants are now interviewed, Mr. Schwartz said that that had not been determined.
"We still need some time to analyze the issue," he said.
Welfare advocates said yesterday that the proposed cutbacks could have a devastating effect on many poor people, but they questioned the Mayor's assertion that many recipients might be tempted to leave town. Liz Krueger, executive director of the Community Food Resource Center, said that relocating is often very expensive, requiring cash for apartment security deposits and moving costs.
"Where does he think they're going to go?" she asked. "Is he offering train tickets, or large sums of resettlement money? We aren't talking about people who moved here. These are New Yorkers, and most of them have no interest in picking up and leaving town."
Henry Freedman, executive director of the Center on Social Welfare Policy and Law, based in Manhattan, said that many states, including New Jersey, Connecticut and Massachusetts, have implemented or have proposed sharp cutbacks in their own welfare benefits, making it less likely that New York welfare recipients will flee the state for higher benefits.
He said that census data on migration showed that poor people move in the same directions as those who are not poor, usually toward states with jobs and booming economies rather than those offering higher welfare benefits.
"If people become very desperate as a result of these cuts, it's likely they'll try to move in with their extended families," he said. "That may mean moving to another state, but it would not be for the welfare benefits."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S. Economy Slowed In First Quarter of '95
The economy slowed to a 2.8 percent growth pace in the first three months of 1995 as consumers paused after a year-end spending spree, the Government reported. As a result of the slowdown in consumer spending, inventories of unsold goods swelled by the biggest amount in a decade.
 At the same time, American businesses increased their breakneck rate of investment in equipment and buildings, which analysts said should keep the economy moving satisfactorily ahead until shoppers revive in the next few months. Page 1.
 
Appeals Court Overturns E.P.A.'s Ethanol Standard
A Federal appeals court said the Government could not require corn-based ethanol as an additive in a cleaner-burning gasoline now sold in 17 states. The three-judge panel concluded that while the Environmental Protection Agency had "the authority to set a standard" for cleaner gasoline, it could not "mandate the manner of compliance or the precise formula" for the fuel. The ruling was in response to a lawsuit filed by the petroleum industry; the E.P.A. said it had not decided whether to appeal. 9.
 
More Records for Stocks
Recovering from a morning drop, the major stock market indexes rose to highs for the third day this week. The Dow Jones industrial average ended at 4,321.27, up 6.57 for the day and 51.18 for the week. The New York Stock Exchange composite index and the S.& P. 500 also broke records. 39.
 
The dollar rose again against major currencies, despite the news that American economic growth was slowing. 45.
 
Paine Webber's President Quits
Paul B. Guenther resigned as president of the Paine Webber Group, saying he wanted to spend more time working with charitable and nonprofit organizations. 39.
 
Taking a Hard Line on Trade Senior American officials decided to rebuff an overture from Japanese trade negotiators to limit the scope of auto trade talks. The American negotiators' aides continued to draft a list of possible Japanese targets for sanctions. 36.
 
Turnabout on Lending Law
Bank of America, Chemical Bank, Nationsbank and Home Savings of America broke ranks with the rest of the industry, saying they would not back Republican bills to repeal large sections of the law that requires banks to lend in poor neighborhoods. 38.
 
Disney and Thorn EMI in Talks
The chairmen of Walt Disney and Thorn EMI met and discussed the possibility of Disney's acquiring the big music company, music industry officials said. But prospects of a deal are highly uncertain. 37.
 
Orange County's Suit Continues
The admission by Robert L. Citron, the former Orange County treasurer, that he broke the law by misappropriating millions of dollars and misleading investors is expected to have little impact on litigation between the county, which is in bankruptcy, and its former broker, Merrill Lynch. 37.
 
Phone-Pacemaker Link Studied
A scientific advisory group financed by the cellular telephone industry said warning labels should be placed on hand-held phones if they disrupt cardiac pacemakers, as two new studies have found. 48.
 
Circulation Off at New York Papers
Newsday, New York Newsday, The Daily News and The New York Times all lost circulation in the six months ended March 31, their publishers said. But The New York Post reported a 7 percent gain. 37.
 
Hospitals Hunt for Patients
With managed care cutting the amount of money that insurers pay for hospital services, major medical centers in New York City are scrambling to find new pipelines for patients, aggressively courting health maintenance organizations, insurers, smaller hospitals, clinics and doctors groups. 25.
 
Germany's Miners Are Uneasy
Germany's coal miners are the highest paid in the world, but their affluence is at risk as the Government struggles to maintain subsidies in the face of rising opposition. 4.

HEADLINE: G.M. Will Shed Some Models, Stressing Brand

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 28

 BODY:
Ronald L. Zarrella, the outsider hired by General Motors to impart distinct and vivid personalities to its muddled divisions and models, emerged from four months of studying the company today to announce that he agreed with the basic marketing strategy G.M. already had in place.
 But he is clearly fine-tuning the strategy. While General Motors has no plans to kill or merge any of its seven divisions, it will do away with some car or truck models, Mr. Zarrella said in a speech today to the Automotive Press Association here. 
 General Motors, the largest auto maker, has too many car and truck models -- up to 77, all told, he said, adding that "the challenge of the future is to increase total sales volume with fewer vehicle-line brands." He declined to say what lines might be eliminated.
 Mr. Zarella also provided a glimpse into the sorts of technology he is hoping to harness in better differentiating G.M.'s brands. He offered visions of lasers in Pontiac showrooms to captivate young people, and of Buick showrooms that resemble country clubs to put its older customers at ease.
 Shares of General Motors rose $1.625 today, to $45.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 Mr. Zarrella, who is vice president and group executive for sales, service and marketing in G.M.'s core North American operations, said he hoped to hire 20 to 30 "brand managers" by the end of the year -- perhaps turning to companies like Johnson & Johnson and Procter & Gamble for some of them -- to nurture an image for each car and truck.
 He also said that sales were slower than expected in April, and that G.M. now expected a mild downturn in the car and truck market in 1997. Previously, G.M. economists had projected continued slow growth in sales, without specifying a time sequence.
 Mr. Zarrella, who was hired away from Bausch & Lomb in November, said he would pursue some marketing methods that are not universally popular with G.M. division chiefs, such as "value pricing," which is selling cars at firm, predetermined prices, reducing haggling in showrooms. "We know it works," he said.
 Mr. Zarrella also said that customers were already showing they were happier with General Motors. In the fourth quarter of 1994, he said, G.M. passed Toyota for the first time in a G.M. survey that determines how satisfied customers are with vehicles they purchased in the last six months. G.M. started collecting such data in the late 1980's, he said.
 When G.M. controlled almost half the American market, its divisions could afford to compete with one another because there were enough customers to go around. But G.M. now controls less than a third of the market, and its divisions are stealing one another's buyers, in addition to wasting money by duplicating efforts. By contrast, the Ford Motor Company has just three divisions, and the Toyota Motor Corporation, two.
 Yet Mr. Zarrella -- echoing the view of other top G.M. executives -- argued that a multiplicity of divisions could help the company. "If we can carve out the right role in each of the market segments and target our products to more differentiated segments," he said, "it's a distinct advantage for General Motors."
 Mr. Zarrella sketched personalities for each division that accord with G.M.'s long-established aims, with Oldsmobile aiming for import buyers and Pontiac for driving enthusiasts. He is creating a new system in hopes of disciplining G.M.'s bureaucracy to let those personalities develop.
 He said brand managers would have responsibility for nourishing each model's image by avoiding three industry pitfalls: monomaniacal focus on price, inconsistent advertising themes, and a "model-year syndrome" that has auto makers promoting vehicles on introduction and ignoring them later.
 The brand manager will be responsible for the profitability of the model, and will decide its price and content, among other things.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Seeks Fish Sellers For Market

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
Turning up the heat in negotiations for new leases and rent increases at the Fulton Fish Market, New York City officials have begun soliciting merchants who might replace some fish wholesalers now at the market.
 Randy M. Mastro, chief of staff for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, said yesterday that several hundred letters were sent this week to wholesale seafood dealers who had either expressed interest in moving to the market or who the administration believed might be considering doing so. 
 Mr. Mastro would not identify the dealers, but said the letters were sent to dealers in the New York region as well as in other cities and countries.
 The letters marked the latest salvo in a struggle between the city and the fish market, which the Mayor has characterized as being rife with corruption and mob influence. Two weeks ago, representatives of many of the market's 40 dealers threatened to move out of the market if the city raised rents substantially.
 And on Wednesday, representatives of the market's three merchants associations inspected sites in Yonkers, and the vendors have said they would also consider moving to Brooklyn or New Jersey.
 "In light of the public comments by certain wholesalers that they would consider leaving the market," Mr. Mastro said, "it is only prudent on the city's part to have discussions with parties who have an interest in doing business at the market."
 The city is the landlord for most of the three-block section on South Street in Lower Manhattan where the market has been situated for more than 150 years. Many of the businesses date back decades.
 Late last month, the Giuliani administration proposed a bill to the City Council to crack down on the market by licensing and regulating all businesses there. The administration also began negotiations to raise rents for 40 dealers who pay a total of about $270,000 a year. Their rents have not been raised since 1982.
 Two days after the administration's proposals, a fire that investigators classified as arson caused severe damage in one of the market's two main buildings. No arrests have been made.
 The letters to potential tenants were sent under Mr. Mastro's name and state that the city is "implementing a comprehensive plan to improve business operations" at the market to make it "a better, safer, and more desirable place in which to do business."
 In letters sent specifically to dealers who had already contacted City Hall, Mr. Mastro added, "We appreciate the interest that you have recently expressed in obtaining such a lease and stand ready to meet with you to discuss this matter further."
 Mr. Mastro, in all of the letters, said that the city was meeting with prospective tenants and that the dealers should get in touch with Daniel Kurtz, the senior vice president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, the agency handling the lease negotiations.
 The market is the nation's largest wholesale fish center, with about 1,000 employees, and generates annual sales and wages of $800 million to $1 billion.
 According to the merchants associations, the city is demanding increases that would raise some rents tenfold. Such increases, the dealers assert, would force them to inflate prices sharply for customers -- mainly retail fish stores and restaurants -- or leave the market.
 Mr. Mastro refused to disclose the increases the city is seeking.
 Joseph L. Forstadt, a lawyer for the South Street Sidewalk Association, a group of 11 dealers, said that he doubted that any replacement merchants could afford the rents that the city is demanding from the established dealers.
 "The city is currently asking for a level of rent that is just too high for anyone to survive," said Mr. Forstadt, a partner in the firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan.
 Mr. Forstadt said that a lease agreement reached in 1982 with the dealers limited rent increases by the city to the rise in the annual cost-of-living rate. He maintained that the agreement was still in effect, although the city had not asked for a change in 13 years.
 In their search for alternative market sites, the dealers associations appear to be making little headway.
 Andrew J. Maniglia, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development in Yonkers, said that on Wednesday merchants from the market inspected a number of privately owned places in that city, including the parking lot at Yonkers Raceway.
 "They need 200,000 square feet," Mr. Maniglia said, "and there are not many sites of that magnitude available in Yonkers." The merchants were advised by Yonkers officials to deal directly with the private owners for leases, Mr. Maniglia noted.
 Lillian C. Liburdi, the director of Port Development for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said that she had rejected requests by market associations to inspect vacant buildings and warehouses owned by the agency on the Brooklyn and Newark waterfronts. These places, she said, were intended for marine commerce and not for the large-scale parking of trucks required for a seafood market.

HEADLINE: TERROR IN OKLAHOMA: THE FAR RIGHT;
Manual for Terrorists Extols 'Greatest Coldbloodedness'

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER 

 BODY:
Since the Oklahoma City bombing, leaders of paramilitary groups have said in dozens of interviews that their groups were organized solely to defend themselves against a Government they view as out of control.
But a number of internal training manuals sold by the most influential of these groups advocate a campaign of terror and lay out specific strategies for actions, including attacking vulnerable Federal buildings, kidnapping important people, sabotaging the food supply and executing enemies. 
 By far the most complete and explicit of these documents to emerge so far is the multipart "M.O.D. Training Manuals," distributed by the Militia of Montana, one of the three most influential paramilitary groups in the country, along with the Michigan Militia and the United States Militia Association, based in Idaho. Just what "M.O.D" stands for is unclear.
The $75 manual, consisting of more than 200 pages, is part of an extensive catalogue of videotapes, audiotapes and literature marketed by the group. It describes what it says are the biblical and ideological justification for a guerrilla war in the United States and provides details about how to conduct it.
The Federal authorities have not said whether any paramilitary groups were involved in the bombing of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City. But the main suspect, Timothy J. McVeigh, and James and Terry Nichols, the two brothers who have been charged with conspiring to make explosive devices, attended at least one meeting of a paramilitary group in Michigan, members of the Michigan Militia have said.
The manual distributed by the Montana group was obtained by the Southern Poverty Law Center, a group that monitors the new paramilitary movement, which has set up organizations in least 30 states. The directives of the training manual include these:
*Undertaking a campaign of domestic terrorism, defined as "an action usually involving the placement of a bomb or fire explosion of great destructive power, which is capable of effecting irreparable loss against the enemy." It goes on to say: "Requires theoretical and practical knowledge of how to make explosives. It is an action the urban guerrilla must execute with the greatest coldbloodedness."
*Coordinating sabotage attacks to cripple the "economy of the country, agricultural or industrial production, transport and communication systems, the military and police systems."
"Public offices, centers of government services, government warehouses are easy targets for sabotage," the manual says, adding, "Industrial workers acting as urban guerrillas are excellent industrial saboteurs since they, better than anyone, understand the industry, the factory, the machine or the part most likely to destroy an entire operation, doing far more damage than a poorly informed layman."
*Destroying "the firms and properties of people that are not Americans," it says, explaining, "Firms and property in this country that are not owned by Americans must become such frequent targets of sabotage that the volume of actions directed against them surpasses the total of all other actions against vital enemy points."
*Conducting a "war of nerves" by planting false rumors with the police, exploiting Government mismanagement and letting "false plans" fall into the hands of authorities. The aim of the disinformation campaign, the manual says, is to create "an air of nervousness, discredit, insecurity, uncertainty and concern on the part of the government."
*Raiding armories in order to seize "arms, ammo and explosives."
*"Kidnapping of personalities who are known artists, sports figures or are outstanding in some other field, who have evidenced no political interest." Such kidnapping "can be a useful form of propaganda for the revolutionary and patriot principles, provided the kidnapping is handled so that the public sympathizes with it."
*Executing spies, government officials and "those who go to the police of their own free will to make denunciations and accusations, who supply clues and information and finger people" in paramilitary groups.
*Developing skills in weather forecasting, survival, ambushes, assassination and sniper attacks, and handling night vision equipment, booby traps , hand grenades and other ordnance.
*Keeping militia activities secret from members' families. "Under no circumstances is the material in your field manual to be divulged to or read to your wife and kids unless they have been approved by your cell leader for actual recruiting and membership."
In effect, said Rabbi Marvin Hier, the founder of the Simon Wiesenthal Center, a human rights group in Los Angeles that tracks hate groups, the manual is a basic text for teaching disaffected citizens how to conduct a low-intensity conflict intended to foment a right-wing revolution.
Neither he nor other experts said they knew what the "M.O.D." stood for in the manual's title.
David Trochmann, 49, a co-founder of the Militia of Montana, confirmed in an interview on Wednesday that his group was distributing the manual. His group's name and address is on the front page.
But, he said, the paramilitary group was not the manual's author. Furthermore, he said he did not know who the author was or what "M.O.D." stood for. He also said he had not read the documents and did not know about their contents.
"If this stuff is in here and we haven't checked it out completely, then it's coming out of the catalogue," Mr. Trochmann said. "This manual has not been checked out thoroughly, and it should have been checked out. I don't agree with any of that stuff. We didn't realize this kind of stuff was in there. This one slipped by."
Mr. Trochmann also said he did not know how many manuals had been distributed, even though the $75 price made them among the most expensive items in the Militia of Montana's extensive catalogue.
Rabbi Hier said the training manuals provided more documented evidence that the militia movement had tried to mislead the public by insisting that its aims were merely defensive.
"They say they are law-abiding patriots but at the same time they are training and looking behind every tree for Federal agents," Rabbi Hier said. "It's a recipe for disaster."

HEADLINE: Working Less, And Not Upset;
Japan's Slump Cracks Tradition of Long Hours

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 28

 BODY:
When Sumitomo Metal Industries began closing its offices and factories for two workdays each month to save money, many employees at first dreaded the loss of income. A year and a half later, some of the steel company's workers now worry that the shutdowns will end.
 "People are getting used to it," said Nobuaki Masuda, an assistant manager in corporate planning. "We are saying that if we have to work five days a week every week we will die." 
 Yes, even the Japanese enjoy some time off. And owing in part to the nation's economic slump, they are now getting it. Indeed, by some measures, the Japanese, who have been known for six-day workweeks and long stretches of overtime, are now apparently working fewer hours than Americans, whom Japanese politicians were denouncing only a few years ago as lazy.
 The Japanese worked an average of 1,904 hours in 1994, down from 2,111 hours in 1988 and way down from a peak of 2,432 in 1960, according to the Ministry of Labor.
 Comparable American figures are hard to come by because of different calculation methods. Looking only at blue-collar manufacturing workers, the Labor Ministry estimated that Japanese employees put in 2,017 hours in 1992, compared with 1,957 for American workers. But by 1994, the Japanese figure had dropped to about 1,960 while American work hours, buoyed by a strong economy, had risen about 2.4 percent, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics in the United States.
 Japan's prolonged recession, which has sharply cut overtime, is not the only reason for the decline. There has also been a longer-term fundamental shift to a shorter workweek and more vacations, as a now-affluent nation no longer has to work so hard to make ends meet.
 Some say the reduction in work hours is not as great as the statistics indicate because many employees, either out of a sense of duty or because of corporate pressure, put in time for which they are not paid and which is not recorded. One Government survey found that employees estimated they had worked about 400 hours a year more than the statistics showed. This so-called service overtime has probably increased as companies have clamped down on paid overtime.
 "Overtime work continued; overtime pay was cut," said Hiroshi Kawahito, a labor lawyer. He added that cases of death from overwork, known as karoshi, have not declined from an estimated 10,000 a year.
 It is also not clear how long the reduction in work hours will last. In the last few months, paid overtime has increased as the economy has shown some signs of recovery. The long recession has also changed the priority of workers from reducing hours to preserving job security.
 Still, regular working hours should continue to decline -- despite concerns by many business executives that Japan's competitiveness could be hurt -- as the nation moves toward a statutory workweek of 40 hours, down from the 44 to 48 hours that was typical a decade ago.
 Much of the change has been a result of Government directive, after other nations contended that Japan was competing unfairly by virtually enslaving its population to fuel its export machine.
 To counter such criticism, the Government started a program to make Japan a "life style superpower" as well as an economic one, by coaxing and sometimes practically forcing people to take it easy.
 Companies, sometimes reluctantly, sometimes out of self-interest, went along, at times even paying their workers extra to take vacations and turning off the lights to get people to go home.
 Experts and everyday workers alike say there has been a gradual shift away from the mentality of sacrificing one's personal life for the company.
 "When I was young there was a sense that if your boss was still working you should stay," said Toshiya Tsugami, 38, a bureaucrat at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, which is nicknamed the "ministry where people routinely work overtime."
 "But recently, that mood has disappeared," he said.
 One factor is that employees are seeing that the lifetime employment system, which provided security in exchange for loyalty, has been weakened by the prolonged slump.
 Many companies have introduced flexible working hours and merit pay systems, so that employees are now evaluated on their accomplishments, not merely on the basis of seniority or hours worked. And companies are now saying that well-rested employees are more valuable than stressed-out ones.
 "It used to be the person who stayed in the office the whole time was considered a good employee," said Junzo Ishino, a spokesman for Mitsubishi Motors. "Now a good employee is considered one who can take a vacation." The auto company requires its employees to take at least three consecutive weekdays off once a year.
 Still, the change is gradual. Asked how many vacation days he took last year, Mr. Ishino hesitantly replied, "not so many." And some Japanese workers say that despite what their employers say, pressures remain to work late and to skip vacations.
 "I took 16 days of the 44 I was owed and went to Australia last year," said one office worker at a major electronics company. "It was regarded as a kind of scandal."
 The Government's goal is an average of 1,800 working hours a year by the fiscal year that ends in March 1997. With two years to go and 100 work hours to cut, the goal does not look achievable.
 At the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, average working hours have already fallen, to 1,802 in the year that ended in March 1994, compared with 2,050 four years earlier. The company achieved the reduction by cutting overtime, shortening the workday by 15 minutes, increasing vacations and introducing sabbaticals.
 To cut hours -- and save money -- many companies have established no-overtime days, also called "refresh days," usually on Wednesdays.
 "They literally lock the doors at 8 so you really have to leave the office," an employee of a major bank said. At the headquarters of NEC, the electronics company, computers shut off the lights at 7 P.M. on Wednesdays.
 Some employees say they have come to like the system. "I can make appointments for sure on Wednesdays," said Ayako Imai, a 23-year-old office worker for the Kuwayama Jewelry Company.
By March 1997, companies with 30 or more employees will have to institute a 40-hour workweek. To help companies cut hours, the Government is offering subsidies to pay for labor-saving technology or for the hiring of extra workers.
 Most big companies and Government agencies already have a five-day week, while small companies still usually work on Saturdays.
 Paid vacation days have increased, too, with big companies now giving about 20 days a year. The challenge is getting people to take those days.
 In Japanese companies, in which employees often work in teams, it has been considered an imposition on colleagues to take a long vacation. It can also be seen as a lack of dedication.
 Suffering from an acute need to rest, people instead take off on national holidays, when it is socially acceptable to stay away from work. A result is huge traffic jams and crowded resorts on those occasions.
 Some companies have started using sign-up sheets to get employees to take their vacations. Many big companies are also offering what are called "refresh vacations" -- short sabbaticals for veteran workers, often accompanied by some money to help them have a good time. At Ricoh, the office equipment maker, employees in their 20th year get an extra 10 days off and 200,000 yen, or about $2,400.
 Responding to such programs and Government exhortations, Japanese workers now take an average of 56 percent of their vacation days, up from 50 percent a few years ago.
 The Government has also been increasing the number of holidays. There are already 14 national holidays, compared with 10 Federal holidays in the United States, and another one, Ocean Day, will be added next year. Many companies supplement the holidays by closing for extra days around New Year's Day, the middle of August and the first week of May. This year, some companies will be adding a few days to the early May holiday, which begins on Saturday, because business is slow.
 But further moves to cut working hours are starting to find opposition. "As the five-day workweek proliferates, some people feel that they don't need any more holidays," said Shunichi Ando, a Labor Ministry official.
 With pay increases crimped by the economic slump, some workers want more overtime pay. And companies have cut many workers in the recession, increasing the workload on those who remain.
 Companies are also resisting additional moves toward shorter hours. "We are already in a situation where Japan's labor hours are not particularly long," said Shigeru Hasegawa, manager of the personnel management division of the Japan Federation of Employers' Associations.
 Executives say Japan's competitiveness has been hurt because wages have not been reduced even as the workweek has been shortened and vacation days increased.
 "We went from one Saturday off a month to two Saturdays last year," said Takashi Kuroiwa, manager of a printing shop in Tokyo. "Our productivity was lower and our delivery time lengthened."

HEADLINE: A Traditional Coalition Shows Signs of Wear

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, April 28

 BODY:
With his defection to the Republican Party earlier this month, Representative Nathan Deal of Georgia left a sharp tear in the tattered biracial coalition that many had once thought could save the Democratic Party in the South.
In switching parties, the Congressman from the hilly country of north Georgia had little effect on the balance of power in his state's House delegation, serving only to tip it further toward the Republican Party. But the shift by Mr. Deal, who is white, left a stark racial contrast: now all eight Republican Representatives are white and all three Democrats are black. 
 While Mr. Deal, who was first elected to Congress in 1992, undoubtedly did not set out to create such a racial split, analysts and some officials found the results unsettling.
"This is obviously troubling for the long-term implications for the biracial coalition," said David Bositis, an analyst with the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a Washington group that focuses on political trends involving blacks and other minorities nationally. "It is still out there in a number of Congressional districts in the South, but it is tenuous. And the dissolution of multiracial politics in the South would be unwholesome and in the long term harmful."
Mr. Deal's district has historically been one of the state's whitest Congressional districts, with a voting-age population that is only 3 percent black. Mr. Deal and his Democratic predecessors, unlike many of their Southern colleagues, rarely had to juggle the concerns of entrenched whites with those of a surging black electorate.
Merle Black, a political scientist at Emory University who has written several books on Southern politics, suggests that race had little to do with Mr. Deal's decision.
"The motivation for his switch was more because his district was voting increasingly heavily Republican in Presidential races and getting disenchanted with the direction that people like Richard Gephardt were taking the national Democrats," Mr. Black said. Mr. Gephardt, of Missouri, is the House minority leader.
Nevertheless, he said, Mr. Deal's switch had sharp racial implications, sketching a state Congressional delegation that mirrored a deepening racial polarization in the South.
While a decade ago, nearly all the Congressional seats in Georgia, Alabama, Louisiana, Mississippi and South Carolina were held by Democrats, 19 of the 36 seats are now held by white Republicans, 9 by white Democrats and 8 by black Democrats. And in most of those districts represented by white Democrats -- as well as in Mr. Deal's -- Republican Presidential candidates have received more votes than their Democratic opponents in the last two elections.
After Mr. Deal announced his decision, one of the state's black Democratic House members, Representative Cynthia McKinney, expressed satisfaction and said that Democrats did not need any "worried warriors" like him.
Many white Democrats in the region were either silent or openly sympathetic to Mr. Deal. Representative Mike Parker of Mississippi, for instance, said the move was simply a reflection of the frustration and anger that conservative Southern Democrats, himself included, felt about the direction of the party.
Mr. Parker, a three-term Congressman from Jackson whose district is 41 percent black, stopped short of saying that he, too, was likely to bolt the party, but warned that Democrats nationally were likely to find that black voters in the South are more conservative and willing to try different approaches than many think.
"We have been telling them that," Mr. Parker said, "but they still don't get it."
It is the concentration of black voters after the Congressional redistricting in 1990 that many point to as crucial in the growing Republican dominance. In Georgia, for example, in all but one of six seats that have shifted to Republican from Democratic over the last two elections, the percentage of the voting-age population that is black declined after the districts were redrawn.
And by the same token, as Mr. Black pointed out, those same districts were increasingly willing to vote Republican, giving majorities to George Bush in 1988 and 1992.
For now all of these "short-term factors" in the region favor greater Republican gains, Mr. Black said. But he added that short-term factors by definition never last forever.
Even Mr. Deal's seemingly provident switch could ultimately bite him. Local Republicans -- who charged that the change in parties was "brokered in Washington" by Speaker Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, without consulting them -- said that Mr. Deal was likely to face opposition in the next Republican primary.
"It's not a 100 percent love fest up here," said State Representative Steven Lyle Stancil, a Republican and potential challenger. "A lot of people feel like it was unfair to those who had labored in the vineyards. Nathan isn't out of harm's way by a long shot."

Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 6.57 to a Record After Recouping Early Loss

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks recovered from early losses yesterday to push the Dow Jones industrial average to another record high.
The rally was led by big cylical companies like General Motors, Alcoa and Caterpillar on expectations that interest rates would remain stable. 
 "Worldwide economic growth is strong and the dollar is weak enough for demand to enhance earnings growth of multinational companies," said Phil Schettewi, chief portfolio strategist at Loomis Sayles in Washington, which manages $2.5 billion.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.57 points yesterday, to 4,321.27, its 22d record high this year. "The Dow is hitting new highs every day," said Kenneth Ducey, director of trading at BT Brokerage. "People are starting to look through rose-colored glasses -- not looking at 4,300, but at 4,500 now."
The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.16 points, to 514.71, its 24th high this year. The Nasdaq composite index rose 3.03 points, to 843.98, its third consecutive high.
Among stocks moving the market yesterday, shares of Procter & Gamble rose, lifting the shares of other household-product makers, after the company reported strong third-quarter earnings on Thursday. Yesterday, a Merrill Lynch analyst, Deepak Raj, raised his fiscal 1995 and 1996 earnings estimates for the company. P.& G. shares rose 1 5/8, to 69 7/8. Scott Paper shared the good news, rising 1 1/2, to 89 1/8. Clorox climbed 1 1/8, to 58 3/4.
The Bell stocks rose after the seven regional telephone companies won approval to offer nationwide long-distance cellular services -- an important step for the Bells in their quest to enter the long-distance market. Ameritech jumped 5/8, to 44 3/4. BellSouth rose 5/8, to 61 1/8.
Chrysler gained 1 3/8, to 43 1/4, after Kirk Kerkorian said he had hired D. F. King & Company in New York to solicit proxies from Chrysler shareholders, possibly setting the stage for a proxy fight. Ford Motor gained 1/4, to 27 1/8, while General Motors rose 1 5/8, to 45 1/8.
CBS rose 3 1/2 to 64 3/4. Dan Dorfman, the financial correspondent for the CNBC cable channel, said there was speculation on Wall Street that Westinghouse might be interested in buying CBS for $80 a share. Both companies declined to comment on the report. Westinghouse was unchanged at 15.
Shares of gold mining companies sank after gold prices fell, reversing earlier gains. Newmont Mining slid 1 1/8, to 41 7/8, and Placer Dome was down 7/8, to 23 3/4.
Intel continued to lead technology shares higher, joined by Microsoft, which rebounded from Thursday's fall.
Intel set the pace, posting its fifth consecutive record high. After the market closed on Thursday, Intel announced a 2-for-1 stock split and said it would increase its dividend to 4 cents a share from 3 cents after the split. Intel climbed 1 3/4, to 102 3/8.
Microsoft rebounded from its decline on Thursday, when the Justice Department filed an antitrust suit to block the company's proposed acquisition of Intuit. Microsoft shares rose 3 1/8 yesterday to 81 3/4 and Intuit fell 5, to 67 3/4.
Among the technology shares that faltered were Cyrix, which slipped 2 1/2, to 23 3/4, after analysts expressed concern about whether the semiconductor company would ship its new high-end products, which will compete with Intel microprocessors.
Gateway 2000 lost after it warned that component shortages might hurt earnings this quarter. The personal computer maker announced first-quarter earnings that matched analysts' forecasts. Its shares slid 25/16 , to 1815/16 .
In Japan, stocks ended the week lower in lackluster trading. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 77.24 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent, at 16,806.75

HEADLINE: Kamp-Lintfort Journal;
Once-Mighty Miners Now Have Backs to the Wall

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: KAMP-LINTFORT, Germany

 BODY:
This town in the Ruhr Valley, with its immaculate streets, tidy brick row houses, bright flowers and modern cars seems a long way away from its American counterpart, a run-down West Virginia coal-mining town.
But then the German coal industry is perhaps different from that in any other country. Not only are German miners the highest paid, earning on average almost $40,000 a year. They also produce the most expensive coal in the world. 
 Here, thousands of feet underground, Ruhrkohle A.G., owner of the Kamp-Lintfort mine, spends $200 to extract a ton of the hard black rock used to fuel Germany's electric power plants. The world price is more like $60. What that means is that Germany and its taxpayers pay about $7 billion to subsidize the 52 million tons of hard coal produced yearly in this country.
But Kamp-Lintfort's combination of working-class affluence and seven-hour workdays along a 1,000-foot coal face is at risk as the Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl struggles to maintain such costly subsidies in the face of rising political opposition and a populace showing the first signs of weariness with Germany's high tax rate.
"Germany still needs a coal industry to make sure it has its own source of energy," Werner Flegel, a 47-year-old miner, said as he took a break during his shift some 3,300 feet under Kamp-Lintfort. "This is not just a question of the German people supporting 90,000 coal miners and their families. It's a matter of national security."
Defenders of the security argument note that Germany has no oil and no interest in being hostage to oil shocks of the kind that emanated from the Middle East in the 1970's. But more and more, as world energy prices have declined or remained stable, and the country has obtained new sources of soft coal in the former East Germany that can be strip-mined at a much lower cost, that logic has seemed worn.
Miners find they are fighting harder than ever to hold onto public support, with critics describing them as "leeches" because of the huge subsidies they enjoy.
They have had to argue on the basis of local political impact, contending that shutting down the mines would create enormous social dislocation and pain.
They say they are not as affluent as many think, noting that they have accepted pay cuts and other reductions in their benefits that have dropped them from the eighth highest paid workers in Germany to No. 48.
But they are concerned that the Government will renege on its promises to continue large subsidies, destroying an industry that has already seen its payroll shrink to 95,000, from 600,000 in the mid-1950's.
"Our sons are not coming into the business," said another miner, Dieter Ernst, 42. "And those who can are looking to change jobs. We're probably the last real generation of coal miners."
Ulrike Platen, a 34-year-old worker at Ruhrkohle, worried that the character of Kamp-Lintfort would be changed, and she joined in a five-week sit-in at a local church to dramatize the miners' plight.
"This town must not become a dormitory for people working in Dusseldorf or elsewhere," she said.
Political tensions began to heat up in December, when Germany's constitutional court ruled that the so-called kohlepfennig, a fee levied on all electric bills, was unconstitutional and that revenues for the coal subsidy had to come out of general Government taxes. Immediately, debate began over whether to impose new taxes or cut the Government subsidy. Taxes were to jump anyway in 1995 by more than 10 percent.
Mr. Kohl's Christian Democrats and the opposition Social Democrats supported a new tax. But the tiny Free Democratic Party, a vital member of Mr. Kohl's governing coalition, threatened to pull out if new taxes were imposed. And Mr. Kohl gave in, at least temporarily, meaning that to support the coal miners other Government programs will have to be cut.
Moreover, until early April the Kohl Government refused to pay 1995 subsidies on hard coal production by such companies as Ruhrkohle, trying to put pressure on the states, which also reap enormous social benefits from the subsidies, to pay a larger share.
Industry officials and miners warn that though the Government eventually reached an agreement with the states, the political jockeying is far from over. Germany faces the highest levels of unemployment in decades. The strong German mark is all but certain to dampen exports, restricting economic growth.
And now every year during the budget debate in the Kohl Government, the industry subsidies will be a potential target of its opponents.
"Next year we may be in the same position again," said Elke Weiler, a coal worker here who was part of the church sit-in. "It's nothing to be happy with."
Using an old-time German expression, Mr. Platen added, "The cow is not safely off the ice."

GRAPHIC: Photo: German coal miners like these in Kamp-Lintfort are the highest paid in the world, earning on average almost $40,000 a year. At $200 a ton, the heavily subsidized coal they produce is the world's most expensive. (Nathaniel C. Nash/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Japan Jobless Rate at Postwar High

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 28

 BODY:
Japan's unemployment rate hit a postwar high of 2.9 percent in the fiscal year that ended on March 31, the Government said today in the latest reflection of the nation's prolonged economic slowdown.
 The unemployment rate was 2.6 percent the previous fiscal year. 
 The latest reading was the highest since 1953, when the Government adopted the current method for computing unemployment data. The previous high of 2.8 percent was recorded in fiscal 1986 and 1987.
 The rates would be much higher if calculated by United States or European methods. In Japan, people who work more than one hour in the last week of a month and all members of the armed forces are counted as employed.
 A five-year economic slump and the persistent rise of the yen against other currencies have squeezed the job market as many manufacturers shift production overseas, where labor and other costs are cheaper.
 A Government official said the effects of the earthquake that struck Kobe in January helped nudge the monthly rate a tenth of a percentage point higher in March, to 3 percent.
