HEADLINE: Managed Care Leads to Marketing Strategies as Hospitals Compete

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
One recent afternoon, Barry R. Freedman, the director of Mount Sinai Hospital, traveled to Westchester to speak with administrators and physicians at a hospital there about becoming part of the Manhattan medical center's growing health care network.
 As he emerged from the meeting into the reception area, Mr. Freedman bumped into an old friend, Dr. Spencer Foreman, director of the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, who was there to make a similar bid on behalf of his hospital. Like two door-to-door salesmen arriving at the same house, the two laughed, nervously. 
 By trying to woo the suburban hospital, both men were hoping to secure one of its most valuable assets: its patients.
 With managed care cutting the amount of money that insurers pay for hospital services, administrators of major medical centers in New York City are scrambling to find new pipelines for patients.
 But rather than reaching out directly to individual patients -- whose choices of doctors and hospitals have become more limited because of managed care -- hospitals are aggressively promoting themselves instead to health care providers with large volumes of patients: health maintenance organizations, insurers, smaller hospitals, and clinics and doctors groups.
 The patients are referred to variously as "covered lives," "potential revenue sources" or just plain "bodies," and hospital executives say that they need to serve more of them to keep their institutions afloat.
 "What you have on now is a hunt for bodies," said Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton University.
 "We like to use the word 'position,' " said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association. "What hospitals here are doing is positioning ourselves to maximize potential in this move toward a market orientation, which is coming now with a vengeance."
 The search for patients is one of the many signs of how the health care landscape in New York has changed in recent years in a somewhat belated response to the surge of managed care across the country. Regional hospitals that just a few years ago tried to insure their survival by seeking out affiliations with large medical centers now find themselves pursued because of their access to patients.
 But the pursuit goes beyond the regional hospitals. Many large medical centers are reaching out to virtually every link along the health care delivery chain in the hope that it will increase the number of patients who come through their doors.
 And in some cases the hospitals are reaching out to the H.M.O.'s that they shunned only a few years ago in resistance to the whole concept of managed care.
 Hospitals are choosing different strategies for building up these bigger patient bases. Some are buying smaller hospitals or large doctors' offices outside the city. Beth Israel Medical Center, for example, bought a chain of doctors' offices 18 months ago in Westchester; the chain serves more than 150,000 patients, who are now referred almost exclusively to Beth Israel when they need surgery or other advanced care.
 Others are forming affiliations that nudge but don't force patients their way. Mount Sinai, for one, has formed a health system network that includes 22 hospitals, long-term care centers and physicians' groups in the metropolitan area and Florida, in the expectation that doctors in the affiliates will send patients their way.
 And some hospitals have joined together to form looser alliances that offer a wide range of services, locations and medical specialization to the health maintenance organizations that control the gates to so many patients. Montefiore Medical Center, for example, joined with a group of five hospitals to appeal to one insurer and teamed up with a different group of institutions to close a deal with another.
 "There are a variety of mechanisms," said Gerard F. Anderson, the director of the Johns Hopkins Center for Hospital Finance and Management. "But there is one goal: to maintain and build patient volume."
 Dr. Foreman said that Montefiore was "in touch with insurance companies, other institutions, physicians constantly, every day, trying to expand our reach."
 "Underlying this is not the relationship of hospital to hospital," he explained. "The linkages are promoted in order to induce doctors who practice at smaller hospitals and H.M.O.'s to send patients who need a different level of care to us."
 The competition is fierce. Of a dozen hospital administrators who were interviewed, all refused to go into any detail about the way they pitch their hospitals to potential affiliates, and they gave only brief outlines of the deals they have made with other providers.
 In fact, Dr. Foreman and Mr. Freedman declined to name the Westchester hospital where they unexpectedly crossed paths, each fearing that doing so might jeopardize a successful courtship.
 "People who used to be colleagues are now either partners or competitors," Dr. Foreman said.
 Many of the objects of this desire are grinning over their newly found popularity, having been long shunned by major medical centers resistant to managed care and to associating with colleagues at less prestigious institutions.
 "In 1987, I would have loved to have had Mount Sinai or some of these other places on our panel," said Thomas A. Travers, vice president for health care delivery, contracting and network development for Oxford Health Plan, one of the fastest growing managed care companies in New York. "They would listen cordially; then they would remind us who they were and that they didn't need us. Now that we have over 353,000 covered lives, I get at least three calls a day from people and facilities in the greater New York area making a pitch to us."
 Some of the presentations are slick, said Mr. Travers and other administrators of health care companies. They described promotions offering slides, brochures and handshakes with celebrity specialists, like surgeons who work on world-famous transplant teams. Others use a more homespun touch, with the suitors talking over cups of tea and simple handouts about being like a family or a community.
 What all the overtures have in common is that they are initiated and handled by high-level executives at the major medical centers. "This is the future of our hospital and has to be handled at the highest levels," said Peter A. Kelly, executive vice president for operations at Beth Israel. "It demonstrates interest and intent and offers the best source for information."
 But while the sought-after doctors' groups, hospitals, insurance companies and H.M.O.'s know that they have a lucrative asset in their patients, they also realize that the major medical centers that pursue them have benefits to offer in return. Among the lures they dangle are low-interest loans, consultations with world-renowned specialists, prestige and academic posts for staff members.
 "A lot of doctors are insecure in this climate and want to be part of a bigger institution rather than being self-employed," said John P. McGovern, a health care consultant for the consulting firm of Ernst & Young.
 For Doctors' Hospital of Staten Island, an affiliation with Beth Israel Medical Center has brought several advantages to a 117-bed community hospital. In exchange for referring all its cardiology and other speciality care patients, Doctors' Hospital gets to use the medical center's laboratory and radiology services at reduced rates and now sends its staff members to Beth Israel for management and professional seminars. In addition, the hospital has an entree to H.M.O.'s and managed care companies that had given little notice before to a small, local hospital.
 Before the affiliation, Doctors' Hospital was not on the panel of a single insurance company; it is now associated with four.
 "We gave them a conduit to patients," said Stephen N. F. Anderson, executive director of Doctors' Hospital. "And they gave us a conduit to specialists that we never had before and to penetrate the managed care market."
 The big hospitals use different methods for scouting out new sources of patients. They rely both on casual suggestions through word of mouth and sophisticated analysis of data on the patients who already use their services: Where do they come from? What are the major doctors' practices there? Are there other areas in the region with similar demographics where people are not using the hospital? What are the institutions there?
 "The first thing you have to do is understand your market share," said Mr. Freedman of Mount Sinai. "Then you try to figure out what your opportunities are to preserve that market and penetrate others. To form a strategy of where other opportunities lie, we do a demographic and geographic analysis. Then we start to look at provider profiles that might exist in those areas."
 This "zoning in" as he called it, often involves questioning Mount Sinai staff members about certain doctors or clinics in the suburban communities where they live. "We have actually gone to the Yellow Pages just to get an understanding of the possibilities," he said.
 "The patients are there," he added. "We just have to find a way to them."

HEADLINE: Queens Man Is Accused In Bar Killing

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
A Queens man shot and killed a fellow bar patron, then barricaded himself inside the bar for seven hours before police officers stormed the place early yesterday -- only to find him asleep, the police said.
 The suspect, Frank Napolitano, 60, of 130-32 117th Street in Ozone Park, Queens, has a long criminal history dating to 1952, when he served about six years at the Sing Sing Correctional Facility for killing a man in Brooklyn, according to the Queens District Attorney's office. 
 Yesterday, Mr. Napolitano was charged with second-degree murder, criminal possession of a weapon and attempted murder, said Mary de Bourbon, a spokeswoman for the Queens District Attorney.
 Mr. Napolitano was arrested about 2:30 A.M. yesterday inside the Winners Circle Bar on Rockaway Boulevard in Queens.
 The incident began when Mr. Napolitano got into an argument with the victim, Brian O'Connor, 37, of 105-27 91st Street in Woodhaven, the police said.
 The police said Mr. Napolitano had been asked to leave the bar early Thursday evening after drinking for most of the day and becoming boisterous. He left, but returned about 15 minutes later with a gun, they said, adding that about 7:30 P.M. he fired five times at Mr. O'Connor while eight other people fled the bar.
 Police officers who arrived were met with gunfire as they tried to enter the bar, though none was hurt. They backed out and called the hostage negotiating team. More than 50 officers cordoned off several blocks around the bar.
 The ensuing seven-hour standoff snarled traffic and forced residents to stay off the street. Customers inside a Home Depot across the street had to stay in the store. At 2:30 A.M. the police said, they finally stormed the building and found Mr. Napolitano asleep.
 Mr. O'Connor, a bus maintenance worker, was found dead on the floor of the bar, with several gunshot wounds. He worked at the Kingsbridge bus depot in the Bronx for nine years.
 Mr. Napolitano "had been drinking since earlier in the day," Deputy Chief Lawrence Loesch said. The police reached him by telephone during the standoff, he said, but "he'd talk to us and he'd fade out."
 During the negotiations, Mr. Napolitano voiced anger against the Federal Government and mentioned the bombing of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City, said Sgt. Kerry Schreiner of the hostage negotiating team. The sergeant did not elaborate, but there was no indication that there was any political motive in the shooting.
 Mr. Napolitano, an unemployed carpenter, was treated at Jamaica Hospital for a cut to the head and intoxication.
 Besides the 1952 murder, Ms. de Bourbon said, Mr. Napolitano's criminal record includes a 1967 conviction for gun possession, a five-year prison term in 1970 on a conspiracy and weapons conviction and a 1982 charge of attempted murder that was dismissed when the victim died of natural causes before the case went to trial.
 Yesterday, Mr. Napolitano said nothing as he was led out of the 106th Precinct station house. He was wearing blue hospital garb and had a large bruise near his temple.

HEADLINE: U.S. Rebuffs Japanese Overture To Limit Scope of Auto Talks

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 28

 BODY:
Senior Administration officials today rebuffed an overture from Japanese trade negotiators to limit the scope of auto trade talks, as American negotiators continued to draft a list of possible Japanese targets for American trade sanctions.
 Laura Tyson, the head of President Clinton's National Economic Council, said tonight that the officials had unanimously agreed to insist on progress on all three sticking points in the trade talks, and not just on two out of three issues, as urged by the Japanese. 
 Japanese officials have taken a conciliatory position on increasing the number of Japanese car dealers that carry American vehicles, and on relaxing regulations for auto inspections and repairs in Japan so that more American spare parts can be used. But they have objected to American requests that targets be set for additional Japanese purchases of parts for the assembly of new cars.
 Ms. Tyson said that all three issues would have to be resolved. "That was the strong consensus decision within the group," she said.
 American trade officials are drafting a list of Japanese car parts and some consumer products on which the United States would threaten to apply stiff punitive tariffs if the trade talks do not produce an agreement. A trade consultant who insisted on anonymity said tonight that as much as $7 billion to $9 billion of annual Japanese imports could end up on the threat list. Any actual sanctions, however, would subsequently be applied to considerably less than half of these goods.
 Ms. Tyson refused to accept questions on what the United States might do if Japan rejected its demands. "I'm not going to discuss any of the options that we discussed today," she said.
 American and Japanese negotiators are scheduled to hold further talks next week in Vancouver, British Columbia. The United States team will be led by the Administration's top trade official, Mickey Kantor. Administration officials with responsibility for Japan trade policy will meet again at the end of next week to review their options, Ms. Tyson said.

HEADLINE: ECONOMY SLOWED TO 2.8% GROWTH IN FIRST QUARTER

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 28

 BODY:
The economy slowed to a 2.8 percent rate of growth in the first three months of 1995, the Government reported today. That was well below the 5.1 percent pace of expansion in the fourth quarter of 1994 as consumers paused after a year-end spending spree.
The fourth-quarter pace was about twice as fast as could be sustained without causing inflation to heat up, and economists generally welcomed today's report. 
 "This economy is still growing," said Michael L. Penzer, vice president and senior economist at the Bank of America. Because of the slowdown in consumer spending in the first quarter, inventories of unsold goods swelled by the biggest amount in a decade. Still, Mr. Penzer added, the inventory buildup is not so large as many had feared, and there are signs that auto makers and other companies have already set about paring them.
The Clinton Administration quickly hailed the report on the gross domestic product, the nation's output of all goods and services, which showed that growth was the slowest since the summer of 1993.
"The expansion continues while the economy moves to a more sustainable long-run growth rate," Joseph E. Stiglitz and Martin N. Baily, senior economic advisers at the White House, declared in a joint statement. "Strong, noninflationary growth, concentrated in investment and the private sector, gives this period one of the best macroeconomic performances in recent history."
Private analysts were more cautious in their praise; many suggested the desired slowdown from overrapid growth -- 4.1 percent for 1994 as a whole -- might prove uncomfortably abrupt. Even though the slowdown was greater than analysts had expected, few saw any significant risk that the economy would skid into recession. The slowdown results from the Federal Reserve's efforts to brake the economy by pushing up interest rates seven times since early last year.
At the same time, companies have stepped up an already breakneck rate of investment in new equipment and buildings, a phenomenon that analysts said should keep the economy moving satisfactorily until consumer spending picks up in the next few months.
"I expect the consumer to come back in the second half" of the year, said Richard Aspinwall, senior vice president and chief economist at the Chase Manhattan Bank. He cited solid job growth, increased consumer confidence and a recent decline in long-term interest rates.
Today's G.D.P. report by the Commerce Department also showed a moderate uptick in inflation, but no more than economists had expected. Most said the Federal Reserve was likely to be pleased with the way the economy had slowed without stalling, thereby limiting upward pressure on prices.
Securities markets showed little reaction to the data on G.D.P. Instead, traders focused on a separate report by corporate purchasing managers in the Chicago area that showed surprising industrial strength in the Midwest, taken by some as previewing national purchasing results to be published on Monday. Since the rise in the Chicago-area index, to 57.6 for April from 55 in March, contrasted sharply with a survey last week by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, bond prices eased. Stocks initially fell with bonds but subsequently recovered.
A report by New York purchasing managers, also published today, showed that the overall pace of business weakened in April, with the index of current conditions slipping to 47.2 after a March spurt. The manufacturing component, however, advanced sharply to the highest point since October.
In still another indicator, the University of Michigan's index of consumer confidence edged down to 92.5 for April from 93.8 at its interim reading in mid-month. The March figure was 90.3.
Mr. Aspinwall predicted that the economy would grow as much as 2 percent in the current quarter and 2.5 to 3 percent in the second half of the year. "Inventories have been unusually low relative to sales," he said.
Goods that are produced but not yet sold are counted as part of G.D.P., making inventories a major swing factor in tabulations of economic growth.
Large stocks tend to lead eventually to production cutbacks, but analysts say that even after four straight quarters of sizable increases -- the latest, $63 billion at an annual rate, is the biggest -- inventories are still not a major burden.
Consumers did little during the first quarter to bolster the economy. Personal spending rose at a rate of just 1.4 percent, far below the 5.1 percent splurge in the October-December period.
This meant that the sector that accounts for two-thirds of G.D.P. -- $3.64 trillion of $5.47 trillion at the first-quarter rate -- accounted for only one-third of the growth and contributed only enough to offset the contraction from the import-export sector. Exports actually fell slightly after a big advance, with shipments to Mexico down enough to trim G.D.P. by perhaps two-tenths of a point, one official estimated.
With the various negatives, including another decline in purchases by the Federal Government, David Bostian, economist at Herzog, Heine, Geduld, cautioned that the economy "may hit the runway a little bit harder" than the hoped-for soft landing sought by policy makers, but he predicted there would be no recessionary "crackup."
Corporate investment in new equipment grew at a sizzling annual rate of 20.8 percent that included all subgroups, the report also showed, while nonresidential structures climbed at a 14.1 percent rate.
Among prices related to output, the G.D.P. deflator showed a 2.2 percent inflation rate in the first quarter, up from 1.3 percent in the final months of last year. The fixed-weight price index for domestic purchases, which in contrast to the deflator does not reflect shifts in the composition of output, rose to 2.8 percent from 2.6 percent.
G.D.P. expressed in current dollars rather than in constant 1987 dollars, advanced at a 5.1 percent pace in the latest period, down from 6.4 percent in the fourth quarter of 1994.
Reflecting lower spending by consumers, the savings rate -- personal saving as a percentage of disposable personal income -- moved up to 5.2 percent from 4.6 percent, the department also reported.

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Weaken on Some Upbeat Economic Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were weaker yesterday after economic data on manufacturing and consumer sentiment failed to confirm that economic growth was slowing enough to allay fears of inflation.
The Government reported yesterday that economic growth slowed to a 2.8 percent pace in the first three months of 1995, from 5.1 percent in the previous quarter. Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist at PNC Bank in Pittsburgh, noted that the data showed a moderation in economic growth nearer to the level sought by the Federal Reserve, while inflation held steady at around 3 percent. 
 But the effects of the Government's report were undermined by independent data showing strength in manufacturing in the Chicago area and in consumer sentiment.
The price of the 30-year bond slipped 1/32 of a percentage point, to 103 17/32 , leaving its yield unchanged at 7.33 percent. Prices of shorter- maturity bills and intermediate-term notes were weaker. The yield on the one-year bill rose 6 basis points, to 5.91 percent, and the yield on a five-year note rose 4 basis points, to 6.87 percent. Yields and prices move in opposite directions; a basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Traders focused on the Chicago Purchasing Management Association's index for April, which rose to 57.6 from 55 in March, a sharper rise than expected.
The Chicago index is often viewed as a prelude to the report by the National Association of Purchasing Managers, which is scheduled to be released on Monday. The Chicago report showed strength in manufacturing in the upper Midwest, contrasting sharply with the regional weakness seen in a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia last week.
Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, noted that all the components of the Chicago index -- except for supplier deliveries and prices paid -- registered increases during April. "The data, nevertheless, indicate a deceleration in activity relative to 1994," she said.
One trader said yesterday: "The purchasing management report doesn't necessarily signal a resurgence in manufacturing around the country. But has the economy slowed? Yes. Has it stopped? No."
In another sign of economic strength, the University of Michigan index of consumer sentiment rose to 92.5 in April from 90.3 in March.
Mr. Hoffman of PNC Bank noted that some of the strength in yesterday's data showed that the deceleration in the economy was not a free fall. "Over the last couple of months, everything has been down," Mr. Hoffman said. "What today's report did was remind the market that things can go up."
He added, "The slow rise in consumer confidence and the Chicago purchasing managers' index in April confirm that the slowdown is not snowballing into something worse."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
In Thin Trading, Dollar Rallies Against the Mark and the Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rallied against the German mark and the Japanese yen yesterday in thin, choppy trading.
Some currency dealers attributed the advance to growing perceptions that the American economy could strengthen later this year and to resilient hopes after this week's meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations that there may be some coordinated international effort to bolster the dollar. Technical factors also helped the dollar, dealers said. 
 The volume of trading was light, exaggerating movements, ahead of holidays in Europe and Japan. Monday is a national holiday in much of Europe, and next week is the Golden Week of holidays in Japan.
But traders said the advance yesterday was significant and suggested a possible shift in underlying sentiment about the anemic dollar.
"We're closing on a very positive note for the end of the week," said Paul Alley, assistant vice president at the foreign exchange desk of the New York branch of the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan. Still, "this whole thing could disappear Monday," he said. "If there's no follow-through buying, this was an aberration."
The dollar rose as high as 1.3945 marks, its highest level since April 13, before settling in late New York trading at 1.3874 marks, up from 1.3785 marks on Thursday. The dollar climbed to 84.26 yen, from 83.68 yen. For the week, the dollar was up 1.77 percent against the yen, its biggest one-week gain in four months.
The dollar initially weakened on a Government report that the United States economy's growth rate fell to 2.8 percent in the first three months of the year, the weakest since the summer of 1993. But dollar buyers emerged and the currency zigzagged higher throughout the rest of the day.
The dollar was further bolstered by a report from the Purchasing Management Association of Chicago that pointed to strong economic growth in April.
"We've overdone the view that the U.S. economy is weakening," said John Rothfield, a currency market analyst with the Chicago office of Nationsbank.
The dollar was helped further yesterday by traders who had sold the dollar short, or bet the dollar would fall. When the dollar began rising instead, they had to buy dollars to minimize their losses, which created a big run-up in the dollar's value late in the day.
"The dollar went through certain levels, and this initiated the move in the dollar all the way up to 139.50 marks," said Jesse Torres, chief dealer at the New York branch of Bank Austria. "Once everyone cleaned out their short positions, some sellers moved in."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Lumber Prices Decline Sharply; Gasoline Rises to 3-Year High

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Lumber prices fell sharply yesterday as yards unloaded inventories because of the weak housing market.
"A lot of wholesalers and yards bought lumber last week to plug holes in their inventories, but now everyone seems to be concentrating on just selling what they've got," said Curt Cunningham, president of the Pacific Futures Trading Company in Eugene, Ore. "There's no new business out there to justify any price increases." 
 On other commodity markets, gasoline prices rose. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities fell 0.16 point, to 235.30.
May lumber fell $3.40, to $254.40 for 1,000 board feet, on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the lowest price since July 1993.
Higher mortgage rates have dampened growth in home sales, leaving bulging inventories at companies that stocked up on lumber in anticipation of a seasonal surge in construction. About 70 percent of the lumber produced in North America is used in the construction industry.
"Right now, it seems like all segments of the lumber business have slowed," said Gene Walters, general lumber sales manager with Willamette Industries Inc., a forest and paper products company in Portland, Ore.
Gasoline rose to the highest price in nearly three years as companies bought the expiring May contract as a way to secure supplies, which some analysts say will not be sufficient to meet demand.
American gasoline inventories fell last week and now are 3 percent smaller than a year ago, even as refiners increased gasoline production and total output to the highest rate since early January, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, unleaded gasoline for May delivery rose 0.37 cent, to 65.33 cents a gallon, the highest price since June 1992. June crude oil slipped 5 cents, to $20.38 a barrel, while the expiring May heating oil contract lost 0.07 cent, to 51.19 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Replacement Umpires Called Out in Toronto

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Baseball management suffered another legal loss yesterday when the Ontario Labor Board ruled that the American League cannot use replacement umpires for Blue Jays games in Toronto.
 The league received one break: The board made the decision effective next Wednesday, after the Blue Jays' current homestand ends, meaning neither the league nor the team faces a problem until the Yankees play at the Skydome on May 9. 
 "This will give the parties an opportunity to consider their legal and collective bargaining positions prior to the Blue Jays' return to Toronto later in May," the board's decision said.
 The 64 major league umpires have been locked out since Jan. 1. The American and National Leagues took that step when their collective bargaining agreement with the umpires expired. Replacement umpires worked all exhibition games and have worked the games since the season began Tuesday night.
 Ontario provincial law prohibits the use of replacement workers during a strike or a lockout. When the players were on strike, and it appeared that the owners were going to start the season with replacement players, the Blue Jays planned to play their home games at their spring training site in Dunedin, Fla.
 League lawyers had argued that the law didn't apply to the American League because it was not a Canadian employer. But the board found, after a two-day hearing, that not only was the use of replacements unlawful, but the lockout was also unlawful.
 Richie Phillips, the umpires' lawyer, was delighted at the outcome, saying he hoped "this monumental victory for the umpires will pave the way for a total resolution" of the dispute.
 In the dispute over salaries and other economic issues, the two sides are an estimated $10 million apart over what would be the four-year term of a new agreement.
 Speaking of the Ontario ruling, the leagues' negotiator, Robert Kheel, said, "In practical terms it has no effect at all until the next homestand, by which time we can make whatever arrangements are appropriate, either with the association or by use of other creative legal procedures."
 If no settlement is reached by May 9, the league may tell the umpires association four of its members can work Blue Jays home games. But Phillips has said that would be a selective end to the lockout, and would not be legal.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The High Court Loses Restraint

 BODY:
In deciding that Congress lacks the power to outlaw gun possession within 1,000 feet of a school, the Supreme Court has taken an unfortunate historical turn and needlessly questioned previously settled law.
Chief Justice William Rehnquist mustered a 5-to-4 majority for this brake on Congressional power to legislate a wide range of activities under the Constitution's commerce clause, but the dissenters had the better case. Justice Stephen Breyer made clear the value of judicial restraint, of deferring to Congress when Congress showed a rational basis for finding an interstate commercial impact in its law. Justice David Souter warned that the Court might be repeating past mistakes when justices obstructed Congress by substituting their judgments about commerce for the legislature's. 
 At its best, the Court has recognized the genius of the American way of fostering and regulating commerce in a large and free nation. Chief Justice John Marshall honored the early vision of a national common market not subject to toll collectors at every state line, for the movement of goods and services. Regulation of commerce "among the several states" is assigned to the national Congress, a body not confined to state borders nor bound to concepts of an 18th-century economy.
The Supreme Court occasionally threw obstacles in the way. A century ago it made hair-splitting, unreal distinctions between "manufacture" and commerce, hobbling consumer legislation aimed at an entire industry's operation. Most freakish was the Court's famous discovery that organized baseball was not commerce at all, just a game.
Another wrong turn by the Court crippled the early New Deal laws. The last time the Court struck down a law as beyond the commerce power was in 1936, when the "Nine Old Men" held that labor relations at a coal mine were "a local affair." By 1942 the Court was sustaining -- rightly, the justices agreed this week -- Federal crop limits imposed on an Ohio farmer who grew wheat only for his own consumption.
Like most states, Texas, where the court case arose, has its own gun laws aimed at school safety, so localities can survive the reversal of Alfonso Lopez's conviction in Federal court for carrying a .38-caliber hundgun into his San Antonio high school. But the Court decision has cast doubt on many other enactments as well. The opinion seriously undermines the doctrine of deference to Congress, especially at the edge of economic change where Congress, for all its faults, is better positioned to know what modern interstate commerce means.
The dissenters argued cogently that Congress, in passing the Gun-Free School Zones Act of 1990, had sufficient reason to invoke its commerce power. Gun violence in city schools affects the economy by influencing where businesses and people locate and by hindering the education of the future work force.
According to the Chief Justice, Alfonso Lopez "was a local student at a local school; there is no indication that he had recently moved in interstate commerce." That ignored decades of understanding that Congress has the right to consider the ripple effect of matters that did not, at first glance, seem directly related to manufacturing, transportation and sales.
This gun law can probably be restored, perhaps by requiring the prosecution to prove that the weapon moved in interstate commerce. But such formalism should not be necessary. Nor should Congress wonder anew about the constitutionality, for example, of abortion-clinic safety laws. They are based in part on the fact that when clinics are bombed, sometimes by terrorists who have moved themselves or their explosives across state lines, women must travel to other states to exercise their constitutional right to terminate a pregnancy.
This newspaper has questioned the wisdom of much new crime legislation that makes a Federal case out of local muggings. But to strip Congress of the power to function is a throwback to the misguided rulings of earlier times. The nation will be better off if the Court now makes clear that the Lopez case was a single day's departure from judicial restraint in what the majority deemed an extreme overreach by Congress.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: A Business-Hungry Vietnam Forgets . . .

BYLINE: By Peter Ross Range; Peter Ross Range was Time magazine's last bureau chief in Saigon.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The general yawn provoked in Vietnam by Robert McNamara's controversial mea culpa tells a great deal about the enduring difference between the American and Vietnamese relationships to the war.
In both Hanoi and Saigon, as the bustling southern city is still commonly called, the focus is on the present and future, not on the sins of the past. "Vietnam is a country, not a war," Deputy Foreign Minister Le Mai is fond of saying. Mr. McNamara's tears are not Vietnam's. 
 Even tomorrow's 20th anniversary of the country's reunification (in Vietnam, it's the reunification, not the war victory, that counts) is seen as a minor distraction from the real business at hand -- that of becoming the next Asian tiger. Workers were building bleachers in the park in front of the old Presidential palace in Saigon last week for a parade, but almost nobody I met cared.
Vietnam today is in the business of business. Even Hanoi, the once sleepy outpost of post-colonial charm and Soviet collectivism, is a cauldron of capitalism. Everybody, everywhere, is selling something. From the soup stall to the high-rise construction cranes, the country resembles nothing so much as the unbridled free-market economies of the West or, better, of the Asian tigers Vietnam seeks so ardently to emulate. Hanoi is madly striking deals with international investors eager to rebuild roads, phone systems and the remaining machinery of a market economy.
Yet American businessmen find themselves handicapped in a game fueled by cash streams from Hong Kong, Japan, Taiwan, Singapore and Australia. The lack of full diplomatic relations between the U.S. and Vietnam, held up by the demands of the tiny missing-in-action lobby, cripples American companies by preventing them from using such key instruments as the Export-Import Bank. The consensus among Americans in Hanoi is that closer relations would foster closer cooperation and enhance the full accounting that M.I.A. lobbyists seek. President Clinton should break the impasse with a historic exchange of ambassadors with Vietnam.
Hanoi strikes the visitor as a surprisingly free and open place. I detected none of the dangerous electricity I always felt in the Moscow and East Berlin of old, where you knew the heavy hand of the secret constabulary was only a phone tap away. In Hanoi, men in uniform were few and far between; if anything, the city needs more cops on the street to manage the colossal traffic.
This climate extends to the flow of information. Local TV is heavily westernized. On my first night in town, I was stunned to see "Apocalypse Now" showing on the main channel. On other days, Oprah, Popeye, the Masters tournament and the N.C.A.A. final four -- the jewels of American popular culture -- washed over the doorman and drivers gathered before the TV set in my hotel lobby.
Though Government-controlled, the press is relatively uppity, reporting all manner of corruption, scandal and general incompetence. When the much admired Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's semiretired dictator and Hanoi's unofficial chief adviser, was in town this month, he publicly upbraided the Government of Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet for "your inability administratively." He was impatient with continuing bureaucratic impediments to private investment and miffed at yet another power outage that had killed his mike and darkened the hall where he was about to speak. All this received front-page treatment in the press.
This does not mean Vietnam is free in larger terms. It is a one-party state with secret surveillance of those thought to be a threat. Some key Buddhist leaders are imprisoned, some intellectuals gagged or hounded, some harsh sentences meted out for the slightest show of dissent -- such as the 15 years given to a man named Pham Van Quang for waving the flag of the former South Vietnam during the 1992 Ho Chi Minh City international marathon.
Still, political repression is hardly a topic that's on everybody's lips. As best I could tell, in fact, it was on nobody's lips, unless I brought it up. The national preoccupation is economic, not political, and Vietnam is clearly a country on the make.
Nine years into doi moi, Vietnam's perestroika, the leadership is obviously doing something right. "The Communists have succeeded," said my old anti-Communist friend Ly Quy Chung one day in Saigon. It was an extraordinary admission from a former opposition politician, now a journalist, who had battled both the Viet Cong and the U.S.-supported Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu in the 1970's.
He meant that his old enemies, after the "10 dark years" from 1975 to 1985, had now got it right, not merely economically but politically as well. By giving the people what they want -- the liberty to pursue economic happiness -- the Communist gerontocracy is able to keep what it wants: full control.
But many think Vietnam, opened to the West and electronically liberated by sidewalk fax and photocopy stalls, is slouching toward democracy. By putting the war behind them and eagerly grasping their future, the Vietnamese are able to forgive and forget and move forward. The question is whether America is ready to do the same.

HEADLINE: METHOD & MADNESS;
Eyes on the Prize

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS WADE 

 BODY:
A PRIZE TO HONOR INVENTORS the way the Nobel Prize exalts scientists? That's what the Massachusetts Institute of Technology thinks is needed. And last month, with a $500,000 purse from a wealthy inventor, Jerome Lemelson, it chose its first laureate.
A prize committee led by the economist Lester Thurow scoured the nation for a candidate who would "personify American ingenuity." And what cutting-edge invention did they find to honor? What new Edison was ushered onto the public stage? The palm went to an automotive engineer employed by General Motors. His chief gift to civilization: not the phone, the transistor or the Internet, but helping to develop the traction control system of the Saturn automobile. 
 Mr. Lemelson, if you'd been hoping to get the public excited about invention, M.I.T. has just blown $500,000 of your money. Instead of thinking about the prize creatively, they've spent it cozying up to a big corporate sponsor. And like the many award givers that strive to imitate the Nobel Prize, they've missed some easy ways to improve on it.
There are two kinds of prizes, one designed to prompt new invention, the other to reward work already done. The prospective kind of prize requires superb technical insight. A suitable technical goal has to be set, one that's not too easy but doesn't require the next century's technology either. In 1959 the physicist Richard Feynman presciently offered two $1,000 prizes for the first steps toward what is now called nanotechnology. He had to pay up for one almost immediately, for the other 26 years later.
Henry Kremer, an English industrialist, offered a 50,000 prize (roughly $100,000 at the time) in 1959 for the first human-powered flight under reasonably testing conditions. His challenge wasn't met for 18 years, when Paul MacCready created the Gossamer Condor, a glorious mixture of piano wire, economic design and bicycle power that now hangs in the Smithsonian.
Another stimulating prize of the prospective variety is the $100,000 that the computer scientist Edward Fredkin has offered for the first computer program to win the world chess championship. The prize hasn't yet been claimed, but it may be only a matter of years before a non-human triumphs in this most intellectual of sports.
Choosing the right goal is a matter of fine technical judgment, but M.I.T. would surely not shrink from the challenge. Its inspiration should be the 23 major unsolved problems drawn up in 1900 by the mathematician David Hilbert, an agenda that has energized mathematicians ever since. I would have M.I.T. devise a list of the 20 major technical innovations likely to have the greatest impact on the economy, and I'd award a $500,000 prize each time one of these landmark objectives was reached.
But if the goals were properly challenging, that wouldn't happen every year. So most years I'd allot the $500,000 to a retrospective prize, though not by the lazy method of the Nobel committee and its many imitators. What those prize givers crave most is safety. They like to give their award to scientists who have collected lesser prizes already, which is why a narrow group of scientists garners almost all the available prizes. A principal exception to this rule is the Lasker Prize for medical research; its committee seems to work harder and is willing to take chances. Last year, for example, it gave its prize to Stanley Prusiner, a neurologist at the University of California at San Francisco, for inferring the existence of disease agents called prions -- even though Prusiner has not proved their existence to everyone's satisfaction.
Even the safety-first method doesn't prevent prizes from being wrongly awarded on occasion. Prize committees seldom have the time or aptitude to investigate the specific circumstances of a discovery. Columbia University in 1980 and the General Motors Cancer Research Foundation in 1981 both gave prizes to Cesar Milstein for the invention of monoclonal antibodies, ignoring the other author on the discovery paper, who was a mere graduate student of Milstein's. Had they or their advisers bothered to ask, they would have learned that the graduate student, Georges Kohler, conceived and executed the critical experiment. (In 1984, Kohler shared the Nobel Prize for Medicine with Milstein and a third recipient.)
The Nobel physics committee honored Antony Hewish in 1974 for the discovery of a unique class of stars called pulsars, doubtless because the professors who advised the committee believed professors deserve credit for everything that happens in the laboratory. But the pulsars were first discovered, and their nature confirmed, by Hewish's graduate student Jocelyn Bell.
The wider point is that, by making heroes of individual scientists, the Nobel and other prize committees distort the true pattern of discovery, which is often an interactive process in which many researchers contribute vital pieces to the problem. Like Robin Hood in reverse, a prize committee often robs credit from many to make just a handful rich.
Why do scientists, for whom intellectual credit is so important, tolerate the crudities of so slapdash a system? There's an easy way to make prize-giving more rigorous, and M.I.T. should apply it to the retrospective part of the Lemelson prize.
Having decided which discovery to honor, the selection committee should assign a historian of science or a journalist to write its full history, going beyond the deliberately ahistorical accounts in the scientific literature by interviewing all those who contributed pieces to the puzzle. The history of the invention would be laid out in a monograph, and all those mentioned would thereby receive due credit for their work, even if the prize money were given just to the major contributor.
Prize committees seldom give written explanations for their awards for fear of challenge. But a well-researched monograph would prevent a committee from honoring the wrong person. It would also show the public how often scientific discovery is a rich and complex social progress, not the crude apple-drops-on-Newton affair implied by the Nobel Prize and its imitators. A scientific prize committee that produced visible proof of having done its homework would so distinguish itself from its peers that it would soon eclipse them.
Mr. Lemelson, the $6.7 million gift you've given M.I.T. for your prize surely buys the right to expect some fun, some fireworks and the intellectual energy to distinguish between a creative invention and improving a power train. Don't let them rob you again next year.

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
Hems and Haws

BYLINE: By MAX FRANKEL 

 BODY:
IF YOU'VE EVER THROWN OUT A RACK OF skirts because they suddenly looked too short or a collection of ties because they suddenly seemed too wide, you have been, depending on your attitude about shopping, either a beneficiary or victim of fashion. If you have wondered about the source of those periodic changes of taste, you also qualify as a student of fashion. Responding to these urges, hundreds of journals and newspapers deem it their duty to instruct you in the vagaries of dress and the musings of designers; indeed, some exist mainly to harvest the advertisements that flourish in such manuals. But they rarely teach you what is really going on.
The best of the fashion magazines, like Vogue and Harper's Bazaar, satisfy a lust for fantasy, the imaginary try-on of clothes you couldn't afford, fit into or dare to wear. The better newspapers report colorfully on the semiannual runway romps in Paris, Milan and New York. That is where the most famous designers advertise themselves by draping unnaturally thin, beautiful women in outrageous or sumptuous ways and exhort the public with novelties of style that might stimulate the sale of mass-produced imitations. 
 Only rarely, however, do fashion articles satisfy my primal urge to understand the designers' sources of inspiration and the industry's strategies of obsolescence. How do they plot the hemline's descent from thigh to ankle, or shall it be the knee? Who leads, who copies, who resists? Does Barneys' vote count for more than Bradlees'? Will they next attack my wide lapels or merely condemn the white collar on my blue shirt? How much influence do consumers really exert?
I FOUND ONLY A FEW CLUES THIS SPRING IN the coverage of the shows in Europe and in the tents of Bryant Park in New York. Even the most knowledgeable magazines were so busy celebrating and prescribing novelty that they drowned out sober analysis:
"Suddenly clothes are beautiful again, rich-looking, well cut, sexy and demure at the same time in that Grace Kelly kind of way," Vogue proclaimed in March. "We go through these unfortunate and dangerous periods of puritanism in this country when to look nice is equated with possession by the devil or being Nancy Reagan. . . . The hard-edged, Joan Crawford-style face is definitely giving way to a more delicate -- but equally icy -- Grace Kelly look." (Imagine this tone in other contexts: Suddenly chasing welfare cheats is popular again in that Ronnie Reagan kind of way. . . . The bleeding-heart, Lyndon Johnson-style is definitely giving way to a more responsible -- but equally humane -- Herbert Hoover look.)
Just a month later, without a by-your-leave, Vogue was weakening on the tough stuff again: "Who says soft florals -- and other feminine prints -- can't have their harder side? In the spirit of Pulp Fiction's retro chic, spring's key looks -- simple dresses, flirty skirts and structured swimsuits -- are toughening up with dramatic details, including slick stiletto heels and deep red lips and nails." (Who says Newt Gingrich can't love orphans?)
But then, between March and April, there seemed to be real news developing. Vogue quietly pulled up the hems in its photographs, to the knee. Harper's Bazaar brazenly pounced on the whiff of a trend: "Paris says it's official: the new length is on the knee . . . jackets are tiny and waisted . . . shoes are stilettos . . . stockings are sheer . . . hair is set . . . jewelry is back."
Paris says? Milan and New York only parrot? "It is the only length that can be accepted in a feminist epoch," Marc Audibet, a French designer, intoned in Time -- ignoring a decade of wild hem gyrations. "A long length isn't practical, and a miniskirt won't work because of today's sexual wars. This skirt length is the only one that could be really new."
Time itself ratified the trend but insisted on credit for America. It argued that recent obituaries for Audrey Hepburn and Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis had reinforced the sexy but classy Grace Kelly look. And Bazaar opined that just as the grunge look hit the runways in the week of Bill Clinton's election, "the Newt Length" was riding the wave of rising Republican fortune.
"Still," Bazaar added, presumably for Democrats, "the emotional symbolism contained in these trends goes beyond straight party politics. . . . What makes the 50's-flavor feel right is the way it harks back to everything people feel they'd like in their lives now -- a sense of certainty and order, consensus, self-discipline and optimism."
I might have bought all this political linkage if it weren't for my colleague Amy Spindler. She dared to recall that designers, with desperate disdain for the customer, have been evoking a new era every six months, even in political off years. Yet she, too, smelled a trend in this year's American collections: they were "increasingly commercial" and betrayed the pressures designers were feeling from retailers and their own boutiques, from sales staffs, licensees and the fashion press.
Women's Wear Daily, the industry's house organ, elaborated on these business pressures by greeting the New York shows with a loud reminder of Seventh Avenue's "Great Depression." It ran a full-page portrait of Sigmund Freud, cigar in hand, complaining that 30 years of research still left him wondering, "What does a woman want?" It caught retailers complaining about designers, designers complaining about the models and everyone complaining about the press. By rewarding glitz and glitter with flattering publicity, it seems, the press had lured designers into betraying their true artistry.
Only between the lines did I sense that pressure from retailers weighed heaviest on this year's fashion circus. Business has bombed of late and left everyone panting for that rarity -- a design consensus for a salable head-to-toe makeover. As Elisabeth Bumiller described the longed-for look in The Washington Post: "Conservative chic for women in their late 30's and 40's and 1960's mod for their daughters." Bazaar not only concurred but, with remarkable restraint, buried its trepidations deep in its report: "Bluntly, it's that or fashion Armageddon."
THESE CULLINGS FROM ONE SEASON'S fashion file should suffice to suggest what rich veins of sociology, commerce and psychiatry have been left unexplored by journalism. The big fashion magazines are so clearly part of the industry that they cannot stand analytically apart. (Because of a longstanding feud, even independent-sounding WWD unprofessionally forbids any mention of Geoffrey Beene, whom Spindler judges one of the best: "innovative and, yes, intellectual.")
The big newspapers, alas, too often consign fashion articles to their "soft news" pages, and write them accordingly. They seem to think that the decision of millions of women to replace or not to replace half their wardrobe has no real relevance to front-page economic and political life. In the hidebound, event-driven conventions of newspapering, the news that a President or First Lady favored longer skirts to stimulate the economy would probably land on the front page. But let normally competitive and contentious designers join with hungry retailers in a frantic international campaign to drop the hem to the knee and hardly any headlines catch the drift or track the trend. Maybe the mostly men in charge will notice when Brooks Brothers starts pushing Eisenhower jackets.

HEADLINE: Quick Trips to the Hermitage

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRAEBER; LAUREL GRAEBER is a writer and editor who contributes frequently to The Times.

 BODY:
RUSSIA has never been famous for sharing its secrets with the West. But this spring witnessed a notable exception: the opening of "Hidden Treasures Revealed: Impressionist Masterpieces and Other Important French Paintings Preserved by the State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg." Both a substantial symbol of the new Russian openness and a major event in the art world, the exhibition consists of 74 paintings that were taken out of Europe by Russian forces during World War II and concealed under lock and key for 50 years. On view through October 29, the exhibition includes Degas's "Place de la Concorde," which was presumed destroyed during the war; Renoir's "In the Garden," never before exhibited, and one of van Gogh's final paintings, "The White House at Night."
"Every day I get many letters and many phone calls about the exhibition," said Valentin I. Manturov, director, U.S.A., of the newly established Russian National Tourist Office in New York. "People ask how to go, how to book hotels, and they have many questions about the exhibit." 
 In response, many tour operators are offering short packages departing from Finland (and sometimes from the United States). It's possible to travel by air, train, bus or boat, and to find excursions for a range of budgets. A tour of the Hermitage and of "Hidden Treasures Revealed" are usually included, with the advantage that the traveler does not have to wait in one of those legendary Russian lines for entry. There are also more opportunities for independent travel, with individual itineraries and private guided tours. Keep in mind that a Russian visa is almost always required, and that hotels usually impose a surcharge for single rooms. The accommodations mentioned here have been rated by the Russian Travel Bureau: five-star hotels are deluxe, Western-style establishments; four- and three-star are clean and comfortable but have fewer amenities (don't expect room service or an ice machine in the hall). Here are some of the options.
 
By Air
Finnway, a subsidiary of the Finnish airline Finnair, offers both the four-day, three-night "St. Petersburg Flyaway" and the three-day, two-night "Czarist Russia -- St. Petersburg by Air." Both are led by an English-speaking guide.
"What we usually do is part of the regular Hermitage tour and also the Impressionists -- so that everyone going gets to see the exhibit," said Anneli Karppinen, president of Finnway.
For the "Flyaway" tour, flights leave from Helsinki every Saturday morning; the package includes air fare, meals, a theater or folklore performance, sightseeing and a Sunday afternoon tour of the museum. Prices per person staying in a double room vary from $629 at St. Petersburg's three-star Hotel Ohtinskaya to $1,059 for the five-star Hotel Grand Europe, a Western-style establishment. Flights for "Czarist Russia" leave Helsinki early every Friday afternoon from June 2 to Sept. 1. The offerings are similar to those of the "Flyaway"; city sightseeing includes a Saturday afternoon tour of the Hermitage and a Sunday trip to a czarist palace. The price is $830 a person, which includes double accommodations at the five-star Russian-owned Hotel Astoria, which is near the museum. Information: (800) 526-4927 or (212) 818-1198.
Holiday Tours in New York offers several packages from Helsinki to St. Petersburg. Its three-day, two-night "St. Petersburg by Air" follows a schedule much like Finnway's "Czarist Russia," with Friday afternoon flights through the summer. For $775, the tour includes the main attractions of St. Petersburg, a full afternoon at the Hermitage and a visit to an imperial palace, with double rooms at the five-star Hotel Nevsky Palace, which is quite close to the museum. Information: (800) 677-6454 or (212) 832-8989.
For travelers wishing for more variety and a slightly longer stay, General Tours in Keene, N.H., which handles tours of Eastern Europe via Delta Airlines, offers "St. Petersburg Story," a six-day, four-night tour departing from the United States. Prices, including air fare, range from $1,169 for double accommodations at the four-star Hotel Pribaltiiskaya to $1,849 for the Grand Hotel Europe. (Departures from Helsinki can also be arranged, at prices ranging from $1,152 to $1,632, including round-trip train fare.) In either case, a private three-hour guided tour of the Hermitage Museum, including "Hidden Treasures Revealed," is an additional $45. The package is unescorted, but General's staff of Russian tour managers in St. Petersburg are available to handle specific requests. Information: (800) 221-2216 or (603) 357-5033.
Union Tours and the Russian Travel Bureau, both in New York, also offer the option of a departure from either the United States or Helsinki. Among Union's "Short Stay City Packages" is a three-night visit to St. Petersburg. The price covers round-trip trans-Atlantic passage on Finnair and per-person double accommodations in either the renovated three-star St. Petersburg Hotel ($889) or the luxurious Grand Europe ($1,199). (The same tour, originating in Helsinki, including round-trip train fare, ranges from about $289 to $649.) A four-hour private tour of the Hermitage for two people is an additional $50 per person. Information: (800) 451-9511 or (212) 683-9500.
The Russian Travel Bureau, which despite its name is an American-owned company, has put together its "Welcome America" package, a weeklong trip that includes a visit to "Hidden Treasures Revealed." Prices begin at $1,089 for round-trip Finnair flights from the United States to St. Petersburg, connecting in Helsinki, with accommodations at three-star hotels, daily breakfasts, sightseeing, a theater performance and special restaurant and shop discounts for tour participants. (The price for the package with Helsinki as the point of origin, including air fare, is $699.) Weekend departures begin May 21. Information: (800) 847-1800 or (212) 986-1500.
Museums and publications are also planning tours. The Educated Traveler magazine, in conjunction with The Traveler's Guide to Art Museum Exhibitions, is sponsoring three special fall packages: Sept. 4 to 11, Sept. 18 to 25 and Sept. 25 to Oct. 2. The schedule for each includes an afternoon at the Hermitage's private collections (tour members can return for another half-day if they wish) and an entire morning at "Hidden Treasures Revealed," where the guides will include an art historian and Albert Kostenevich, the author of the exhibition catalogue, published by Harry N. Abrams. The cost of the tour, which also includes the Russian Museum, is $3,000 a person; the fee covers round-trip fare on Finnair from New York City (connecting in Helsinki), meals, sightseeing, entertainment and accommodations at the Hotel Nevsky Palace. For information, call International Seminar Design, which is also handling bookings for a tour Sept. 12 to 19 sponsored by the North Carolina Museum of Art: (202) 244-1448.
The Santa Barbara Museum of Art in California is offering its own one-time-only tour, Oct. 5 to 12, that focuses on "Hidden Treasures Revealed." Open to nonmembers of the museum, it is currently limited to 25 people. Participants will spend a full day at the Hermitage, with a private catered lunch and a private guided tour of the exhibition. The cost of $2,885 includes round-trip Finnair flights from New York, double accommodations at the Hotel Astoria, all meals, entertainment and sightseeing. From Helsinki, the package, including round-trip air fare to and from Finland only, costs $2,485. The museum has a 24-hour information line: (805) 963-4364, ext. 336.
 
By Land
Tourists traveling to Finland who would like to have the most economical visit to St. Petersburg can choose to take a train or a bus. Two trains, one Finnish and one Russian, depart daily from Helsinki at 6:30 A.M. and 3:32 P.M., respectively. Depending on the schedule, the trip to St. Petersburg takes seven to eight hours; the return is under six. One-way costs range from $70 for second-class travel to $115 to $130 for first class. Several tour packages take advantage of this inexpensive ground transportation.
Finnway's "St. Petersburg by Train" tour is four days and three nights, running weekly from May 29 to Sept. 4. The $550 price includes a second-class compartment on the Sibelius (the Finnish train) plus meals and double accommodations in a three-star hotel. The program's guide accompanies the group from Helsinki, leading them on tours to city sites, an imperial palace and the Hermitage, where the participants spend an afternoon.
Finnway's "St. Petersburg by Bus," also four days and three nights, departs from Helsinki every Tuesday from May 2 to Oct. 10. Participants ride through southern Finland, and on Wednesday tour St. Petersburg's Nevsky Prospekt in the morning and the Hermitage in the afternoon. Parks and palaces are also among the stops. The $480 price covers meals and a double room at a four-star hotel.
Holiday Tours offers three train tours from Helsinki to St. Petersburg; two are escorted, the other independent. All include morning travel on the Sibelius and a half-day visit to the Hermitage. The four-day, three-night escorted tour, running Monday to Thursday from May 29 to Sept. 4, costs $510 in a four-star hotel. The three-day, two-night escorted tour, available June 18 to Aug. 20, ranges from $495 per person for a double in a four-star hotel to $795 for five-star accommodations. The unescorted tour, three days and two nights, allows travelers their choice of hotel accommodations ($415, $660 or $840 a night), with a private guided tour of the Hermitage and private-car transportation and sightseeing.
Holiday has also put together a four-day, three-night bus tour from May 2 to Oct. 10, which includes three-star hotel stays at a cost of $460 per person. In addition to the Hermitage, all the overland tours include highlights selected from the parks, palaces and squares of the city.
 
By Ship
One of the most popular ways to visit St. Petersburg briefly is on board the Baltic Line's Konstantin Siminov, a Polish-built Russian ship with an English-speaking staff. The Siminov's four-day cruises, departing from Helsinki in the late afternoon on Mondays and Thursdays (the ship arrives in St. Petersburg the following morning), are visa-free, which means that individual visas are not required if the traveler purchases in advance one of several possible shore excursions; he can then get on and off the ship as much as he wants. There is always a shore excursion that includes a tour of the Hermitage.
Eurocruises in New York, for instance, sells a four-hour shore excursion to the Hermitage for $36. The Bergen Line, another New York operator, offers a half-day at the Hermitage for $26; a full day with city sightseeing in the morning and the Hermitage in the afternoon is $37.
Many tour companies book on the Siminov; from mid-May through late September, cruise prices range from a low of $190 per person double occupancy for an inside cabin (these are snapped up so quickly they are rarely available) to $690 for a suite. Good buys are available in between from about $310 to $485. The fees include all meals, on-board entertainment and port charges. For Eurocruises information, call (800) 688-3876 or (212) 691-2099; for Bergen Line, (800) 323-7436 or (212) 319-1300. Russian Waterway Cruises in Brooklyn is another source, offering longer cruises that include St. Petersburg and the exhibition as well as other ports of call. Information: (800) 828-7970 or (718) 934-4100.
 
Tailor-Made Tours
Independent travel, or a custom-designed tour, is another possibility -- an option not readily available under the old Soviet regime. Such tours impose no limits on hotel choices or the amount of time one can wander through the Hermitage. "People want their own guide and to go at their own pace," said Marylou H. Foley, president of Tour Designs in Washington. "We arrange tours to include just the Hermitage or more. And the thing to emphasize is that there is such a range of hotel prices. A small hotel, the Deson Ladoga, was recently renovated and probably qualifies as a Best Western three-star. It's great, but not usually advertised -- and just under $100 a night for two."
Tour Designs, for instance, could arrange a "bare bones" six-day, four-night program, including round-trip Finnair fares from New York City, double accommodations at the Deson Ladoga, daily breakfasts and two visits to the Hermitage (one a guided tour of "Hidden Treasures Revealed") for about $1,299 to $1,428, depending on the dates of travel. A similar four-day, four-night program, including air fare to and from Helsinki only, would cost $585 to $685 per person. Information: (800) 432-8687 or (202) 554-5820.
Russiatours in Tampa, Fla., also puts together packages for individual travelers. "We include round-trip air fare from Helsinki and any number of days in any hotel," said Gregory M. Tepper, director, sales and marketing. "Our tours are all with a private car driver and guide, and we budget a whole day at the Hermitage." A typical four-day package, with city sightseeing, the Hermitage and "Hidden Treasures" tour, a ballet performance and a visit to a country palace would run from $1,075 a person to $1,350, depending on the hotel selected. Information: (800) 633-1008 or (813) 987-2477.
Moscow Nights Travel, an operator in San Francisco, will devise individual or group tours focusing on the "Hidden Treasures" exhibition and departing from Finland or the United States. For information on standard or deluxe packages, call (800) 878-8829.
For continuing information on new tours as they arise, the Europe Travel Center in Herndon, Va., which specializes in Eastern Europe, maintains an up-to-date data base of individual and group programs traveling to Russia. Owned and operated by Jonathan Chase, the service provides both information and bookings. Call (703) 264-9746; they can be reached by E-mail at this address: 73232.1246@compuserve.com.
