HEADLINE: Along Times Sq., Signs of New Life Abound

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
FUSED together in legend and on the map, Times Square and 42d Street are still a world apart economically. Along the bow tie-shaped intersection of Broadway and Seventh Avenue, indications abound of fresh vitality: new leases, new construction, new supersigns.
There is evidence, too, in the demolition and construction that are actually under way, that the renascence of 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues may be at hand. 
 But the prospective tenants for the theaters that line 42d Street -- the Walt Disney Company, Viacom's MTV channel and American Multi-Cinema -- are in a holding pattern. Everyone, it seems, is waiting to see who will take the plunge first because no one wants to do it alone.
Charles A. Gargano, the new chairman of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, the corporate parent of the 42d Street Development Project Inc., said he and Gov. George E. Pataki were committed to "quick progress" on the 14-year-old project. "I'm determined to make this work," Mr. Gargano said.
For the moment, however, much of the action is around the corner, on Broadway.
The office space known as 1601 Broadway, at the base of the Crowne Plaza Hotel, between 48th and 49th Streets, is close to being leased to the American Management Association, which would occupy about 150,000 square feet. The retail space at the Bertelsmann Building, at 45th Street, which has been empty since the tower was completed five years ago, is being readied for a 65,000-square-foot music store (Virgin Megastore); a 35,000-square-foot, 750-seat sports-theme restaurant (the Official All Star Cafe) and the four-screen, 1,400-seat Sony State Theater.
At an "eight-digit" cost, Bertelsmann is rebuilding the shell of the base so tenants can get in by July and finish work on the spaces, said Hans-Martin Sorge, executive vice president and chief operating officer of Bertelsmann Inc. The complex is to open by Thanksgiving, Mr. Sorge added.
More surprising is the supersign under construction between 47th and 48th Streets; surprising because it is being built by Morgan Stanley, a global securities business that is not exactly known for razzle-dazzle self-promotion.
In buying the 42-story tower at 1585 Broadway, Morgan Stanley inherited a requirement, under the special Times Square zoning rules, that the building carry large, kinetic signage. The result is a giant information display, designed by Gwathmey Siegel & Associates and constructed by the Artkraft Strauss Sign Corporation. At the corners are two barrel-shaped maps, 44 feet high, with digital clocks telling the time around the world, highlighting cities where Morgan Stanley has offices.
Above these are three 140-foot-long electronic ticker boards, stacked atop each other. Two are 12 feet high and one is 10 feet high. They will use light-emitting diodes in place of incandescent bulbs and transmit information in "real time," as opposed to traditional traveling-message boards, which are programmed in advance. News bulletins might be carried on one board, with stock quotations on another and sports scores on the third. But nobody will say yet exactly what is planned.
At either end of the tickers will be 30-by-60-foot display boards capable of showing charts and other graphic images, as well as text. Ten decorative fins along the Broadway facade will be clad in mirrors, with blue-neon edges, and characters that spell out "1 5 8 5 B ' W A Y."
If the name "Morgan Stanley" appears anywhere at all on this extravaganza, it will be in discreet 7-inch-high letters on the global clock. But the company feels that a data-laden sign will convey its image as an information nerve center.
Morgan Stanley is readying the building for occupancy by year's end as its headquarters, with trading floors, investment banking and asset management offices. Although 1585 Broadway was virtually finished five years ago by Solomon Equities, the signage requirement does not take force until a certificate of occupancy is requested for more than half of a new building.
Because 1585 Broadway has been largely vacant, it isolated the Crowne Plaza Hotel, to the north, from the rest of Times Square. "This building being empty, without signs, was a missing link," said Michael Silberstein, a Crowne Plaza executive. "By lighting it up, it will make us part of the Great White Way, so we're very, very excited."
IN the base of the hotel structure is an eight-story commercial unit known as 1601 Broadway, which has never been leased. The American Management Association, a not-for-profit organization that primarily conducts seminars to teach people how to manage, is "very close" to signing a lease there, said Frank R. Giglio, corporate vice president and chief financial officer. The group is now at 135 West 50th Street.
By a curious twist, Mr. Giglio said, the association was the original tenant William Zeckendorf Jr. had in mind when he began the hotel and office project in the 1980's. As a result, the column-free floors suit the group's need for flexible meeting spaces.
The association is asking the city for some relief from real estate taxes, for which it would be liable as a tenant. Nonprofit groups are exempt from real estate taxes if they own their own space, but the association cannot afford to buy 1601 Broadway as a condominium. The building is owned by K.G. Land. The lease would run 20 years, Mr. Giglio said, although he would not disclose the rent.
Another vacant space at the Crowne Plaza has been the curving south wall of its base, which was designed for a supersign. It is finally to get a 100-by-20-foot spectacular, which will include a giant television screen (433 inches, measured diagonally). Mr. Silberstein said only that its sponsors would include "some major players from the technology side." The hotel is also replacing its 80-by-16-foot "Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza" sign, to reflect its simpler new name.
Another hotel that is bedecking itself is the Marriott Marquis, between 45th and 46th Streets. The north tower recently sprouted signs for Hertz and Maxwell House. George N. Stonbely, the president of Spectacolor, which leases the sign space from the hotel, said a new sign on the south tower would promote another "premier American corporation" with "a lot of new technology that's never been on display before."
Directly across Broadway from the Marriott Marquis is the Bertelsmann Building, which the German publishing, music and entertainment conglomerate purchased in 1992. Its 150,000-square-foot, six-story retail atrium has been empty.
"Our intention is to create an entertainment center, because we're here in Times Square," said Mr. Sorge, of Bertelsmann.
The Virgin Megastore, designed by B N K Architects and Irvine & Johnston, will be the "largest music-entertainment store in the world," said Richard Branson, chairman and chief executive of the Virgin Group.
On the ground floor will be rock, pop and soul music sections, accessories and other merchandise; the cellar will have blues, Broadway, classical, foreign, jazz, soundtrack and vocal sections and the sub-cellar will have a cafe, bookstore, laser video and CD-ROM section, as well as the entrance to the Sony theaters.
Sharing part of the ground floor with Virgin will be the All Star Cafe, whose main dining room will be on the second floor. The restaurant is being designed by Rockwell Architecture, Planning and Design and developed by Robert Earl, the creator of Planet Hollywood, who described it as the "world's foremost tribute to sport in the form of a restaurant."
The sports theme carries over to the next block, where Strykers Boxing and Sporting Club is to open May 19 in 12,000 square feet in the basement of the Actors' Equity Building, Broadway and 46th Street. The partners in Strykers are Arthur Cutler, the restaurateur behind Carmine's, Ollie's and Docks, and Tom Cavallaro, a boxing promoter.
"We're trying to bring boxing back to Broadway, the way it was in the 40's, when the greats were here," Mr. Cavallaro said. He said the club cost $2 million to build but would not disclose the terms of the lease.
Two generations ago, the space was Zimmerman's Hungaria Restaurant. Its vaulted ceilings survive and its multicolored terrazzo floors have been restored. The centerpiece of the new business is a 20-by-20-foot boxing ring surrounded by dozens of exercise machines, which can be moved aside to create a 540-seat arena. Besides the workout area, there are locker rooms, steam rooms and massage rooms, as well as a lounge. The architect and contractor is the Elevations Design and Construction Company.
Gretchen Dykstra, president of the Times Square Business Improvement District, said Strykers is a "wonderful spin on the whole entertainment theme" and "very sensitive to the gestalt of the neighborhood."
Perhaps the tallest question mark in the neighborhood is One Times Square, the slender tower that is the centerpiece of New Year's Eve. It was purchased last month, reportedly for $27.5 million, by Lehman Brothers, the investment banking house. That put an end to plans for an entertainment complex on the site by Pearson P.L.C., the British company that owns Madame Tussaud's wax exhibition. And earlier this month, the enormous signs on the northern prow advertising Minolta and Pepsi were dismantled by Van Wagner Communications, which maintained the signs and made its own bid on One Times Square.
ALTHOUGH Lehman Brothers is tight-lipped on its plans, Ms. Dykstra said the firm "shows all the potential signs of being a good neighbor." She said she had a "very reassuring" conversation with a Lehman executive who persuaded her of his intention to "find a suitable entertainment use" for the building.
All around One Times Square are the four sites on which Times Square Center Associates, a joint venture between the Prudential Insurance Company of America and Park Tower Realty, once hoped -- and still plans -- to construct four enormous office towers, once the real estate market has regained its strength.
For the time being, most of the existing buildings on those parcels are being renovated to permit an interim retail development of 80,000 square feet. There will also be 42,000 square feet of signage on the sites.
As part of the project, asbestos is being removed from the existing buildings, partition walls are being removed to open up spaces, and new electrical systems and heating, ventilating and air conditioning systems are being installed.
A spokesman for Times Square Center Associates said there was "a great deal of interest by an excellent mix of retail tenants" and that the stores and restaurants would probably begin opening in the first three months of 1996.
The largest available space will be in the former Nathan's Famous Restaurant at Broadway and 43d Street, a streamlined structure built 55 years ago. The first floor has 16,000 square feet; combined with second floor and cellar, it could yield 42,000 square feet. Next door, in the Longacre Building, 9,500 square feet are available.
The next largest block of space is in the Rialto Theater Building, Broadway and 42d Street. This exuberant Art Deco structure was built in 1935 to designs by Thomas W. Lamb and Rosario Candela. It has 12,000 square feet of retail space, plus a 500-seat theater, which was used most recently for "The Montel Williams Show." Several smaller buildings next door also have space.
A new 6,700-square-foot restaurant will be built at the "crossroads" site on 42d Street, between Broadway and Seventh Avenue. There will also be retail space in two other buildings on the same block.
Across Seventh Avenue, several small buildings have been torn down to make way for a new 4,600-square-foot store, which may be leased to the Disney company, along with a three-story building next door. This store would adjoin the New Amsterdam Theater, which Disney is planning to lease from New York State for 49 years and restore for live productions -- provided the cost is not too high and other companies also make a commitment to 42d Street. Disney has until July 15 to make up its mind.
A dramatic makeover is already occurring at the 95-year-old Victory Theater, 207 West 42d Street, which has been renamed the New Victory and is scheduled to open next December or January (about three to four months behind schedule) as a theater for young audiences. The $11.4 million renovation has been undertaken by the New 42d Street Inc., a nonprofit organization that holds the leases to six theaters, and underwritten by Times Square Center Associates, as part of the development deal.
Cora Cahan, president of the New 42d Street, said the Victory was the "second most splendid" of the neighboring theaters (the New Amsterdam is widely acknowledged as the crown jewel) but had "little commercial viability." The building is not much more than an auditorium, with almost no ancillary space. Also, its rich architectural fabric must be restored.
NEW space was excavated under ground for a lobby, lockers and concession stand, while the vault area under the sidewalk was used for new toilets. The dressing rooms and offices will occupy an old tenement on 43d Street that adjoins the back of the theater. A grand exterior staircase will be rebuilt on 42d Street. The architects for the renovation are Hardy Holzmann Pfeiffer Associates and the contractor is the F. J. Sciame Construction Company.
Next to the Victory is a cluster of three theaters on which Viacom holds an option: the Lyric, the Times Square and the Academy (also known as the Apollo). Although the company has developed ambitious plans for a studio complex including its MTV music channel, it has said almost nothing publicly. Mr. Gargano said the option had been extended until May 15 and that prospects for the project are good.
On the other side of 42d Street is a site on which American Multi-Cinema has proposed a 29-screen theater complex that would show first-run, second-run, revival and foreign movies, as well as virtual-reality offerings. This complex would include the Empire, Liberty and Harris Theaters, as well as a parcel to the west that is now in the process of condemnation.
Finally, at the westernmost end of the block, on Eighth Avenue, between 42d and 43d Streets, is the 57,500-square-foot, L-shaped parcel that has been set aside for a hotel and other uses. Three development teams are competing to develop the project and Mr. Gargano said a designation should be made before mid-May.
The teams are Marriott International and Triarc Equities Corporation, with Michael Graves as architect; Tishman Urban Development Corporation and Disney Development Corporation, with the Arquitectonica architectural firm and Milstein Properties Corporation, Weiler Arnow Management Company and Hilton Hotel Corporation, with the architect Zaha Hadid.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 6; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
Retiring the Water-Guzzlers of the Toilet World

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
NO conservation-minded inquisitor is likely to demand that New York City's householders reveal the number of times a day they flush their toilets. That's fortunate, because even ardent reflection may produce a blank.
But sages at the New York City Department of Environmental Protection say that there are at least four at-home flushes per person a day in the city. That's an average of 180 million gallons a day, or about 13.5 percent of total water consumption. The figure doesn't include flushes made in commercial and other nonresidential buildings. 
 Find a way to cut back on water consumed by toilet flushing and the pressure to expand the city's pumping capacity would be eased, as would the economic pressure on housing from rising charges for water and sewer service. Lower-income housing in particular has been hurt by the steady rise in water and sewer rates in recent years, largely because of higher occupancy rates.
So the department introduced the New York City Toilet Rebate Program, now entering its second year. It offers cash to owners who replace their old-style toilets, which use from 3.5 to 7 gallons per flush, with one that uses only 1.6 gallons, the only type that it is now legal to sell. They have to get low-flow showerheads and faucet aerators at the same time if they don't have them already.
The city pays $242 for the first toilet replaced and $150 for each additional toilet in the house or apartment. (Nonresidential buildings get a straight $150 per toilet.) In multifamily buildings at least 70 percent of all the toilets have to be replaced for the building to qualify. The work has to be done by one of the 350 licensed plumbers who have registered with the program.
The rebate is so calculated that the out-of-pocket cost to the participating owner is usually zero. The money goes eventually to the plumber, covering the cost of the product and the installation.
The program became effective citywide last August and has recently been picking up steam. The goal over three years is to replace about a third of the city's 3.5 million to 4 million toilets. That would save about 80 million or 90 million gallons of water a day. As of last Monday, owners had replaced 180,000 toilets in 6,800 properties, generating rebates of $32 million. There were 50,000 replacements in April and there will be 50,000 more in May. "We're on target," said Warren Liebold, director of water conservation in the environmental agency's Bureau of Water and Energy Conservation.
As expected, lower-income housing and lower-income neighborhoods have been the leading participants. Higher-income buildings, including many Manhattan co-ops, so far seem to be carrying on with high-consumption toilets. Since occupancy per unit is lower, water costs are a less significant factor in operating cost, though rising rates over time may change that. Nor have single-family homeowners come forward in large numbers. (Call (212) 685-5575 for information about the program.)
But it also appears that many landlords are hesitant about participating. "They're foolish!" said Jerome Waxenberg, principal in Norwax Associates in the Bronx, an owner-management firm that has installed new toilets in 3,000 apartments. "They say they don't want to be bothered by the paperwork, or they're afraid of stoppages, or leaks in the building, or they don't want the aggravation of dealing with the tenants."
The program has been set up to encourage entrepreneurialism. It has brought to the city, for example, a firm called Nationwide Consultants Inc., which has organized installations of low-flow toilets in California and Florida. Working for Bay Ridge Mechanical Inc., a Manhattan plumber, Nationwide has handled marketing and paperwork and on-site preparation in over 15,000 replacements in 40 buildings. It provides the financing for owners so that there are no out-of-pocket costs.
"Gaining access to apartments is the biggest problem," said Nicole Ager, who manages Nationwide's Manhattan office. "We kill ourselves to get 95 percent, working mornings, evenings, weekends -- whatever it takes. But we have to get cooperation from the owner. If the owner doesn't care then we'll get by with 75 or 80 percent."
Another entrepreneur who has emerged is Fred Glass, a master plumber who set up a storefront business called Water Savers Inc. in 1993 at 451 West 46th Street, specifically in hopes of making the rebate program into a production-scale business.
Potential customers can witness the flushing capabilities of a variety of competitive products at his storefront, which helps in choosing the product. More than 100 toilet models qualify for the rebate.
"I EXPECTED that people would fly in the door, but it's not happening," Mr. Glass said. "People in the middle-income buildings, the co-ops, are cautious. Water is too cheap for them." But he has replaced 1,500 toilets, mainly for owners of buildings with 20 to 40 apartments. "We've finally managed to sign up three big buildings, including two co-ops," he said.
One of the city's largest plumbing firms, New York Plumbing & Heating Corporation, is doing 14,000 replacements for Metropolitan Life at Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, plus other work. And many other plumbers with long relationships with building owners have been drawn in.
"We are repipers from the old days," said Morris Miller, whose company, Diamond Plumbing of New York, has completed 160 buildings. Typically it takes eight days to do a 40-unit building, he said. Crews work over the weekend to be sure of gaining access to the maximum number of apartments.
A few firms have already been thrown out or suspended from the rebate program for violating its guidelines, city officials said. Plumbers participating are not allowed to split the rebate with owners or managing agents, for example. Sales people cannot represent themselves to owners as "endorsed" or "certified" by the program.
Nor does the installation in a rent-regulated building make the owner eligible for a rent increase under the major capital improvement program. City and state housing offices are kept informed of the buildings that enter the rebate program.
The plumbing team, arriving at a building after tenants have been notified, replaces the old toilet and takes it to one the city-designated dumping points. It gets a receipt that is submitted with documentation to the Department of Environmental Protection, which issues the check in about three weeks. The payment can go to an owner, a managing agent, the owner and a third party or the managing agent and a third party.
Rising water and sewer costs have been the fastest-growing component of operating costs in low-income housing for several years, so much so that the Water Board has capped the increase at $500 per apartment per year if conservation standards are met. But conservation alone will probably not be able to protect low-income-housing owners from the financial impact of billing by consumption rather than by the old frontage method.
The current water and sewer charge is $2.62 per 100 cubic foot, or 748 gallons. A study has shown that the average charge per unit a year under the frontage method in multifamily housing is $320, and that with metering -- and no caps -- it would be more than $500 per unit a year in 21 percent of the city's housing units -- mainly the lower-income stock.
Owners of lower-income housing say that a cap lower than $500 a unit is needed urgently. But they also endorse the rebate program. In the Bronx, for example, the Rosenberg Diamond Development Corporation said it had replaced toilets in all 50 of its buildings, reaching 95 percent of its 3,000 tenants.
"The best feature of the program is that it costs the owner nothing except a little time in insuring coordination and preparing a contract," said Robert Rosenberg, president. "Consultants survey the building, recommend plumbers if necessary, meet with tenants, make appointments, work on weekends and do all the paperwork. Why wouldn't anyone want to do it?"

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Swiss Bank Beefs Up the Stamford Office Outlook

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: STAMFORD

 BODY:
LAST year, 1.3 million square feet of office space was leased in this business hub of Connecticut, bringing the vacancy rate under 20 percent for the first time in this decade. And now the city anticpates the construction of Swiss Bank's huge North American headquarters in a prime downtown location.
Nevertheless, the first quarter of 1995 saw more space vacated than rented and jobs have been lost because of corporate consolidations. 
 Employment figures fell from a peak in 1987 of 82,270 to 61,782 for February of this year, below the 1980 total of 66,000, according to figures supplied by Sacia, the southwest Connecticut business council. The anagram stands for Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association.
Office vacancies rose from 17 percent in the last quarter of 1994 to 18 percent for the first quarter of 1995. But leases are still ahead of the first quarter of 1994, when vacancies were just above 20 percent. And the vacancy rate is substantially down from the 23.6 percent of 1990.
Among real estate professionals these blips are regarded as "purely statistical," said Owen J. Brown, senior director of Cushman & Wakefield of Connecticut, commercial realtors who supplied the figures.
"American Tobacco is vacating some 67,000 square feet in its merger with Brown & Williamson, and Waldenbooks is leaving almost 295,000 square feet -- merging with Borders Books under Kmart ownership and moving to Michigan," he said. "That's healthy -- freeing up large spaces for which there is a crying need."
In addition, Xerox is consolidating within its 250,000-square-foot headquarters, vacating 280,000 square feet in two other buildings.
In spite of the empty spaces prices are rising. "Increases of 30 cents to $1.16 a square foot bring rents between the mid-teens to the mid-20's, depending on location," said Michael H. Siegel, executive director of Edward S. Gordon Company, a commercial brokerage. In 1990 the range was low teens to low 20's.
Swiss Bank's projected move from two of its three locations in Manhattan to an 11-acre site that Morgan Stanley considered in 1991 and rejected, is not yet a done deal. Earlier this month, the bank put $2 million in escrow to seal an agreement with the city guaranteeing a minimum first phase building of 930,000 square feet and 1,200 jobs, less than its original guarantee of 1.2 million square feet and 2,000 jobs. The reduction resulted from a 41 percent drop in profits for 1994.
A 10-year corporate tax credit offered by the state, based on the number of employees, wase a major reason for the move to Connecticut, but the terms must be approved by the General Assembly. On April 17 the Joint Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee voted favorably, 36 to 3, on the modified building and job figures. The measure will go to the Senate in May and then to the House of Representatives.
"The bank gets a 30 percent credit on their corporate taxes to start," said Arthur Diedrick, the state's Commissioner of Economic Development. "As they expand up to 2,000 employees it increases to 50 percent."
Should they expand to 3,000 employees in the 11th year, he said, they would get an additional five years of credit at 50 percent annually.
APPRAISALS of the 33 parcels on the site -- bounded by Atlantic Street, North State Street, Washington Boulevard and Federal Street -- "will guide the city in negotiating with landowners, exercising its eminent domain authority," said Anne Dayton, interim director of the city's Urban Renewal Commission.
According to Frank Kerwin, the Assessor, the land is worth $45 a square foot, or $21.5 million. "Property taxes would be $335,000 for the first phase, and around $2 million when fully built," he said. The bank could eventually have about 2 million square feet of space and employ 3,000 people. Property taxes on equipment and furniture will add considerably to the totals.
The first phase is estimated to cost $184 million, including land, a 12-story office building and trading pavilion, a 1,400-car garage, furniture and equipment. Construction could begin in July and would be completed early in 1998, according to Matthias Beckmann, spokesman for the bank.
The project may be telegraphing "the next wave in Fairfield County real estate -- a return to new construction for specific clients," said Gerard P. Hallock, senior vice president of Rostenberg-Doern Company, commercial realtors.
Some new construction has already begun.
Pitney Bowes, a Stamford company founded here in the 20's with its world headquarters on the waterfront, is completing a 300,000-square-foot office building and shipping depot in Shelton, where it has owned and occupied a second building for several years. "They have also purchased 32 acres for future development," said James Ryan, Shelton's Director of Economic Development.
Omega Engineering is putting up a 106,400-square-foot office building in the Riverbend Industrial Park here, and Duracell will complete its 308,000-square-foot headquarters at Berkshire Corporate Park in Bethel in October. Six of the eight other locations that the company now occupies in the park will be vacated, leaving 175,000 square feet empty.
Significant acquisitions of existing buildings include the purchase by Virgin Atlantic Airways of a 41,000 square foot headquarters building in Norwalk for $4.1 million. Foreclosed and never occupied, its partially finished interior is now being completed.
"WE will move there from Manhattan in August," said David Tait, executive vice president, who mentioned that "Connecticut was much nicer with cash incentives than New York or New Jersey, where we also looked." A regional sales office will remain in Manhattan and half of the 210 Norwalk jobs will be filled locally.
About 20 percent of downtown Stamford's 6.6 million square feet of first-class space was purchased for $146 million from 1992 through 1994 by Zell-Merrill Lynch, the Chicago-based real estate investment firm. The buildings have an overall vacancy rate of only 12 percent.
"They are always looking for additional properties and they will buy more if the occasion arises," said Margaret Carlson, leasing agent for Equity Office Properties, the firm's management company.
W&M Properties of Connecticut is targeting smaller tenants who don't need to be in downtown Stamford and who pay modest salaries. Their employees have serious problems with the high cost of living in Stamford and must commute long distances to less expensive towns, causing more highway congestion and wasted time in traffic.
"That's why we bought Soundview Plaza at Exit 9 of I-95 on the Stamford-Darien border, and Merritt View off the Merritt Parkway and the I-95 extension in Norwalk," said Anthony E. Malkin, president of the Manhattan-based W&M Properties, which built and owns the 276,000-square-foot Metro Center in Stamford. "Employees will save up to 40 minutes round trip." The buildings are undergoing extensive renovations for openings in May and September.
Stamford's future does seem to be evolving around an entrenched high cost of living. "Typically," said Mr. Brown of Cushman & Wakefield, "we are getting elite firms or divisions of companies whose employees are accustomed to New York and can afford to live there or here."

HEADLINE: State Seeks to Preserve More Meadowlands, With Developers Picking Up Part of the Bill

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

DATELINE: LYNDHURST

 BODY:
The future of the Hackensack Meadowlands the 32-square-mile region of virgin marshes, 12-lane highways and abandoned dumps that has long stood midway between national treasure and national joke -- is being reshaped by a new master plan meant to strike a balance between construction and conservation.
The plan, essentially a vast zoning map, was carved out after years of negotiation among landowners and state and Federal agencies. It seeks to preserve fragile wetlands, cut red tape for developers and require them to pay for environmental protection. If adopted by the state, it will replace a 1972 master plan that was widely regarded as visionary -- with a sleek new city center overlooking fields of waving marsh grasses, the New York skyline shimmering on the horizon -- but has long since been overtaken by economic and environmental realities. 
 "This will be a model for the nation," said Anthony Scardino, executive director of the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission, the state agency that acts as a supergovernment for the parts of 14 cities and towns that make up the region. "It will provide a sense of certainty to both the development and environmental communities, and create a balance between the two."
But the new plan is provoking bitter criticism from environmentalists and some planners, who say it does not go far enough in guaranteeing protection of fragile wetlands, and threatens to lure development away from Newark, Jersey City, Elizabeth and other nearby cities. They say the wetlands should be bought by the state and designated for protection instead of having their future tied to the financial contributions of real estate developers.
"This document simply fails to preserve what needs to be preserved," said Bill Neil, the New Jersey Audubon Society's assistant director for conservation. "And there is no guarantee that the plan won't be reworked again to the detriment of the wetlands."
Mr. Scardino said approval of the plan should speed construction of two major projects that have been on drawing boards for years: the Town Center in Carlstadt, where the Empire Development and Mills Corporations want to build offices, stores, a hotel and 5,000 apartments; and Allied Junction in Secaucus, where Allied Outdoor Advertising plans a 4-million-square-foot office complex and a railroad station linking Amtrak and local commuter lines.
Perhaps most critical to the plan's success are the financial links it envisions between development and wetlands protection at a time of shrinking Federal and state environmental budgets. It calls on developers to fill part of the void in government financing -- contributing more than $300 million for environmental work -- and do so at a time when the weak economies of New Jersey and New York City have discouraged almost all new construction.
Still, after seven years of preparation, the meadowlands commission plans to issue an environmental impact report on the new plan in late May. That will begin a process of public comment, which officials say they hope will lead to final approval by the end of the year.
If the new plan is adopted, it will come after slow and uneven progress in reclaiming an area of garbage-strewn marshland that by the 1960's had become a national symbol of environmental abuse in the same way that the South Bronx symbolized urban blight.
The state's biggest success in the meadowlands has been shutting down all but one of 27 garbage dumps that received more than 30 percent of New Jersey's garbage.
Although little garbage now ends up in the meadowlands, only five of the dumps have been cleaned up enough to stop leaking toxic material, and the 20-year plan calls for dedicating 60 percent of the money raised for environmental protection to cleaning up the old landfills, two of which are so severely polluted that they are on the Federal Government's list of Superfund sites.
While environmental projects have moved slowly in the meadowlands, so too has development. Particularly disappointing to some officials has been the pace of housing construction. Seventy thousand new homes, mostly apartments, were envisioned in the original master plan; only 3,000 have been built. (The new plan sets a goal of 14,000.)
State and Federal officials attribute the slow pace of development in part to the deep economic slump that brought almost all new construction in the region to a halt in the late 1980's. But they say a more important constraint has been Federal environmental laws, mainly the Clean Water Act and Coastal Zone Preservation Act, both passed in the 1970's, that created layers of bureaucracy and red tape.
Now, according to Robert Hargrove of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, applications for new development in the meadowlands languish for six years or more as they are reviewed by more than a dozen state and Federal agencies.
He said one of the biggest benefits of the proposed 20-year plan had come in the process of drafting it, since his agency, the Army Corps of Engineers, the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection and other agencies have agreed to work closely together in the application process, shortening it to less than a year.
In contrast to the 1972 master plan, in which 1,800 acres of the 20,000-acre meadowlands district were designated for development, the new plan sets aside only 850 acres for new development.
For developers, the biggest change is the requirement that they contribute to a pool of funds for environmental cleanup. They would pay $4 into the fund for every square foot they build. And since some of the new projects would be huge, the fees could add up quickly. Counting those fees, state and Federal grants, and income from the meadowlands' garbage transfer station, officials hope to raise nearly $1 billion for cleanup.
Still, the plan has provoked sharp criticism, not just from environmentalists but also from some of the 14 municipalities that were forced to give up their local zoning powers when the district was established in 1969. "They are going to inundate us with traffic and overly dense development, and it's just not fair," said Mayor Anthony E. Just of Secaucus.
But Mr. Scardino of the meadowlands commission said he was confident that the plan would be adopted because of the unusual consensus that has formed among state and Federal agencies. "This is a state-of-the-art approach to reversing the degradation in what has been the country's most severely assaulted wetlands area," he said.

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
Where Hope's Eternal and Jackpots Are Few

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
"BE HERE by 8:45 sharp," Mary Fasano had warned me when I bought my $18 ticket. "They wait for nobody."
I'm there by 8:30, and the bus is full of people in late middle-age and beyond -- the cannon fodder of Atlantic City's slot-machine-based casino economy. Mrs. Fasano waves me on. She is a cheerful woman who owns a candy store in Nutley. She also runs a monthly bus trip to Trump Castle. 
 She is a tiny player in a big business. Day and night, casino charter buses ply the highways of the Northeast like those farm-labor buses of old. Last year, more than 300,000 of them brought 8.5 million passengers to Atlantic City casinos; most were slot players gamely seeking that elusive jackpot.
Mrs. Fasano's trips leave in the middle of a month. "People usually have to wait to get their Social Security checks," she explains. One man brings as much as $1,000, "but a lot of them are in the $300 range." A few come not to gamble but to socialize. The quarters the casinos hand out to prime the pump buy a very nice lunch if you don't drop them in a slot machine first.
Brandishing her clipboard cruise activities-director style, Mrs. Fasano works the aisle to see that everyone is content. The bus leaves right on time. "Here we go!" an elderly man yelps.
Once out on the Garden State Parkway, Mrs. Fasano and a friend come up the narrow aisle, selling raffle tickets. "Compliments of S. W. Brown & Son Funeral Home," the stubs say. Somewhere near Exit 117, I win $6. "Congratulations," booms Frank, the man sitting beside me.
We arrive at 11. A casino employee bounds on board and distributes vouchers for $15 in coins. "I'm impressed," Mrs. Fasano murmers. "I was expecting $10."
"Last time I got $20," a man grumbles as we file out.
The casino is jammed. Mrs. Fasano spots a woman at a dollar slot machine with a bell on top that is ringing like a burglar alarm. "That lady just won $1,000," she explains. Still, she heads for the nickel machines. "Your money lasts longer that way."
Though I am the youngest passenger on the trip, I am plenty old enough to remember Atlantic City before the casinos came. Among the wonders of the old Steel Pier was the Piano Playing Duck. When a dime was dropped in the slot, this duck would waddle out of its cage and peck enthusiastically at a toy piano. Because the duck did not get a food pellet each time, its behavior appeared to be motivated solely by optimism. For that duck, hope sprang eternal.
Now I learn that the duck was a harbinger. It was really demonstrating the basic principle of the slot machine. According to Scott Wood, a professor of psychology at Drake University, slot machines are variations on the "Skinner box" -- devices that employ intermittent rewards to reinforce certain behavior in lab animals. Just as a duck can be conditioned to peck at a piano, the professor explains, slot machines elicit "behavior that is very, very persistent and will last for an extended time."
Last year, slot players engaging in some very persistent behavior lost $2.3 billion in the slot machines at Atlantic City's 12 casinos, which make twice as much money from slots as from all other forms of gambling combined. Overwhemingly, these frequent slot players are retired people living on pensions and Social Security.
After getting my free quarters at Trump Castle, I catch a jitney to the Boardwalk and saunter into the huge Taj Mahal, across from Steel Pier. Trading my quarters for dollars, I drop one into a machine and pull the handle. To my astonishment, the machine shrieks and spits out 60 dollar coins. Easy money! Twenty sweaty minutes later, the machine has taken it all back. I skulk out into the flourescent seashore glare, glad the duck isn't still around to say I told you so.
By 5 o'clock, as we line up for our trip home, the departure area at Trump Castle looks like the Port Authority at rush hour.
"How much did you lose?" a gray-haired woman in front of me asks.
"Oh, I spent the day walking. How about you?"
"A little over two hundred. But it was a nice day out."
Mrs. Fasano checks us us all off on her clipboard. As our bus joins the long procession of charters headed home, it seems to ride high and easy on the road. I figure that's probably because it's about 5,000 bucks lighter.

HEADLINE: HMO Or No?

BYLINE: By HOLCOMB B. NOBLE 

 BODY:
THE VOICE on the home phone was daughter Amy's. "Dad," she said, "I'm sitting here with a book with a list of doctors: Which one do I choose?"
Her father is Dr. Stanley S. Bergen Jr., president of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. But despite his long years of experience and exalted position in New Jersey medicine, he could not be of great help to his daughter. He knew a few of the doctors on the list provided by her new health maintenance organization, her H.M.O., but not well enough to recommend one. "It's a strange way to have to pick a doctor, isn't it?" he reflected. 
 Strange, and increasingly commonplace.
As the nation's medical system is tortuously transformed after years of sharply increasing costs, Americans find themselves faced with all manner of baffling decisions about their health care:
* Should they continue to get health care in the traditional manner, by seeing their own independent physicians, paying a fee for each visit and filing a claim with an insurance company?
* Should they heed the promise of lower costs and sign up with the rapidly expanding managed-care companies that provide and manage all their medical care for a set monthly fee?
* And if they do decide to switch, what kind of managed-care system should they join and how should they navigate it to their best advantage?
Here in New Jersey, as around the nation, more and more people are considering their options and deciding to make the change. As recently as two years ago, only 10 percent of New Jerseyans belonged to H.M.O.'s, according to the State Health Department. Today, that number has more than doubled; in a recent New York Times poll, 30 percent of New Jerseyans questioned said they belonged to H.M.O.'s. (This month the New Jersey Supreme Court recognized the growing reach of H.M.O.'s when it ruled that they should no longer be shielded from malpractice suits.)
This movement to managed care has given rise to a furious debate whose central ingredients are money, medical ethics and the quality of care. Though there can be little dispute that managed care has tempered health-care costs, many in the medical community fear that the companies' determination to do just that has compromised the quality of the care they offer. The managed-care companies and their supporters argue, in turn, that costs can be cut without harming quality, and they cite patient-satisfaction surveys to buttress their arguments.
Though several studies are under way to assess these issues, their answers are a long way away. In announcing one of these studies recently, the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation of Princeton said that while "managed-care executives are constantly trying to make their operations more efficient to save costs, they do not yet have a systematic method for assessing the ethical dimensions of their decisions."
Still, amid all the point-counterpoint, one thing is sure: The pressure to switch to managed care is considerable and will only increase as employers muster carrots and sticks to keep their own health insurance costs in check.
So what is the consumer to do? In New Jersey, some of the most difficult decisions may be faced by the families of 300,000 state- and local-government employees who have had virtually free medical care for years. This year, Governor Whitman is proposing to give them a choice: switch to an H.M.O. or have the state pick up only a portion of the traditional health insurance premiums. "Christie Whitman says it's time the state entered the real world," remarked one state official.
But while that official considers herself quite knowledgeable about the health-care options available in the state, even she is at sea: should she pay the $40 a month it will cost her to continue with her own doctor, whom she has been satisfied with, or save the money and try something new? "At the moment," she said, "I have no idea what to do."
 
Getting Started
The A B C's of H.M.O.'s
These days, when it comes time to sign up for a health-care plan, you will probably find yourself staring at a forbidding bundle of folders, each containing vast amounts of information about different managed-care plans or generally more expensive traditional insurance policies.
In making your decision, then, first understand precisely what these new managed-care creatures are. An H.M.O., a dominant form of managed care, is usually a for-profit or nonprofit company that hires doctors under contract to treat patients for a set range of fees. Another common, and simpler, form is a preferred provider organization, or P.P.O., usually a network of physicians who have signed up with an insurance company and agree to treat its enrollees at below-standard rates.
Once in an H.M.O., you select a primary-care physician, called a "gatekeeper," who will do your checkups and treat a range of common illnesses. Generally, whenever you want to see a specialist, you must first see the primary-care physician, then get approval and a written referral to a specialist in the company's network. Though there is normally a small co-payment for each primary-care visit, from about $2 to $15, you pay no deductible, fill out no reimbursement forms and pay nothing more to see the approved specialist.
There can be a catch, however: if your gatekeeper keeps the gate closed and denies you permission to see a specialist, you may be out of luck. You can appeal. But that can be tedious or time-consuming under some plans. And you may lose the appeal.
Most H.M.O.'s also offer what may prove to be best of all worlds, a "point-of-service option," which, for a higher cost, lets you see a specialist outside the network.
The second thing to remember is that consumers' costs are beginning to come down under managed care. On average, the cost of premiums and doctor visits is significantly lower with H.M.O.'s than with fee-for-service plans. As a result, after years of steady increases, the average cost of health benefits for American workers declined last year to $3,741 from $3,781 the year before, according to a recent survey by Foster Higgins, a benefits consulting firm. During the same period, the Federal Labor Department reports, employers' insurance costs dropped by 1 percent.
But these economies cut to the heart of many of the criticisms of managed care. In their most general form, the fee-for-service doctors' arguments against managed care go like this: By managing health care with restrictions on what a patient may or may not do, the companies' decisions can place money before medicine. Furthermore, they say, quality suffers when patient and doctor are forced to give up the mutual trust, and the physician's knowledge of medical history, built up over the years.
"Making a profit is the American way, but there is something almost obscene about that quantity of dollars suddenly being earned," said Dr. Fred M. Palace, president of the Medical Society of New Jersey. "Making money has to be secondary. The first consideration must be the health of the patient, and that is often not the case with the health-care corporations. The bottom line is the primary consideration."
To Dale Florio, counsel to the New Jersey H.M.O. Association, these criticisms are attempts "to strike fear into the hearts of consumers" by doctors "afraid they are going to lose money." But, he said, "consumers are smart and willing to forgo the personal in favor of a health system that provides for all their needs." As for the argument that patient-doctor relationships will be severed in H.M.O.'s, Mr. Florio says consumers are finding it easier to stay with one doctor, the H.M.O. primary-care physician, than in the past, when they might have gone from one costly specialist to another.
The H.M.O.'s also point to their own national surveys, which most of them say show a high level of patient satisfaction, often greater than 90 percent. But it is not always easy to know precisely what is being surveyed. Tod Cooperman, president of Care Data Reports, an independent research group, said that while "the plans try to put their best material forward," the range of satisfaction goes from a high of 70 percent "highly satisfied" to 62 percent "dissatisfied."
By and large, the satisfied patients they are talking about are people like Marcia Gilbert of North Brunswick, who has been a Health Insurance Plan member since 1976. At first, she said, she was reluctant to leave a family doctor to join an H.M.O. but now she and her husband, both retired, are "extremely satisfied."
"We have always received what we needed -- and more," she said. "Twice we thought my husband was having a heart attack. Fortunately he wasn't, but the care and service he got were wonderful."
 
The Debate, Part 1
Calling In a Specialist
 To the critics of managed care in New Jersey, the problems have less to do with primary care than with what happens when a patient is seriously ill or injured. What they are seeing, they insist, are more than isolated anecdotal cases of bad medicine. They complain about patterns of problems in four areas: illnesses requiring care by a specialist; emergency decisions; premature hospital discharges of patients who suffer complications, and mental health. (All of these issues are now being studied by the State Health Commission, which is preparing its first revision of H.M.O. rules in two decades, due this summer.)
Often, the critics contend, the managed-care companies' restrictions keep patients from seeing the specialists they need.
Dr. James A. Charles, a neurologist in northern New Jersey, tells of a woman in her 40's, a member of H.M.O.-Blue (a New Jersey Blue Cross affiliate), who had a rare blood-clotting disorder, antiphospholipid-antibody syndrome. This was causing strokes that were, in turn, causing almost uncontrollable epileptic seizures. Dr. Charles, a consulting physician on the case, thought it crucial that the woman see one of the world's leading experts in this disorder, Dr. Orrin Devinsky at New York University Medical Center, who agreed to take the case.
"I received a phone call from an H.M.O.-Blue nurse," Dr. Charles recalled. "She said she had never heard of the disease, and directed me to the physicians' supervisor, a Dr. Platt. He told me he was looking to cut costs, and that the patient could be treated in New Jersey. He berated me, saying he had heard stories before from other physicians who want to transfer patients to New York or Philadelphia or Boston for more expensive treatment out of network. Five minutes later, I got another call from an H.M.O-Blue neurologist, a Dr. Wasserstrom, who said he agreed with me that the patient should go N.Y.U." In the end, though, he declined to authorize the transfer, saying H.M.O.-Blue was trying to cut costs.
Dr. Charles added: "This story had a happy ending: Her husband's insurance company authorized the transfer; she was treated in New York and is now doing well." But he said the case illustrated the seriousness of the problem.
H.M.O.-Blue said that neither the organization nor Dr. Ronald Platt would comment on the case, out of respect for patient confidentiality. But Dr. William Wasserstrom acknowledged that he had discussed the case with Dr. Charles. He declined to comment further, other than to ask how the patient had made out; when told, he said, "All's well that ends well."
Spokesmen for the H.M.O. industry say its doctors are as eager as anyone to have a top specialist treat a complicated case when necessary. Indeed, the Fragale family of Hewitt had just such an experience.
Starting when he was just a week old, the Fragales' son, Patrick, needed three rare operations to fix his heart, which had formed without a left ventricle or mitral and aortic valves. The odds against him were high, and several times during the months after the first two surgeries, his lungs filled with fluid. He turned blue and was near death. Then, to everyone's amazement, he began to spring back with full force.
In the midst of all this, his mother, Kara, recalled, the Fragales heard from their fee-for-service insurance carrier.
"Our insurance company started asking questions and said it would pay only a certain amount of the bills, leaving the balance of this financial burden on us," she said. "Here we were trying to save our son's life. It was just not something we wanted to deal with at that moment."
But Patrick's father then changed jobs and switched to U.S. Healthcare H.M.O.-N.J. When the day came for the third operation, Mrs. Fragale said, their new H.M.O. said, "No problem, just worry about your son." U.S. Healthcare never questioned the bills and paid them promptly -- "without the high deductibles we were used to."
"I never wanted to switch to an H.M.O.," she went on. "But they were great!"
 
The Debate, Part 2
Coping With a Crisis
Emergency care and hospital discharges are two other areas in which the fee-for-service doctors say sound medical judgment is often brushed aside in an effort to hold down costs.
For example, some physicians who work for H.M.O.'s said the companies had told them to transfer patients from non-network hospitals to network hospitals, even though they were too sick to be moved. Similarly, they told of having been discouraged from moving critically ill patients into intensive care until space opened up at a network hospital, rather than transferring the patient to the first open space at any nearby hospital. But the doctors were unwilling to speak for attribution, saying they feared having their H.M.O. contracts canceled.
Mr. Florio of the H.M.O. association said he could not comment on any such cases without knowing the details but insisted that H.M.O. doctors were under no such pressure. "They know an emergency is an emergency," he said.
The last main area of debate is mental health. Dr. George Wilson, chairman of psychiatry at Monmouth Medical Center, who has studied patient complaints for the New Jersey Psychiatric Association, says managed care is often inadequate or nonexistent for patients with serious long-term conditions -- clinical depression and anxiety, bipolarism and schizophrenia.
"Most H.M.O. plans are designed to provide short-term crisis intervention, brief anxiety or family conflicts, illnesses of brief duration," he said, adding that some lack enough psychiatrists. "There is pressure on the primary-care physician to treat these people themselves, financial disincentives not to refer them to the specialists. So they will prescribe Prozac, for example, thinking it has no side effects -- which is true in most cases but not all -- and they lack the expertise to detect the difference and properly monitor the medicated patient."
Recently, Dr. Wilson said, he had to hospitalize a Health Improvement Plan patient who was on an antidepressant, was not properly monitored and became suicidal.
Dr. Jack Ward, chief of the Center for Human Development, which provides mental health services for H.I.P., said he could not comment on the case since the patient's name was not given. But generally, he said, a consumer will have all the options an employer has contracted for. With H.I.P., he said, the basic plans provide for short-term crisis intervention, but some of its more expensive options do offer long-term care.
"What you get is what you pay for," he said, and when employers want to economize, "the first thing they seem to cut out is mental health health benefits." But, he added, this has become just as true with traditional insurance plans.
 
Decision Time
Charting the Territory
If neither side in this medical battleground has yet proved superiority, the case studies cited by the doctors can help you chart the managed-care territory.
The first step in assessing a managed-care plan is to seek information about the primary-care physicians, specialists and hospitals in your area, which are all listed in the brochures. As one doctor concerned about the managed-care trend said: "Remember, there are docs and not-so-good docs, good hospitals and not-so-good." So ask around. Ask the benefits people at your company who hear about good and bad experiences; ask friends, relatives. And ask doctors you respect if they are in a plan or if they know good physicians who are.
Call the plans you're considering and ask these questions:
* What is a plan's percentage of board-certified doctors (those who have passed national examinations establishing expertise in a specialty), as opposed to those simply licensed to practice medicine? Some plans have this important information readily available; some do not. You'll especially want to know if a primary-care physician is a board-certified internist.
* What does the plan cover -- or not cover? If you know you have a rare disease or a genetic predisposition toward such a disease, does the plan cover it? If there is chronic mental illness in the family, does the plan cover that?
* Does the plan have a 24-hour-a-day, 7-day-a-week appeals process available for emergencies, or a 48-hour response period for urgent matters?
* What are the monthly premiums? In comparing costs, remember to factor the deductible into any fee-for-service plan. Most H.M.O.'s don't have deductibles.
* How much does the company pay the primary-care physician? Generally, the good doctors tend to sign with the plans whose compensation they think is best. And how are the doctors paid? Network doctors and the H.M.O.'s frequently argue over whether the amounts and methods of payment discourage the doctor from making referrals or providing comprehensive treatment. Find out if a doctor feels pressure to limit referrals and keep treatments short.
* If you're not happy with your primary-care physician, can you switch to another in the network at any time?
* What does the H.M.O. offer for mental-health care?
* What does the H.M.O. offer if you want to go outside the network? And how much do these options cost?
 
The Future
Best of Both Worlds?
 Here in New Jersey, in an attempt to respond to the criticism that managed care is too beholden to the bottom line, several new plans are starting to talk as much about quality as cost. In a variety of ways, they seek to give the patient the best of the old and new ways of providing health care.
One of the fastest-growing H.M.O.'s is Oxford, and its managers contend that a principal reason is its emphasis on point of service, which enables a patient to go outside of network if he believes it necessary.
Citing similar motivations, two other plans have set up shop in New Jersey in the last year. One of them, First Option, was founded and is controlled by a group of doctors and hospitals. With no stockholders to answer to, its president, John Odessa, explained, the company's board has voted to limit its profit margin to 5 percent.
The other is a statewide academic-medicine managed-care organization, University Healthcare. Built around the state's six teaching hospitals, it was set up in March by the University of Medicine and Dentistry. Each of its preferred provider networks is made up largely of doctors and facilities affiliated with the teaching hospitals and under contract with University Healthcare to provide service at reduced rates.
To Dr. Bergen, the university's president, University Healthcare balances the economies of managed care and academic medicine's attention to high quality. Referring to skyrocketing health costs that led to the rise of managed care, he said, "I don't think there is any doubt that the doctors were culpable, but now with private companies taking over, the potential is there for the organization of medicine to become so commercialized that we lose sight of the need to treat and care for our patients."

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Mortgage Rates Nearing Lows of a Year Ago

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
YOU wouldn't know it from the weak housing market of the last few months, but mortgage rates have been falling steadily to their lowest level in almost a year.
For anyone thinking about buying a home, long-term loans at fixed rates look especially attractive. The national average rate on a 30-year mortgage fell to 8.48 percent on Wednesday, from a recent peak of 9.41 percent on Dec. 16, according to HSH Associates, a mortgage research company in Butler, N.J. It is now at its lowest point since June 10. At current rates, the monthly payment on a standard $100,000 mortgage is $767, versus $834 at the peak. 
 Mortgages with rates that adjust periodically have not dipped as much. The national average for a one-year adjustable mortgage was 6.30 percent on Wednesday, down from its recent high of 6.90 percent on Jan. 20.
"The rate gap between fixed-rate mortgages and adjustables has closed," said Keith T. Gumbinger, an analyst with HSH Associates. The gap had been unusually wide for many months, making adjustables more attractive, he said, but it has now settled back to the normal 2 to 2.5 percentage points.
Home buyers have reacted, predictably, by taking out more fixed-rate loans. Adjustables accounted for just 44 percent of the loans made in March, down from 59 percent in January, according to the Federal Housing Finance Board in Washington. (The figures for adjustables include hybrid loans, which carry fixed rates for several years and then adjust to a market rate.)
Shifting consumer preferences may have less to do with which type of loan is a better deal than with which direction rates are headed. "When rates go up, people start to buy more A.R.M.'s," Mr. Gumbinger said. "And when rates go down, they start to buy more fixed."
Personal factors, like how long people expect to live in a house, come into play as well. But certainty beats uncertainty hands down for many borrowers. Most adjustable loans have lifetime caps of 6 percentage points, so a 6.9 percent adjustable loan could rise to 12.9 percent someday.
Home sales have not been rising as some might expect and as many would hope in a time of falling rates. Sales of previously owned homes rose 5.8 percent in March, for the first advance in three months, but remained far lower than a year earlier. The previous month, sales fell 5.3 percent to the lowest level since August 1992. The bright spot is the Midwest, where sales are brisk.
New homes are even harder to move than old ones. In February, the most recent month for which statistics are available, new home sales declined 14 percent to the lowest level in almost three years, according to the Commerce Department.
Housing analysts suggest that sales are sluggish in part because of lingering job insecurity, unfavorable demographics, slow wage growth and a lack of affordable homes, particularly for first-time buyers.
"You have a jaded populace out there that is demanding affordable starter homes, and in places like the Midwest, where there is an inventory of those kind of homes, the market is doing well," Mr. Gumbinger said. "In other places, where you don't have this inventory, it is not."
Although attractive in historical terms, rates have not tumbled to the 25-year lows that many people remember seeing just 18 months ago, when fixed-rate loans were as low as 7 percent, and adjustables had initial teaser rates as low as 3 percent.
Some analysts also suggest that just as potential buyers jump into the market when rates start to rise (to get head ahead of any further increases), they also delay buying homes when rates are falling (to catch rates when they hit bottom).
Lyle E. Gramley, a consulting economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association in Washington and a former governor of the Federal Reserve Board, found signs of a consumer awakening in the March numbers. Home buyers may have finally realized that interest rates are favorable and that lenders are aggressive, he said. One large builder, Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation in Sacramento, Calif., announced last week that it is offering mortgages with no money down on its homes priced under $315,000.
Analysts are divided about whether rates will fall much further. "This time last year, people were predicting 10 percent interest rates," Mr. Gumbinger said, when asked about the possibility of rising rates.
Mr. Gramley said he did not expect long-term rates to rise substantially unless the Federal Reserve raises short-term rates again. "We are probably in a period of stability for the time being," he said.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT: IN THE VINEYARD;
Immigrant's Search For Logic Leads Him To Top of C.P.A. Class

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE 

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

 BODY:
FOR Vitaly Sorkin, life is not what it used to be. When he immigrated here from the Soviet Union in 1990 he spoke little English and worked in a deli. "You want lettuce on that?" he used to say. "Mustard or mayonnaise? Tomatoes?"
Now Mr. Sorkin is an accountant with a Big Six firm, KPMG Peat Marwick. And he says that complicated terms like amortization, depreciation and intangible assets are a piece of cake. 
 It's a classic: the hard-driving immigrant. But Mr. Sorkin is not merely upwardly mobile. By one measure, he has gone higher than anyone else. Just a few months after his graduation from Bryant College in Smithfield, R.I., he earned the best score in the nation on the legendarily difficult Certified Public Accountant exam.
In other words, just as he switched from Russian to English, this 23-year-old son of Communism also mastered capitalism's main language in five years.
"It was a pretty hard test," he said, swishing a prawn through clarified butter at a downtown restaurant here. "But . . ." He trailed off, modestly.
Very modestly, in fact. Only about 12 percent of prospective C.P.A.'s pass the four-section, 15 and a half-hour exam on their first try.
Mark M. Chain, a partner at another of the Big Six firms, Deloitte & Touche, said many of the field's top people had taken the test three or four times before they could put those three letters after their names.
"Anyone who passes the first time, much less gets the highest score, it's pretty amazing." he said, confessing that he took the test three times.
Moreover, Mr. Sorkin was not flush with resources on either side of the Atlantic. He was born into a working-class family in Gomel, a small city 175 miles southeast of Minsk in Belarus.
"In Russia it's not what you know but who you know that counts -- and we didn't know anyone," he said, laughing. It didn't help that Gomel was the site of some of Chernobyl's heaviest fallout.
So Mr. Sorkin and his family immigrated to Pawtucket, R.I., on Feb. 12, 1990. His father found work as a mechanic and his mother cleaned rooms at a nursing home, while Mr. Sorkin and his younger brother went to school.
Mr. Sorkin said he majored in accounting to be able to make a living right out of college. But he also gives other reasons for his career choice -- and in them are clues to the desire that took him so far, so fast.
"I was drawn to accounting because I was curious about America," he said. "Business is the engine of the society. Here the system is rational. There's a procedure for everything, from getting movie tickets to doing a leveraged buyout. Once I plugged into the logic of how things work, I was, like they say, a duck in water."
He paused, then traced the story back again to his childhood in Russia.
He recalled the ever-longer lines for basic goods in the late 1980's as the Soviet system breathed its last gasps, with crime and rampant inflation rising and expectations nonexistent.
"As a student there I was drawn to math because it was logic and order," he said. "It was a rational realm in a world without reason."
And now he is surrounded by the order he craves.
"When the results came back from the test everyone here congratulated me and I got a small bonus," he said, popping another prawn into his mouth. "Then it was back to work. That's how it goes here."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 11; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1580 words

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Here's a Course in Personal Finance 101, the Hard Way

BYLINE: By ROBERT BRYCE 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
NICOLE WALTERS, a 20-year-old junior at the University of Texas, carries two Visa cards, two Mastercards, two department store credit cards -- and two part-time jobs to dig herself out of debt.
"I was buying things here and there and all of a sudden, $4,000 later, those little things added up," Ms. Walters said. She recalls buying a $600 car stereo, some clothes and gas for her car, but nothing else major. 
 Just a few hours on the university campus here turned up nearly a dozen students with similar tales of woe: a 19-year-old freshman with five cards said he owed $2,200, a 22-year-old senior acknowledged running up $8,000 on eight cards and a 26-year-old senior described $9,000 in bills on eight cards. The spending sprees weren't for school-related essentials, but for personal items and luxuries. For the card holders who graduate with thousands of dollars in student loans, too, managing the debt may amount to a crash course in personal finance.
Credit counselors in college towns across the country say students with large card debts are increasingly common. "Five years ago, we weren't seeing anybody still in college with as much debt as we are seeing now," said Candace Acevedo of the San Francisco office of the Consumer Credit Counseling Service, a nonprofit group providing financial education and debt advice. Five percent of the clients in her debt management program are students with at least $5,000 in credit card debt, she said. And the group's other offices in big college towns like Austin, Raleigh, N.C., and Columbia, Mo., report similar figures.
Although some students reach out to credit counseling agencies for help when their card bills become overwhelming, many resort to the most reliable creditors of all: Mom and Dad. Thus, parents paying for books, tuition and housing may also wind up paying their son's or daughter's Visa and American Express bills. If they don't pick it up before, parents may be tempted to pay off card debt at college graduation so their children can embark on their working lives without a burden.
"I think it's the parents who really take the brunt of this," said Irene Leech, a credit counselor and assistant professor of consumer studies at Virginia Tech in Blacksburg, Va. "Parents want their child to have the best, so they do all they can to help their children deal with these debts."
For a student, a credit card is as readily available as a class syllabus. Card applications are found in bookstores, campus publications and student mailboxes. To attract students, card issuers offer free concerts, plane tickets, T-shirts, even candy. According to Roper College Track, a research division of Roper Starch Worldwide, more than half of the 5.1 million full-time undergraduate students at four-year universities in the United States now have at least one major credit card. Mastercard International estimates that 80 percent of all college students carry a credit card by their senior year.
In 1994, Americans used more than 350 million major credit cards -- Visa, Discover, Mastercard and American Express -- to purchase more than half a trillion dollars of goods and services. With that much plastic money coursing through the system, why are issuers bothering with relatively poor college students?
For one, they want to build loyal customers at an early age. A study several years ago by Marketing Week magazine showed that 75 percent of college students keep their first card for 15 years, and 60 percent keep that card for life. Furthermore, college students are not entirely without money. Roper says the average student has an annual income of $4,000.
But if a student owes $2,000 on a credit card, repaying the debt can take years, especially when interest rates rise. The recent increase in rates caught Kevin LeBlanc by surprise. Mr. LeBlanc, a senior at the University of Texas, has two major credit cards with $500 credit lines, both of which are at their limit. "I just got a letter that said, 'We are changing your interest rate from 14.9 percent to 18.9 percent' and you can't do anything about it," he said.
Before the rate increase, Mr. LeBlanc said, his minimum payment "used to pay off a little bit of the balance." Now, he said, "all it does is pay my interest."
Overall delinquency rates on credit cards have been declining since 1989, when nearly 5 percent of card holders were behind in their payments. Last year, the delinquent portion fell to about 3 percent, but it has risen recently.
Although no statistics are available on late card payments by students, who now account for less than 3 percent of the domestic credit card business, counselors suggest that the group may be having more trouble than other borrowers. "I think it's a much bigger problem than is being recognized," said Allen Clary, a credit counselor in Raleigh, who figures that the average student in his program has $10,000 in card debt.
If students were falling hopelessly behind on their debts and refusing to pay, card issuers would undoubtedly stop lending to them. James Daly, editor of Credit Card News, a newsletter published in Chicago, says the parental safety net may keep that from happening. As credit risks, college students look no worse than the rest of the population, he said. But he added, "My impression is that a lot of them are getting help from their parents."
Critics say the card issuers have courted collegians too aggressively. Last year, Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, the Massachusetts Democrat, threatened to introduce legislation that would limit the ability of issuers to provide credit cards to students. Mr. Kennedy also conducted a hearing of the House Banking subcommittee on consumer credit and insurance to hear complaints from students and parents about the industry.
RUTH E. SUSSWEIN, executive director of the Bankcard Holders of America, a consumer advocacy group based in Salem, Va., testified at the hearing. In a recent interview, she said students "are being encouraged to put all these things on plastic" -- things like vacations.
Rus Maxham, a sophomore engineering student from Dallas, owes $2,200 on his credit cards, mostly because of a skiing trip to Lake Tahoe for spring break. Are credit cards too easy to get? "Yes," Mr. Maxham said. "A Visa card came in the mail, and I didn't even ask for it. It said, 'Just call this number to activate it.' It's like they're saying, 'Here's some rope, kid. Go hang yourself.' "
For several years, Ms. Susswein has been pushing credit card companies to help educate their young clients. The issuers have responded. American Express has distributed 10,000 personal finance education packets to high school teachers across the country. In 1991, Visa developed a personal finance program that is now used in 10,000 high schools, said Susan Murdy, a spokeswoman for Visa. In 1993, Mastercard created a video program on personal finance, which it has distributed for free to 18,000 high schools.
In general, high schools spend little time teaching students about budgeting and banking. "I think schools are doing a better job on sex education than they are on financial education," said Steve Apesos, a spokesman for Mastercard. "In a survey we did two years ago of 400 high school students, 96 percent of them said they don't get any personal finance education in school."
Some students have gotten the message, whether from their parents or their teachers, and use their credit cards strictly for convenience, fastidiously paying off the balances every month.
Larry Sacks, a senior at the University of Texas majoring in history, carries a Visa and a Mastercard but says he stopped short of taking an American Express card. He says he does not overdo the card purchases. "Who can afford to charge the maximum on them?" asked Mr. Sacks, who comes from St. Louis. "I think they are a dangerous thing, so I pay mine off every month."
What's a student to do if he flunks the credit card test the first time?
Consolidating the bills into student loans at interest rates of 7 to 9 percent may be a less painful way to pay off the cards, most of which charge interest rates of 15 to 20 percent.
Eva Hensley, director of the credit counseling office in Columbia, considers that preferable to a parental rescue. "It doesn't teach the students any responsibility if every time they get into a difficult situation they have their parents bail them out," she said, noting that 26 percent of the clients of her office are students and that their average card debt is $7,500.
Ms. Walters, the University of Texas junior, has not hidden her problem from her parents. During the school year, she has been working about 30 hours a week, on weekend days as a sales clerk and on weekend nights as a restaurant hostess. While she is making progress, she plans to "work a whole lot" this summer to get her debt firmly under control. She has decided not to get any more cards, even though the applications keep rolling in, and she has cut up the ones she had.
"We pay all of her college expenses and insurance for her car, so her only expenses are for clothes and makeup," said Nicole's mother, Anita Walters. Although she and her husband, Bill, a sales manager for a large electronics concern, could easily pay off Nicole's bills, she said they had decided against it. "She has to learn in this day and age that you can't do that," Mrs. Walters said. "Mom and Dad aren't going to be here forever."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nicole Walters, left, a student at the University of Texas, works two part-time jobs to pay down her credit card debts. (Michelle Bridwell for The New York Times)
