HEADLINE: The Art of the Neighborhood Deal

BYLINE: BY TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
BACK in January, when the Parks Department disclosed plans to let a high-priced dinner circus pitch its tent in a small neighborhood park, Ross Graham was not at all pleased. Few words in a leftist's lexicon have a more odious ring than "privatization," and Ms. Graham, who chairs a community board on the West Side, was loath to turn over a patch of public space in her park-poor district to commercial use.
But Ms. Graham is a pragmatist, too, and figured that Community Board 4, an unpaid panel that can advise but not veto, could not count on blocking the $150-a-ticket circus, which happens to be a pet project of Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern. 
 So she decided to cut a deal. The 5.3-acre DeWitt Clinton Park, site of the circus's proposed seven-month run, has been neglected for two decades. Its bleachers are an unusable eyesore, its ball field is practically bare, and prostitutes conduct business under the stone steps at its entrance. If the Department of Parks and Recreation were to agree to a shopping list of improvements, Board 4 might be willing to lend its grudging support.
It was up to Ms. Graham to persuade the city that these concessions were a small price to pay for avoiding noisy protests and public relations problems. Within weeks, Ms. Graham, a veteran horse-trader, got almost everything she wanted: the Parks Department promised to tear down the bleachers, reconstruct two handball courts and two basketball courts, build a dog run, pay for new playground equipment and require producers of the circus, called "Pomp, Duck & Circumstance," to resod the ball field.
But Ms. Graham also had to yield on a couple of points. Getting rid of the stone steps of ill repute, for example, would be prohibitively cumbersome, the board chairwoman was told.
Still, Ms. Graham had obtained enough to go back to her board earlier this month and listen quietly while her carefully crafted deal was loudly denounced. In the end, a resolution endorsing the plan squeaked through by a one-vote margin.
After her nine years on the board, and two as chairman, Ms. Graham, 67, is an old hand at mediating between a community wedded to principle or sometimes resistant to change and a more powerful city government determined to assert its authority.
Compromises like the one on "Pomp, Duck" have become something of a signature. Instead of a reflexive and ineffectual "no," she tries to find a way to say "yes" -- but festoons her resolutions with conditions, like so many Christmas tree lights. While many community boards are assailed as bastions of "not-in-my-neighborhood" obstinacy, Board 4 has developed a reputation as a sophisticated organization with the political skill to leverage its limited powers, the willingness to master the tedious details of local government and the fortitude to withstand heat from constituents.
"Trying to balance everybody's interests and at the same time leading -- it's a challenge, but it's the part that's fun," said Ms. Graham.
Ms. Graham practices her craft in an economically and culturally diverse district, where many people eye the future warily, fearing their neighborhoods are potentially juicy targets of exploitation. Stretching from 14th Street to 59th Street, Board 4 encompasses Chelsea and Clinton, two waterfront communities that have undergone dramatic change in the decades since the city's shipping industry fell into decline. Chelsea's Eighth Avenue has displaced Christopher Street as a major gay center. Closer to the river, new art galleries have been springing up in abandoned loft buildings. Affluent professionals live in well-maintained town houses and send their children to schools once filled by the offspring of Irish dockworkers.
Clinton, also known these days by its once-discarded but more evocative name of Hell's Kitchen, is home to large numbers of low-income theater workers and immigrants, now primarily coming from Central and South America, as well as better-heeled residents, who, lured by the convenience to midtown, have restored some of the tenement buildings in the West 40's. Both the Coliseum and the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center lie within Board 4's boundaries.
"When you say 'Chelsea' or 'Clinton,' you think of a lot of different things -- it's very hard to pin us down," said Ms. Graham. "It's one of the most exciting community boards, because of the different focuses of its various communities."
 
 
NEW POWER, NEW RESPECT
 Ms. Graham's tenure has come at a time when community boards seem to be flexing their muscles in part because of new functions granted them by the last charter revision, and also because of the respect some are able to command with city agencies. The boards, whose members are appointed by the borough president and the City Council members representing a particular district, now have the responsibility to exercise initial review of all proposals to develop or improve property within their district and the authority to develop blueprints for their communities' future.
They also offer a pipeline to local elected officials and a mechanism for disgruntled residents to let off steam. "The people on the fringes are a good foil," said Roberta Brandes Gratz, author of "The Living City." The airing of an extreme, off-the- wall position makes it easier for a moderate view to seem acceptable, she explained.
While the visionaries among its members are preparing for the next century, much of Board 4's time is devoted to more immediate concerns of urban life: whether to give its blessing to a street fair sponsored by a church, how to help a resident fight a noisy neighbor, what to do about a lumber yard whose curbside operations are blocking neighbors' access.
Like the neighborhoods they represent, community boards have distinct personalities. Board 5, in the heart of midtown, has been dubbed the business board because residents make up only a small proportion of its constituents. Board 3, on the Lower East Side, is considered unruly and largely ineffective. Board 8, on the Upper East Side, reflects its more conservative constituency.
"Board 4 is a from-the-neighborhood kind of board -- it's probably the most mixed in the city ethnically, economically and in terms of sexual orientation," said Councilman Thomas K. Duane, who represents most of the district. "It's a gorgeous mosaic, with people from the projects, middle-income co-ops, brownstones and tenements."
In the other boroughs, many boards are said to be controlled by local politicians to a degree that would not be tolerated in Manhattan. "There's a long history," said Ronald Shiffman, a planning commissioner and chairman of the graduate urban planning program at the Pratt Institute. "The boards in Manhattan, from the time that Percy Sutton was borough president, have been more representative of the community and more articulate."
In the often-scruffy world of community activism, the auburn-haired Ms. Graham stands out in her silk blouses and sling-back heels. And in the context of Board 4, Ms. Graham is considered a moderate, in part because she believes that negotiating with opponents "is not necessarily selling out." But asked if she is a socialist, she pauses a moment and murmurs, "Close, close."
Raised in rural Massachusetts and Pennsylvania, Ms. Graham, the daughter of two teachers, became a reporter for The Reading Times in Pennsylvania after graduating from Tufts University and subsequently held several jobs in publicity and trade journalism. Inspired by John F. Kennedy's election as President, she started moonlighting in politics, joining the Chelsea Reform Democratic Club in the early 60's. There, she met State Senator Manfred Ohrenstein and in 1964, quit her dead-end post at Paper Trade Journal to become his aide.
It was the beginning of a political partnership that lasted until her retirement in 1985. "Ross literally was the first woman to be a major staffer in Albany," said Mr. Ohrenstein, a longtime Senate minority leader. She was a key participant in New York's five-year effort to legalize abortion.
Ms. Graham made her only bid for elective office in 1972, when she dropped a challenge to Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, a West Side Democrat. She then focused on getting other women elected, and today, she is president of Eleanor's List, a political action committee she helped found with the goal of getting more pro-abortion Democratic women into the New York State Legislature.
Her political experience makes her unique on a board whose members include a retired social worker, a guidance counselor, an optometrist, an artist and a public relations consultant. Some would not be happy being described as left-wing, but they share a sort of urban populist ideology: to prevent low-income people from being driven out; to rehabilitate existing housing stock wherever possible, rather than rebuild; to welcome social service agencies as long as they are modest in size and not bunched together, and to oppose allowing business improvement districts to take on government functions like sanitation.
During her two-year term as chairwoman, which ends in June, Ms. Graham has focused much of her attention on the future of Clinton and Chelsea and the long-delayed first steps to develop the waterfront. Her goal is to prevent these neighborhoods from going the way of, say, Yorkville, and being transformed into Third Avenue-like enclaves of bland high-rises.
"On the other hand, I want them to continue to thrive, and that means some kind of development -- new kinds of commerce within the scale we have," she said.
A step in this direction was taken last year when the city finally agreed to pay attention to a decade-old community-generated plan that aims to preserve Clinton's mix of residential, commercial and light industry spaces. It all came down to a basic horse trade: trucks for housing.
Ms. Graham saw her opening when the Giuliani Administration had to quickly find parking spaces for 60 sanitation trucks parked under the Williamsburg Bridge or face losing $95 million in Federal funds for rehabilitating the bridge. Other community boards flatly rejected the trucks, but Board 4 was willing to cooperate, provided that the city agree to let the board choose the site and meet certain other demands, including taking the Clinton plan out of mothballs, rehabilitating six dilapidated apartment buildings in the area and accelerating the board's move to nicer quarters in the old McGraw-Hill building on 42d Street.
Ms. Graham recalls that at one meeting, Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter expressed concern about the cost of relocating the trucks. "It seems to me, a little extra money to make the community less unhappy may be worth it to you,"' Ms. Graham said she told Ms. Reiter. At the same time, she remembers, Borough President Ruth W. Messinger was telling administration officials "that they were getting an extraordinarily cooperative community board on one of their crises, and they should be good to us."
The deal was struck at a subsequent meeting attended by several politicians and city officials against a backdrop of great urgency.
The upshot was that, for the first time, said Alice K. Olson, head of the Clinton Urban Renewal Area Task Force and Ms. Graham's predecessor as Board 4 chairwoman, the city took a serious look at her group's plan. More recently, housing officials agreed to allow a corporation formed by the community to begin seeking financing to implement the plan. "She made it happen," said Ms. Olson, referring to Ms. Graham's arm-twisting.
 
LIMITING HIGH-RISES AND USING THE PIERS
 In Chelsea, where Ms. Graham has lived in a one-bedroom apartment since 1966, she is engaged in a philosophical battle with the City Planning Department over where future high-rise buildings in that neighborhood should be situated. Board 4's blueprint for Chelsea, also a decade in the making, calls for rezoning to prevent what she describes as "tunnels of high-rises" from developing on Eighth and Ninth Avenues and altering the neighborhood's aesthetics.
As Chelsea grew, Ms. Graham notes approvingly, taller buildings like the Chelsea Hotel on 23d Street and St. Peter's Episcopal Church on 20th Street were placed in the middle of the block, alongside smaller row houses, rather than on the avenues.
But so far she has struck out with department officials and can only hope the board will win over the Planning Commission itself, which now has some community board alumni among its members.
When the Chelsea plan was on the drawing board, the building boom of the '80s was in full swing and encroaching development was a preoccupation at Board 4. But the collapse of the real estate market has helped nudge waterfront issues to the forefront and turned them into the current obsession.
Ms. Graham and the board helped expedite a $100 million project that is bringing a huge sports complex to several piers between 17th and 22d streets, and they have taken a lot of flak for it. Gloria Sukenick, a Chelsea resident for 25 years, said the Chelsea Piers project was rammed through without community support. "We wanted a view of the river, not this," she said.
But an unimpeded view of the Hudson was never an option, said Ms. Graham, who was co-chair of the board's Waterfront Planning and Preservation Committee when the sports complex was first proposed; certain points along the river had been designated by the state as revenue-generators for the park that is to be built along the river once Route 9A, the successor to the abandoned Westway, is completed. The alternative to the athletic complex could easily have been luxury housing rather than "something that the whole community could use," she maintained.
Once again, she extorted concessions in exchange for the board's cooperation. Project managers were required to provide public access around all of the piers, and had to leave a large part of Pier 62 sports-free so people could enjoy the river. To her regret, she lost one battle that resulted in the rest of Pier 62's being allotted for two in-line skating tracks, which are slated to open in June. But the deal also stipulates that these tracks be dismantled when Route 9A is finished.
Roland W. Betts, chairman of Chelsea Piers, had approached the board with trepidation. "If you get into a stink with a community board, it's going to be a hell of a lot harder to get it done," he said, referring to his project. "We lucked out in that we have a constructive board, a board that recognized that the public and private sectors can and should work together. A lot of other boards just say, 'No, no, no.' "
 
 
SYNERGY OR MANIPULATION?
 The Chelsea Piers project also highlighted the potential conflicts that can occur when community leaders who are also business people help to broker a commercial project. Ms. Graham's co-chair on the waterfront committee, Michael Kramer, was the object of unwanted attention after his family-owned company, Audio Speaker Technics, agreed to install the sound systems at the sports complex. "He is doing a ton of work for us," said Mr. Betts.
Defending Mr. Kramer, Ms. Graham said he did not enter into a deal with Chelsea Piers until "long after the basic arrangement" for the complex was completed. "I don't think it was in Michael's mind," she added.
Mr. Kramer said he withdrew from all discussion and decisions involving Chelsea Piers once he started doing business with Mr. Betts.
Under the city's conflict-of-interest rules, community board members are not barred from "having an interest in a firm that may be affected by" the board's action. But the rules also state that members must not vote on any matter "which may result in a personal and direct economic gain to the member or any person with whom the member is associated."
"The whole point of community boards is that they should be made up of people who are interested in and have expertise in things that happen in their community," said Ms. Graham. "What we are careful about is that anyone with a direct financial interest in something is removed from voting on that piece of that activity. But we don't want to lose that person altogether from that activity."
Marc Boddewyn, a landscape architect who is also chairman of the board's Parks and Open Space Committee, is just the kind of person she is talking about. At the April board meeting, two opponents of the "Pomp, Duck" project touched a sensitive nerve when they suggested that he stood to gain financially from alterations to DeWitt Clinton Park.
"Yes, I have worked for the Parks Department as a consultant," Mr. Boddewyn acknowledged, his voice rising. "But no, never have I worked on DeWitt Clinton Park. Nor do I have any possibility of gaining anything from this but pure aggravation." He told the two speakers to "go to hell" but subsequently apologized.
Mr. Boddewyn said in an interview that far from bringing him work, tangling with the Parks Department on a regular basis has done little to endear him to city officials. "It's actually not appreciated by the Parks Department that I'm doing what I'm doing," said Mr. Boddewyn, who quit the board once out of fear of losing future landscape work when the Hudson River Park is finally built. It was Ms. Graham who persuaded him to stay, he said, and he estimated he has spent 80 hours since then working on the DeWitt Clinton issue alone.
The reward? "The reward is that you feel you're not just being NIMBY," he said. "'The easiest thing in the world would be to say 'no' to 'Pomp, Duck & Circumstance.' The difference with Ross was that she was able to keep a debate going that let us explore the potential of this offer fully. That was her greatest gift here."
 
 
 
Community Boards: A Primer
Who's Who
There are 59 boards. Each has a maximum of 50 members, half of whom are appointed by the Borough President and half by the district's City Council members. Members serve without compensation and must live, work or have some other "significant interest" in the district.
 
The History
Community boards have evolved gradually since their origins in 1951, when Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner established 12 neighborhood councils to advise him on planning and land-use matters.
As Mayor, Mr. Wagner extended the concept citywide, hoping to use the boards to weaken the Democratic Party bosses and decentralize decisions on how massive infusions of Federal urban renewal funds were to be spent, says Richard C. Wade, professor of urban history at the City University Graduate Center.
The boards were incorporated into the City Charter in 1963, and staffs were added in 1969. As the influence of the political clubs continued to wane, the boards expanded their role, if not their power. In 1975, they were given additional advisory functions and gained an official voice in the city's uniform land-use review process.
In the most recent charter revision, in 1989, boards were given first crack at new land-use proposals and the authority to develop blueprints -- albeit, nonbinding -- for their communities' future. Community Board 6 in Brooklyn recently became one of the first boards to take advantage of this new right when it submitted a widely praised plan for revitalizing Red Hook.
 
How They Work
Some boards are more effective than others. Their role is purely advisory but they can affect the outcome of development and government proposals -- depending on their credibility and their ability to mobilize and leverage local opinion.
Boards often find it difficult to attract and keep talented volunteers.
The boards are concerned that city budget cuts will make it more difficult to conduct the day-to-day business of handling complaints. These days, if you have complaint about a noisy bar or a proposal for a homeless residence, you may find yourself talking to an answering machine.
In the old days, the incubator for an aspiring politician was likely to be a Tammany Hall clubhouse. A number of today's public officials have cut their teeth on a community board.
"The best training I had to be a council member was being a community board member," said Councilman Thomas K. Duane, an alumnus of Board 4.
 
The Duties
Boards have 21 separate functions, many of which are performed by the district manager hired by the board.
The boards' duties include:
*Assisting city departments and agencies in communicating with the people in the district.
* Preparing comprehensive plans for the "growth, improvement and development" of the district.
* Submitting to the mayor its priorities for how capital and community development funds should be allocated.
* Exercising the initial review of proposals "of public agencies and private entities for the use, development or improvement of land located in the community district."
* Evaluating delivery of local services, including fire, sanitation, police and transportation.

GRAPHIC: Photos: A meeting of Community Board 4 at St. Clare's Hospital. Some meetings can get noisy and contentious. Around the city, some boards are more effective than others. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times)(pg. 16); Ross Graham, chairwoman of Community Board 4, in DeWitt Clinton Park. She has developed a reputation for being able to discern the limits of possibility in dealings with government officials and developers. (Jim Estrin/The New York Times)(pg. 1)
 
Map/Photo: "The West Side Story"
Commuinity District 4 in a hybrid of rich and poor, families and single people, industrial and residential blocks. It is an area with mant hot issues. Ross Graham recently toured the district and made these observations.
 
THE UPSIDE OF THE DOWNSIDE
For a decade, Board 4 has been trying to stave off gentrification in this part of Clinton. The collapse of the real-estate market has been in their favor, Ms. Graham says. "I believe one reason that this current administration is now working with us is that they don't see any other development happening here anytime soon."
 
GHOSTS OF WESTWAY
"We would like the use of Pier 94 for community recreation purposes," says Ms. Graham. That's one reason she supports for construction of Route 9a, the successor to Westway. "Nothing's going to happen on the park until the road gets built," she says. "If you put off the road then who knows when or if any of these other things would happen."
 
THE POUND MUST GO
Ms. Graham is trying to remove an unsightly tow pound from a prime waterfront location. She says the city should lease slots from private parking lots. Is she advocating a form of privatization, a concept Board 4 deplores? "I guess I am," she said. "But city people would be doing the towing and manning the office."
 
GOING TO THE MAT
 Big Issue: Where to put the Guadalcanal, an aircraft carrier that is to serve as the West Side's new heliport, is one of Board 4's major worries. Under the city's plans, the heliport would block the view from the only pier in Clinton that is accessible to the public. "My line to the city is, 'You've got to understand that if you insist on putting Guadalcanal there, that's lie-down-in-front-of-the-bulldozers time,' " Ms. Graham said.
 
ART OR COMMERCE
 Board 4 wants Pier 64 turned over to the public. "We haven't figured out what to do with it inside. Lots of people have lots of different ideas." One suggestion is for art galleries and a small cafe, but with public access throughout. "What we would do is fix the bays so that you would have a wonderful view."
 
KEEPING THINGS SMALL
When a high-rise building sprouted on Eighth Avenue about a decade ago, the neighborhood was "energized" into taking preventative action for the future. Ms. Graham says. "We didn't have anything to say about it, and that kind of made us think about what this would be like if there were those on both sides up and down the avenue."
 
CONFUSING CIRCLE
"This ought to be a real entrance to Central Park and a gateway to the Upper West Side," Ms. Graham says. She would also like to see the confusing traffic patterns altered. "I don't know whether it's city inertia or the buses like going the way they go," she said. "Right now, it's not on the front burner."

HEADLINE: COPING;
A New York Story: The Mugging That Wasn't

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
THE mugger struck at 10:30 in the morning. Ilana Reich, who recounted this story, first in a letter, then in person, is a psychotherapist specializing in the treatment of post-traumatic stress, particularly in the victims of accidents and crimes.
On a Friday two months ago, a day off, Ms. Reich was walking briskly along West 15th Street from Sixth toward Fifth Avenue, a gym bag in one hand, a shopping bag filled with heavy photographic equipment in the other. Her pocketbook strap was looped over her shoulder, her elbow securing its bulk to her side. She remembers hearing thumping footsteps behind her, half-turning, then dismissing as no threat the man behind her. After all, it was 10:30 in the morning. 
 A moment later, he was alongside Ms. Reich. He yanked down on her pocketbook, breaking the strap. He pulled it away from her, turned and lumbered back toward Sixth. Ms. Reich turned after him and yelled: "Please, please take the money but leave the pocketbook."
The pocketbook contained a number of checks to be deposited, her vacation ticket for the next week, her keys and address, and the lists, schedules, notations of a crowded life. Her wallet contained credit cards and $65 for the errands she was running.
To Ms. Reich's astonishment, he stopped and began digging her wallet out of the pocketbook.
"This is the part my daughters hated," said Ms. Reich the other day, in her comfortable living room filled with the momentos of exotic travel. "They say it reinforces my 'naive belief' that I can talk to anyone."
The mugger was a chunky man in his early 30's, wearing jeans and a bomber-style jacket. Once he had the wallet out, he seemed bewildered and began walking back toward her. He had a tan complexion, she noticed, and she wondered if he was Hispanic. He had no accent when he said, "It's such a mess when your pocketbook is stolen."
As he handed her the pocketbook, Ms. Reich said, "Thank you very, very much, I really appreciate it." And then she snatched back her wallet.
He said, "I never do this. This is not what I usually do. I really am sorry. I feel very badly, but I was just at welfare, they turned me down again and I can't get a job. You know, the system really stinks. I feel desperate, but I'm really sorry."
As he talked, Ms. Reich felt herself switch into a professional track. But when he began to cry, so did she. Then he put his arm around her and began to comfort her. In retrospect, she thinks she was crying as much from tension relief as empathy.
Ms. Reich asked him if he ever had a job. He said he had been fired because he broke his finger. He held out a finger, which looked fine to her. Ms. Reich suggested he go to Workers' Compensation. He said he had gone there, and been rejected. Ms. Reich assumed he was working illegally, off the books, and had no recourse.
She plucked all the money out of her wallet, $65, and offered it to him. He refused at first, but when she told him he should not be mugging people because he was not good at it and would probably get hurt or arrested, he took the money.
Then she "took charge," she said, and walked away.
"I knew if it went much further, I'd be involved in his life," she said. She laughed. "Who knows, he'd be living with me, I'd be taking care of him."
"Shouldn't you at least have given him a free therapeutic hour?" I asked.
"He needed a social worker, not me," she said. "He was not a good candidate for psychotherapy. First of all, he didn't have insurance. Second of all, he was in pretty good psychological shape; he was polite, compassionate, concerned about me. His problems were about poverty, unemployment, re-training, getting social services.
"What he did wasn't crazy. It's easy to snatch a purse when you think the system is screwing you. You're angry. That particular crime doesn't seem so violent, so dreadful. There's a logic to it."
Ms. Reich says that the worst part of the story is that she couldn't help her mugger then, and still couldn't now, even if given a second chance; she has told the story to many friends and colleagues and no one, she says, has had a concrete suggestion of what she might have done to aid a man suffering "a poverty attack." She wonders what phone number of what agency she might have given him, what solution there might be.
"I think there are many people in similar positions," she said, "and the number will keep growing as the cuts get deeper. This won't be such an odd story. Some of the endings will be much worse."
Ms. Reich is bright, lively, and direct, but when she begins to muse about her mugger, her features soften. "I'd like to know what happened to him. What was the story he told his friends. We cried together. Did it change his view of things, did it change his life?"

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
How the Other Half Defies Its Image

BYLINE: By SARAH BOXER 

 BODY:
"WHERE we gonna go?" "How we gonna get there?" "What we gonna do?" "Who we gonna fight?" "If we fight, what we gotta whip?"
 This was the caption Dorothea Lange wrote to go with her photograph of five displaced tenant farmers, looking dejected but calm in front of a house in Hardeman County, Tex., in 1937. But it could just as well have been the caption for Joseph Rodriguez's 1993 picture of four gang members in East Los Angeles, posturing defiantly for the camera -- one with a beer can, one with a knife and two with guns (one of which was pointed directly at the photographer). Of course, the words would have a completely different meaning. 
 The documentary photographers Dorothea Lange and Joseph Rodriguez, separated by more than half a century, make an uneasy couple. But because their work is being exhibited concurrently at the International Center for Photography in Manhattan, until today -- the Lange pictures upstairs in the main exhibition hall and Mr. Rodriguez's downstairs -- it's hard to resist a comparison. The two, as befits their positions in the museum, represent the heaven and hell of documentary photography. One is a view of long-suffering people battling the odds, a view with an obvious moral. The other is a vision of hellish recklessness, a violent world with no exit and no wish for salvation.
 Viewers pass through the three rooms devoted to Lange's work in hushed reverence, paying homage to American grit and stoicism. They walk up to the pictures of bread lines in San Francisco, look carefully at the prematurely lined faces and hands of white migrant workers in the San Joaquin Valley, study the gestures of black tenant farmers in Alabama, stare at the tags hanging on the coats of Japanese American families being packed off to internment camps. People huddle around as if looking at a family album. One viewer expressed the general sentiment of the gallery: Looking at the photograph of the five displaced tenant farmers, he said, "I know these men."
 It was a comment one was unlikely to hear in the room with Mr. Rodriguez's pictures of the Evergreen gang in East L.A. The photographs were big. The room was small. There was piped-in rap music. There were bewildering quotes from gang members that were connected only loosely to the photographs. There were large charts and graphs barely touching on the causes of the surrounding violence. Then there were the images themselves -- a man showing his baby daughter how to hold a .32-caliber pistol while the baby's mother watches, smiling; people looking on (many more curious than disturbed) at the open coffin of a baby killed in a drive-by shooting. How was one to react?
 While Lange's photographs seemed to evoke exactly what she intended -- the feeling, as John Szarkowski put it in "Photography Until Now" (1989), that these "are people of exceptional value, proud and independent and competent, who are unlikely to ask for help, but who clearly deserve it" -- Mr. Rodriguez's photographs evoked a feeling of desperate futility -- the feeling that these are people who, if they saw people coming to help, would rob them blind and shoot them without a second thought. The question one immediately felt was not "How is this possible?" but rather, "How can I get out of here as quickly as possible?"
 Why such a difference? Somewhere between the Great Depression and the depressing times we live in now, something changed. Is it just the subjects or the photographs, too? Is it the times or the way we now look at how they're represented?
 Traditionally, documentary photography has come with a political mission. The moral problem of peeking into other people's lives has been vitiated by the good that comes of it. The tacit agreement is that viewers have a social responsibility to look at the scary pictures and, if they're bothered enough, to do something. It's voyeurism with a purpose. And it comes with a certain esthetic. According to Mr. Szarkowski, the classic documentarians "sought pictures that would look ingenuous and free of guile: that would seem not merely honest but artless." Of course, they were not artless.
 Jacob Riis's photographs of New York slums and sweatshops, published in "How the Other Half Lives" a century ago, (and now exhibited at the Museum of the City of New York) were intended to shock and bring about change. And they did. Some of New York's slums were cleared and new tenements with air shafts were built. Fifty years later, Dorothea Lange and Walker Evans, employed by the Farm Security Administration, took their pictures with the purpose of getting more Government relief to the poor. Again, it worked.
 But what about now? Have we outgrown this medium?
 John Berger examined the moral mechanics of documentary photography in his essay "Photographs of Agony" in a book titled "About Looking" (1980). The most extreme photographs, he wrote, "show moments of agony in order to extort the maximum concern." But what if the photographs do not extort concern? What happens when the voyeurism inherent in documentary photography is cut loose from its moral function?
 We have inherited from documentary photography an obligation to look squarely at disturbing images. And photographers have adopted the idea that there is something intrinsically good about showing them. But the subjects of the photographs have, more and more, resisted the program.
 In Robert Frank's book "The Americans" (1958), Jack Kerouac described the beginnings of this change: "The faces don't editorialize or criticize or say anything but 'This is the way we are in real life and if you don't like it I don't know anything about it 'cause I'm living my own life my way and may God bless us all, mebbe' . . . 'if we deserve it.' " By now the subject's stance toward the photographer and the viewer is not just blase, but downright contemptuous.
 When Joseph Rodriguez photographed gang life, with the aim of getting to the roots of gang violence, he did what most documentary photographers do: he won the acceptance of his subjects, and he promised to represent them with respect. But the simple prescriptions he seemed to offer -- more jobs and more money for schools -- looked pathetically small next to the brutality he captured on film.

 
 
Their Own Program
 His subjects refused to go along passively. While Riis's subjects were often caught off guard and Lange's complied quietly with her project, Mr. Rodriguez's gang members seemed to have their own ideas about image-making. Their poses -- with guns, knives, cocaine and stacks of money -- defied any romantic vision of them or what could be done for them. The same could be said of Eugene Richards' infamously grisly photographs of crack addicts.
 The medium of documentary photography is, more and more, detached from its original message. In a recent show at the New Museum of Contemporary Art, in Manhattan, Andres Serrano included some of his portraits of the homeless layered in colorful clothing and moody shadows. He borrowed the traditional subjects of the documentarian -- homelessness and violence -- without adopting any of its social rhetoric.
 But it is Mr. Serrano's photographs of corpses in a morgue -- gigantic images of lives extinguished by fire, by stabbing, by rat poison -- that make the point most clearly. Like the classic documentary photographs, the morgue photos are unblinking and unbearable glimpses of violence. But the most disturbing thing about them is that no matter what feelings of horror and terror they evoke, there is absolutely nothing to be done.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Foreign Aid: Under Seige in the Budget Wars

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Foreign aid is one of the least understood -- and least loved -- parts of the Federal budget. Case in point: 41 percent of Americans said in a recent poll that foreign aid was the largest single item in the budget, even though it represents just 1 percent.
 In their search for budget cuts that will generate the least protest, the new Republican majority in Congress has made foreign assistance a prime target. Treating it as a distasteful form of welfare for foreigners, many Republican leaders are talking of chopping the $15 billion aid budget by 25 percent or more. 
 Overseas aid is used to reduce population growth in Kenya, build roads in Haiti, feed refugees in Rwanda and Bosnia, finance F-15's for Israel, and provide Russia with expertise on privatization. America's contributions to the World Bank help underwrite development loans, while the Export-Import Bank's low-cost loans enable other countries to buy American exports.
 Even as Republicans threaten wholesale cuts, though, it is widely recognized that the two largest aid recipients by far -- Israel, at $3 billion a year, and Egypt, at about $2 billion -- will escape largely untouched. This means that the cuts will come out of just $10 billion of the $15 billion aid budget ($10 billion is what Washington spends each year on farm subsidies). This also means countries other than Egypt and Israel will be cut by far more than 25 percent.
 Some Republicans want to eliminate most of the $1 billion in annual aid to Africa on the ground that the United States has no vital security interests there. The Republicans are also frustrated that after years of receiving millions in aid, many African nations are as bad off as ever. Other likely targets for cuts are $500 million in annual spending for population programs and $1.5 billion for the World Bank and other international development banks.
 The current hostility to foreign aid is a far cry from the program's early days when when the Marshall Plan sometimes spent more than $50 billion a year, translated into current dollars, to help Western Europe recover from World War II. While even then many Americans opposed foreign aid, the nation by and large was proud that this generosity not only helped consolidate democracy and restore prosperity in Western Europe, but helped it resist the siren song of Communism. But that was a different time. The Marshall Plan was successful largely because it helped industrialized nations rebuild, a far easier task than helping developing societies make the leap into modernity.
 Indeed, from the late 1940's until the Soviet empire collapsed five years ago, the central purpose of foreign aid was to lure countries away from Communism. Alleviating poverty and hunger was a secondary goal, American officials acknowledge. Now, with the cold war over, some Republicans suggest that foreign aid can be relegated to the dustbin of history.
 J. Brian Atwood, who heads the Government's main foreign aid arm, the Agency for International Development, insists that foreign assistance is just as vital today as during the cold war. The world is still plenty dangerous, he cautions, and a steady flow of aid is needed to prevent future Somalias and Rwandas.
 Foreign aid, he asserts, is needed to address the problems that spawn such crises: overpopulation, hunger, destruction of the environment. And, he says, it can help former Communist nations avoid economic chaos. "When societies fail there are wars and huge flows of refugees, and then the whole world has to spend a lot of money to resolve these problems," he said. "A little more investment earlier on might help prevent such crises." STEVEN GREENHOUSE

HEADLINE: The Nation;
The Conspiracy That Never Ends

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON 

 BODY:
WHILE most of the world waited for news of the official investigation into the Oklahoma bombing, callers and talk show hosts on World Wide Christian Radio, the Nashville shortwave station that has become the shrill voice of the far right, had it all figured out: the Federal Building was destroyed as part of a plot by the United States Government, acting on behalf of a secret international cabal, the New World Order, whose symbol, the cold staring eye in the pyramid, mocks Americans from the back of every one dollar bill.
 Within days, the bombing had been tightly woven into the sprawling conspiracy theories that have obsessed some Americans since the beginning of the Republic. The historian Richard Hofstadter coined the phrase "the paranoid style in American politics" to describe this pathological world view in which history is a Manichean struggle between the forces of light and of darkness. The conspiratorial fantasies are not simply an expression of inchoate fear. There is a shape, an architecture, to the paranoia. 
 Rule No. 1: The conspirators are internationalist in their sympathies. In this century the main targets of conspiracy theories have been Jews, depicted as people whose loyalty to fellow Jews makes them endemically antipatriotic, and international Communism. The United Nations is suspect, as is the Trilateral Commission, the Council on Foreign Relations, Interpol and even the Red Cross because they supposedly place international agendas above patriotic concerns. In the 19th century, the chief conspirators were said to be the Vatican and the Freemasons. In the mind of today's political paranoiacs, which include some militia members, followers of the Liberty Lobby (the Holocaust-is-a-myth crowd) and the Ku Klux Klan, all these groups are mushed together into the New World Order, or One World Government.
 The first rule is of more than academic historical interest because of Rule No. 2: In a conspiracy theory, nothing is ever discarded. Right-wing mail order bookstores still sell the "Protocols of the Elders of Zion," the anti-Semitic fantasy hatched in Russia a century ago. Another big seller is "Proofs of a Conspiracy," a 1797 book reprinted by the John Birch Society, which fueled speculation that a Freemasonic group called the Order of the Illuminati plotted with the Jeffersonians to turn over the fledging United States to followers of French Enlightenment philosophy -- the 18th century equivalent of secular humanism.
 This brings us to Rule No. 3: Seeming enemies are actually secret friends. As evil as the Communists, in the right-wing mind, are the Rockefellers and international bankers (often a synonym for Jews). Through the lens of the conspiracy theorists, capitalists and Communists work hand in hand.
 To what end? That's Rule No. 4: The takeover by the international godless government will be ignited by the collapse of the economic system. In an elaborate decades-long check-kiting scheme since the dollar was removed from the gold standard, the Federal Reserve has been creating money out of thin air. Once the conspirators give the word, the bankers will yank out the rug from this house of cards and your money will be worthless.
 As a sign that the conspirators have taken over the currency, they had printed on the back a Freemasonic symbol: the all-seeing eye of the enlightened ones perched atop the pyramid. And there, under the emblem, is their name: Novus Ordo Seclorum.
 Finally, Rule No. 5: It's all spelled out in the Bible. For those with a fundamentalist bent, the New World Order or One World Government is none other than the international kingdom of the Antichrist, described in the Book of Revelation. Revelation also speaks of the "mark of the beast," a symbol of the satanic leader that will be imprinted on everyone's forehead and right hand. Fundamentalist preachers like Hal Lindsey have popularized the notion that the mark of the beast is the zebra-striped Universal Product Code, which will be tattooed on everyone by laser to increase the acuity of the panoptic big eye.
 We may never know what went through the real conspirators' minds when, as investigators say, they rented a truck, packed it full of fertilizer and fuel oil, and ignited it where it would do the most harm. But if they hung out at militia meetings, or even just tuned in occasionally to WWCR, they would have been exposed to this kind of thinking, over and over and over again.

HEADLINE: Illinois Town, Fearing Racial Imbalance, to Advertise for Whites

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MATTESON, Ill., April 29

 BODY:
This community 40 miles south of Chicago has begun a $37,000 advertising campaign to lure affluent whites and slow racial change.
Some experts say the effort may fail, and critics say it is offensive to the growing black population here. "Let's be realistic," said a black resident, Ernest Wooten Jr. "There's some racism behind this. They say they want to keep it mixed. But my feelings are if you don't want to live here I don't want you here." 
 Village Administrator Ralph Coglianese said the difference from other communities was that Matteson was explicit. "Most of the people would just rather not do anything," Mr. Coglianese said. "It's the easy way out. We've seen no history of people being able to maintain racial diversity without working at it."
Matteson has neat single-family homes and tree-lined streets, with little crime. A boom in the 1970's attracted middle managers seeking housing within easy train commuting distance to Chicago. Split in half by Interstate 57, the older east side is mostly white, and the west side has become predominantly black. The construction of $100,000 to $300,000 houses has continued into the 1990's, mostly on the west side.
"When I moved here nine years ago, it was probably 50 percent black, 50 percent white," said Mr. Wooten, a west side resident. "Now it seems they're steering nothing but blacks here, and whites are moving out."
In 1980 the village was 12 percent black, according to the Census Bureau. In 10 years the black population grew 32 percent, and the white population dropped 31 percent. Today, experts say, 48 percent of the 11,500 residents are classified as black.
A panel made up nearly equally of blacks and whites has recommended promotions through brochures and advertising aimed at "white home-seeking prospects interested in residing in a racially diverse suburban community." The advertisements could appear in the summer.
Village Trustee Denise Clemons said the drive was about economics, not racism. "If you have only one group of people looking at real estate in this area," Ms. Clemons said, "then you're not seeing the whole market. This is about home values and the quality of life here."
Historically after a community becomes mostly black, housing prices drop and decay follows, said Doug Massey, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania who specializes in studying urban segregation. The black middle class is often too small to make up for an exodus of middle-class whites, Professor Massey said, leading to increased renting to lower-income people who do not keep up the properties.
"The racism is not the individuals in the community who are trying to fight the downward spiral in housing costs," he said. "The racism is in the structure of the housing and lending markets and in the general society."
Property values in communities that maintain predominantly white populations rise consistently, experts said. In Evanston, where the black population has remained at 22 percent for years, the median home value climbed 109 percent from 1980 to 1990, the Census Bureau said. In Matteson the increase was 31 percent, compared with 68 percent nationally.
Trying to reverse such trends is difficult, and efforts can easily be perceived as racist, said Edwin Mills, a professor of real estate at the J. L. Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern University. "Nobody advertised to bring blacks in, I bet," Professor Mills said. "The evidence I see is that whites are more concerned about class than race nowadays. But many whites are obsessively prone to identify lower class with blacks."

HEADLINE: On Saigon's Day of Defeat, a Glitter of Rebirth

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam, Sunday, April 30

 BODY:
In the glittering chaos of Vietnam's boom town, it is difficult to imagine that 20 years ago today, Saigon was a city so defeated that it was forced even to sacrifice its name.
Government-issued maps now identify it as Ho Chi Minh City, the name it was given on April 30, 1975. That was the morning when a North Vietnamese tank crashed through the gates of the presidential palace of the collapsed, American-backed Government of South Vietnam. 
 But for most of this city's four million residents, this is -- and will always be -- Saigon. They never stopped calling it Saigon.
And exactly two decades after it came under the control of the Communist North, this city is more prosperous and, in many ways, more powerful than at any time in its history.
Much more than the aging Communist soldiers in Hanoi who won the war and humiliated a superpower, the ambitious capitalists of this city are pointing the way to Vietnam's future -- rushing into the free markets that today even the Communists must grudgingly endorse.
Anyone who doubts their independence need only witness how the people of the city are marking the 20th anniversary of its capture.
To be sure, large buildings in the city have been draped in banners and bunting bearing the hammer and sickle and the grinning, wispy-bearded image of Ho Chi Minh. But for every banner with a portrait of Ho, another flutters in the warm breeze with the red, white and blue logo of Pepsi Cola, an official sponsor of the celebrations.
"I think Saigon is the most exciting city in the world," said Lu Thang, a 25-year-old business student who, when asked about her career goal, replied in a gentle voice, "Real estate." She said she would miss the anniversary parade today because she had work to do at her father's newly opened computer store.
The war, she said, "is over -- we do not want to talk about it anymore."
"I think everybody, including all the people in Hanoi and all over Vietnam, agree that what is best for our country is that we try to make some money and feed ourselves and have enough clothes," she added. "And we are doing that."
 
From Embassy Roof, A City Transformed
 Twenty years ago this weekend, the view from the top of the United States Embassy in Saigon was one of panic as thousands of Vietnamese pushed in desperately against the embassy gates. Their goal was to reach the staircase leading to the seventh-floor roof, where American helicopters offered the final route of escape from the city.
The Communists were closing in. Mortar fire had turned night into day. In the embassy garden, American marines were making a bonfire of millions of dollars in cash that had been brought into Vietnam to pay informers and was too heavy to carry out on the helicopters.
Today, the abandoned embassy is crumbling, the helicopter pads coated with orange-brown rust from the tropical heat. The panorama from the rooftop is one of a fixed forest of construction cranes, signaling the birth of a futuristic skyline for Vietnam's largest city.
Since the Communists made their first grudging steps toward the free market in 1986 under a policy known as doi moi, or renovation, the city has been transformed. Applying lessons of their Western patrons -- first the French, then the Americans -- the people have set to work on rebuilding a city shattered by war and the neglect born of poverty. The result is a town that glories in its newfound prosperity, with freshly painted store fronts decorated in marble and neon lights.
The most famous boulevard -- known as Tu Do (Freedom) Street before 1975, and renamed Dong Khoi (Revolution) Street by the Communists -- is crowded with expensive cafes and boutiques that would not be out of place on the grander avenues of Manhattan.
Many of the big multinational companies that have rushed back have taken over decrepit villas dating from the French colonial occupation and turned them into shimmering palaces of commerce.
At night the streets become a dense parade of fancy new motor bikes. "I wonder what the old Communists think when they see this new chrome," an American banker said. "Remind me: Who won this war?"
Hanoi, the once-dour Communist capital, is also beginning to prosper. The notorious prison known as the Hanoi Hilton, once a place of brutal confinement for American prisoners of war, is falling to the wrecking ball this month, to be replaced by a plush office complex.
But there is still no comparison in the wealth of the two cities. Per capita income in Ho Chi Minh City is nearly $850, more than three times the average in the rest of the country and almost double that of the capital.
 
Lingering Bitterness Of the Vanquished
 While the physical scars from the war have begun to vanish from Ho Chi Minh City, the other sort remains. For many Vietnamese, it has proved far easier to forgive the Americans for any damage that they may have done to this country than to forgive each other.
"The hostility is always in my mind -- the anger is in my mind even today," said Le Tay Nguyen, who was a captain in the South Vietnamese Army in 1975.
Mr. Nguyen was one of hundreds of Vietnamese who sat patiently one afternoon last week on the wooden benches outside the offices of the Orderly Departure Program. Set up by the United States, the program offers asylum to former soldiers of the South Vietnamese Government and others who were persecuted after the war.
Mr. Nguyen said he wanted desperately to leave. After the war, he said, he was interned for six years in a Communist re-education camp in which conditions were "terrible." "They knocked out my teeth," he said, pointing to a long row of dentures along his lower jaw before pointing to his feet. "They ran sticks along my feet as torture," he explained.
Ee Duc Thanh, 55, clutched papers showing he had worked in the American Embassy from 1967 to 1975 as a translator. The only reason he was unable to join the evacuation 20 years ago, he said, was that a thief had stolen a suitcase that contained the documents verifying his position. It has taken him all these years, he said, to obtain new copies.
"I must go to the U.S. to live because I have difficulty in my life in Vietnam," said Mr. Thanh, who added that his children had paid the biggest price for his past. "Because I worked for the Americans, my children could not go to university and they cannot find a good job," he said. "That is why they want to go to America too."
A few blocks away, in the offices of the Vietnamese Veterans' Association, the victors in that long-ago war sat beneath a faded lacquer portrait of Ho Chi Minh and insisted that they had not set out to punish the vanquished. "We know that some of the South Vietnamese joined in the war with the Americans," said Vo Thang Kiet, a 66-year-old retired colonel in the North Vietnamese Army. "But for these people, we do not feel any hostility, any dislike."
That sense of charity was not found at the nearby offices of the Ministry of Labor, War Invalids and Social Welfare, which has never bothered to include the South Vietnamese Army casualties in official totals of war dead. "We do not care about what happened to these people," said Nghiem Xuan Tue, a ministry spokesman.
 
Two Decades Later, 'The War is Over'
 Twenty years ago this morning, Ly Quy Chung prepared to surrender Saigon to the Communist North, an act that would reunify his homeland after a generation of war and the loss of millions of lives, including those of at least 58,000 Americans. The last American diplomats had fled the city hours before.
Mr. Chung, who had been drafted as the Information Minister for the Saigon Government only three days before its collapse, remembered the quiet as he waited in front of the presidential palace for something to happen. Finally, he said, a tank appeared in the distance.
"When the tank arrived, it fired a shot at the palace -- boom -- to create a certain panic," he said. "They shouted for us to raise our hands to surrender."
The tank crashed through the heavy gates, and a soldier rushed toward the palace demanding to know how to reach the flagpole on the roof. "I told him to follow me," Mr. Chung said. "So we went to the elevator, but the soldier refused to enter because this was the first time in his life that he had seen an elevator, this strange box."
"I told him not to be afraid," Mr. Chung recalled, grinning at the memory. "Finally we got to the roof." Minutes later, the red and gold flag of the Communist forces was fluttering over Saigon, which hours later would become Ho Chi Minh City.
Mr. Chung had been one of the few opposition politicians in South Vietnam, a member of the so-called Third Force that opposed the repressive American-backed regime of President Nguyen Van Thieu.
"History pushed me into this situation," he said of his role in the surrender. "It was not a happy end for me." But with reunification, he said, "it was a happy end for the country." Because he had opposed the Thieu Government, Mr. Chung, now 55, was spared imprisonment in a re-education camp. He is now editor of his own weekly newspaper, which like all publications in Vietnam is subject to tight censorship.
But what he cannot say in print in his newspaper, he will say in person. He readily concedes that the Communists made disastrous mistakes in the 10 years after they captured Saigon, including collectivist economic policies that drove the country to the brink of starvation.
"It was a very dark period," he said. "There were bad economic policies, bad political policies, and that is why so many people left the country in this period." He was speaking of the mass exodus by more than one million Vietnamese who became known as the boat people.
Mr. Chung's family was among those who took to the rickety boats. All seven of his brothers and sisters now live in the United States or Canada, and his mother later left for New York under the Orderly Departure Program. "I am the only one left," he said.
With the Government's move to the free market in 1986 and the rebirth of this city, the conditions that drove his family away have ended, Mr. Chung said. "Now, I think the life in this city is better than before 1975," he said. "The people are more optimistic than ever before. The dark period is over. The war is over."

GRAPHIC: Photos: A woman sells T-shirts in Ho Chi Minh City, which has more entrepreneurial zip now than the Saigon of old. (Associated Press) (pg. 1)
 
Chronology: "A History of Turmoil"
 
 Some main events in the history of Vietnam, which has undergone colonization, war and economic and political turmoil for more than a century.
 
FRENCH RULE AND RESISTANCE
 
1859-83 France colonizes Indochina.
 
1930 Ho Chi Minh founds Communist Party of Indochina.
 
1940 Japan takes control of Indochina but rules through Vichy French administration throughout World War II.
 
1945 Viet Minh nationalists and Communist Party begin insurrections throughout the country in August, declare end of French rule, abolish monarchy of Emperor Bao Dai. On Sept. 2, Ho Chi Minh proclaims independence and establishes Democratic Republic of Vietnam.
 
FRENCH DEFEAT AND A BREAKUP

1954 French defeated at Dien Bien Phu in May after a 56-day siege, signaling end colonial rule. At Geneva Conference on Indochina, Vietnam is divided at 17th parallel pending elections for reunification. Nearly one million people, mostly Catholics and people fleeing land reform, begin an exodus to south from north, which came under control of Communists under Ho Chi Minh.
 
1955 Ngo Dinh Diem, the southern leader, rejects Geneva agreements, becomes President of Republic of Vietnam, known as South Vietnam.
 
1956 South Vietnam, with United States support, cancels the elections, which were expected to favor the Communists.
 
INTERNAL CONFLICT
 
1957 Vietnam completes land reforms begun in 1953. People's tribunals convict landlords.
 
1959 Communist Party Central Committee supports insurgency in South. Weapons and men infiltrate down the Ho Chi Minh Trail. Diem steps up campaign against dissidents.
 
1960 Military coup in Saigon fails. Communists establish National Liberation Front in Saigon to unite oppposition to Diem. United States increases aid to South Vietnam.
 
1961 People's Liberation Army, the Viet Cong guerrilla force, is formed to overthrow South Vietnamese Government and gains control of much of countryside.
 
1962 United States has about 12,000 military personnel in South Vietnam. Peasants are forced to regroup in 16,000 fortified villages, or "strategic hamlets."
 
1963 Government suppression of Buddhists provokes civil unrest. In November, Diem is overthrown in American-backed coup. He and his brother Ngo Dinh Nhu, the security chief, are executed. By the end of 1963, 80 percent of "strategic hamlets" are destroyed.
 
U.S. JOINS THE WAR
 
The Tonkin Incident
 
1964 In August, United States reports attack by North Vietnamese patrol boats on American warships in Gulf of Tonkin. United States begins bombing North Vietnam. Congress passes Gulf of Tonkin Resolution, allowing President Johnson to take steps "to prevent further aggression."
 
1965 Marines land at Danang on March 8, the first American combat troops officially in Vietnam.
 
A Turning Point
 
1968 North Vietnamese and Viet Cong attack American positions across south in Tet Offensive. Johnson halts bombing of North Vietnam. American military presence peaks at 549,000 troops.
 
1969 President Nixon begins withdrawing American ground troops. Ho Chi Minh dies on Sept. 2.
 
1970 Henry Kissinger and Le Duc Tho begin secret talks in Paris.
 
1971 About 139,000 American troops in Vietnam by year-end.
 
1972 North Vietnam Army strikes across 17th Parallel. United States steps up bombing of North Vietnam, in attempt to expedite Paris peace talks, and mines Haiphong harbor.
 
1973 Kissinger and Tho sign cease-fire in Paris against wishes of South Vietnam's President, Nguyen Van Thieu. Peace Agreement signed by all parties on Jan. 27. United States completes troop pullout in March. Hanoi releases prisoners of war.
 
1974 House of Representative rejects Admnistration request for increased military aid to South Vietnam
 
THE FALL OF SAIGON
 
1975 North Vietnam and Viet Cong coordinate attacks. Southern cities fall one by one until Communist forces seize Saigon on April 30.
 Over four days, North Vietnamese first attack from south and east, between city and sea, and then from north.
 
REUNIFICATION

1976 In July, Vietnam is reunified as Socialist Republic of Vietnam, after elections for National Assembly.
 
1978 In December, Vietnam invades Cambodia to oust the Khmer Rouge.
 
1979 China attacks Vietnam. Hundreds of thousands of ethnic Chinese flee Vietnam.
 
1981-85 Economic crisis in Vietnam.
 
1986 Sixth Communist Party Congress approves economic reforms.
 
1989 Vietnam completes troop withdrawal from Cambodia.
 
1991 After Soviet Union collapses, Vietnam loses main aid donor and markets. Cambodia peace agreement is signed. Vietnam and China normalize relations.
 
1992 New constitution reaffirms Communist Party leadership.
 
1994 In February, President Clinton lifts trade embargo against Vietnam.
 
1995 In January, Vietnam and the United States settle property claims dating back to war and set up liaison offices in Hanoi and Washington. (pg. 14)

HEADLINE: Expulsion Seen as Sign Of New Mood

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: PLAINFIELD, N.J.

 BODY:
Dozens of trophies collected during seven years in the Scotch Plains-Fanwood schools clog the dresser top and most every surface in Jason McLean's bedroom -- a Most Valuable Player statue from his freshman football team, a plaque honoring his four years as a varsity wrestler.
The room is a shrine to what should be the end of a charmed high school career -- yearbooks the 17-year-old worked on, mementos from two years as class president, his two-toned black and white shoes from the junior prom. 
 But three months before Jason's graduation, Scotch Plains-Fanwood High School declared him a nonresident, handed him his transcript and told him to leave. The expulsion last month came on his first day back after his crowning wrestling triumph for the school -- finishing at the top 16 at the state championships in Atlantic City.
"You have to have all your teachers sign you out," Jason said. "I broke down crying in the hall and then I went home."
Jason McLean's experience is a striking example of how in these tough budget times, public schools are going to new lengths to make sure that every student is a resident and is entitled to attend the district's schools.
The McLean family acknowledges that it does not live in Scotch Plains anymore. They declared bankruptcy in 1994, losing their house. The parents said that they moved away at the start of the school year and that that fact was widely known in the community -- Jason was even picked up for wrestling matches from his new home in neighboring Plainfield. But, they said, Scotch Plains officials turned a blind eye until the wrestling season ended and the school could no longer benefit from his athletic talents.
Scotch Plains officials countered that their residency investigation just happened to coincide with the end of wrestling season, but either way, the case illustrates the aggressiveness of residency crackdowns going on statewide.
As budget cuts have taken hold under Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, local school officials have pressed to make sure that no outsiders are trying to get a free education in their districts.
The New Jersey School Boards Association estimates that the number of such "rogue" students peaked at 8,000 to 10,000 last year and is now falling because of the new hardball tactics.
"The general cutbacks from the Whitman administration have made dollars scarce, so districts want to make sure that the dollars they have to spend on education programs benefit children domiciled in their community, " said Dr. Lawrence S. Feinsod, president of the Garden State Coalition of Schools, a group of 110 largely prosperous districts.
"There has been an increased effort by school districts to weed out students who do no live in the district because of the increasing scarcity of resources," he said.
Most cases are not like Jason McLean's. They usually involve parents sneaking younger children into suburban programs not available in their own poorer urban districts -- all-day kindergarten, for example.
But Jason's experience has been a particularly painful test of the new attitude.
"What we are most upset about is the way that they did it," said Agness McLean, Jason's mother. "They allowed Jason to wrestle. They allowed him to participate up until the end of the wrestling season. The next school day they put him out. We feel they used him."
So far, an editorial in the school newspaper, a petition drive and pleas from the McLean family that Jason be allowed to graduate with his classmates have not elicited a response from the Union County school.
The family, while admitting that it should have been more open with officials, is considering a lawsuit to get Jason a diploma from the high school where he spent 3 3/4 years.
Under the rules at Scotch Plains-Fanwood High School, seniors who start the year have the right to finish even if their parents move away. The McLeans say that they are owed this right, having been forced out of their house after the start of the school year on Sept. 8, 1994. Jonathan J. McLean, the father, lost his job as a boilermaker and was unemployed for eight months before the family declared bankruptcy.
School officials said that the family had moved earlier, and in any case forfeited the right by not coming forward to explain the problem and by enrolling Jason's two younger brothers as a junior and a freshman. They were expelled at the same time he was.
"It was our observation that they intended to go through with the junior for two years and the freshman for four years," said Dr. Terry Riegel, principal at the 1,100-student high school.
"It is flagrant fraud," he said, noting that the school could have pursued the family for $30,000 in tuition.
Dr. Riegel said that it was a coincidence that the undercover residency investigation culminated on the very Monday after the wrestling championships.
He said an anonymous tipster called in mid-February and gave them a license plate number of the McLeans' car. An investigator shadowed the car from Plainfield until it dropped the three boys off at the high school.
"I like to win and I like to be a champion, but the kid was not a legal resident," Dr. Riegel said.
Roy Schleicher, associate director of the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association, said the school would not forfeit its wrestling ranking as long as the student involved was considered a legal resident at the time of the championships.
The McLeans said that they had hoped to keep the brothers in school together for one last year to anchor them while their family life was in such turmoil.
"We are the adults here, " Mrs. McLean said. "We made a horrible mistake. Things are bad enough. This kid has lost his home. Do you punish him even further by denying him the opportunity to graduate with his peers when he has given so much?"
Penny Venetis, a professor at Rutgers University Law School's Constitution Litigation Clinic who represents Jason, said she believes that there might be two grounds to legally reinstate him. First, there was no formal hearing after his expulsion, she said, and second, the school benefited from Jason's enrollment by allowing him to wrestle even while suspecting his residency.
Some students reacted with an editorial this month in the school newspaper and collected 400 signatures on a petition asking that Jason be reinstated.
"Whether school officials were ignorant of the situation because of incompetence or ulterior motives is not an issue," the editorial said. "The fact is that McLean had completed the majority of his senior year. His education has already been paid for through tax money and no one stood to gain anything by removing McLean from school. In fact, McLean's dismissal only resulted in a great loss to many."
The McLean family moved to Scotch Plains in May 1988, gaining instant local fame when the oldest son, Dana, helped reverse the high school football team's losing streak. Mr. McLean, 41, coached youth league football and baseball teams. Jason still umpires for one of the Police Athletic League baseball teams. Mrs. McLean, 39, has collected three scrapbooks and a plastic shopping bag full of articles about the family's athletic triumphs.
The McLeans said that as African-Americans they never felt overt hostility but never felt quite welcome either in a community that is 88 percent white.
Jason was popular, winning the class presidency his sophomore and junior years. Teachers said they found him to be an enthusiastic pupil. "He was always active -- taking pictures, writing copy, working on the layouts," said Michelle Zarro, the yearbook faculty adviser.
His wrestling coach did not want to comment, but fellow students said they liked watching him wrestle in the 126-pound class. "When you went to a wrestling match he was the one people would go to watch because he was so exciting," said Craig Costello, a senior. "He was very energetic on the mat."
After his expulsion, Jason enrolled in Plainfield High School. He is considering repeating his senior year at a local private school to pull up his B-minus average and get into a more competitive college with a strong wrestling program.
For now he wants to add just one thing to his room: a diploma from Scotch Plains-Fanwood High.
"I didn't realize how much I liked it until the day I was leaving, until the day I started crying in the hall," he said. "I didn't realize how much a part of that school I was until kids started walking up to me in the hall and telling me that they were sorry about what happened. I didn't realize how much a part of it I was until I wasn't there."

HEADLINE: U.S. Enslaves Japanese, Cabinet Official Says

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 29

 BODY:
A Cabinet minister has bitterly rebuked the United States, saying it enslaved the Japanese people as it once enslaved Africans, but he then backtracked by saying he had meant his comments to be off the record.
The official, Transport Minister Shizuka Kamei, was expressing Japan's frustration at its predicament as the yen rises against the dollar. 
 "If I dare to use a metaphor, there was a time when America bought black slaves from Africa and produced wealth," Mr. Kamei said, according to Japanese press reports on Friday. "The recent behavior of the United States makes me suspect that it may be using Japan and saying, 'There are very diligent Japanese whom you can use as slaves and produce good results.'
"Doesn't it seem that the feelings toward Japan of the United States, the country we democracies depend on the most, have chilled recently? This may sound like the weeping of a jilted woman, but that's the sort of feeling I've got."
Mr. Kamei's remarks underscore the growing anger at what is seen as American indifference to the shift in exchange rates. The yen's trajectory -- to about 84 yen to the dollar now, compared with about 100 yen to the dollar at the beginning of the year -- is a major political issue in Japan.
While Japan is a bit proud of its strong currency, it is extremely concerned about the effects on exporters, who find it much more difficult to compete in international markets at today's exchange rates. In addition, even purely domestic companies are now facing growing pressure from imports that are much cheaper because of the strength of the yen.
Mr. Kamei, an outspoken former police official, made his remarks in a speech Thursday night in Tokyo to the Japan Critics Association, a writers' group.
After his remarks caused a stir in Tokyo, Mr. Kamei appeared to backtrack, but he stopped short of an apology or retraction. According to Japanese press reports, he told the Foreign Minister and the Chief Cabinet Secretary that the remarks were inappropriate.
Asked for a response, he told Japanese reporters on Friday: "This was a place I lectured on the condition of its being off the record. I have no intention of announcing it publicly to the United States."
Americans tend to blame Japan in part for the strength of its currency, saying that it should do more to deregulate its markets. In theory that could fuel extra economic activity, which could lead to more imports and a declining currency. But Japanese officials contend that they are already deregulating markets, and they are concerned about losing influence in areas they have dominated for decades.
Many economists say that in the immediate future Japan is more likely than the United States to suffer the consequences of the strong yen, so that the problem should be addressed in Japan now.
"They can't come up with a coherent policy, so they look for a scapegoat," said Mineko Sasaki-Smith, an economist at Morgan Stanley Japan.
