HEADLINE: New York Pledge to House Poor Works a Rare, Quiet Revolution

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
In 1986, Mayor Edward I. Koch made a bold commitment, promising that New York City would spend $4.2 billion in the following decade to build new homes for poor and working-class New Yorkers.
Nine years later, the city has made good on much of that ambitious pledge. Under Mr. Koch and his successors, the city has financed and overseen the creation of more than 50,000 new apartments and houses -- enough to fill a small city. 
 The investment has transformed huge swaths of New York's most blighted neighborhoods, including Harlem, the South Bronx, Crown Heights, East New York, Brownsville and Bedford-Stuyvesant.
Abandoned, gutted buildings have been rebuilt. Houses have gone up on empty, littered lots. In some areas, stores have begun popping up for new homeowners and apartment dwellers. Property values have increased, and banks are granting mortgages.
The Giuliani administration has devised several new programs to revive the remaining vacant buildings, which are small and scattered, representing a potential for 12,000 new apartments. But many housing experts fear that the city will run out of money and political will before it runs out of small abandoned buildings.
Should that happen, community organizers and housing developers warn, the little miracles that have brought neighborhoods back to life will no longer be duplicated.
On Williams Avenue in East New York, Brooklyn, for example, one of the toughest blocks in one of the city's most high-crime neighborhoods, a vacant three-story building with nine apartments was completely rebuilt in 1993. So were several smaller buildings on the street.
That same year, there were three drug-related murders and 500 drug trafficking arrests on the block, in an area known as "the dead zone" by local planners. Today, after repeated efforts by the police and community organizers working for the nonprofit group that reconstructed the buildings, the dealers have moved on.
The local group, the East New York Urban Youth Corps, has rebuilt 32 small buildings within six blocks of Williams Avenue over the last four years, delighting longtime residents who stuck out the lean years. "It was bad, bad, bad, bad, bad," said James Worth, who has owned a house in the neighborhood for 32 years. "It went down so far it had no place to go but up. There have been a lot of improvements."
Perhaps the most notable aspect of the city's effort is its scale. New York's program is not simply larger than those of other cities, specialists in low-income housing say; it is larger than those of every other American city combined.
And yet, because middle-class and affluent New Yorkers so seldom venture into neighborhoods like East New York, many are unaware of their revival. "It was one of those secret successes," said Carol Lamberg, the executive director of the Settlement Housing Fund, a nonprofit agency that owns and manages many buildings.
 
Crisis
Steps to Counter An Abandonment
 In the mid-1980's, city housing officials found themselves at a crossroads. Every poor neighborhood in New York had been devastated by the economic decline of the 1970's. The South Bronx, Harlem and central and eastern Brooklyn were littered with more than 5,000 burnt-out wrecks, many of them not much more than brick walls and foundations, filled with garbage, piles of tires and even abandoned cars. Homeless families were filling up shelters and welfare hotels.
The Federal Government, under President Ronald Reagan, had withdrawn from its traditional role as the prime builder of low-income housing, although it continued to provide rent subsidies for poor people.
With New York City having finally recovered from the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, Mr. Koch and his advisers decided they had no choice but to step in, committing major resources to revitalize poor neighborhoods by rebuilding their housing stock.
They had few models. Traditionally, the low-income housing provided by the Federal Government was in high-rise projects.
Paul A. Crotty, who is now the city's Corporation Counsel and who was Housing Commissioner in 1986 and 1987, recalled several early crucial decisions. Officials reasoned they could reduce construction costs by taking advantage of an unlikely resource, the abandoned buildings and vacant land that had fallen into the city's hands through tax foreclosures.
And they decided to create a half-dozen new programs, instead of one large effort, so they could tap into many different constituencies: private, for-profit developers, nonprofit housing managers, community and church groups, and national foundations committed to community development.
A related goal was to produce new housing for New Yorkers of different economic classes, including families with moderate incomes as well as the working poor and the destitute.
In effect, they tried a series of experiments to see what would work best. "We were going to try to hit all the notes," Mr. Crotty said. "We tried to get a lot of things going at once."
In one component, the city gave vacant shells to private developers. In another, the buildings went to nonprofit community groups. The new owners used varying combinations of city subsidies, bank financing and a Federal low-income housing tax credit to underwrite the reconstructions. In a third segment, the city directly hired large construction companies to rebuild clusters of abandoned shells.
Today, more than 3,000 abandoned apartment houses have been rebuilt, providing more than 39,000 new apartments. And 12,000 new one-, two- and three-family houses have been constructed on vacant, city-owned land and sold to working families. In all, the city has spent $4 billion in the last nine years.
 
Experiments
City Learns From Its Mistakes
 There were growing pains, of course, like more than $50 million in cost overruns in one program.
The city hired top-of-the-line construction companies to rebuild two clusters of buildings, one a group of 46 small vacant shells in central Harlem and the other a group of 14 larger gutted structures on Walton Avenue in the South Bronx. The Harlem buildings eventually cost about $140,000 an apartment, and the Bronx cluster $98,000 an apartment. They had originally been projected to cost $65,000 an apartment.
City officials learned from these problems, and they reconfigured the program to reduce costs, using smaller clusters of buildings and hiring smaller construction companies with more experience renovating apartment buildings.
Other rehabilitations of gutted buildings were more successful. In the vacant buildings program, through which private developers bought shells for $1 and reconstructed them with city subsidies, the rebuilding cost about $65,000 an apartment.
Housing officials say it would have cost much more to build new mid-rise apartment houses from scratch. The city's Housing Authority, which manages high-rise projects built with Federal money a generation ago, estimates that if it had to replace its 180,000 apartments today, it would cost $125,000 an apartment.
There was debate in the early years over who should live in the city's rebuilt structures. In one program, the city filled buildings with homeless families.
Many community organizers and housing managers assailed the practice, arguing against congregating so many poor, troubled families together. By 1989, the Koch administration was putting homeless people in only half the apartments in this program.
Today, at least a half-dozen of these buildings have aged badly. But the cause of their deterioration may have had less to do with who lived there than with who managed them: in almost every case, the city.
Drug dealers took over a building at 815 Fairmount Place, in East Tremont just north of the Cross-Bronx Expressway, causing such extensive damage that the city had to replace the elevator.
On Avenue St. John, just off Southern Boulevard in the South Bronx, two adjacent buildings that gleamed when they were completed in 1989 are now worn. Five apartments are boarded up at 1037 Avenue St. John, and the front hall is marred by graffiti. "It's been bad for two or three years," said Iris Romero, who has lived in the building since it re-opened. "H.P.D., bad landlord," she said.
Officials of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development did not dispute the assertion; they said the building and the one next door would be turned over to a local nonprofit group this year. The building on Fairmount Place is now managed by a local group, as are most of the 200 buildings in this segment.
 
Success
New Communities For False Ones
 But if the housing revival has occasionally misstepped, it has nonetheless altered the landscape of countless blocks, bringing a measure of hope to places where it is often in short supply.
"The hemorrhaging was stopped," said Ronald Shiffman, director of the graduate center for planning and the environment at Pratt Institute. "Buildings that were abandoned were put back on line, rebuilding and reinvigorating neighborhoods."
On what were once vast tracts of vacant land in a section of East New York, hundreds of single-family houses have been built, creating an entirely new community.
A mile away, the apartment house at 1610 St. Johns Place in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, was a hulking, abandoned shell just three years ago. Today, it is home to families like Elaine Newkirk and her three children, who were once homeless and now share a tidy three-bedroom apartment. With its clean brick facade and bright red fire escapes, Ms. Newkirk's building and its three identical neighbors illuminate an otherwise bleak block at the eastern edge of Crown Heights.
"This is as good as it gets," Ms. Newkirk said.
On Fulton Avenue in the South Bronx, a row of buildings, their brick exteriors steam-cleaned, sit high on a hill overlooking the Cross-Bronx Expressway. Once, they defined urban despair, so much so that desperate city officials with no money to spend for renovations in the early 1980's put vinyl facings showing shutters and flowerpots over blocked-up windows, trying in vain to disguise the buildings' demise.
And in Harlem, 46 buildings have been reconstructed in a five-block area bounded by 139th Street, 144th Street, Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard and Lenox Avenue.
Noreen Lynch moved in January into one of the biggest and most handsome of these renovated buildings, at the corner of 142d Street and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard. Ms. Lynch once worked as a home health-care attendant in a public housing project right across the street, and she used to watch workers remaking the building.
Now, after spending four years in a city hospital because of severe injuries from an auto accident, Ms. Lynch is delighted with her new home, which has 24-hour security and a conscientious superintendent.
"These buildings were really redone nicely," she said.
Without the city's intervention, the blighted neighborhoods surely would have continued to decline. Neither the state nor Federal governments were prepared to commit significant resources for new housing, and private business did not show much willingness to invest in poor neighborhoods.
"It's one of the best examples of government accomplishing something in an age when there is a lot of cynicism about government's ability to get things done," said Abraham Biderman, who was Housing Commissioner under Mr. Koch in 1988 and 1989.
 
The Future
Plans Are Certain, But Not the Will
 Where the housing program goes from here is uncertain. Deborah C. Wright, the Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, has devised new ways to clean up the hundreds of small abandoned buildings still scattered around neighborhoods. She is packaging them with rundown, occupied buildings also owned by the city, and plans to turn these small clusters over to local for-profit housing managers and nonprofit groups for rebuilding.
"What we're trying to do is have a comprehensive approach that focuses on the neighborhood and not on individual buildings," Ms. Wright said. "We're trying to address the unit that matters, which is the block, and to address every single housing problem on the block."
Many community groups have applauded the approach, although some object to the use of private housing managers. But they fear that Ms. Wright may not get enough financial and political support to complete the job begun under Mr. Koch and continued under Mayor David N. Dinkins.
Housing experts contend that the city must also commit more money to upgrade another segment of the city-owned housing stock: the 38,000 apartments in old, dilapidated occupied buildings.
Others say the city should devise new programs to spur renovation of thousands of rundown apartment buildings still privately owned.
Many people are worried, too, about the long-term stability of the neighborhoods that were so recently revived. Federal rent subsidies are likely to be cut; if the Mayor and City Council decide to significantly reduce city spending on housing, many experts fear the consequences.
"If we cut off public and private resources, these neighborhoods will slide back very quickly," said Katherine Wylde, president of the New York City Housing Partnership.

HEADLINE: A Proposed Definition of Poverty May Raise Number of U.S. Poor

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 29

 BODY:
Experts at the National Academy of Sciences will soon recommend to Congress huge changes in the way poverty is defined and measured, and the changes could substantially increase the number of working Americans classified as poor.
The official definition of poverty used by the Federal Government for three decades is based simply on cash income before taxes. But in a report to be issued on Wednesday, a panel of experts convened by the Academy three years ago at the behest of Congress says the Government should move toward a concept of poverty based on disposable income, the amount left after a family pays taxes and essential expenses. 
 Under the proposal, the Government would count not only a family's cash income, but also noncash Government benefits like food stamps, subsidized housing, school lunches and home energy assistance. Those items would increase family income.
But other recommendations would reduce family income. Specifically, the panel said that taxes, work expenses, child care costs and medical expenses paid by consumers from their own pockets should be deducted from cash income.
If its recommendations are adopted, the panel said, there will be "higher poverty rates for families with one or more workers and for families that lack health insurance coverage, and lower rates for families that receive public assistance."
The 12-member committee, the Panel on Poverty and Family Assistance, was convened in 1992, when Congress was controlled by Democrats. But the forthcoming report seems unlikely to be embraced by the Republicans who now control Congress and who could block changes to which they object.
The recommendations have immense political implications. Voters and politicians use poverty statistics to assess the performance of Presidents and the health of the economy. Eligibility for more than 25 Government programs, including food stamps, Head Start and Medicaid, is linked in some way to the official poverty levels. Poverty is also a factor in the formulas for distributing billions of Federal dollars to state and local governments for education and other purposes.
In its report, the panel tried to estimate the effects of its proposals on the poverty rate for 1992. In the Census Bureau's original report for that year, 14.5 percent of Americans were officially classified as poor, but under the panel's recommendations, this figure would have been at least 15 percent or 16 percent, and under some of the panel's options for measuring poverty, it could have exceeded 18 percent. Each percentage point represents more than 2.5 million people.
The panel also recommends that the official poverty threshold, now $15,141 for a family of four, be adjusted for geographical differences in housing costs. The threshold is now the same for all families of a particular size, even though it is well known that housing costs are greater in New York City, for example, than in rural Mississippi.
In its report, the panel will say, "Our major conclusion is that the current measure needs to be revised: it no longer provides an accurate picture of the differences in the extent of economic poverty among population groups or geographic areas of the country."
The panel was headed by Prof. Robert T. Michael, a former dean of the Graduate School of Public Policy Studies at the University of Chicago. Members of the panel, including economists, sociologists and other social scientists, said they tried to be nonpartisan and apolitical.
It was conservatives who first demanded a full-scale re-examination of the way that poverty is measured. Since the early 1980's, they have asserted that the current definition of poverty overstates the problem because it ignores the value of noncash benefits like food stamps and Medicaid.
But the report contains a stinging dissent from the one conservative Republican on the panel, John F. Cogan, who was deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget under President Ronald Reagan. The panel's major recommendations, he said, "are not based on scientific evidence," but reflect "value judgments made by scientists with a particular point of view."
The panel does not recommend a specific dollar amount for the new poverty level, saying, "Ultimately, that decision is a matter of judgment." But it does suggest "a reasonable range" for the poverty threshold: $13,700 to $15,900 for a family of four in 1992 dollars. The official poverty level in that year was $14,228, and it would probably rise faster in future years under the panel's recommendations than under current policy.
The original poverty level, developed by Mollie Orshansky of the Social Security Administration in the early 1960's, was set at three times the cost of a minimal diet, because the Agriculture Department had found that the average family spent about one-third of its income on food.
But in its report, the Academy said that the poverty level should be set in a different way, to reflect the cost of food, clothing and shelter including utilities, plus a small additional amount to allow for other needs like household supplies and personal care.
Even under the traditional definition of poverty, the number of poor people has been rising. In its latest report, the Census Bureau said that the number of Americans in poverty rose in 1993 for the fourth straight year, to 39.3 million.
The current measure of poverty was developed in the early 1960's and has remained essentially unchanged since then. "From the beginning," the panel said, "the poverty measure had weaknesses, and they have become more apparent and consequential because of far-reaching changes in the U.S. society and economy and in Government policies."
The official poverty levels are adjusted each year for increases in consumer prices, so they "represent the same purchasing power now as they did 30 years ago," the panel said. But, it declared, the poverty thresholds have not kept pace with improvements in the American standard of living. Indeed, it said, simply updating the thresholds for inflation "ignores changes in living standards over time."
The panel said that the official poverty thresholds should be "updated annually to reflect changes in expenditures on food, clothing and shelter over the previous three years." If President Clinton adopted this recommendation, the official poverty levels would probably rise faster than the current thresholds because consumer spending on these basic goods and services is expected to rise more than prices over the long term.
The panel said that its proposed yardstick would more accurately measure poverty and "would improve the targeting of benefits to needy families." But it could also increase the number of people who qualify for assistance and the cost of social welfare programs. So, given fiscal constraints, the Government may need to readjust the standards for determining need and eligibility, the panel said.
In his dissent, Mr. Cogan, an economist at the Hoover Institution of Stanford University, said the panel's recommendations would "fundamentally change the concept of poverty from an absolute standard to a relative standard." As a result, he said, "the poverty line would rise about 8 percent faster per year than under the current method."
The panel finds many defects in the current measure of poverty:
*"Because of the increased labor force participation of mothers, there are more working families who must pay for child care, but the current measure does not distinguish between the needs of families in which the parents do or do not work outside the home."
*"Because of differences in health status and insurance coverage, different population groups face significant variations in medical care costs, but the current measure does not take account of them."
*The current measure of poverty takes no account of tax laws and social welfare programs that profoundly alter the economic well-being of millions of Americans. For example, Social Security payroll taxes have substantially increased over the last 30 years, reducing workers' disposable income, while the food stamp program has expanded, raising disposable income for beneficiaries.
As might be expected, the panel had great difficulty deciding how to treat medical care benefits. Ultimately, it decided that the value of Medicare, Medicaid and health benefits provided by employers should not be counted as income. And the proposed poverty thresholds, based on the need for food, clothing and shelter, do not include an allowance for medical care.
But the panel said that in determining family income, the Government should deduct any amounts that family members actually pay for medical care or health insurance premiums. "Even with insurance," it said, "many people must pay out of pocket to obtain that insurance or to receive care, and such expenses reduce disposable income."
Likewise, the panel said that income should be redefined to exclude child care costs. "The child care deduction should be capped and apply only to families in which there is no adult at home to provide the care," it said.
The panel also said, "The definition of 'family' should be broadened for purposes of poverty measurement to include cohabiting couples" who are not married.

HEADLINE: TERROR IN OKLAHOMA: SECURITY;
Overseas, Oklahoma City Bombing Is Seen Through Prism of Experience

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

 BODY:
While the Oklahoma City bombing has thrown the United States into a clamorous debate over what steps will be needed to control domestic terrorism, many in the Old World have been looking on with an experienced and somewhat paternalistic eye, as if to say, "Welcome to the club."
In many Western European countries, domestic terrorism has been a fact of life for decades, whether from the Red Army Faction in Germany, the Irish Republican Army in Britain, Basque separatists in Spain, the Mafia in Italy, Algerians in France or one of the many other groups seeking violent publicity for their causes and grievances. Cities like Beirut and Belfast have become synonyms for political violence, and many nations, like Israel, have learned to live under constant threat. 
 Rooted in such a background, many comments in the foreign press focused on America's loss of innocence. "Whatever happens, one conclusion is already clear," Le Monde of France said in an editorial. "The United States is no longer impervious to that urban terrorism which their West European allies have known for a long time."
Along with expressions of sympathy came somewhat more testy reminders that the United States could hardly regard itself as less violent than the rest of the world. If Americans have tended to view terrorism as a foreign phenomenon, they noted, much of the rest of the world has often seen the United States as a nation that indulged a passion for guns and an addiction to violence.
Russians commonly blame the proliferation of American movie violence for the spread of crime and street violence, and American incursions into Grenada and Panama prompted many European commentaries on the tenacity of the "cowboy mentality" in American foreign policy.
"The fact is that America is dominated by an excess of violence and that conflicts there are far too often resolved with weapons," Stuttgarter Zeitung in Germany editorialized.
From a Third World perspective, Cairo's Al Akhbar el Yom expressed the hope that Oklahoma City would serve as a lesson in humility for the powerful states: "No longer will the great powers be able to reprimand small countries and complain that their measures to contain terrorism violate human rights."
Indeed, the central question in the aftermath of the Oklahoma blast was how far the world's leading democracy was prepared to curtail civil liberties to combat terrorism. It was a question many other major democracies had already been forced to confront, and many had responded with legislation that nudged up against, or breached, the canons of civil and human rights, usually with the reluctant consent of their populations.
Britain's long struggle with the Irish Republican Army calmed after a cease-fire last Aug. 31, but the legacy is bitter. Since it first sent troops into Northern Ireland to counter the militant nationalists of the I.R.A. in 1969, the British Government has tried a variety of measures, with varying degrees of effectiveness.
It made even membership in the I.R.A. a crime, and Northern Irish courts were authorized to dispense with juries and the usual rules of evidence in the trials of terrorists. For several years in the early 1970's, I.R.A. suspects could be interned indefinitely without trial, and after that provision was lifted, they could still be held up to a week without being formally charged.
Most of the measures were limited to Northern Ireland, but a large bomb explosion in England in 1974 led to the passage of the Prevention of Terrorism Act, which the Government itself described as "Draconian" but necessary. Since then, 35 people have been killed in the 20 most serious attacks, and mainland Britons have learned to live with roadblocks, bomb threats, impromptu searches and barricades.
One of the more curious measures was a law passed in 1988 that allowed I.R.A. spokesmen to be seen on television, but not heard. Thus Gerry Adams would be seen speaking, but his words would be spoken by an actor or written out in subtitles. The law was believed to derive from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's abhorrence for the voices of the nationalists, and with Mrs. Thatcher no longer in office, it was recently dropped.
In West Germany, the rise of the fanatic Red Army Faction in the late 1960's and the attack by Palestinian terrorists at the Munich Olympics in 1972 challenged the resistance to a strong national police force that had originated in the abuses of the Nazi era. In 1973, the elite federal police group known as GSG-9, or Grenzschutzgruppe-9, was set up to respond to airplane hijackings and other acts of terror.
Most German laws draw no distinction between terrorists and other criminals, but a few special measures have been enacted. A law passed in 1976 made membership in a group that had been declared terrorist punishable by up to 10 years in prison, and several Red Army members were imprisoned this way.
The German police have been empowered to tap the phones of suspected terrorists and to open their mail, and prosecutors have the power to reduce the sentences of terrorist suspects who cooperate with investigators. Other measures bar any contact among jailed terrorists and provide for the Government to monitor their meetings with lawyers. Prison wardens are authorized to place convicted terrorists under surveillance and to separate them from visitors with glass partitions.
Like Germany, Japan has been reluctant to give excessive powers to the police, but unlike Germany, it has not been pressured to do so. The only direct consequence so far of the recent poison gas attacks in Japan has been to ban the nerve gas sarin. Otherwise, there is no anti-terrorism law, and laws on surveillance and wiretapping are generally vague.
Battered by Middle Eastern terrorists in the 1980's, France responded with a variety of special measures. One of them recently backfired when Prime Minister Edouard Balladur came under fire for authorizing a wiretap against the relative of a judge investigating the finances of Mr. Balladur's party.
The bombing in Oklahoma City, despite the enormous damage and carnage, did not represent the sort of pervasive threat that much of Europe has faced.
But if in the past the United States was prone to remind the Old World about the primacy of human rights over security, the veterans of terrorism in the Old World seemed to feel it was now their turn to issue some reminders to America.
Writing in Liberation in Paris, the columnist Jacques Amalric raised the hope that Americans "would come to question the virtues ascribed to isolationism, that chronic disease of the United States, which supposedly protects them from the evils of the world."
In London, The Guardian asserted, "Beefing up the F.B.I. is not the real answer to the sickness of American society."
The Schwaebische Zeitung in Germany editorialized, "Controlling enemies must not bring a return to the McCarthy era, when Communists in the United States were hunted like wild animals."
And The Economist of England proclaimed, "The dangers of government acting too strongly may be greater than the dangers of failing to act."

HEADLINE: U.N. Aid Officials Plead for Food Relief

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 29

 BODY:
United Nations officials in charge of funneling relief aid to victims of war and drought are warning of severe food shortages in Central Africa, Bosnia and Herzegovina and other areas because of multiplying crises and cutbacks in donations by wealthy nations.
Relief officials are making emergency pleas for the United States, Japan, the European Union and other donors to contribute additional food to help hundreds of thousands of refugees from wars in Rwanda, Bosnia, Liberia and the Caucasus region who are now receiving a fraction of the normal daily food allotment. 
"Right now we are operating hand to mouth," said Catherine Bertini, executive director of the World Food Program, a United Nations agency responsible for emergency food relief. There are currently 25 crises involving 24.3 million people.
"Our stockpiles are at an all-time low," she said. "We borrow from everywhere we can. If there is a new crisis, it will be very difficult for us to come up with more food. It's all needed so desperately."
In Goma, Zaire, for example, some 700,000 Rwandans in refugee camps have been receiving rations of 1,077 calories a day, half the desired amount. Donor nations have contributed just one-sixth of the 138,000 metric tons of food needed this year to feed about 1.7 million people fleeing wars in Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia and Chechnya.
Last week the World Food Program made an emergency plea to donors, saying it would have to slash rations for 437,000 people in Sarajevo and 300,000 people in other encircled Bosnian enclaves in July unless wealthy nations immediately contributed more money.
"We have never been in such bad shape in the former Yugoslavia, and we are really getting nervous," Ms. Bertini said. "We need firm pledges right now."
Similarly grim observations are being made by officials at the United States Agency for International Development, the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization and private relief groups.
Relief experts fear their efforts to meet emergency needs could fall hopelessly behind this year if either of two feared catastrophes materializes: a flood of refugees from Burundi, whose ethnic tensions parallel Rwanda's, or a prolongation of the drought in southern African countries including Botswana and Malawi.
"We're all worried that drought could produce a very bad harvest in southern Africa this year," said Lionel Rosenblatt, president of Refugees International, a Washington-based relief organization. "We're definitely out of food and money for the next big emergency."
In one sign that the cupboard is nearly bare, the United States has just $25 million left in its $817 million emergency food budget with five months left in the fiscal year.
Governments, aid officials say, usually come up with enough food to prevent famine when a Bosnia or Rwanda leaps onto the evening news and front pages. That was the case a year ago, when Rwanda's ethnic massacres and refugee crisis galvanized the world into action.
But many of the new shortages are arising in areas where crises have dragged on for years, like Bosnia, or in places that have only hovered near catastrophe, like Liberia, where civil strife has disrupted food production since 1989.
In another factor contributing to the worst emergency food situation in more than a decade, 23 donor nations including the United States have reduced aid commitments to 5.35 million metric tons of grain for next year, from 7.5 million metric tons, under an international food treaty.
Under pressure from Congress to cut foreign assistance, the Clinton Administration has proposed cutting American food aid to $1.02 billion next year, less than half the amount allotted in 1993.
Compounding the shortfall are cuts in agricultural subsidies, which have effectively erased vast surpluses that many Western countries used to tap to relieve crises overseas.
Demand, meanwhile, has grown steadily. First came crises in the Sudan and Afghanistan that required outside agencies to feed more than two million people. Angola was added to the list in 1989, and Somalia, Liberia, Sierra Leone and Rwanda the following year.
War broke out in 1991 in the former Yugoslavia, where the World Food Program is now feeding 2.1 million people. Food emergencies have since arisen from assorted wars in the former Soviet Union, from Georgia, Armenia and Azerbaijan to Tajikistan and most recently, Chechnya.
"There are a lot of weary donors around the world," said David Garms, an American representative to the United Nations food organizations.

HEADLINE: District of Columbia Special Election Will Test Influence of Marion Barry

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 29

 BODY:
When Marion S. Barry Jr. was elected Mayor of the District of Columbia last November, vacating a seat on the City Council, he won more than 91 percent of the votes in the ward he represented.
But that level of confidence faces a stern test in a special election on Tuesday when voters in the ward choose a successor to complete Mr. Barry's four-term council term from among 21 candidates. The Mayor is a strong supporter of one of the candidates, Eydie D. Whittington. 
 Throughout his campaign last year, which followed three terms as Mayor, six months in jail on a cocaine charge and election to the council in 1992, Mr. Barry promised better times for the residents of his ward, No. 8.
The ward has the city's highest rates of crime, unemployment and welfare recipients, and it remains the poorest jurisdiction in the city. Stark reminders of people in need abound: the ward has no movie theater or bowling alley and there are 32 liquor stores to 1 supermarket.
Many residents say that since Mayor Barry took office, instead of improvements they have only suffered as a result of the city's current fiscal crisis and the subsequent cuts in services. And with a Federal control board soon to be appointed to oversee the city's finances, many ward residents contend that their quality of life could get worse.
"Very few people even think he did anything as a City Council member to enhance the ward," James Bunn, president of the Ward 8 Democratic Party and one of the council candidates, said of Mr. Barry. "With a control board coming, he has done even less. This has always been the least-served ward in the city and we've already seen cutbacks."
Further, Mr. Barry has recently become embroiled in an investigation over the possible diversion of $2,000 from the Mayor's campaign fund. A former housekeeper said that she was instructed to cash a check to her son from Mr. Barry's wife, Cora Masters Barry, and give the money to Mrs. Barry's son, Walter Masters.
The authorities are also trying to determine whether a contractor working in the house offered the housekeeper a job to change her story. They are also looking into accusations that former members of Mr. Barry's security detail tried to intimidate the housekeeper into changing her story.
If all that reflects badly on the Mayor, it could also hurt Ms. Whittington, a 39-year-old marketing director for a downtown law firm and a neighborhood worker who is making her first run for a position in city government. Mr. Barry has worked tirelessly for her, helping her raise more than $15,000 in campaign contributions, more than any other candidate.
The cost to her, however, is that opponents and many voters view her as the Mayor's pawn, a vote he can count on at a time the council is showing independence. Twice, for example, the council has voted against Mr. Barry's efforts to raise $40 million in property taxes.
At a candidates forum on Thursday night, William Lockridge, a counselor in the public schools and one of the leading contenders, called the Mayor's endorsement "patronage politics" and suggested that any mayoral endorsement of a council candidate "violates the spirit of the electoral process."
Ms. Whittington bristled at the suggestion she would become a rubber-stamp for the Mayor, insisting that they disagree on several issues, and cited as an example the Mayor's belief that the department of education, an independent agency, should be placed under his control. Ms. Whittington says it should remain independent.
Of the Mayor, she said, "I think he sees in me someone who is committed, energetic and persistent in wanting to do something about Ward 8."
When the question of Mr. Barry's support arose at the forum, Ms. Whittington responded sharply: "He walked past 20 candidates to endorse me. I didn't ask for his endorsement. He gave it to me. Please get over it. I have it."
With a light turnout expected and so many people running for the 18-month term -- more than in any other local election since the District won limited home rule from Congress more than 20 years ago -- political analysts are reluctant to predict a winner. Most agree, however, that the leading contenders include three of the 18 Democrats running: Ms. Whittington, Mr. Lockridge, 46, and Sandy Allen, 51, who is active in the community and who served as Mr. Barry's constituents service director in the ward for six years and as his campaign manager in the ward in 1992.
Ms. Allen said she was less upset over Mr. Barry's not endorsing her than his backing for Ms. Whittington. Ms. Allen, a fourth-generation resident of the ward, said that Ms. Whittington, who moved to the ward in 1987, and others are not as familiar with its problems as she is.
If Ms. Whittington is riding Mr. Barry's political coattails, Malik Shabazz, a 28-year-old law student at Howard University and a follower of Minister Louis Farrakhan of the Nation of Islam, is clutching at them. Mr. Shabazz, who won national attention last year for his anti-Semitic remarks in a speech, is running as an independent on a platform of self-sufficiency for blacks. He advocatesa boycott of all stores in the ward owned by Asians. Their presence, he argued at the forum, prevents blacks from establishing an economic foothold.
His campaign literature includes a picture of Mr. Barry, and in response to a question at the forum about his experience, Mr. Shabazz described himself as a "student of the previous legislator, Councilman Marion Barry."
After winning the Democratic primary last September, Mr. Barry began distancing himself from Mr. Shabazz. "There is a young man hanging on to my camp, Malik Shabazz," he said then. "I've been trying to get out of the way for a long time."

HEADLINE: British Watch Trial Of Simpson

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 29

 BODY:
Since it began in January, the O. J. Simpson trial has been beamed here by satellite every night, providing the British with a window into a peculiarly American mix of crime, race and celebrity. But in a country where cameras are not allowed in courtrooms, the most extraordinary thing about the Simpson trial is that it is shown on television at all.
For Tougay Hassan, a grocery clerk in north London, broadcasts of the trial are exotic and compelling. But as much as Mr. Hassan enjoys watching it, he said, he is also distressed by the focus on celebrity, by the chatty analysis and by what he perceives as American overplay. Although Britain has its tabloid excesses, pretrial publicity is forbidden under British law and lawyers and judges are not allowed to discuss cases out of court. And Mr. Hassan said that might not be so bad. 
 "I don't think you can get a fair trial with all this razzmatazz," said Mr. Hassan, who first heard of Mr. Simpson when watching the freeway chase on television in June.
Newspapers here began covering the case when Mr. Simpson was arrested and still regularly publish articles about the trial. The British Sky Broadcasting Group, the Rupert Murdoch-owned satellite system, is providing nightly broadcasts of the trial, both taped and live, on its 24-hour all-news channel for more than four hours, starting at 7 P.M.
The BBC's second channel is broadcasting a weekly, hourlong Sunday program that includes trial highlights, commentary and coverage of the coverage. The program, which is broadcast in the evening, has been drawing audiences of 1.5 million to 2 million, or about an 8 percent share of the audience then.
Why is anyone here interested?
"People get a chance to watch amazing lawyers at work," said Janey Walker, series editor for the BBC program covering the Simpson trial. "They get a chance to see something that they know is a phenomenon in America. And they get a chance to hear extraordinary details about how a group of people in California live their lives."
But for legal experts like Geoffrey Robertson, a high-profile lawyer who regularly watches the BBC program, the value of the coverage lies in its insight into the American court system.
"When I watch it, it makes me want to salute America for televising the courts, because television cuts lawyers down to size," said Mr. Robertson, who argues that the British court system is far too shrouded in secrecy.
"The oversized ego of F. Lee Bailey was reduced by the disastrous cross-examination of Fuhrman," he said, referring to one of the police detectives. "I think that's good because lawyers, and particularly American lawyers, are greedy egomaniacs."
At Sky Broadcasting, Liz Roberts, a spokeswoman, said that its daily coverage of the trial attracts an average audience of 112,000, or double the figure for its news, and that 38 percent of satellite owners have watched part of the trial on Sky.
Gary Solis, an American lawyer who provides commentary for Sky, said he was amazed at viewers' responses, not just across Britain, but also in continental Europe. What strikes foreigners, said Mr. Solis, who teaches criminal law at the London School of Economics, is how open, almost folksy, the American system seems.
"In England you don't have the informal and humorous exchanges between the judge and practitioners, and between the practitioners themselves, and you don't have the lawyers making statements outside the courtroom," he said. "And certainly judges here in their robes and wigs wouldn't drink Diet Coke out of a black coffee mug."
Mr. Solis has become something of a celebrity here, touted by his neighbors and even recognized on the street, where a passer-by once called out, "I really admire your work," as he waited for a taxi. In the end, he said, what interests the British is the same thing that interests Americans.
"I bet I've asked 50 people here why British people are interested at all in an individual that they clearly didn't know about before," he said. "The answer is that there's sex, celebrity, money, fame and violence all in this courtroom. The things that fascinate on the other side of the Atlantic seem to fascinate here as well."

HEADLINE: CLINTON SEEKS WAY TO RETAIN GUN BAN IN SCHOOL ZONES

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 29

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that he was "terribly disappointed" by the Supreme Court ruling this week overturning the Federal ban on gun possession within 1,000 feet of schools. The President ordered Attorney General Janet Reno to recommend ways to get around the decision, perhaps by linking Federal education aid to states' enforcement of such bans.
"This Supreme Court decision could condemn more of our children to going to schools where there are guns," Mr. Clinton said in his weekly radio address, in an unusually pointed Presidential comment on a Court ruling. "And our job is to help our children learn everything they need to get ahead in safety, not to send them to school and put them in harm's way. 
 "I am determined to keep guns out of our schools. That's what the American people want, and it's the right thing to do."
Mr. Clinton made his comments at the end of a week in which he repeatedly pledged to protect the public with new Federal measures to combat terrorism. The remarks represent his latest effort to argue for a Federal role on a contentious issue like gun control by casting himself as a defender of children's health and safety. He has made a similar case in opposing efforts by the Republican Congress to curtail the Federal school lunch program or relax environmental regulations.
"We all know that guns simply don't belong in school, so members of Congress of both parties passed the law," Mr. Clinton said in the speech, which he taped on Friday for broadcast today. "Unfortunately the Supreme Court struck down the specific law. They said the Federal Government couldn't regulate that activity, because it didn't have enough to do with interstate commerce."
"I am directing the Attorney General to come back to me within a week with what action I can take to keep guns away from schools," he added. "I want the action to be constitutional, but I am determined to keep guns away from schools.
"For example, Congress could encourage states to ban guns from school zones by linking Federal funds to enactment of school-zone gun bans. At least we could tie the money we have for safe schools to such a ban."
More than 40 states have laws banning guns in or near schools. So Mr. Clinton's order has more symbolic import than practical effect.
But it was not lost on the White House that the ruling was the first in nearly 60 years in which the Court has overturned a Federal law on the ground that it exceeded the Congressional power over commerce. In 1936, at the height of the New Deal, the High Court struck down minimum-wage and maximum-hour requirements for the coal industry.
In a bitterly divided 5-to-4 ruling on Wednesday the Court held that Congress acted beyond its constitutional authority to regulate interstate commerce five years ago, when it made possession of a gun within 1,000 feet of a school a Federal crime. The ruling, while overturning no precedents, nevertheless cast doubt on Congress's ability to regulate a range of activities it has recently defined as Federal crimes, including carjackings and drive-by shootings.
Both of Mr. Clinton's two appointees to the Court, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Stephen G. Breyer, were in the minority. In his dissent Justice Breyer said the decision "threatens legal uncertainty in an area of law that, until this case, seemed reasonably well settled."
Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, writing for the majority, said the Gun-Free School Zones Act of 1990 was a criminal statute that had nothing to do with "commerce" in the traditional sense. He rejected the Administration's argument that guns and violence in schools hurt the economy by impeding education and making children less productive potential workers.
The opinion left open options like Mr. Clinton's suggestion to tie Federal aid to the adoption of state gun bans. Attaching such strings to Federal money in exchange for state action is a traditional approach in a host of fields like highway aid and education.
In fact, as Mr. Clinton noted today, Congress last year passed a somewhat similar measure, the Gun Free Schools Act. It requires school districts around the country to expel for at least a year any student caught taking a gun to school, and Mr. Clinton authorized the Education Department to withhold Federal aid from districts that do not comply.
Under the law, school districts have until October to adopt "zero-tolerance" policies on gun possession or risk losing aid.
In reserving comment on the Court decision until today, Mr. Clinton assured himself wide coverage in large-circulation Sunday newspapers and broadcasts. But White House aides said he had not made the decision to speak out against the ruling lightly. With relatively rare exceptions, Presidents cut the Supreme Court a wide berth in interpreting the law of the land.
"It comes down to the fact that kids are different," the senior Presidential adviser, George Stephanopoulos, said. "The President believes we are measured by how we treat our children, and it's simply common sense to keep guns out of schools. The importance of signaling a strong stand against violence and the prospect of kids' killing kids with guns -- they shouldn't have outweighed the traditional reluctance to comment."
In his address Mr. Clinton cited statistics on school violence from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to buttress his case. He said the C.D.C. has recorded 105 violent school-related deaths in the last two years. In 1990, Mr. Clinton said, a study found that 1 in 24 students carried guns in a 30-day period, and by 1993 the ratio was 1 in 12.
"The number of high school students carrying a gun doubled in only three years," Mr. Clinton said. "This is certainly a national crisis, and we must have a national effort to fight it. We need a seamless web of safety that keeps guns out of the hands of our children and out of our schools."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Blue Jays Take Aim On Belated Chance For 3d Straight Title

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Eighteen months have passed since the Toronto Blue Jays won their second successive World Series. Because no one won a World Series six months ago, the Blue Jays are the only team this year that can win the Series for a third consecutive time.
"Doing it twice is a remarkable achievement," Gord Ash, the Jays' general manager, said. "Doing it a third time would be even more so." 
 If the Blue Jays were to win this year, their feat would fall short of the three in a row won by the Oakland Athletics in 1972-73-74 and the Yankees in the 50's and 30's. The achievement would not be cheapened, but the streak would be tainted slightly because of the relatively poor season the Jays had last year.
When the strike ended the season prematurely, Toronto was 16 games from first place, had virtually no chance of making the playoffs even as the wild-card team and had a losing record (55-60) for the first time in 12 years. What happened, and what might be different about this season? Ash offered a multipronged view.
"Winning two championships in a row puts not so much a physical but a mental drain on the players," the general manager said. "When you look at the time element alone, starting spring training in the middle of February and going almost to November, it is mentally taxing."
Specifically, Ash pointed to the absence of Duane Ward, the team's closer, who had recorded a league-leading 45 saves the previous season.
"We just weren't ready to start the season," he said. "Our guys were worn out, we were a little tentative in the bullpen, our hitters put too much pressure on themselves to score runs to make up for the deficiency in the bullpen."
Ash recalled an early-season game that he said was critical to undermining the team's confidence. Having scored five runs each in the eighth and ninth innings, the Blue Jays took a 13-6 lead into the California half of the ninth, but the bullpen squandered it as the Angels erupted for seven runs in the ninth, then won with another run in the 10th.
"It's hard to point to one game and say it had that much effect, but it set the tone for a while," Ash said. "We didn't get cranked up until sometime in June."
Seeking a more general reason for the decline of a two-time champion, Ash said: "Maybe it's overplayed and it's hard to prove, but that mental edge wasn't there." But why should it have been there entering the 1993 season and not last year?
"From '92 to '93, we turned over the roster a little," he said. "We had some fresh faces. Paul Molitor was one of them, and he was leading that charge in terms of being hungry to win. That wasn't so much the case from '93 to '94. There were a couple youngsters in there who were new, but it wasn't the same as having veterans like Molitor coming in. They were in a little awe playing for a two-time championship club, taking the place of important people. That had some bearing on what happened."
The Blue Jays have a pair of rookies in this season's lineup, Alex Gonzalez at shortstop and Shawn Green in right field, but the awe should be absent. Further, the pitching rotation has a pair of new veterans, David Cone and Danny Darwin, who Ash said are "hungry to win."
The Blue Jays generally are eager to return to their '92-'93 status. "Not having the kind of season we wanted to have will have an impact," said the general manager, himself a rookie eager to duplicate the performance of his predecessor and mentor, Pat Gillick.
 
Righetti Still Wants a Role
 A year ago in spring training, Dave Righetti was discussing the efforts of some of his fellow aging relievers to hang on as long as they could, moving here and there and wherever else necessary to get a job.
"I don't know if I want to bounce around and do that," he said, sitting in the Oakland Athletics' clubhouse. "I didn't really want to leave the Yankees and go somewhere else. Then I'd rather have finished my career with the Giants. Now I'd like to make this my last stop. But if things don't go well this year, you won't see me anymore. I'm almost sure of that."
Righetti, now 36 years old, hasn't been seen prominently this year, but he's still around.
The Athletics released him last April 27. Eighteen days later, he joined the Blue Jays' organization and split the rest of the season between Knoxville and Toronto. The Blue Jays released him after the season. This year, the left-hander went to spring training with the Chicago White Sox, but he didn't win a major league job. Now he has bounced to the minors again, Nashville this time. The next bounce, he hopes, will land him in Chicago.
 
New Dodger Discoveries
 Watching the Los Angeles Dodgers shed Orel Hershiser, Brett Butler, Kevin Gross, Jim Gott, Roger McDowell and Cory Snyder, one might be tempted to conclude that they were playing the payroll game. Tommy Lasorda, beginning his 19th year as the Dodgers' manager, was asked if the roster moves were economic or strategic.
"I would have to say it's practically all strategic," he said, "because if there's a player we felt we needed, we would get him, so it's not strictly economic. But we feel we wanted to give the young players the chance to play, like we did two years ago with Mike Piazza. We wanted to give him the opportunity so we let Mike Scioscia go. The same with Eric Karros. We let Kal Daniels go. The same thing with Raul Mondesi last year. All three of those guys were the National League rookie of the year."
The Dodgers, Lasorda said, like outfielders Billy Ashley and Todd Hollandsworth and pitchers Hideo Nomo and Pedro Osuna. "If we didn't have these guys, we would've signed those other guys," he added. "We have good young talent, and talent used develops. Talent not used wastes away."
 
Reinsdorf Responds
 No one ever accused Jerry Reinsdorf of being acutely sensitive to criticism, but he draws the line when he is cited for decisions his baseball people make.
It was suggested here recently that Reinsdorf, the behind-the-scenes leader of the hard-line owners in the labor dispute, cares more about winning off the field than on it. Exhibit A was the failure of the Chicago White Sox to sign Mickey Tettleton as a free agent, opting instead to make Chris Sabo their designated hitter.
That decision, Reinsdorf said, was made by General Manager Ron Schueler and his aides, a fact Schueler confirmed.
"We just did not want any strikeouts in the No. 4 hole," Schueler said. "Last year, we tried to get away from it with Franco. We found we were better off putting the ball in play. We're not concerned with the power."
In the past six seasons, Tettleton has hit 153 home runs to 101 for Sabo but has struck out twice as often, 782 times in 2,742 at-bats (once every 3.5) to 367 in 2,607 for Sabo (once every 7.1). Strikeouts notwithstanding, Tettleton, in that period, has driven in 449 runs to Sabo's 355.
 
Belcher Bides Time
 Assessing his plight as a free agent during spring training, Tim Belcher said he made the mistake of having a bad season for a bad team. His 15 losses for the last-place Detroit Tigers led the American League, and his 5.89 earned run average was the highest for any pitcher with 131 innings or more.
He remains jobless, working out with a former team, the Los Angeles Dodgers, in their extended spring training program at Port St. Lucie, Fla.
"He had a number of offers, but the offers basically were low in the economic track and with teams he didn't want to pursue," Scott Boras, Belcher's agent, reported. "So he basically has taken the tack that he's going to get in shape, have a normal spring training, and when clubs start looking for starters, his market will be better than it has been."
 
Total Payroll Holds Steady
 With about three dozen free agents accepting pay cuts that exceeded last year's average salary of nearly $1.2 million and others signing for tiny salaries as well, it seemed very likely that the total major league payroll would plummet this season. Preliminary indications, however, are that it should be about the same as a year ago.
After eight players who had filed for salary arbitration signed Friday, the total payroll was about $810 million. The 39 players left on the arbitration list are seeking about $100 million in salary; their clubs have offered about $75 million.
Most of those cases will settle close to the midpoint of the players' and clubs' figures. Of those that reach hearings, players will win some, clubs will win more. Add about $85 million for all of those players to the current total, and the payroll reaches $895 million.
One more step is needed to compare the payroll with last year's figure. Because of the abbreviated spring training, clubs have 28 players on the rosters. If the extra players are basically young players at or close to the minimum salary, their total of about $9 million could be subtracted from the estimated payroll, leaving $886 million.
That is virtually the same total that opening-day payrolls came to last season.

HEADLINE: Waterways Give Up Grim Telltale Signs of Spring

BYLINE: By JENNIFER KINGSON BLOOM 

 BODY:
To those who patrol the waterways in this city of rivers, bridges and mobsters, the arrival of spring foretells a phenomenon that is as unpleasant as it is inevitable: floating bodies.
Bodies appear in the waterways year round, but harbor officials estimate that as many as half of those recovered annually are found in April and May. At this time of year, the water warms to 38 degrees Fahrenheit and higher, and gases are produced inside a submerged body, causing it to float to the surface. 
 While the United States Coast Guard and the city's Fire Department vessels often find the bodies first, only the Police Department's Harbor Unit is authorized to retrieve them. The task may sound macabre. But harbor veterans whose jobs include spotting and retrieving bodies view the duty with nonchalance.
"The first time you get a little bit queasy, but after a while if you pretend it's actually not a person, it's a lot easier," said Jason Cirillo, who has been a Coast Guard seaman for four years. "If you look at it as just like a sack of potatoes -- oh, I know, it sounds morbid."
The procedure has spun off its own lore. Officers sometimes swap stories while waiting for detectives to come to investigate a possible homicide and the Medical Examiner's office to take the body to the morgue. "The person with the least seniority has to search the body for any identifying effects," said Sgt. Jim Cowan, a Harbor Unit diver.
Capt. Vincent Abbene, commander of the Harbor Unit, said most of the recovered bodies were suicides, and their numbers fluctuated with the economy. "I guess things weren't so great for New Yorkers in the early 80's, so there were a lot of suicides," he said. "In the late 80's, things got better."
Winter is the season with the most suicides. Because many people jump from bridges at night, often nobody sees them and their bodies are not recovered until much later. Cold temperatures also cause the water to function as a refrigerator, preserving a body under ice.
"If somebody jumps in the water in the summer, they'll be up the next day, but if somebody jumps in November, they won't come up until the spring," Sergeant Cowan said. "The deeper the water, the longer they take to come up."
Spring rains and melting snow also churn up the water and bring bodies to the surface. "The faster current may help to dislodge bodies that are trapped in debris on the bottom of the river," said Dr. Charles S. Hirsch, the city's Chief Medical Examiner. The Harbor Unit has recovered 11 bodies so far this year, compared with 38 in 1994. The numbers have declined steadily since 1984, when 92 bodies were retrieved.
While many of the bodies are, in the waterfront jargon, "jumpers," or people who have committed suicide by jumping off a bridge, others are homeless people who have accidentally fallen in the water unnoticed. But the most memorable are the victims of gangland slayings.
Sgt. John Cummings, a 12-year veteran of the Harbor Unit who does about 1,500 dives a year, said he has helped retrieve bodies the police later identified as mob informers. Divers have recovered people out of the water who have had cement blocks tied to them, he said. "Once all those gases build up, the body can lift all kinds of weight."
Last week, the diving unit searched the Harlem River for a body that a mob informer told the police had been disposed of there two years ago, anchored by 40 pounds of weights and chains. "They think if you put it in the water, it will disappear," Captain Abbene said.
Some bodies turn out to be victims of high-profile crimes. "Joel Rifkin put them in 55-gallon drums," said Sergeant Cummings, referring to the Long Island man who has confessed to killing 17 women and dumping their bodies around the New York region. "We recovered two of them by Coney Island."
The recovery work does have its poignant side. If someone is reported dead but no body is found, surviving family members may have difficulty collecting insurance claims or pensions. Finding a lost loved one also adds that sense of closure.
"If you think about some family missing this person, it fills a void for them," Sergeant Cummings said. "In that way, you kind of feel it's a little something you're doing to try to help the family out."

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

TAKEOVERS
The Day Chrysler Fever Broke
Two weeks ago, Chrysler's stock soared -- simply because one man, Kirk Kerkorian, said he wanted to buy the company. Since then, the stock has done a tentative dance, with doubts creeping in about the deal but investors, remembering the power of Mr. Kerkorian's 10 percent stake, not quite ready to bail out. But last week the company lashed out at its uninvited suitor, saying it had no interest in "gambling with Chrysler's future" and brushing off Mr. Kerkorian's request for a tripling of the dividend (which would add over $100 million to Mr. Kerkorian's annual income). For investors, that seemed to settle it, as the stock fell $2.50 on Wednesday, close to its pre-hysteria level, before creeping up again by week's end.
 
THE ECONOMY
Slowing to a Steady Walk
Surprise! Interest rates went up -- thanks to the Federal Reserve -- and people stopped buying so much stuff. At the end of last year, Americans were still spending big, and the economy grew at a fast 5.1 percent pace -- just the type of too-frantic growth the Fed wanted to head off. But in this year's first quarter, reality set in, wallets closed -- well, part way -- and economic growth slowed to a 2.8 percent rate, the laziest in two years. Keeping things going were corporations that made big investments in equipment and buildings. All this was apparently fine with the stock market, as the Dow industrials kept bumping along to new records.
 
MUTUAL FUNDS
Follow the Money Trail
Mutual funds are where the nation's money is, so their vital signs provide good indicators of what, in an economic sense, is going on. If, that is, you can make sense of those vital signs. Last week came word that cash levels in stock funds were down to 7 percent -- the lowest in well over a decade. What's cash for? Basically, redemptions and safety. But with money flowing in and stocks rising, fund managers seem worried about neither. Fund cash is often what powers the market, though, so is this thin wallet worrisome? Not as long as new cash keeps coming -- which it certainly did recently, going into retirement accounts before the dreaded April 17.
 
THE WORKPLACE
Those Vanishing Benefits
Most employees already know this, of course: companies are getting stingier with benefits. Workers are paying a bigger share of health coverage or being nudged into H.M.O.'s, and must take greater responsibility for retirement through 401(k)'s and the like. But now it's official. A report last week showed that benefit costs for the first quarter showed the smallest rise in eight years. For the past year, in fact, benefit costs rose no faster than overall compensation -- again, for the first time in eight years. The overall report "confirms that there's no inflation push from wages," said Labor Secretary Reich. It also confirms that the days of the all-giving, kindly-uncle employer are vanishing fast.
 
ANTITRUST
One Microsoft, Indivisible
Soon, no doubt, there'll be a Government agency called the Microsoft Department, or at least a Microsoft Division at the Justice Department. The giant company seems a perennial Washington topic. Just last week Justice officials were defending Microsoft one minute against being called monopolistic and then going to court to block its acquisition of Intuit, maker of Quicken personal-finance software, saying this dominance could lead to higher prices and fewer choices for consumers. No inconsistency, the agency said -- different legal issues. And there's no truth, by the way, to rumors that Microsoft is planning to acquire the Justice Department. Just the mint.
 
BANKING
A Human Teller? Naw!
In the old days, we'll tell our grandchildren (by e-mail, of course), you actually saw people at bank windows, talked to human beings on the phone, not multiple-choice recordings. They'll smile an indulgent smile, then log on to their sixth-grade math class. It's true, though. Until late April of '95, you could walk into any bank and hand a teller a deposit. But then First Chicago said you had to pay $3 for that honor (unless you had $2,500 stagnating in a checking account) if you could have used an A.T.M. instead. A teller transaction, you see, costs 6 to 12 times what an A.T.M. transaction does, and they had to watch all those pennies. Even though, in yet older days, the world somehow muddled through with -- brace yourselves -- no A.T.M.'s at all.
 
ORANGE COUNTY
Mr. Citron Takes His Lumps
"The dog ate my homework" may work for a young scholar, but for grown-ups, "the broker ate my lunch" goes only so far. When you're managing a $7.4 billion government fund, as Robert Citron was in Orange County, you're ultimately responsible. For a while, Mr. Citron insisted he was just a blushing victim when the county lost $1.7 billion, blaming Merrill Lynch for leading him astray, but last week that excuse crumbled when he pleaded guilty to felonies like misappropriating funds and misleading investors. He could get up to 14 years in prison. In other words, derivatives don't make money vanish; people do.
 
INNER CITY
Bodegas vs. Pathmark
You can't win. In some people's view, the inner city perpetuates poverty partly because a lack of fair-priced supermarkets forces residents to shop at high-priced bodegas. But when a plan emerged for a Pathmark in East Harlem, opponents cried out that the store would hurt bodega owners. The plan seemed doomed right up to the last minute, but then a City Councilman switched sides and the Manhattan Borough Board approved it, the lure of low prices and added jobs apparently winning the day.
 
TECHNOLOGY
High-Tech Coffee Break
Sometimes we seem to be rushing headlong into a world with all the high-tech stuff jumbled together -- television shows coming out of phones, phone calls coming out of computers, information coming from just about anywhere. But occasionally the world pauses on this mad dash, as when Bell Atlantic decided last week to rethink its idea of offering video services to three million phone customers. Even though the company was well along in the F.C.C. approval process, it said its executives needed to "to catch our breath." So does this point, as some suggested, to mounting confusion in this whole pile-up of technologies? Or does Bell Atlantic just want, as it says, to hold out for better fiber-optic technology? Stay, uh, tuned.
 
AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
And the Sons Did Homework
Thursday was Take Our Daughters to Work Day, a jubilant little affirmative-action idea cooked up a few years ago by the Ms. Foundation. Nationwide, perhaps six million girls played hooky to get a glimpse of the way the adult world works -- or at least the way it works with six million rosy little souls playing hopscotch in the staid hallways of commerce. But "affirmative action" is a dirty word these days -- O.K., two words -- so the glee is now tempered with dissension. Why were boys left out? They get precious little chance to watch Dad -- and Mom -- work. Not to mention that if they saw women doing all sorts of jobs, a lesson might sink in. Then again, why shouldn't girls hog the spotlight for a day? Then again . . . oh, who knows.

HEADLINE: U.N. Should Think Again on Afghanistan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 While Barnett R. Rubin's "Salvaging Afghanistan" (Op-Ed, April 22) strongly endorses the United Nations peace mission to Afghanistan, it fails to take some important political, historical and social realities into consideration. 
 Mr. Rubin's faith in the United Nations ability to restore order through establishment of a ruling coalition backed by a new security force is admirable. However, this lofty goal will not materialize unless the year-old United Nations initiative is revamped or given a new mandate by the Secretary General.
 Afghanistan's problems cannot simply be attributed to ethnic strife, which is more of an effect than a cause today.
 Afghanistan's political disintegration and power vacuum began with the Communist takeover in 1978 and was worsened by a decade of brutal Soviet military occupation that caused innumerable deaths and destroyed the social and economic fabric of the country.
 A generation of children was raised in the midst of war. Billions of dollars' worth of weaponry was supplied by several countries, including the United States, to fight the cold war on the Afghan battlefield.
 Pakistan was the main conduit for arms and aid distribution to the Afghans and favored some extremist groups over other, more moderate ones. Because of regional rivalries, Iran and Saudi Arabia followed suit. When the Afghan Communist regime fell in 1992, a bloody power struggle, instigated by the extremist factions and fueled by foreign sources, followed.
 The sudden emergence of the Taliban movement of Islamic students last October is just the latest manifestation of the same pattern of a foreign-inspired power struggle in Afghanistan. It is the dangerous perpetuation of such actions that may flare up ethnic resentments.
 Any future United Nations initiative would first have to tackle this matter by securing guarantees of noninterference in Afghan affairs. Only then would it be easier for the United Nations to work with the main Afghan powers to accept a realistic, proportional power-sharing formula, and incorporate parts of their forces into a national defense apparatus.
 Thus, Mr. Rubin's assertion that the present powers should dismantle their armies and accept a new "peacekeeping body" is illusionary.
 The United Nations mission's credibility and effectiveness would be best served if the monies that Mr. Rubin would like to have appropriated for the creation of yet another armed force were used to pay for pressing humanitarian and reconstruction needs instead.
 The United Nations does have a role to play in securing peace in Afghanistan. However, after several setbacks, lessons should be drawn. It is time to revise the peace process or start a new one.
 
OMAR SAMAD
Arlington, Va., April 27, 1995
The writer is an Afghan journalist.

HEADLINE: Mickey Mouse Practices Old-Time Capitalism

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re Peter Passell's April 27 Economic Scene, "Disneyland and the old U.S.S.R.: Sharing Something in Common": Mr. Passell asks, "Why doesn't Disney charge for individual rides according to their popularity, thereby reducing the waste inherent in queuing?" 
 It is unlikely that Mickey Mouse is practicing socialism, but rather that Disney is maximizing profits by "bundling." McDonald's bundles a Big Mac, Coke and french fries into a "value meal," which it sells at a discount relative to the total cost of those items purchased separately.
 It does this in hopes of enticing people to buy more than they would if they had to pay full price for every item. McDonald's increases its sales this way, even though it receives slightly less profit on each item sold. So too Disney.
 To get into the Magic Kingdom, a family of four must pay $166. If Disney charged a premium for desirable rides, it would lose many visitors. But if it compensated by lowering its lump-sum entry fee, it would lose a lot of easy money.
 
JAMES LAVIN
Palo Alto, Calif., April 27, 1995
The writer is a graduate student in economics at Stanford University.
