HEADLINE: ON CAMPUS;
Army of Adjuncts Seeks to Organize on State College Campuses

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
They call themselves "gypsy scholars," scurrying from campus to campus, often in a single day. Deprived of office space, they grade papers in parking lots and hold office hours in noisy snack bars. Although many carry full college teaching loads, they seldom earn more than $12,000 a year.
And now these instructors -- adjuncts, or part-time faculty members, at New Jersey's state colleges -- say they are fed up. 
 This spring, an effort was begun to unionize more than 4,000 adjuncts at eight state colleges. The process could prove difficult: because adjuncts have hectic schedules, organizing such a disparate group is itself a challenge. Some fear that fighting for a union will jeopardize their careers, or that college officials could delay the effort with litigation.
But many adjuncts say it is crucial to lobby for higher pay, health benefits, job security and improved working conditions. They also say their drive for recognition is long overdue.
Nationally, the ranks of adjuncts have swelled in recent years as colleges have struggled with tighter budgets. In New Jersey, part-time instructors now make up one-third of the faculty members at public four-year colleges, and more at community colleges.
"As budgets have been cut, there has been a dramatic increase in the use of adjuncts because they are the cheapest option," said Donald Silverman, president of the Council of New Jersey State College Locals, which is leading the unionization effort. The council, which voted in February to help organize adjuncts, already represents full-time faculty members at the eight campuses.
So far, reaction from college administrations has been muted. Since the state's collective bargaining law allows for the unionization of public employees, they cannot prevent the effort. But as the need to cut costs becomes more pressing, the prospect of paying adjunct professors higher salaries can only be unsettling.
"Since there are no laws against what they're doing, we really have no response," said Dr. Larry Carter, vice president for academic affairs at Jersey City State College, one of the eight campuses involved. "I have a lot of sympathy for people with terminal degrees who can't find full-time jobs, but their situation is a reflection of our economy."
At New Jersey's state colleges, most adjuncts do not receive health benefits, pensions or tenure, Dr. Silverman said. They have no job security from one semester to the next, and can be bumped from teaching schedules at the last minute if courses don't fill up. Adjuncts are paid about $450 per credit hour, Dr. Silverman said, and most classes carry three credit hours. If they teach the maximum two courses at one campus, they could earn $2,700. Some earn three times that amount in a semester, but that involves a staggering load of 18 credits.
For full-time instructors at state colleges, the beginning salary is $27,755, Dr. Silverman said. Tenured professors can make as much as $74,775.
"The salary is just laughable," said Cherie Kipple, an adjunct professor who teaches composition at Jersey City State. "A lot of us have master's degrees and doctorates, but we have to run our legs off to survive."
Since February, the council has been compiling lists of adjuncts at the eight colleges. They include Jersey City State, Kean College in Union, Montclair State University, William Paterson College in Wayne. Ramapo College in Mahwah, Rowan College in Glassboro, Richard Stockton College in Pomona and Trenton State College.
"I have never encountered a campaign with more positive support," said Mel Driban, a representative of the American Federation of Teachers who is supervising the effort. "It's very unusual to have not only the adjuncts, but the full-time faculty recognizing that it's time to end this abuse."
Although many adjuncts have credentials equal to or better than those of full-time faculty members, there can be drawbacks. Ralph Edelbach, an associate professor of technology who is supervising the union effort at Trenton State College, says full-time faculty members have more time to spend with students.
"There are situations where adjuncts can bring unique skills into the classroom," he said. "But there's no doubt that for basic classes, full-timers are the best option."
Mr. Driban said that if there are no obstacles, the state Public Employee Relations Commission could hold an election for a bargaining agent as early as December. But in the past, administrations at other New Jersey colleges have fought the unionization of adjuncts. At Raritan Valley Community College in Branchburg, litigation delayed a unionization effort for six years. And at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, part-time faculty members spent three years establishing a chapter of the American Association of University Professors. It took them another three years to negotiate a contract.
The potential challenges do not faze people like Ruben Diaz, an adjunct professor of mathematics who teaches at Jersey City State and two other colleges. He works six days a week, often from 7 A.M. to 10 P.M., then spends another two hours grading papers. Constantly on the road, he rarely sees his wife and two children.
"My life is never easy, and I am tired of running," he said. "If this will bring some change, I will help work for it."
But even at Rutgers, where the average part-time salary was raised to $650 per credit hour after unionization, there have been few other improvements, said Karen Thompson, vice president of the part-time faculty union.
"There has been a certain lessening of abuse, but it's still overwhelmingly true that part-timers are the invisible faculty," she said. "To stick with this life, you must be driven by an incredible love of teaching."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 7, 1995, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last week about attempts to unionize part-time college instructors misstated the pay scale at Rutgers University; $650 per credit is the minimum salary, not the average salary. The article also misidentified the president of the New Jersey Council of State College Locals. He is Donald Silberman, not Silverman.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LONG ISLAND CITY;
Will It Be Kmart Sono Buoni?

BYLINE: By THOMAS H. MATTHEWS 

 BODY:
The Kmart Corporation has been granted a permit to renovate the old Ronzoni factory, bringing the retail giant one step closer to building a megastore on a strip of Northern Boulevard that is fast attracting large retail outlets.
Kmart officials would not discuss details of the plan to take over the pasta plant (remembered for the slogan Ronzoni Sono Buoni; basically "Ronzoni is good"), but a spokeswoman said Kmart will build on the site if it receives approval. 
 Jesse Masyr, a lawyer for Kmart, said the corporation, which is based in Troy, Mich., had received a permit from the City Department of Planning to build retail space of more than 10,000 square feet on property designated for manufacturing use.
If the store is approved by the Borough President's office and Community Boards 1 and 2, Kmart will become the neighbor of large retail outlets including Tops Appliance City, which opened last August, and the Sports Authority, which recently broke ground for a 45,000-square-foot store. The planned Kmart would be about 123,000 square feet.
"This area of Queens is the geographic center of New York," Mr. McCaffrey said. "There is access to over a million people here."
Though Mr. McCaffrey touted the income and employment that large retailers bring, the influx of large stores on Northern Boulevard has raised concerns. Julian Wagner, a member of several business organizations, said that the lack of express subway service and growing traffic volume could overwhelm local roads. "What we're going to see is gridlock all day and all night in that area,' he said. But he added that he does not oppose the megastores.
"We could not, should not and will not stand in the way of economic development," Mr. Wagner said. "To lay down in front of progress would be nonsensical."
 THOMAS H. MATTHEWS

CORRECTION-DATE: May 7, 1995, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about Kmart's plans to renovate the old Ronzoni factory on Northern Boulevard incorrectly described a permit the company has received. Kmart has received certification to begin the city's uniform land-use review process; it has not been given a permit to build.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2988 words

HEADLINE: Noblesse Oblige . . . With Strings

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT and SHELBY WHITE 

 BODY:
MAYBE it is better to give than to receive. But leave it to the very rich to figure out how to do both.
In perhaps no other country are the rich so rewarded for charitable giving as they are in America. Not only does Uncle Sam give them substantial tax breaks for their largess, but many of the 575,000 not-for-profit institutions in this country cultivate them, lionize them and reward them with seats on boards, names on walls and accolades at candlelight fund-raising dinners. 
 Their efforts were not in vain: charitable gifts of more than $1 million totaled nearly $975 million in 1993 up from $931 million in 1992, according to Giving U.S.A., a philanthropy-research organization. Gifts from all donors rose to $126 billion from $122 billion, the group reported.
It isn't that the wealthy are more generous than less well-heeled Americans -- quite the contrary. A philanthropy researcher, Claude Rosenberg, estimates in his book "Wealthy and Wise" that people with income-producing assets of more than $1.3 million give away half of 1 percent of that wealth annually, on average, while those with income-producing assets of between $40,000 and $1.3 million part with between 0.8 percent and 1.5 percent.
It's just that the rich are, well, rich, and can still give big sums. "People put them on boards because they think eventually it will pay off with a big donation," said one leading fund raiser, who requested anonymity.
Good luck. Interviews with some of the mega-billionaires who top the Forbes magazine list of America's richest people, and an analysis of the activities of their charitable foundations, indicate that they generally take the same approach to doling out their money as they did in amassing it: they drive tough bargains.
That should come as no surprise, especially in the wake of the scandal involving misappropriated funds at United Way, America's biggest charity.
"Entrepreneurs as donors often drive bargains. That is how they lead their lives, and they want to make sure that charities do not misuse their funds," said Willian D. Zabel, author of "The Rich Die Richer and You can Too." Mr. Zabel is a trust and estates lawyer at Shulte Roth & Zabel.
Laurence A. Tisch, chairman of CBS and Loews Corporation who frequently plays an active role on charitable boards said: "We want to make sure that what we do has the positive impact that we are desiging the gift for. We want to be sure that we have confidence in the people running the institution."
While the public generally sees the splashy big-dollar headlines, it rarely catches a glimpse of the months of complex and intensive negotiations over such issues as deferred payments, the value of noncash gifts and conditions like matching gifts.
Just ask the Guggenheim Museum. It received a $10 million pledge from Ronald O. Perelman, chairman of Revlon, in early 1994. Mr. Perelman was subsequently named chairman of the Guggenheim, but so far, the museum has received no cash from him toward that gift. Instead, he has given the museum a brownstone on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, which it has yet to sell. And, the sale is complicated because the land beneath the building is owned by someone else. The museum knew the terms from the outset but a museum spokeswoman declined to comment on them.
Earlier, the Guggenheim got another $10 million pledge, the largest ever at the time, from the builder Samuel J. LeFrak, who agreed to make the gift in 1993 "with no strings attached."
But when the New York City Landmarks Commission declined to approve the LeFrak name on the exterior rotunda at Fifth Avenue and 89th Street, Mr. LeFrak apparently had second thoughts. He and the Guggenheim began looking for other "naming opportunities," as Mr. LeFrak's spokesman put it a year later.
To mollify Mr. LeFrak, the Guggenheim managed to get his name on the fifth floor gallery. "Wealthy people are paying more attention to making certain that their contributions work the way they want them to," said Russ Prince of Prince & Associates, a fund-raising consultant.
And with good reason. The late investment banker Andre Meyer donated $2.5 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. After his death the 19th century painting galleries were named after him. His heirs are disappointed that today only one gallery bears his name. A museum spokesman said Mr. Meyer had given the money to construct the galleries, not to name them.
Donors have always wanted their names emblazoned on the walls of prominent institutions. Those who do give often want the world to know. Fund raisers estimate that less than 5 percent of giving is anonymous.
Then there are the gifts, announced by the recipient and the charities with great fanfare, whose actual amounts can vary. In 1992, the Central Park Conservancy in New York announced a $17 million gift over five years from Richard Gilder, a partner at Gilder Gagnon Howe & Company, an investment firm.
The contribution, however, was a matching gift, with no minimum payment required. Thus, Mr. Gilder will pay the entire $17 million only if the conservancy and the city come up with a total of $34 million. The city has pledged its share, and the conservancy is trying to raise its part. Mr. Gilder has so far contributed $3.5 million.
Some of the delay reflects the well-intended desire to influence how the recipients use the money. Laurence Tisch and his brother, Preston, are paying out a $30 million pledge to New York University Medical Center over 15 years. The delayed payments not only make the gift more affordable because of inflation but also assure that the brothers will have a continuing say in the institution's affairs.
Nonetheless, a lot of the rich are procrastinators when it comes to philanthropy. They fully intend to spread their wealth around -- someday. Bill Gates, the Microsoft chairman and the richest man in America with an $11.2 billion fortune, is aiming to do some serious giving when he is 50 or 60 years old. He is now 39. The investor Warren E. Buffett, No. 2 on the Forbes list of the super rich is holding onto the vast bulk of his fortune until he dies.
And others just hate to say it all in cash. "There are other ways to give," said Sumner M. Redstone, chairman of Viacom Inc., whose stake in the company is valued at $4 billion. "Not to denigrate money, but I feel best about the teaching I have done" at Harvard Law School.
According to Paul G. Schervish, associate professor of sociology at Boston College, some entrepreneurs "see their making of money and the expansion of their business as a contribution to society."
Still other rich people give their money away, then take it back. Last month, Lee Bass, the billionaire from Fort Worth, got a $20 million gift back, plus interest, from Yale University after the school had failed to create a Western civilization curriculum to his liking -- and refused to give him veto power over the professors who would be carrying out his mission.
And in rare cases, the recipients have had to go to court to collect. According to the Chronicle of Philanthropy, Joel Jablonski, a real estate executive, thrilled Yeshiva University in New York in 1990 when he promised the school 55 percent of his estate -- valued at $6 million at the time. After the Washington Heights campus was renamed after him, he gave away assets to relatives, arguing that the size of his estate was not his problem. The university sued him for breach of contract in 1993, and the case was settled privately.
Likewise, the financier Saul P. Steinberg irked Lawrence Woodmere Academy in Woodmere, L.I., his children's prep school, in the mid-1970's, when he failed to pay more than half a $375,000 pledge. His reason: Israel was in such "severe and dire straits," he wrote, that he felt compelled to reorder priorities. A court found his "formal, printed pledge" binding and ordered him to pay up, and he appears to have learned a lesson. He has since donated $36 million to his alma mater, the University of Pennsylvania, where two buildings bear his name. And he is a highly regarded board member of several prestigious nonprofits including the New York Public Library.
So just how are some of the richest people in the United States, as identified by Forbes magazine, giving away their money these days?
 
 
Bill Gates
The Tribulations Of a Future Donor
 Bill Gates, the co-founder of Microsoft, has already had an overwhelming impact on the software industry. Now he wants to exert the same influence on the charity scene.
There is only one problem. Most of Mr. Gates's $11.2 billion fortune is in Microsoft stock and putting that into a foundation would tie his hands. "There are incredible limitations," he said in a telephone interview. "A foundation can't vote stock."
His biggest gift to date was a $12 million grant to the University of Washington in his home state to finance a new molecular biotechnology department. He has given another $10 million to other causes.
"I have made a decision that most of my money will go to charitable causes," he said. "It will be later in life, after I'm 50 or 60."
To charities instead of his heirs? "My relatives will not be running this company," Mr. Gates said firmly. "This is not a family company. Microsoft is not a dynasty."
Not yet, anyway. Mr. Gates married Melinda French on New Year's Day 1994. There may someday be children yanking at his financial heartstrings. One longtime fund-raiser says it is likely that Mr. Gates will change his tune.
 
Warren E. Buffett
Billions of Dollars, Billions Of People
 Warren E. Buffett, founder of Berkshire Hathaway, a company with a storied investment record, gets a lot of credit for Berkshire Hathaway's policy of letting shareholders direct a specified number of corporate dollars for each share they own to their favorite charities. His favorite charity, however, is his own foundation.
The Buffett Foundation, which reported assets totaling $21.4 million in its latest fiscal-year tax returns, has given away $14.1 million in the last five years, mostly to population-control groups but also to high schools in his native Omaha. Virtually all of that money originated with the company.
And the philanthropic world will have to sit tight before it gets its hands on the really big money. Mr. Buffett has publicly voiced his concerns about population growth and plans to put the bulk of his $10.3 billion on the line, presumably to slow the increase in the number of the world's inhabitants.
But Mr. Buffett approaches charity as he does investing: long term. He's willing to wait. And so the world will have to wait, too, until he and his wife are gone. Mr. Buffett declined to be interviewed, but associates say he plans to hold onto most of his 40.3 percent stake in Berkshire Hathaway as long as he and his wife are alive.
 
John Kluge
Shunning 'Designer Giving'
 John Kluge, the 80-year-old media mogul with a $5.9 billion fortune, is not as rich as Mr. Buffett, but he has pledged $110 million to recruit professors and give financial assistance to students at Columbia University. And his goal is to create a $1 billion charitable foundation in his will. He has made some big gifts to blue-chip institutions like Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital in New York, the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation and the Library of Congress.
Mr. Kluge, who acknowledges being sympathetic to communist causes as a young man, also donated money after the collapse of the Soviet Union to fund an exhibition of Russian archives at the Library of Congress. "I found out Lenin wasn't a nice guy," he said in an interview at his New York office.
But over all, he explains, he eschews "designer giving" to socially acceptable charities. Nor does he want his name on a building. "In 100 years, the building is dusty," he said. "Nobody cleans the nameplate."
One example of that contrarianism is the money he has showered on minorities. Born in Germany, Mr. Kluge and his widowed mother emigrated to the United States in 1922 when he was 8. He later won a scholarship to Columbia and says he wants to give minority youths the same chance. That determination has led to a $700,000 donation to the Institute for Education in Transformation at Claremont University in California, to study how children of different cultures interact in the classroom.
 
Sumner M. Redstone
Teaching and MTV As Philanthropy
 Sumner M. Redstone is ill at ease as an billionaire. He avoids limousines and fancy houses and buys off-the-rack suits. Similarly, the contributions that excite him the most are low-budget: He volunteers his time as a teacher of law at Harvard and Boston University.
"When I teach, I feel good. For me teaching is a kind of philanthropy," he said. "These students could have the best professors, but someone like myself brings a unique experience."
Mr. Redstone, 71, whose controlling stake in Viacom Inc. is worth $4 billion, also believes that using his influence as an arbiter of popular culture can do at least as much good as signing checks. Viacom's MTV television music channel, he says, has been involved in fighting racism and intolerance, been active in fighting AIDS and gotten "lots of young kids to vote."
"To use what you do instead of money is phony," he says. "But there are a lot of ways to give money away."
And Mr. Redstone's way? His two personal foundations have given $1.7 million in the last five years. Though the company would not provide documentation, a Viacom spokesman said Mr. Redstone should also be given credit for about $33 million in gifts that the entrepreneur has made personally and through companies he controls the last five years.
Among the recipients: the Dana Farber Cancer Center, the United Jewish Appeal and a chair at Harvard Medical School. Another gift went to the Massachusetts General Hospital burn center. Mr. Redstone nearly died in a hotel fire in Boston in 1979, and had to undergo more than 60 hours of surgery. A lawyer who is not shy to litigate, he sued the hotel for $12 million, settled and gave the proceeds to Massachusetts General. The burn center was subsequently renamed after him.
 
Ronald O. Perelman
What's in A Name? Sometimes Dollars
 Ronald O. Perelman, the 51-year-old Revlon chairman, reaped his wealth by building a patchwork of businesses ranging from television stations to lip gloss. His charity is equally diversified. "My giving is entrepreneurial and not systematized," Mr. Perelman said in an interview.
Since 1988, he says he has pledged $125 million of his $4.5 billion fortune and has donated $77 million so far.
His gifts have one thing in common, though: he likes to attach his, or his company's, name to them. For example, he has pledged $12 million to the Revlon Breast Cancer Center in Los Angeles, and agreed to give $10 million to build a student center bearing his name on the University of Pennsylvania campus.
In yet another transaction, Mr. Perelman offered New York University's medical school $10 million to construct a building. The cost of the building escalated, and when Mr. Perelman didn't up the ante, another donor's name went on the building instead. Mr. Perelman got the consolation prize: his money went for research in biomolecular medicine, and the university named its department of dermatology after him.
Sometimes, his contributions to charities are rather convoluted. Of his announced $10 million gift to the Guggenheim, the only asset that has actually changed hands is a brownstone. The building, in the East 50's of Manhattan, has yet to be sold, and the land under it is leased. The museum and the holder of the lease have jointly put the building up for sale for $11 million.
If and when the sale goes through, the Guggenheim would get a unspecified portion of the proceeds. Mr. Perelman and the Guggenheim signed a confidentiality agreement not to reveal the specifics of the deal.
"Most boards prefer cash or stock," said one New Yorker who serves on four boards. "Generally they don't want the burden and uncertainty of selling a nonliquid asset."
 
S. I. Newhouse Jr.
The Money Follows The Company
 While Mr. Perelman appreciates the clout that comes with blockbuster gifts, S. I. Newhouse Jr. and his brother, Donald, who own a $9 billion media empire, prefer to do their giving in smaller spurts.
Tax returns for the Samuel I. Newhouse Foundation, their primary vehicle for philanthropy, show that it has given $32 million or so the last five years. That is virtually all the family's charitable giving, Donald Newhouse said. "We are giving on a very significant scale," he added.
The causes they adopt also tend to hug their business interests. Of the $7.3 million the Newhouses gave away last year, for example, an estimated $2 million was targeted to cities where they own either cable systems or newspapers.
 
Richard DeVos
Sports and Religion Taken Seriously
 Richard DeVos woke up one morning about 15 years ago and realized he was rich. " 'O.K. You have a lot of money,' " he recalled telling himself. "You say, 'O.K., you could do something big.' "
"A lot of money" is an understatement. Today, Mr. DeVos, 69, is worth $4.5 billion as co-owner of Amway, the direct marketery. His motivation for doing something big is simple. "I was brought up in a typical Midwestern Christian home," Mr. DeVos said from his home in Florida. He said he and his wife, Helen, give heavily to Christian causes, hospitals and community organizations. "We don't just throw it up against the wall and hope it sticks," he said.
One place it stuck was in America's national pasttime. Years ago, Mr. DeVos -- a sports fan and owner of the Orlando Magic basketball team -- started baseball chapels for players with Bobby Richardson, the former New York Yankees second baseman. "We gave it the seed money," he said. "Now others contribute."

 CORRECTION:
An article on April 30 about charity among the wealthy misstated the amount pledged by Ronald O. Perelman, chairman of Revlon Inc., to build a student center at the University of Pennsylvania. Shortly before the article was published, he increased his pledge to $20 million from $10 million.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: April 30, 1995

SECTION: Section 7; Page 6; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1837 words

HEADLINE: The Dark Defile

BYLINE: By James Atlas; James Atlas is an editor at The New York Times Magazine and the author of "Delmore Schwartz: The Life of an American Poet." He is at work on a biography of Saul Bellow.

 BODY:

EDMUND WILSON
A Biography.
By Jeffrey Meyers.
Illustrated. 554 pp. Boston:
A Peter Davison Book/Houghton Mifflin Company. $35. 
ONE of the surest ways to estimate a writer's reputation is to count the biographies. By this measure, Edmund Wilson (1895-1972) is doing well, with a respectable two. While Lewis Dabney's authorized biography drags on into its second decade -- rumors of its imminence have been around for years -- the indefatigable Jeffrey Meyers has managed to slip in under the wire, coming out on the centenary of Wilson's birth with what his publisher describes as "the first full-scale biography of a literary titan." According to the breathless press release, "the University of California-trained literary critic and biographer, author of 400 articles and 37 books, Fellow of the Royal Society of Literature and university lecturer, worked inexhaustibly, seven days a week, for only a year to produce this . . . volume." Phew!
Mr. Meyers's output is prodigious. Fat biographies bearing his name appear with alarming frequency. But his prodigality has not always served him well. His biographies tend to be uneven, to say the least -- haphazard, hasty, on occasion ill-tempered, as if the author himself were weary of his frenetic pace. His most recent book -- or was it the one before the last? -- a biography of F. Scott Fitzgerald, devoted an unseemly amount of space to Fitzgerald's penis size. For Mr. Meyers, biography is a marathon, a sweat-inducing labor; he's adding to the gross national product.
So it was with little hope, with trepidation even, that I approached this hefty opus. Not only was the biographer a dubious quantity, his subject was problematic. Edmund Wilson was one of this country's greatest men of letters, and he deserves a major biography. But the trouble with actually writing one (or reading one, for that matter) is the familiarity of the material. Wilson's shelf of books -- nearly as long as his biographer's -- is heavily autobiographical. Between the thick volumes of journals, some of them verging on a thousand pages, the memoir "Upstate" and the several volumes of letters, what is there left for a biographer to reveal that Wilson did not reveal himself? He wrote his own biography.
Yet somehow Mr. Meyers has produced a highly engaging book. Lively, well proportioned, insightful about the life and work, his brisk narrative puts it all together: the lonely middle-class childhood in Red Bank, N.J.; Princeton University, where Wilson met Fitzgerald; the hard-drinking Greenwich Village and Vanity Fair era in the 1920's; the four wives, including the famously difficult Mary McCarthy; the celebrated quarrels with Vladimir Nabokov and the drones of the Modern Language Association; the years at The New Yorker, where Wilson created a base of operations for his critical and literary forays. Mr. Meyers has wisely grouped his material by theme and period, for example, "Nervous Breakdown, 1927-1929," "Marxism and Russia, 1932-1935," "Mistresses, 1936-1937."
The result is a biography that -- how rare in this day of "definitive" doorstoppers -- is fun to read. It was Wilson's great distinction to have devised a style that made literature accessible to the general reader; he resented that academics -- "the professorial sodality," his biographer calls them -- had taken over the field.
Mr. Meyers has managed to do for Wilson the one thing Wilson couldn't do for himself: bring some insight to his life. For all his unremitting and clinical self-scrutiny, Wilson was notably disinclined to introspection. Working mostly from published sources, Mr. Meyers has assembled an evocative portrait of Wilson as the only child of two unloving parents. His father was remote and depression-prone and his mother resented -- to borrow Mary McCarthy's blunt image -- "that his large head had torn her vaginal tissues as he was being born." It was from his own unhappy childhood, Mr. Meyers theorizes, that Wilson formulated the central trope of "The Wound and the Bow," "that genius and disease, like strength and mutilation, may be inextricably bound up together."
Our image of Wilson as a grand old man -- even as a young man, he looked old -- obscures the pain and struggle that dogged his life. Literary recognition came to him fairly late, after years of itinerant freelancing -- "Axel's Castle," which established his reputation as a critic, was published when he was 36. The failure of his first novel, "I Thought of Daisy," had precipitated a full-scale nervous breakdown two years earlier. He earned pathetic amounts of money: his advance for "To the Finland Station" was $1,700 -- less than $300 for each year he worked on it. A regular writing job at The New Yorker, where he signed on when he was 48, provided a measure of stability, but his finances were precarious to the end. He spent a good part of his 60's sitting in the offices of the Internal Revenue Service in Utica, N.Y., negotiating settlement of the tax bill he had neglected to pay out of some combination of principle, neglect and megalomania. (Wilson recounted the story of his long skirmish with the I.R.S. in "The Cold War and the Income Tax.")
His private life was just as embattled as his public life. After his divorce from the actress Mary Blair in 1930, he married the hard-drinking Margaret Canby, a wealthy California socialite who died of a skull fracture two years into their marriage by falling down a flight of stairs. Then there was Mary McCarthy, who fought with him -- sometimes physically -- for the duration of their notoriously stormy partnership. Mr. Meyers usefully collates the considerable data on their seven-year marriage scattered throughout McCarthy's copious memoirs and Wilson's equally copious journals, supplying few fresh details. But in his sympathetic telling the two high-strung and willful writers both come off better than they did in their self-serving accounts.
WILSON'S last marriage, in 1946, to the stylishly cosmopolitan Elena Thornton, was the only happy one he had -- which didn't prevent him from having a fling with the New Yorker film critic Penelope Gilliatt at the Princeton Club in his 75th year. (He also worked in a hot affair with his dentist's wife.) When it came to sex, Wilson was a truly prodigious engine. Women applauded his "bull-like physical stamina," and the chronicle of sexual encounters enumerated by Mr. Meyers is richly salacious. "The most idiosyncratic aspect of Wilson's sexual taste was his obsessive foot-fetishism," according to his biographer, who also recounts episodes of sadism, masochism and other dank activities (I never knew that Wilson briefly owned a whip). An avid student of his own sex life, Wilson was "amoral and clinically distant," in Mr. Meyers's words; he tended to concentrate on what Cyril Connolly, reviewing Wilson's semi-pornographic novel, "Memoirs of Hecate County," devastatingly complained of as the "insect monotony" of sex. Wilson's lifelong quest for sexual adventure had a poignant source: at the root of his trouble with women was his fear "of not being loved, which I have carried all my life from childhood," he confided to Mary McCarthy.
Wilson was hard to like -- one of his wives described him as "a cold fishy leprous person." Even Mr. Meyers, his admiring biographer, concludes that he "lacked warmth." He was cruel to his wives, largely indifferent to his children, at times breathtakingly obtuse. (Not a model family man, he read "The Story of O" at the dinner table.) He was not an attractive drunk -- in one scene, Mr. Meyers quotes a neighbor who remembers Wilson crashing through the door of his apartment. And he could be intransigent, even abusive in literary debate, as in his remorseless attack on Nabokov's translation of "Eugene Onegin," which eventually destroyed their friendship; Mr. Meyers, putting this trait in its kindest light, quotes Anais Nin's description of his "harsh absolutism and literalness."
What makes this a vigorous biography is Mr. Meyers's authorial voice: he has a point of view. He is not one of those "democrats of the archive," in Leon Edel's phrase, who lay out the material without troubling to interpret it. For one thing, he is partisan; he likes Wilson's writing. Mr. Meyers is good on Wilson's strengths as a critic -- his psychological acuity, his ability to summarize complex literary trends in lucid and straightforward prose, his energy and curiosity. But Mr. Meyers is not afraid to point out his subject's weaknesses -- the historical myopia that enabled Wilson to apotheosize the architects of the Russian Revolution in "To the Finland Station" just as Stalin was consolidating power; his tin ear for poetry; the woodenness of his fiction; the disorganization and laziness of his compilations. Mr. Meyers also notes Wilson's tendency to overpraise mediocrities like Phelps Putnam, Elinor Wylie and Wilson's lover Edna St. Vincent Millay. He seduced Anais Nin by writing feeble encomiums to her books. But Wilson's enthusiasm for his friends' work was a generous fault, Mr. Meyers observes with characteristic forbearance.
ON occasion, Mr. Meyers manifests a sly wit, as when he speaks of the catholicity of Wilson's interests, which ranged from "the natives of the Algonquin Hotel to the tribes of the Iroquois." Like his subject, he has strong opinions about people: Nabokov was "as touchy as a Samurai," Robert Lowell was a "brilliant maniac," Brendan Gill of The New Yorker had "a nasty streak." At times, the voice is too pronounced. Mr. Meyers has a weakness for jocund asides -- a pointless footnote about Woody Allen's satire on the Dead Sea Scrolls; a dumb joke about carrots and lettuce (Wilson's nickname was Bunny). Describing Wilson's feud with Nabokov, he offers up an unpardonable pun about "when Pushkin came to shovekin." But even these off-the-wall outbursts personalize the book; you feel there is a sensibility there, however quirky and obnoxious.
Wilson's last years make for a somber story. As early as the mid-1950's, according to Mr. Meyers, he identified himself with "a half-obsolete group of survivors from the Victorian age." His later work is curmudgeonly to the point of self-parody; the journals of his 60's and 70's recount a desolate cycle of drink and depression, exacerbated by diminishing sexual powers. Mr. Meyers conjures up a sad image of Wilson in old age -- "the dark defile," as he memorably called it -- sitting on the toilet and reading old reviews of his books to boost his morale. Yet Mr. Meyers, chin up, maintains an elegiac tone. "The qualities exemplified in Edmund Wilson must be valued and restored if our literary culture is to survive," he writes.
It won't happen. No culture is ever restored, only transformed. In Mr. Meyers's summing up, Wilson was "the best, and one of the last, of the learned democratic critics who expressed a genuine love of literature." One of the last: the values that Edmund Wilson exemplified belong to history.

HEADLINE: Fund Offering More Than Fresh Air

BYLINE: By SARAH JAY

 BODY:
Before last summer, she had never traveled far from her housing project in the Bronx. In fact, she had never spent a night away from her mother.
But when 8-year-old Alanah Wade returned from two weeks in Pennsylvania's Amish country with a Fresh Air family, she was bubbling with smiles and stories: She had had corn on the cob and ice cream sundaes, picnics by day and fresh berries at night, Sunday rides in a horse-drawn buggy. 
 "If you sit in the front, the horse's hair gets in your face," Alanah said. "And he got white sweat on his back."
She was awed by the Pennsylvania countryside, where the trees and the grass and the woods never end. "It's like being in a wide open park, wherever you go," Alanah told her mother.
This year, Alanah can hardly wait to return. "They're going to teach me how to swim and ride a bike," she said.
And so it goes every year, as thousands of the city's poorest children anticipate the return of summer, and the chance to reunite with their adopted families in the Fresh Air Fund, which has been arranging free vacations for needy youngsters since 1877.
That first year, the Rev. Willard Parsons, a Presbyterian minister, urged his parishioners in Sherman, Pa., to open their homes to 60 children living in New York City tenement houses. Since then, 1.6 million children have become Fresh Air alumni, many of them forming lifelong bonds with their host families.
The organization, now in its 119th season, begins its annual fund-raising campaign today.
Jenny Morgenthau, executive director of the fund since 1983, has watched countless city children blossom under the sunny attention of their host families.
"They see that they have options and choices," Ms. Morgenthau said. "It makes kids feel good that the families didn't get paid to do this, that they did this out of affection for them."
For many, the vacation is also a sort of summer school, a chance to learn about nature. "Sometimes they don't know that milk comes from a cow, not from a supermarket," Ms. Morgenthau said.
Alanah, for example, discovered that vegetables grow in the ground and not cans. Her brother Julian, 9, spent lots of time in a treehouse. His family, also Amish, had no television. "But I didn't even care," he said. "I listened to the radio."
Eyon Flament, 8, joined a Fresh Air family in Akron, Pa., and learned to swim. He chased fireflies. He caught snails and used them as bait while fishing. He and his family got along well, and like most Fresh Air children, he has been invited back. "They're nice to me," he said. "Plus, they have a computer."
The Fresh Air Fund also sends 2,900 children, ages 8 to 15, to camp. The 3,000-acre campsite in Fishkill, N.Y., is equipped with a model farm, a planetarium and a wildlife refuge. Last year, a career awareness camp was added.
Ms. Morgenthau has two main concerns this summer. "One is to get more host families," she said, noting that the number has been slipping for two decades and has only recently begun to rise again. "The other thing is money. Like everyone else, I'm concerned about the economy."
At a time when welfare programs are coming under fire in Congress, she said, the fund can have a vital effect on the lives of the children, most of whom are on public assistance.
It costs the fund an average of $315 to arrange a visit with a volunteer host family and $912 to send a child to camp. About 80 percent of contributions come from private donors. Last year, the fund raised $4,117,604 from nearly 50,000 individuals.
The Fresh Air Fund is an independent, nonprofit agency with 42 staff members. It depends on 7,000 volunteers to help recruit and interview host families in 13 states, from Maine to Virginia, and Canada. Children come from low-income families affiliated with about 60 social service organizations in New York.
Last summer, 6,686 children stayed with host families, and Ms. Morgenthau said she would like the number to top 7,000 this year. She also wants to expand the base of New York City residents who take children to their summer homes and on vacations in the country. Only 51 New York families participated last year.
Families that want to be hosts may call (800) 367-0003. To offer other help, volunteers may call (212) 221-0900. Tax-deductible contributions may be sent to the Fresh Air Fund, 1040 Avenue of the Americas, New York, N.Y. 10018.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jenny Morgenthau, executive director of the Fresh Air Fund, met in Bryant Park recently with children in the program -- from left, Alanah Wade, Julian Wade, Jose Benitez, Eyon Flament and Jerry Wade. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Save the Dollar: Encourage Saving

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
For connoisseurs of pointless bickering, the run-up to last week's meeting of the Group of Seven finance ministers was a joy. Those who think the plunge of the dollar is an American problem demanded that the United States tighten something, either fiscal or monetary policy. To which Robert Rubin, the Treasury Secretary, said, in effect, "So's you mama." By international standards the American budget deficit was not all that big, he said, and higher interest rates could hurt the economy.
 In the end, the Group of Seven countries, pretending that they are all allies embarked on a common course, put out a statement saying that the dollar was undervalued but not indicating much of anything that should be done about it. Currency traders jeered, but in fact the battered buck did rally a bit. 
 The foreign criticism was focused on the wrong deficit. The budget deficit would not matter much if the question was one whether the American Government paid its bills by taxing or borrowing from its own citizens. But with the massive trade deficits also being run, this has become a country that gets by through issuing i.o.u.'s Japan exports cars and electronic equipment. We export wheat and dollars.
 The rest of the world could put a stop to that if it wanted to, simply by refusing to accept dollars. That is, as yet, unthinkable, but the hesitance of lots of foreigners to hold dollar-denominated assets is a major reason for the dollar tumbling to its current state of absurd undervaluation.
 The trade picture is likely to soon brighten on a cyclical basis, as the low dollar bolsters exports even more and as a slowdown in growth cuts imports. The national savings rate is rising slowly, but not nearly as fast as is needed or as fast as one might expect given that the older Baby Boomers are about to turn 50 and are in the stage of life where they should be accumulating assets to fund retirement.
 This country needs to find a way to lift savings substantially before the boomers retire. The likeliest answer to that is in tax policy. And perhaps the most encouraging aspect of the current political climate is that taxes are suddenly a fashionable topic of real debate, rather than just a way for irresponsible posturing of the "balance-the-budget-while-slashing-taxes" variety.
 If we were starting from scratch, a pure consumption tax might be the answer. Senator Richard Lugar of Indiana, in his bid for the Republican Presidential nomination, has proposed such a thing through a European-style value added tax. The big problem with that - aside from political realities - would be the transition. When Britain raised its value added tax and cut its income tax some years ago, the result was a predictable boom and bust, as everyone rushed to buy before the sales tax took effect and then stopped buying when it did.
 The lates proposal may also be the best. Senators Sam Nunn of Georgia and Pete Domenici of New Mexico last week put forth something called the "Unlimited Savings Allowance" tax system, which called for most Americans to pay 40 percent of their income in taxes, but only after deducting net savings from income. They claim it would bring in as much money as the current tax system.
 To fundamentally change the tax system will require bipartisanship and willingness to avoid demagogic opposition. In other words, getting anything accomplished is a long shot. But it is worth the effort.

LENGTH: 2441 words

HEADLINE: Reverse Commuting Is Making Some Gains

BYLINE: By PHILLIP LUTZ 

 BODY:
WHILE the number of commuters from Long Island to New York City has essentially stopped growing, the daily flow of workers to the Island continues to increase.
Economists and planners say the growth of so-called reverse commuting reflects more than the usual cycles of economic activity. The trend indicates a growing interdependence between the city, where many people seek entry-level jobs, and the suburbs, where such jobs often go begging. 
 Aiding the growth, the experts say, are changes in transportation, including new peak-hour trains and connecting buses, upgraded stations and intensified marketing by transit agencies that now regard reverse commuters as a distinct group.
"They're becoming a more significant commuter flow, a more significant part of our economy," the chief economist for the Long Island Regional Planning Board, Pearl Kamer, said, "and something that we want to facilitate."
From 1980 to 1990 the total of morning work trips by New York City residents to Nassau and Suffolk Counties increased 43 percent, to 87,000, and the trips by Long Islanders to Queens, Brooklyn and Manhattan remained at 269,000, according to an analysis of census data by the regional planning board.
Continuing that growth, reverse ridership on the Long Island Rail Road from 1991 to 1994 increased 14 percent, to 7,600, compared with a 1 percent increase for the usual ridership, said a spokesman for the L.I.R.R., Sam Zambuto.
The importance of the reverse commuters goes beyond their numbers, Ms. Kamer said. "It's the industry of employment and the occupations of the reverse commuters," that are important, "because they provide occupational skills we don't have in our resident labor force."
The economic profiles of the two commuter groups contrast sharply. According to the board's study, 41 percent of citybound commuters are executives, managers or professionals, compared with 29 percent of reverse commuters. Conversely, 13 percent of the citybound are clerical workers, compared with 20 percent of the Island-bound, and 4 percent of the citybound hold service jobs other than that of guard, compared with 11 percent of the Island-bound.
The median household income of citybound commuters in 1991, the latest year for which the railroad has statistics, was $66,000, 50 percent higher than that of reverse commuters, Mr. Zambuto said.
Most reverse commuters drive, and their number has been increasing since jobs began to spread into the suburbs. But proportionately more growth has recently occurred among the rail riders.
Nearly half of all reverse rail riders begin their trips at Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan, with most of the others' boarding in Brooklyn, Queens and western Nassau. Ms. Kamer said she thought that many of those passengers were recent immigrants who were "willing to take jobs that many Americans won't take, and have been doing so in large numbers."
A senior fellow at the Regional Plan Association, Jeffrey M. Zupan, said the new riders might be "people who typically have not come from a culture where everyone was seeking a car at the age of 16."
Businesses on Long Island actively recruit immigrants and minority members in the city, Mr. Zupan said. "The lower-skill-level jobs that are in the suburbs, are not easily filled by residents of the suburbs," he said.
The hotel business is one sector looking to fill such jobs. The improved economy has led to an increased demand for hotel rooms and for people to clean them. City residents, many of whom have recently arrived from Haiti and Jamaica, are taking the jobs, said the general manager of the 302-room Huntington Hilton, Michael Hollander.
About one-quarter of the the 300 hourly employees, including most housekeeping and food-service workers, live in New York City, Mr. Hollander said, adding that newspaper advertisements for readers in in Queens and Brooklyn and on Long Island usually generated responses just from the city, where word spreads in immigrant and minority communities about the jobs.
"It's hard for me to find people," he said. "With all the stories you hear about unemployment I have jobs available."
Workers travel to the hotel on Broadhollow Road near Route 110 in Melville in several ways, he said. Many take trains, buses or combinations. Those who have cars often drive several co-workers and share the expenses. At times, Mr. Hollander added, other hotels have sent buses to central locations to pick up workers.
At the Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point a diverse group of reverse commuters accounts for many of the 206 workers, according to a spokesman, Capt. John Jochmans. Because its site on the North Shore is poorly served by public transportation, Captain Jochmans said, many workers drive. But, he added, some low-paid workers cannot afford cars, and they have come up with unusual ways to travel from their homes in the city to the academy. A group of six cleaners from the Bronx rents a van, Captain Jochmans said.
Most reverse commuters are from Queens. Many more reverse-work trips -- 66,000 -- were made from there than any other borough in 1990, although the growth rate of reverse-peak commuting was higher in Manhattan and Brooklyn.
The workers have been important to the expansion of the Island economy, and would be important to expansion, Ms. Kamer said. "That our clerical jobs grew so rapidly during the 1980's and could grow so rapidly stems from the fact that they could draw on the large residential clerical labor force living in Queens, particularly eastern Queens."
Some banks are moving back-office operations off the Island, and demand at major banks for clerical workers is apparently not as strong as the demand for hotel housekeepers. Perhaps a few hundred Queens residents work at the huge credit-card and other operations of Chemical and Chase Manhattan banks in Hicksville, Jericho and Garden City, spokesmen said. But many more, economists said, are clerks in smaller companies.
Reverse commuters are not just clerks and service workers. They are also blue-collar manufacturing workers. Less than 10 percent of traditional commuters, compared with more than 15 percent of reverse commuters, hold manufacturing jobs, the regional planning board found.
Some businesses seek professionals from the city. One company, Mondo Publishing in Greenvale, which produces educational books, hired two city residents a few months ago, for sales and editorial jobs, said the sales director, Jane Binkoff. Six of the 12 employees at Mondo are reverse commuters, Miss Binkoff said.
"These kinds of volumes are growing more rapidly than growth into the core," Mr. Zupan said.
Transit agencies, seeing that the proportion of employed Long Islanders with jobs in New York City declined slightly from 1980 to 1990, according to the planning board, are trying to take advantage of the growth in reverse commuting, even as they take credit for some of it.
Literature handed out at major reverse-commuter stations beginning next month will aim at increasing the awareness of a program under which employers buy transit vouchers for employees and receive tax breaks.
Eighty companies on Long Island participate in the program, an increase of 20 percent over 1993, said Larry Filler, executive director of the Transit Center, an agency that runs the Transitchek voucher program. As many as900 Long Island employers are eligible.
Transitchek, which opened a sales office in Garden City this year, is organizing seminars, sending mailings and installing computers to identify potential customers.
Expansion of the program fits in with the L.I.R.R. strategy, based on a study of 1990 Census data, that identifies reverse commuters as a market.
"Because of the employment pool," Mr. Filler said, "you're going to get a lot of people coming in from the city. As a matter of fact, although it's difficult for the L.I.R.R. to run a huge number of trains in a reverse direction because of the constraints on the system -- all the trains going westbound in the morning -- those trains are pretty crowded."
New trains for reverse commuters are part of the strategy. Last year the railroad restored half-hourly reverse-peak service on the Port Washington Branch after track work had cut the service to hourly, Mr. Zambuto said. The number of riders leaving the train in Port Washington increased from 1991 to last year by 109, to 317, he said.
He credited the addition of the two new Penn Station trains in the morning, the 5:48 to Huntington and the 7:39 to Ronkonkoma, with helping increase reverse-peak ridership at Mineola and Hicksville. Both trains stop at Mineola, where the daily riders leaving the train in the morning rose from 1991 to 1994 by 102, to 435, and at Hicksville, where ridership grew 27, to 402.
The railroad has added a train that stops at Stony Brook, the 7:09 from Huntington to Port Jefferson. In addition, a train that had originated at Smithtown now begins at Stony Brook.
Two morning trains were added from Penn Station to Babylon, the 7:10 and 7:49, as well as a westbound evening train, which leaves Babylon at 4:35 and arrives at Jamaica at 5:11. The new Babylon trains have not made a perceptible difference in the volume at that stop. Despite the addition of the Ronkonkoma train, that station has declined in popularity as a destination.
Mr. Zambuto said economic and other factors were sometimes more important than improved service. But, he said, ridership more than doubled at Farmingdale, to 187, where the Ronkonkoma train also stops.
A further increase is expected at Farmingdale, he said, because of improved bus service, which includes a new shuttle linking the train with Route 110 in Melville. Riders on the Farmingdale shuttle have been taking 130 trips a day since it began in September, Mr. Zambuto said.
In Woodbury the number of daily trips on a shuttle linking the Hicksville station with the Crossways and Gateways commercial complexes has increased 50 percent, to 90, since the shuttle started last year, he added.
Reverse ridership should increase as a result of plans to modernize popular reverse-commuting stations like Jamaica, Woodside and Forest Hills, Mr. Zambuto said. He attributed an increase in reverse ridership at Penn Station, in part, to a $190 million renovation. With the improving economy as well as improved service, the number of riders leaving Penn Station in the morning has increased in the last three years by 423, to 3,692.
At Jamaica, which is used by 1,205 riders, or 16 percent of the reverse-rail market, work is scheduled to begin in July and finish next year on a $15.5 million renovation of the waiting room, ticket office and mezzanine. Jamaica is the station used second most often by reverse commuters.
At Woodside work is also scheduled for July, on new platforms, an escalator and elevators. Scheduled to be finished in early 1998, the joint venture with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will cost the L.I.R.R. $25.5 million. Woodside is the fourth most popular point of origin for reverse riders, with a daily ridership of 379, or 5 percent of the total.
At the end of the year, $4.3 million in renovation work is scheduled to begin at Forest Hills.
And by 1998 work is to be completed on the Hempstead Hub, a $17.5 million project being designed to include a new station building, new platforms and improved parking.
Although the most reverse-work trips are taken between eastern Queens and the Town of Hempstead, the Hempstead terminal has a daily reverse-peak ridership of 224, a substantial number still well below that of other major stations, despite its proximity to major employment centers.
Mr. Zambuto said officials hoped to increase the use of the terminal by expanding links with the bus terminal across the street, making signal and track improvements and starting half-hourly reverse-peak service.
There may be evidence that reverse commuters will choose public transportation when it is reasonably convenient. About 30 percent of travelers from Jamaica to Hempstead and North Hempstead use buses.
In an encouraging finding for rail supporters, the study reported that one-third of the work trips from downtown Brooklyn to North Hempstead were by rail. But, Mr. Zambuto said, the L.I.R.R. is physically limited in providing reverse peak service.
Although the railroad has an opportunity to increase its small share of the reverse-peak market, he said, doing so will depend on obtaining $700 million for more track between Bellerose and Hicksville and on electrifying the Main Line between Ronkonkoma and Yaphank. Both projects have been supported by state legislators, but will be competing for money in a tight market.
Meanwhile, Ms. Kamer said, the railroad can employ new pricing strategies. "In cases where they're running a train almost empty in the reverse direction," she said, "there's almost zero marginal cost to bringing these workers out at a very low fare."
Officials of the planning board and the railroad have informally discussed reducing fares, Ms. Kamer said. But, Mr. Zambuto added, the railroad has no plans for a reduction. Reduced-fare, multiple-trip tickets are available.
Some other strategies have also been discussed, like providing shuttle buses. Although planners say it is critical to address transportation from stations to work sites, problems could discourage using buses at locations where they are most needed, like Route 110.
"The difficulty," Mr. Zupan said, "is one of microscale design. Because these buildings are set back from the road you get off a bus and you have to walk. Sometimes there's no sidewalk, no shelters where you're waiting."
Ms. Binkoff of Mondo Publishing said that she found time to think on her one-hour drive from the Upper East Side of Manhattan to Greenvale and that she liked the flexibility the car afforded for the return trips.
Lack of flexibility is the main complaint of a co-worker of Ms. Binkoff, Louise Gruber, an editor and a reverse-rail rider. Although Ms. Gruber spends just a few minutes walking from her home on East 32d Street in Manhattan to Penn Station and from the train to the office, she said, there is a two-hour gap between trains that leave Greenvale at the most critical time of night.
But, she added, she did not want to drive. Having won a trip to England in a contest sponsored by the L.I.R.R., Ms. Gruber might have been favorably disposed toward the railroad for that reason. But even before she won the prize, she had adjusted to her reverse commuting.
"I've found it pretty pleasant," she said.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Tales Tall and Tales True, Family-Style

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
IT'S storytelling time at the Crossroads Theater Company. But not just that, though the splendid way Ossie Davis, Ruby Dee and Guy Davis tell tales, the tall and the true, is the heady stuff of an evening's abundance.
There is more. 
 The show, in its world premiere, is "Two Hah Hahs and a Homeboy," a title that takes some getting used to. Mr. Davis and Ms. Dee are husband and wife, sustained by laughter (hence, one ha for each). Guy Davis is their son. That explains homeboy. About the show's subtitle, "Or, How Come We All Ain't Crazy?," don't ask.
Give thanks that this compilation by Ms. Dee of folk tales and folk songs in the first half and mostly original material written by all three in the second does not turn consciousness of selves into a thematic device or even a reference point.
It doesn't have to. The family's affection is a felt thing, a consummately professional interaction. It is a pleasure to behold them beholding one another. And the show's fusion of humor and history, in an airy staging by Micki Grant, gorgeously designed by Felix E. Cochren, is self-evident.
In dedication to Zora Neale Hurston ("spiritual mother to the three of us," Ms. Dee writes in a program note), the first act is defined by those Ms. Hurston called "the once-upon-a-time people who could neither read nor write and who never heard of Ibsen."
Listen to "Beatcha Makin' Money" (told by a victorious slave), "Sis Snail" (she's Ossie Davis, narrating in backwoods dialect, shawl over his head, putting snuff to his inside lower lip), "Pieced Up Rock" (which hilariously explains why the Christian church is split up into so many different denominations) and "John Wanted to Go to Heaven" (a joyous stage traffic among three accomplished farceurs in a life-and-death story of priceless, knowing irony).
These are Ms. Hurston's accounts of slaves and masters, horses and buggies, the tricksters and the tricked. They evolved "out of the sky, out of the ground, out of the water," Ms. Dee tells us. And watch Guy Davis (as John), fleet of foot, running from God.
Joshua's "Gig in Jericho" (lyrics by the elder Mr. Davis, music composed and played by the younger on acoustic guitar and harmonica) enhances the first act. Ossie Davis's own eloquent and funny piece, "Talking Drums and Haitian Dumplings" -- a majestically told grown-up fairy tale involving "dumplings jumping and soldiers dancing," a lovely revenge for Toussaint L'Ouverture, a mighty defeat for Napoleon and a resonating freedom for Haiti -- sends the audience off to the intermission with a positively liberating glow.
In content, Act II represents something of a downhill slide. A child's first haircut, recollected by Guy Davis, allowing too much leeway to imprecise language, is not the heart-tugger it means to be. The joy of "Thumb Thing," a comic sketch by Ms. Dee, the writer, proves utterly elusive, a waste of the charms of Ms. Dee, the actress.
In contrast, six domestic arguments and reconciliations of a married couple are astutely observed, filled with wicked turnarounds and truths that only rare people in love have the wisdom to acknowledge and the wit to express.
In "Litany of the Laid Off," a bravura display of performing art by Ossie Davis, he becomes the "National Unemployed Worker of the Year": the spokesman for the President's new economic policy.
Ms. Dee is the personification of star; it is not possible to avert one's eyes when she is on the sidelines, reacting. The actor and writer to whom she has been married for 46 years is clearly a sly political satirist as well. The two have nurtured a son of grace and talent.
There is more.
This classy family dresses to kill.

HEADLINE: Role of Visiting Nurse Services Changing

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
THE more things change, the more they remain the same. Home health care, newly important in today's health-care system with its emphasis on short hospital stays, prevention and personal responsibility, took root in Westchester nearly 100 years ago.
A visiting nurse association, an outgrowth of the Visiting Nurse and Henry Street Settlement started by Lillian Wald on the Lower East Side of Manhattan in 1893, was established in Yonkers in 1901 to care for the immigrant families of workers who came to build the railroads. Similarly, the Dominican Sisters Family Health Services in Ossining is the outgrowth of a service that began on the West Side of Manhattan when Mary Walsh and a dedicated band of volunteers brought home care to newly arrived immigrants 115 years ago. 
 Nonprofit home health care agencies are still providing skilled nursing services in Westchester communities. "In 1994, we made almost 100,000 home visits, seeing 4,000 patients, which represents a 400 percent increase since 1988," said Joseph J. Burns, president and chief executive of the Visiting Nurse Services in Westchester, based in White Plains, the largest nonprofit certified home health agency in the county.
Mr. Burns continued: "With numbers like that, plus all the other services we offer, such as free blood pressure testing, nurse counseling at over 40 different sites and educational programs, you might think we have a secure place in the changing health care system, but we are facing a double-edged sword as we head toward our 100th anniversary.
"On one hand, as the Westchester population ages, the demand for our services increases, but on the other hand, there are those who would like to control the home health care system and push agencies like ours out of the way."
What is happening, Mr. Burns said, is that during the last five years three Westchester hospitals -- New Rochelle, White Plains and United Medical Center in Port Chester -- have set up their own certified home health agencies, which has resulted in a significant reduction of patient referrals to community-based home health agencies like Visiting Nurse Services. In addition, the hospitals have formed two hospital networks -- the Westchester Health Network and Excell -- of five hospitals each, which control the hospitals' home health assignments and have virtually shut out the Visiting Nurse Service.
"Seventy-five percent of our business comes from referrals from hospitals," Mr. Burns said. "But now in the changing health care environment we are competing with controlled home health care referrals. How much we will eventually lose has become a major concern of our board."
What prompts the concern, Mr. Burns said, is that hospitals, facing a reduction in patients, are looking for ways to generate additional revenue. "They see that their future depends on expanding services out into the community, which literally puts them in direct competition with nonprofit certified home health agencies like ours," he said.
Visiting Nurse Services, he continued, is striving to make home health care more accessible at lower costs with an even higher level of quality in order to compete.
"In this changing health care scene, we have to decide what kind of a partnership we should develop in order to survive," he said. "Why survive? Because we believe that our community home health care nurses -- and we have almost 100 of them -- have proven time and time again they are the best qualified and trained to provide special care in the home, which is different from care by nurses in hospitals."
When asked what makes Visiting Nurses different from other nurses, Mr. Burns said: "They are, first of all, highly qualified, independent, rugged individualists who can work without a doctor at their side. Their mission is skilled nursing for patients, but they are also confidants and household organizers who occupy a very unique place in the homes that they visit."
In order to continue to deliver high-quality health services, Mr. Burns said, the 15 certified nurse services in the county would be more effective if they combined forces. "We are the largest not-for-profit, more than double the size of the next largest agency," he said. "But if all of us -- all the home health agencies in Westchester -- would ban together, the fear of the smaller being gobbled up would lessen. Together we would be able to reduce all our overhead. We would be saving countless salaries by having 1 administrator for all instead of 15 individual administrators. Savings would also accrue by eliminating expensive duplication of services that we have presently."
With one agency, he said, fewer staff specialist nurse practitioners would be needed. Specialist nurses, like wound specialists and psychological nurses, earn salaries of more than $50,000 a year.
"This is nothing new," he said. "We've been down this road before. Twenty-five years ago with the passage of Medicare and its many new requirements and restrictions, many of the smaller Visiting Nurse Associations weren't able to deal with them. Their choices were to surrender or ban together. At that time nine of the small Visiting Nurse Associations in Westchester made a decision to consolidate and stay afloat under a new partnership umbrella. Together we formed the Visiting Nurse Association of Westchester into one freestanding nursing service."
Visiting Nurse Service operates on a yearly budget of $10 million, 90 percent of which comes from reimbursement from Medicare co-payment insurance companies. The other $1 million is raised through fund-raising activities.
"No one is ever turned away because of financial need," he said. "About 8 percent of our patients get free care every year."
Sister Virginia Hanrahan, executive director of the Dominican Sisters Family Health Service in Ossining, which serves patients and their families in the area, including Westchester and Suffolk Counties and parts of the Bronx, said that in 1994, Dominican Sisters Service provided help to 5,600 patients and families and made 132,300 home visits. About 10 percent of the visits were provided without cost to the patient.
"The hospital-based home health care agencies are quite different from ours," she said. "We are Catholic related, and special emphasis is given to the poor. We have many free programs, outreach services, and in addition to providing skilled home care, we provide case management, home health care aides, long-term health care and AIDS home care programs and pastoral care."
But, Sister Virginia said, Dominican Sisters is continuing to look at all possibilities for consolidating and networking some of its services with other home health care agencies.
During the last decade, the pressure on hospitals to discharge patients earlier and earlier has increased the need for home health services.
"Home health care is more economical than hospitalization or convalescent homes," Mr. Burns said. "Technical advances have made it possible for specialty services that used to be available only in hospitals, such as intravenous therapies to be done at home. And portable equipment has made it possible for physical therapy also to be done in the home." Services to new mothers by Visiting Nurses have also escalated, he added.
As for personnel, Mr. Burns said, there is no shortage of registered nurses for home health care positions. Why? "Because, after years of shortages, to save money, hospitals are getting rid of R.N.'s and substituting lower-paid nurse assistants."
