HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Manalapan;
Despite Growth, the Ambiance Is Rural

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW 

 BODY:
THE name Manalapan means "land that produces good bread" in the language of the Leni Lenape Indians who inhabited the site before the first English and Scottish settlers arrived in the late 17th century.
Indeed, the 31-square-mile township has been a breadbasket for more than 300 years, producing grain, vegetables and livestock. Today about two dozen working farms hang on amid residential development. 
 "We still own and farm 320 acres," said Lydia S. Wikoff, township historian and matriarch of a sixth-generation farm family that moved to the area in 1839. "We used to rent much more land from developers for farming, but now they are building on it. Soon there may not be enough land to make it economical for us to operate the large equipment we need for farming."
Mrs. Wikoff complains about the "heavy traffic" on Gordon's Corner Road near the family farm. She recalls when it was a dirt road that her father would plow and scrape in winter, with the aid of horses, in exchange for a tax abatement.
Today, Manalapan (pronounced Ma-NAH-la-p'n), in northern Monmouth County in south central New Jersey, has slightly more than 9,000 housing units and a population that has doubled since 1970. More than two-thirds of the housing units are single-family, with most of the remainder in the 1,831-unit Covered Bridge, a senior-citizen condominium community off New Jersey Route 9, and in two other condominium communities -- Oak Knolls off Longwood Drive and Southfield off Symmes Road.
While old-timers think the town has become crowded, newcomers are attracted by the remaining rural ambiance. Among them are Marion E. and Eamon G. Greene, who moved to Manalapan from neighboring Freehold with their 2-year-old daughter a year and a half ago.
"There are still horse farms here," said Mrs. Greene. "It is far less congested than northern New Jersey and is less than half an hour from the Jersey shore."
Mr. Greene commutes 60 minutes daily to New York City, where he works in an insurance brokerage. Mrs. Greene is a homemaker and former systems manager for Merrill Lynch. The Greenes bought a four-bedroom split-level home on half an acre in the Yorktown development, one of the older housing areas. Mrs. Greene describes most of her neighbors as being "in their late 50's and 60's, having purchased their houses 30 years ago when the development was built." She terms her relationship with her neighbors as "friendly" but would like to see more young families move into the neighborhood.
HOUSING prices in Manalapan range from about $165,000 for some small three-bedroom homes without basements in the older central and northern sections of town, up to $750,000 for some of the large new homes in the southern section. One of the priciest and most prestigious neighborhoods is the Taylorr Lake Estates section in the southern area off Kinney Road, where some of the houses have six bedrooms, maids' quarters and three-car garages.
More typical new construction is in the Pine Hill Estates neighborhood off Pease Road, where 3,100-square-foot custom houses on half an acre start at $325,000.
The largest single-family development is the 30-year-old Monmouth Heights, a 685-home neighborhood built by the Levitt organization off Route 9. The deeds stipulate that homeowners in the neighborhood must join the Monmouth Heights Community Association. The annual fee of $185 entitles homeowners to the use of the association's swimming pool, kiddie pool, two tennis courts and volleyball court off Ryan Road.
According to Linda Trott, president and broker at ERA Trott Realty, four-bedroom, two-and-a-half bath splits, ranches and colonials in Monmouth Heights go for between $200,000 and $270,000, depending on condition and improvements to the original home.
Prices at The Covered Bridge start at $55,000 for a one-bedroom condo and go up to about $120,000 for some ranch-style end units. To buy into the community, at least one spouse must be 62 or older.
The largest condominium community is the 330-unit Oak Knolls off Longwood Drive. Two-bedroom units start at about $115,000, with three-bedrooms selling for about $20,000 more.
Over the next decade, Manalapan is expected to grow by about 30 percent because developers have purchased two parcels of land in the southern section of the township and applied for permits for the construction of 3,580 housing units.
So far, permits have been approved for the construction of 800 units in the smaller of the two parcels, known as Knob Hill. The owners of the larger parcel are in litigation for approvals. Township Administrator James J. Devereaux says the street pattern inside the larger development, to be known as The Villages, is at issue, not the projected 2,780 homes.
Manalapan has no apartment buildings. Rentals, Mrs. Trott says, are hard to come by. Some apartments, however, are rented in The Covered Bridge section or in private homes. Some two-bedroom units rent for $900 and single-family homes for an average of $1,600, Mrs. Trott says.
Manalapan was the site of the Battle of Monmouth, a Revolutionary War engagement involving 30,000 British and Continental troops. Much of the battleground is now the 1,520-acre Monmouth Battlefield State Park, 80 percent of which is in Manalapan. The park, which has a visitors' center, playgrounds and picnic tables, is open from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M.
The park is used for the annual celebration of Manalapan Day, which is to be held on June 17 this year. The day's events include dancing, a re-enactment of the Battle of Monmouth and food concessions.
Near the park on Route 33 is Wemrock Orchards, and just a block away on Wemrock Road is Battleview Orchards. Both are known throughout the region for apple picking in season and for their farm stores, which sell fresh fruits and vegetables and freshly baked pies.
The most widely used park is the Manalapan Recreation Center, a 150-acre municipal area across from town hall on Route 522. It includes nine soccer fields, six baseball diamonds, six basketball courts, six tennis courts, a roller-hockey rink and several playgrounds. Also in the park is the Dryer House, a farmhouse that local historians say was built before 1876 and that has the date 1811 scratched on one of its windowpanes.
The town has three supermarkets and extensive shopping along Route 9. The closest major shopping center is the Freehold Raceway Mall, two miles south of the town line in Freehold Township. The 22-store Manalapan Mall, anchored by Steinbach's on Route 9, is in a state of disrepair, as the mall owner and the township battle through the courts over the owner's request for approval of expansion plans. Nearby homeowners are afraid that such an expansion will increase traffic.
AMONG the more colorful shopping meccas in Manalapan is the Englishtown Auction, a giant flea market on the Freehold-Englishtown Road near the borough of Englishtown, which is surrounded by Manalapan. It was opened as a farmers' auction market in 1929 and attracts busloads of shoppers from as far away as New York City and Washington.
The most colorful restaurant in the town is the Old Silver Tavern on Route 522, known for its inexpensive, tasty grill food and free bowls of popcorn. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman often appears there unannounced for a helping of its spicy buffalo wings.
The Manalapan-Englishtown Regional Schools is a 4,712-student district, in which all but 170 students are from Manalapan. It includes three K-3 elementary schools, two schools for fourth through sixth grades and the Manalapan Englishtown Middle School for grades seven and eight. Manalapan High School, which most Manalapan students attend, is part of the five-school, eight-municipality Freehold Regional High School District. Last year, Manalapan High sent 92 percent of its 416-student graduating class to higher education. It offers advanced-placement courses in English, mathematics, American history and the sciences.
The superintendent of the Manalapan Englishtown Schools, Joseph S. Scozzari, said that the existing elementary schools were nearing capacity and that he intended to ask the township to approve a $13 million bond referendum to construct a sixth elementary school.
"We now have 4,712 students and expect increases of 4 percent per year, excluding the new low- and moderate-income housing," said Mr. Scozzari. "Already next year, some of our schools may have to save classrooms by making art and music traveling subjects." Mr. Scozzari said construction of The Villages and Knob Hill could create a need for two additional schools besides the one that is already necessary.
According to the superintendent, the elementary and middle schools stress reading, writing and problem-solving skills. Indeed, a team from the township's Lafayette Mills School for grades five and six will represent New Jersey at the Odyssey of the Mind international problem-solving competition in Tennessee next month.
Manalapan has many buildings dating from Colonial times. The best known is the Old Tennent Church on Tennent Road. The cedar-clad structure was built in 1751 and is surrounded by a cemetery that dates back to 1730. Also in the township is the oldest black church in Monmouth County, St. James African Methodist Church, built in 1836 by freed slaves.
The main branch of the Monmouth County Library is on Symmes Road in Manalapan. The sprawling building contains 490,000 volumes and collections of videos, audio cassettes, music on compact disks and research materials on CD-ROM. The library is also used extensively for concerts, lectures, meetings and movies.

COMMON SENSE: An incident that befell Thomas Paine, the most influential pamphleteer of the Revolutionary War, in Manalapan in 1777 sent chuckles rippling through the Colonies at a time of great stress for the embattled Continentals. Paine went riding with a friend in the township. When they approached a gate, Paine is said to have dismounted, allowed his friend to pass and closed the gate, leaving his own horse on the other side. In relating the event, the friend noted that it had occurred shortly after Paine published his most famous work, entitled "Common Sense."

HEADLINE: Doing Battle, Once Again, Against Base Closings

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
FOR months, groups from two Connecticut coastal communities, with help from state agencies and the state's Congressional delegation, have been mapping strategies to save thousands of military contract jobs threatened by the 1995 base closure process. This week, those strategies will be put to the test.
At a Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission hearing on Friday aboard the aircraft carrier Intrepid in New York City, officials from New London and Stratford will argue against the Pentagon's recommendations for military installations in those towns. 
 Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of East Haddam and the senior member of the Connecticut Congressional delegation, will supervise the presentation. He said the two regions face a tough fight. "Each and every one involved in this fight feels for the workers involved in this struggle," he said, but the unfortunate fact of the matter was that no one prevails "by basing their case solely on jobs and pain inflicted on a region. It takes cold hard facts, and that's exactly what we think we have."
The Senator continued: "It's clear the Army's assessment of Stratford and the Navy's numbers on New London simply don't add up -- and that, in the end, is the best armor as we head into this fight. It simply makes no sense to break up the unique synergy on submarines in New London -- or junk the Stratford facility, given its important role in our nation's defense."
In Stratford, regional officials are preparing to fight a recommendation to close an Army tank engine plant operated by Allied Signal, which employs 1,600.
"We don't have many employers that large left in the Bridgeport region," said Paul S. Timpanelli, president of the Bridgeport Regional Business Council, which is aiding the efforts to save the Allied Signal plant. Furthermore, the Allied Signal jobs high-paying positions, he noted, and it's estimated that there are thousands of spinoff jobs involved, from barbers who cut Allied Signal employees' hair, to the company's suppliers and subcontractors.
In New London a grassroots group will oppose the Pentagon's proposal that the Naval Undersea Warfare Center be closed, and shift its 1,200 jobs to Rhode Island. In addition, the Department of Defense has proposed that nuclear power schools scheduled to move to the Naval Submarine Base in Groton be moved instead to Charleston, S.C., which would mean Connecticut's not getting 500 instructor positions and 3,000 students a year. William D. Moore, chairman of the Subase Realignment Coalition, the group fighting both recommendations, said he was particularly concerned about the warfare center, which has a payroll of more than $65 million and issued $119 million of contracts last year, many of them to subcontractors in the area that employ an estimated 2,000 people.
"That's a lot of money to take out of the economy," Mr. Moore said. He explained that the schools have not yet been established in the state "so it's a much different economic impact."
"You're not going to lose," he said, "but neither will you realize the benefits for those dollars coming into the community."
Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Bozrah, whose district includes Groton, noted that the region could have fared far worse than it did. Navy documents show that the service ran a computer simulation three times, and each time it recommended closing the Groton base, which would have meant a loss of more than 10,000 jobs.
"We had to come back from the dead to win this fight," Mr. Gejdenson said, crediting work by the grassroots organization and the Congressional delegation to convince the Navy that the base has major military value.
"None of these fights are over -- we still intend to fight for Naval Undersea Warfare Center and the training schools," Mr. Gejdenson said. "But if we'd lost the base, we would not be talking today about saving N.U.W.C. or saving the schools."
The 1995 round of base closures is the fourth since 1988, and the last required under a law Congress passed to reduce the size of the military infrastructure. In the first three rounds, about 15 percent of the military's base structure was ordered closed or scaled back, including more than 100 bases and 200 smaller installations.
This year the Pentagon has recommended 146 closings or realignments that it says will save $6 billion by the turn of the century. But as with past base closures, each community affected gets an opportunity to argue against closure before the commission.
The hearing Friday is the last of 11 conducted around the country, and will focus on bases in New York, New Jersey and Massachusetts, as well as Connecticut. Two of the commissioners will visit the Stratford and New London installations before the hearing, to gather information.
John Earnhardt, a spokesman for the commission, said each decision would be based on eight criteria: four dealing with the military value of a base, one on how much the military will save and three dealing with the economic and environmental impact of the closing on the community. Each state will get one hour for its presentation.
"We are sticking very closely to the schedule," Mr. Earnhardt said. Issues new to the commissioners have been raised -- and even if it's not new, it does not hurt a community's efforts, Mr. Earnhardt stressed.
The commission has until July 1 to make its final recommendations to President Clinton, who has until July 15 to decide whether to accept the list or send it back. If it is sent back, the commission has until Aug. 15 to submit a revised list to the President, who has until Sept. 1 to accept or reject the revision.
If Mr. Clinton accepts either list, it goes on to Congress, which must also accept or reject the list in its entirety. On Dec. 31, the commission will be disbanded.
Frank O'Beirne, a retired Navy captain and consultant to Connecticut's Department of Economic Development on base closure matters, said the two groups faced a difficult task. In the last three rounds of base closures -- in 1988, 1991 and 1993 -- fewer than 15 percent of the Pentagon's recommendations have been overturned, he noted.
"You have to assume the Department of Defense has put a year's worth of efforts into these recommendations, and analyzed them in great detail," he said, "so the commissioners are going to put a great deal of weight on them. You have to come up with some pretty good arguments to overcome them."
Mr. O'Beirne, who worked with the southeastern Connecticut group two years ago when the Pentagon proposed closing the submarine base in Groton, said the strategy of many community groups in the past has been suggest other bases that could be closed to generate more savings.
"The problem is, all the easy decisions have been made now," he said. "That can work in our favor -- we can argue that a choice doesn't make sense. But it means the base closure commissioners' job is going to be that much more difficult."
Southeastern Connecticut is in a much better position to deal with the Pentagon recommendations this year, because it has been through the process twice before. In 1991 the Pentagon proposed closing the warfare center in New London, but the grassroots group convinced the commission to spare it. It was ordered to shrink from 1,500 jobs to about 500. As of early this year, though, there were still 1,200 people working at the center, awaiting other assignments.
In 1993 the Pentagon recommended the submarine base in Groton be closed. The commission overturned that recommendation, and ordered the nuclear propulsion schools the Navy operates in Orlando, Fla., to be moved to Groton.
Mr. Moore said the argument to save the warfare center this year would center largely on money. The Navy said it would cost $56 million to consolidate the offices in New London with its base in Newport, R.I., and a Congressional accounting office worked out, at the time, that if the cost rose by 30 percent the Navy would save no money at all. Since then, the cost has risen to an estimated $120 million. The coalition will argue that the warfare center, which specializes in sonar, should instead become a Navy center for acoustics.
Mr. Moore said the coalition would argue that the nuclear schools belong in Connecticut instead of South Carolina because many graduates of the submarine school in Groton go on to attend the nuclear schools, and it would make more sense for them to be on the same site.
"Southeastern Connecticut is the submarine center of the world," Mr. Moore said. "We've got Electric Boat, which builds the fleet, and a tactics development squadron of submarines, an operational squadron, the research center; in one five-mile loop you've got the heart and soul of all submarine technology. That's something you should build on, not break up."
The Stratford group faces a tougher battle because the tank-engine plant operates at less than two-thirds capacity, and has no military contracts beyond 1997. In addition, the Army's latest vehicles use diesel rather than gas-turbine drive trains.
Still, the recommendation caught the region by surprise. Just weeks before the Pentagon proposed closing the plant, it notified the Connecticut Congressional delegation that it was planning to spend $34.5 million on renovations. Allied Signal apparently had no warning either; four months before the announcement it purchased the operation from Textron Lycoming.
"It was quite a shock," said Maura L. Keefe, a spokeswoman for Representative Rosa DeLauro, Democrat of New Haven, whose office is working closely with the grassroots organization fighting the proposal.
Ms. Keefe said the state and affected communities have hired a retired Army major general, Peter McVey of the Cambridge Group in Washington, D.C., who was program manager of tank systems in the 1980's, and has worked closely with the southeastern Connecticut coalition to develop a strategy. The coalition has formed two subcommittees, one gathering data to prove the military value of the plant.
"This is the Army's only tank-engine manufacturing facility," Ms. Keefe said. "Where are they going to do this work if they close Stratford, and how much time will it take and what will it cost to reconstitute the production lines? These are questions that have to be answered."
The other subcommittee will explore ways to reduce the cost to the Army by bringing in more commercial work.
William Reavis, a spokesman at Allied Signal headquarters in Phoenix, said military contracts currently made up about 60 percent of production, with 40 percent devoted to small aircraft engines.
But the tank-engine operation is one of a handful of Government-owned, contractor-operated plants in the country.
"If the Pentagon's recommendation is accepted, we'd have to shift all our work to another location," Mr. Reavis said. The company has not determined whether the commercial work would remain in Connecticut, he said.
The Stratford Town Manager, Mark S. Barnhart, said the group's argument would be based not only on the military value of the plant, but also on economics. Even if the Army is going to produce fewer gas-turbine engines, it will need the equipment here.
"We think the Army has grossly underestimated the cost of reproducing the production lines elsewhere," Mr. Barnhart said. "It's going to cost the military a heck of a lot more to do something that we do extremely well here in Stratford."
He said that because the Army installation is tax exempt the town would lose only the $1.3 million of taxes on Allied Signal equipment at the plant, which works out to less than 2 percent of the town's tax revenue. The larger impact is the 1,600 jobs, which affects the entire region, in addition to spinoff jobs.
"We hope to have a figure ready for presentation to the commission, but we also know that's not going to be the primary consideration," Mr. Barnhart said. "The success of any argument this year is going to have to be based on military value. And that's what we're going to stress."

HEADLINE: County's Wealth: Two Sides Of the Coin

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
FOR the well-to-do, Westchester is the suburb north of New York City known for its rolling hills, pricey real estate and sought-after addresses like Scarsdale and Rye. But for the struggling middle class -- whose numbers grow smaller each year, according to economists -- and for the poor, the county is a place where the cost of housing is often out of reach and the cost of living daunting.
"Westchester is a fine place if you are one of the haves," said Frank M. Surdey, a regional economist with the State Department of Labor, "but it's not so great if you're a have-not." 
 A study of average incomes in New York made public recently by the State Department of Taxation and Finance showed that Westchester County ranked second only to Manhattan in terms of personal income reported by residents on their 1992 tax returns.
In a separate study of median incomes prepared by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, the county ranked third nationwide.
The Department of Taxation and Finance study, based on adjusted gross incomes, reported $57,906 as the 1992 average income for Westchester residents and $3,255 as the average tax bill paid that year. Manhattan topped the list at $63,661 for average income and $3,850 for the average tax bill.
In the Federal study, based on estimated gross incomes for the current year, the median income in the county for 1995 was estimated to be $66,900. The highest median incomes in the country were reported in the Stamford-Norwalk area at $77,100 and in Danbury at $67,000. San Jose, Calif., followed after Westchester with an average median income of $64,200.
Advocates for the poor, however, take little solace in the numbers for Westchester. They were quick to say that those findings notwithstanding, the county was also home to many who struggled economically.
"It's a pyramid here with a few at the top who make fantastic salaries and a broad, broad base at the bottom of people who earn very little," said Christina Rohatynskyj, executive director of Food Patch in Millwood, a nonprofit agency that distributes food to food pantries, soup kitchens and shelters and is allied with Second Harvest, the largest hunger relief organization in the United States. "This is a county of great contrasts."
At the Sharing Community in Yonkers, a church-sponsored nonprofit organization that serves the homeless and the hungry, the Rev. George Anthony Hoeltzel, its executive director, called Westchester's poverty "the other side of the coin" of the county's great wealth.
"It's a county with gleaming office buildings and sculpture parks on the one hand -- and on the other, public housing with no glass in the windows and no doors on the jambs," Mr. Hoeltzel said.
The County Department of Social Services said that statistics of wealth notwithstanding, there were 39,081 welfare recipients -- 4 percent of the population -- in Westchester.
According to the New York Department of Taxation and Finance study, the average income for the state was $36,381. In Nassau County, it was $49,923; in Rockland, $43,319, and in Putnam, $42,243. The lowest average income for the state -- $22,768 -- was reported in Franklin County in northeastern New York.
The department's spokesman, Karl E. Felsen, said that Manhattan was the hub of economic activity for the New York City region and that Westchester was home to commuters who worked on Wall Street and in the advertising, entertainment and publishing industries.
"There may be a great deal of wealth generated in Manhattan," Mr. Felsen said, "but we also tend to see that wealth spread out around the area where it was earned."
In Scarsdale, the average per capita income in 1989 was $50,494, and in Rye it was $49,796, according to figures from the Bureau of the Census and the county's Department of Planning and the Office of Commerce and Economic Development.
By contrast, average per capita income in Mount Vernon in 1989 was $15,814. In Yonkers it was $16,538.
The latest figures available show that the poverty rate for the county in 1989 was 4.7 percent, meaning that 10,748 of the county's 885,731 residents had incomes below the poverty level. Six New York counties out of 62 had a lower poverty rate.
The highest rate in Westchester County was 9 percent in Yonkers, where 4,492 families lived below the poverty line. The lowest rate -- 0.3 percent or 6 families -- was in Thornwood.
By comparison, the highest rate of poverty for a single county in the state, 25.7 percent, occurred in the Bronx. The lowest countywide rates were in Putnam and Nassau where the poverty rate was 2.1 percent. The figures were presented in the 1994 New York State Statistical Yearbook, compiled by the Nelson A. Rockefeller Institute of Government at the State University of New York in Albany.
But a study of hunger in Westchester by Pace University recommended that poverty rates be regionalized to reflect differences in costs of living. "Such a local correction would help us better understand the depth of suffering in Westchester," the report said.
The official poverty level for 1993 was $14,763 for a family of four. But if the high cost of housing and other economic factors peculiar to Westchester were considered, the report said that 25 percent of all households in the county would be living in poverty.
Nationally, economists said that despite the economic rebound last year and declining jobless rates, the poverty rate remained high -- 14.8 percent in 1992 and 15.1 percent in 1993. The income of the average middle-income household dropped, and income disparities between the wealthy and the middle and lower classes widened, they said.
In 1993, census data showed that the upper class -- the top fifth -- held 48.2 percent of the income.
Or as Mr. Surdey at the New York Department of Labor said, "The rich got richer and the poor got poorer."
In Westchester, the distribution of wealth was even more skewed than it was in the rest of the country. Thomas J. Spitznas, a regional economist in Mount Vernon, said 66 percent of the income in the county in 1992 was held by the wealthiest 20 percent of the population. He added that the average adjusted gross income for that top group was $57,903. For the upper-middle-income group the average was $53,937; for the middle-income group it was $28,022; for the lower-middle-income group it was $12,882, and for the lowest income group it was $3,578.
"There continues to be a shift here toward a more unequal distribution of wealth," Mr. Spitznas said.
The middle class, in particular, was struggling with the high cost of living in the county, he said. Middle-income earners in Westchester accounted for 45.6 percent of the wealth in 1989; three years later, that figure had dropped to 32.7 percent.
He attributed the decline in part to the high number of corporate downsizings in the county. "Many in the middle class are reporting less income now," Mr. Spitznas said, "but some of them are simply out of jobs."
The loss of manufacturing jobs in the county has also hurt the middle class, and many former factory workers have been unable to find work in white collar fields because they lack training.
Mr. Surdey said Westchester was becoming "a dual society of the well-off and the poor."
A report from Second Harvest last year said that the gains of economic growth were not being shared by all classes but were going to the affluent. It attributed the problems to "wage erosion, cutbacks in government benefit programs for low-income families and individuals and increases in the number of female-headed families."
The report said that an "upward drift in poverty rates" had affected all groups, including working families, whites, minority groups, families headed by women and married couples. Among children, the poverty rate grew from 16.2 percent in 1977 to 22.7 percent in 1993.
Noreen L. Preston, an economist for the County Office of Commerce and Economic Development, observed that while those trends are being recorded throughout the United States, "they are happening faster in Westchester."

HEADLINE: THEATER;
First a Movie, Then a Novel, Now a Play

BYLINE: By BUDD SCHULBERG 

 BODY:
Forty-one years ago "On the Waterfront," a gritty American movie in cinema verite style about corruption on the docks of New York, became an instant classic. Ever after, its stars -- Marlon Brando, Karl Malden, Lee J. Cobb, Rod Steiger and Eva Marie Saint -- were identified with the film, written by Budd Schulberg and directed by Elia Kazan.
Mr. Schulberg went on to write a novel with the same title, based on the movie and the true story behind it. On Monday, another "On the Waterfront" opens -- this time on the stage of the Brooks Atkinson Theater on Broadway. With a set designed by Eugene Lee, it stars David Morse as Father Barry, the waterfront priest; Ron Eldard as Terry Malloy, the ambivalent thug; Penelope Ann Miller as Edie Doyle, the woman who awakens his conscience, and Kevin Conway as Johnny Friendly, the mob chieftain. The director is Adrian Hall. 
 Mr. Schulberg, a screenwriter and playwright, is also the author of the novels "What Makes Sammy Run?" and "The Disenchanted," both of which he adapted for the stage. In this article he describes the creative process from film to novel to play.
ON WEST 47TH STREET, I STAND outside the Brooks Atkinson Theater, and there it is, on the marquee in big letters: "On the Waterfront." The play. Not the movie that surprised the director Elia Kazan and me when it overcame rejection by all the major studios to win a record number of Oscars and become a landmark film. But now in a legitimate theater only a 10-minute walk from the piers I had been drawn to after Kazan and I joined forces some 40 years earlier.
Malcolm Johnson's breakthrough expose, "Crime on the Waterfront," in the long-lost New York Sun pointed us to our subject matter. Following Johnson's lead, I had gone down to St. Xavier's Church on West 16th Street to meet one of the most unforgettable characters of my life, the Waterfront Priest, Father John (Pete) Corridan. Tough, canny, fast-talking, chain-smoking and sometimes profane, he had become the champion of the dockworkers who were treated like convict labor by the racket-ridden International Longshoremen's Association, whose officers were literally recruited in Sing Sing and Dannemora.
I had walked into a brutal, inhuman world -- just a few blocks from Sardi's. Longshoremen rebels daring to meet in the basement of St. Xavier's were set upon on their way out by union goons wielding baseball bats and steel pipes. But not a word appeared in any of the New York papers the next day.
Egged on by Father Corridan, I went to Turner Catledge, then the managing editor of The New York Times, and told him about the battle for control of the harbor that was going on from the Brooklyn docks to Hoboken. He invited me to write an article for the Sunday Magazine.
I came back with "Joe Docks, Forgotten Man of the Waterfront," a profile of the average longshoreman. There were some 40,000 of them, shaping up at dawn every morning, forming a human horseshoe around the hiring boss who picked them to work a four-hour shift according to his whims (or according to the amount they were willing to kick back for the job -- $2, $3, even $4 out of the $2.27 per hour they were getting for the most dangerous work in America). "Joe Docks" described them as "forgotten men performing rugged, thankless jobs in a jungle of vice and violence where law and conventional safeguards never existed."
My three years of prowling the waterfront resulted in a screenplay that so excited Kazan he took it immediately to Darryl Zanuck at 20th Century Fox, who promptly threw it back at us with, "Who's going to give a damn about a bunch of sweaty longshoremen?"
Longshoremen, or workingmen in general, were not "in" in 1953, and they're still a rarity if not invisible in the movies of 1995. It was only with the intervention of a colorful, manipulative freebooter, the producer Sam Spiegel, that we managed to get the film made on a B budget and a 35-day shooting schedule.
The Oscars, and the unexpected box-office success, were sweet revenge on the studios that had turned us down. But those years on the waterfront, including every one of the hearings held by the Waterfront Crime Commission, left me feeling that given the tight structure of a 90-minute movie, we could only tell part of the story.
The film focused on Terry Malloy, a fringe hoodlum caught between obeisance to the mob and the gradual awakening of his own conscience, stirred by the innocence of Edie Doyle, the sister of the young rebel Malloy had unwittingly helped to do in, and the prodding of the waterfront priest, now called Father Barry. What may strike many as a cliche -- "If you do it to the least of
Mine . . . " -- becomes dangerous doctrine in Barry's mouth. It was dangerous for him to stand up to the waterfront mobsters because behind them was a complex support system, involving the church, big business and city politics.
In our film, the priest -- memorably portrayed by Karl Malden -- was a heroic figure. But there was no hint of the ordeal that his real-life counterpart had to endure in bucking the archdiocese.
The ideal film moves from sequence to sequence, in a series of mounting climaxes. A novel has time to pause and wonder, time to put a Terry Malloy in proper perspective, to describe a social matrix of which Terry is totally unaware but one that is nonetheless driving him to put his life on the line. Choosing to do the novel through the eyes of "Father Pete Barry" gave me a vehicle for exploring his courageous challenge to church authority and describing his eventual banishment to an upstate, inland parish.
Despite what Sam Goldwyn was reputed to have said -- "If you want to send a message, try Western Union" -- I felt the message of my novel had been overwhelmed in the fame of the film and deserved to be heard more clearly.
Some 10 years ago, my lifelong friend and frequent collaborator, Stan Silverman, and I discussed still a third way of presenting the material: reinventing it as a play.
That the greatest natural harbor in the world was still held hostage by the mob exerted a nagging fascination on us. The cargo ships with their old-fashioned slings into the hold had given way to 900-foot container ships so high tech that two men could do the work of 20. But credit the mob with resilience and resourcefulness. The Gambinos in Brooklyn and the Genoveses in Port Newark-Elizabeth weren't going to go away -- not as long as billions of dollars' worth of cargo was moving in and out.
IF THE SHAPE-UP KICKBACKS WERE ancient history now, the high-level kickbacks from stevedores and shipping companies to crooked longshoremen union officials, and modern methods of corruption, were the old story in a new setting. No one on the inside, from the F.B.I. to the United States attorneys to the district attorney to the computerized bi-state waterfront commissioners, doubts that despite their best efforts, the Five Families are still doing "very lovely" around the harbor.
It struck Stan Silverman and me that it was time to tell the rest of the story. And what better way than on the stage? The theater offers an opportunity to combine the drama of film with the subtext of a novel. But we had to find ways to dramatize the social and moral issues that there had been no time for in the movie and which were often expressed in interior monologues in the book.
While the play includes scenes straight out of the movie and drawn directly from the novel, it also includes new ones that this third "Waterfront" demands.
The love story is still there, somewhat enlarged, in fact, as we had more time to develop the relationship between Terry Malloy and Edie Doyle. While Terry's story remains, he shares virtually equal time with Father Barry, for whom, in the movie, there was not as much space as in the play, where he must come to terms with his own difficult choices and those of his critical superiors.
While there were worker-priests in France in the 1950's, and there have been priests speaking out for the impoverished peasantry of Latin America from the 1970's into the 1990's, the issue of liberation theology and the conflicts within the church about its current social role are sharpening every day.
The activism celebrated in our play may be new for the "X" Generation, which has often been accused of moral aphasia. Concern for one's fellow man or woman is considered old-fashioned and out of step in the era of get rich with Gingrich or starve on your own time and leave us real Americans alone. Why should our hard-earned dollars ease the pain of your unemployment or personal failure? the Gingriches ask. Today's anthem, all too often, seems to be, "If you do it to the least of Mine, it's O.K. by me."
In the play, Terry Malloy expresses his philosophy of survival on the docks: "Do it to him before he does it to me!" It prompts Edie Doyle's question "Isn't everyone a part of everyone else?" The answer to what seems a simplistic question goes to the heart of our modern malaise.
In the course of our play, Terry Malloy, the seemingly soulless street survivor, is forced to face up to the unfamiliar and inexorable demands of conscience, and the question: Where do we draw the line between naked self-interest and responsibility to our fellow beings?
Although the time of our play is still the mid-50's, when crimes in 57 varieties were shrugged off as the facts of life -- and death -- on the waterfront, the moral quandary that Terry and the waterfront priest face is the same one that the film and novel posed 40 years ago. Only now, in hindsight and, we hope, with foresight, are we able in this Broadway version to cut a lot closer to the bone.
ON MY WAY TO THE BROOKS ATKINSON recently, I stopped to buy the morning papers and scanned them over a coffee-shop breakfast. The Javits Center, I read (not exactly with surprise), was a hive of labor racketeering. The waterfront, moved inland.
A carpenter's union official, who had been ousted for daring to speak up for union democracy, had been set on fire. The Mayor was quoted as saying that if the Javits Center situation was not cleaned up, "It will go the way of the Port." And we all know what happened when Mr. Giuliani declared his intention to break the stranglehold of organized crime on the Fulton Fish Market. "They" burned part of it down.
The look has changed, the technology has changed, but the modus operandi of the old waterfront days is doing "very lovely" in the new waterfront days. And what is the waterfront, after all, if not a microcosm of the good-old-bad-old U.S.A. '95?

(Movie Still Archives)(pg. 10); Penelope Ann Miller and Ron Eldard in the play opening on Monday at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on Broadway. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)(pg. 5)

PERSON: SCHULBERG, BUDD BUDD WILSON SCHULBERG (92%); JUSTIN BROOKS 'BROOKS' ATKINSON (71%); KARL MALDEN (58%); ROD STEIGER (58%); MARLON BRANDO JR (58%); ANN MILLER (56%); 

LOAD-DATE: April 30, 1995
